Do you want to build an entire army of emotionless, fearless, fanatically devoted Naginata wielding monks from the Northern end of Feudal Japan? Do you want to put into battle no less than 8 regiments of archers that are dirt cheap but have about 250 men in them each? Do you like answering "You and what Army" with a charge of around a thousand screaming, red-armor clad psychopaths with bows, naginata and katanas out of the woods that ol' boss didn't quite see there? 

Do you like the feeling of spending maybe a half an hour on a game to get yourself started, only to have passed 7 consecutive hours without blinking or getting up to pee?
Do you crave the feeling that playing a game could take centuries of your life if you could just finish that one goddamned tech branch that you need to unlock fire arrows because you'll be damned if you lose one more trading route to that stupid boat spamming prick across the map?

Then look no further than Total War: SHOGUN 2! Now complete with the "Oh Jesus you could actually regress their technology?" and "AHAHAHA GATLING GUNS DO WHAT?" Expansions!

Shogun 2 feels like how you think a samurai war would feel like. Beautiful, honorable, and calm. The art, soundtrack, and the excellent voice acting draws you even closer to the immersion. It's not realistic and it doesn't have to be, in fact I would argue that adding blood and gore kills the charm for me. In a way, the fall of samurai expansion kills the charm with its gunpowder, english unit voice, and new realistic unit portrait.
Either way, shogun 2 is all that I hoped Sengoku era war would be. With how the series is heading lately, I feared on what shogun 3 would look like, if they ever maks one

out of all the TW games, this one has the best flow of battle IMHO. The pace is good, not too fast but also not too slow, and the differences between the factions are there, but not as heavy as you might fear. That way, it is always somewhat balanced, no matter who you play as. Units either die, or they survive, when hit by arrows and the like, with muskets totally obliterating anyone, but being not so precise, requiring direct line of fire, and reloading much slower than bow and arrow. in vanilla, sea battles are exhausting (as always) whereas in FOTS you finally have somewhat proper sea battles.

Streamlined research trees, clever agent mechanics, and unique faction bonuses are all welcome additions.

Single player for total war shogun 2 is a beautiful experience, and multiplayer, even 9 years later, is quite addicting.The main issue a player can experience is an overwhelming and daunting outlook. Forget about it, play the tutorials, and give the historical battles a shot. I recommend starting with the campaign on normal difficulty, if you're a new comer. Naval battles for some people are tedious and boring, but the diversity of ship classes and naval warriors makes the encounters unique, and utilize a different set of battle tactics (watch the film, "The Admiral: Roaring Currents" to get into Naval warfare of the period).The only negative review I have is not playing the game sooner! I got quite addicted during a busy and transformative time in my life, and would have appreciated playing this game as a younger person! If this game is sitting in your library, give it a shot, the remaining barrier may be the power of your rig, but the game is still fun and gorgeous even on low/medium settings (ultra settings is a whole different experience).

The apex of the total war franchise. It's been almost ten years since its release and still remains unparalleled. You won't be able to find another Japanese feudal era RTS that plays and looks as good as this. The game includes an encyclopedia for you to get fairly acquainted with japanese history specific to the era, the factions and units. Like other total war games, provincial management, forging alliances through diplomacy, building and strategically positioning your armies are key to dominance. The game offers visually stunning atmosphere and environment through the 4 seasons. The bushido skill and finesse, and the bravery exemplified on a massive scale is an experience unique only to this game. The sword fight animations across multitudes of samurai warriors delivers an epic spectacle unlike anything ever accomplished in the genre. On top of that, a cinematic mode allows you to take a closer view in the heat of battle. I was completely in awe the first time I played this in 2012 and still plays like a dream today.

Shogun 2 is an excellent, classic strategy game. It is one of the finest entries in the Total War franchise and still holds up amazingly well even today, 9 years after release. Over the past year I've really been delving into the Total War franchise, and I must say Total War: Shogun 2 could be my favorite.  The stunning artistry and flow of the battles, beautiful landscapes seamlessly lending to incredibly exciting and complex strategy executions. Even the music was soothing, or inspiring when the mood called for it. If I had to change anything it would be in the diplomatic relations. I sometimes feel there's no rhyme or reason to some clan actions. Maybe taking a page from the original Rome (probably still my 2nd favorite)... All in all, I LOVE THIS GAME.

I think that CA has not been able to produce a better game after the second Shogun. I have played the first Shogun and although I miss several features from it such as not op one man units, a screen with a sensei who could advise you, a screen with a soldier delivering you decapitated heads, only one bridge crossing battles and a pretty fun Mongol DLC, I loved this game.

Pros:
-Hidden modifiers to the enemy do not break the balance of the game on higher difficulty. Instead, the enemy just plays better and sends larger armies against you. What this means is, that almost every tactical combo makes sense to master.
-Awesome graphics
-Awesome intro cutscenes. You will get a lot of aesthetic cutscenes every time you create a unit or agent for the first time.
-Cutscenes for geishas and ninjas like in good old times. Rome II never had them anymore.
-Since the factions have pretty much same roster, the tournament potential and skills are very important
-Nice interface and art, unit cards drawn in traditional style
-Very easily moddable
-Some of the old sountracks from original shogun are brought back
Cons:
-AI sometimes is clunky.
-Siege battles are weird. The defenders get almost unbreakable morale bonuses in campaign
-Rebels are pretty damn op in the campaign
-Some units like all artillery, Yari samurai and bow heroes are not very useful due to their modifiers and in case of bow heroes, size and limit.
- I would say the game is a bit biased towards Oda as they get pretty damn good bonuses if you compare them against Hojo, Tokugawa or Mori. Date clan is hardly playable as their only province is as big as three normal ones and they take too much to travel.
- Ainu people are not presented in this game though they existed in that period.

Conclusion: does not feel obsolete in 2020, worth a play.

This is the last Total War game I can truly enjoy. From Rome 2 the series went downhill in my opinion. 
Shogun 2 is a great strategy game about the Sengoku period. 
There are some historical innacuracies - when sieging castles your men just climb the walls with their bare hands while historically samurai did use siege ladders, rams and even siege towers. Also, there is way too much focus on the katana as a weapon - there are "catana cavalry" and "catana samurai" units in the game while historically they would use the katana only as a last resort weapon (and cavalry used tachi swords). 
Having said that, the game is pretty fun and there are great mods for it!

Shogun 2 is hard for the average player, and I mean HARD. I'm fairly experienced when it comes to strategy games (I've played EU4, CK2, HOI4 and other Total War games) and even I had some difficulty in Shogun 2. The AI is by far the most competent out of any Total War game ("ahem" Rome II), with it even seeming like they took a page or two of of Sun Tzu's The Art of War. Despite this, players who are keen on mastering the game will probably steamroll through the easier difficulties, especially when they play with the easier factions (Shimazu by the way). Overall, the game is enjoyable and the challenge it poses will make the player feel rewarded for winning. At least you don't have to face enemy AI that gets ridiculous economy or troop bonuses like in the Warhammer games.

I love this game. I love the setting, I love the gameplay, I love playing it with a little bit of a role playing aspect. Completed this game multiple times and I gotta say it's brilliant. This is definitely one that's ripe for a Remaster or something like that.

The CA did a masterpiece on this one. Arguably one of the simplest total wars in terms of game mechanics, but, as the saying goes, "there's beauty in simplicity". And Shogun 2 is definitely beautiful in many ways. And just to clarify, when I say "simple", I mean simpler than Attila or Rome 2. To master the game, you still need to put in tens or hundreds of hours. Here are my reasons why I think that it's a time well spent:
- BEAUTIFUL. I know I've said it already, but I just want you to fully understand. Everything from the opening cinematic, the menu, the campaign map and the battlefield is visually extremely pleasing. Sakura leafs fluttering in the wind. Rainbows shining inside waterfalls. Rain enveloping the battlefield - be it natural rain or rain of arrows. Add tranquil music to the background (campaign) or wild japanese drums (battle) and you've got an aesthethical masterpiece.
- Probably the best campaign AI in all of Total War. 
- Good battle AI.
- Incredibly atmospheric. The quotes on loading screens, the unit images, the research tree, everything screams "medieval Japan".
- Simple, but diverse unit roster.
- Comprehensible research tree
- Great ninja cinematics.
- And just... really good? It's hard to put into words. I can't count how many times I've become shogun. How many times the entire Japan turned against me, how many times I crushed them and established "an empire to last 10 000  years" as the narrator likes to say. The campaigns are one of the shortest in all Total Wars. It takes me around 50 hours to take the entire map. So maybe it's that. Maybe it's how the battles are so beautiful and dynamic, how the AI gives me the toughest time. Or maybe Japan is just a good country for war. One long narrow island and a couple smaller ones. Bays and straits for unique naval engagements. Lot of mountain passes, rivers, bridges and coastlines to have epic land battles on. Who wouldn't like to decide the fate of a country with Mt Fuji towering in the background?

What I grumble about while having the time of my life playing this game:
- Settlements. Siege battles are fun, but the settlements are bare, with barely any buildings. Really poor when compared to Medieval 2 or Attila.
- Naval battles begin to be bit dull after a time. However, the Japanese were terrible sailors, so I can't really blame CA for this.
- Minor multiplayer issues.
- CA's greedy DLC policy.

These, however, are in my eyes minor issues compared to other aspects of the game. In my mind, Shogun 2 is a straight 9.5/10. A must have!

[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Total War: Shogun 2 is a turn-based strategy game mixed with a real time strategy game. Every Total War game has followed this formula, yet the games always manage to incorporate new mechanics to help differentiate themselves from each other. What stands out most obviously in Shogun 2 as the differentiation is the setting. While many Total War games are set in a wide historical era, Shogun is extremely focused. It is concerned exclusively with feudal Japan and offers little to no variety within that. A different game in the franchise, such as Rome, has a focus on the era of the Roman Empire, but offers the ability to play as a wide variety of countries that were present at the time. Japan's historical isolation prevents this, making every playable faction feel very similar. To counteract this feeling of repetitiveness, the developers have created an extremely polished base for Shogun 2. It has some of the best combat of the franchise, while having very little unit variety. Most factions have 1 or 2 notable units that attempt to define that faction, but the core gameplay stays the same. Shogun 2 overall is one of the best Total War games, but has far less replayability than many other games in the franchise. If you like the general feel of feudal Japanese combat, you will love this game, but if not, there aren't many factions that offer a hugely different playstyle.

One of the best Total War games next to the original Rome Total War. By far, the most easily balanced games with both challenge and ease depending on a player's preferences. Easy as anything to pick up, easier so more to bring hideous death from both land, air, and water. Comparatively, it's just as addictive to the other titles. Where Warhammer shines with heroes and epic magic--where Napoleon shines with strategic placement and tests of macro--where Rome shines in it's original recipe--Shogun 2 shines in being the middle point. While not like Three Kingdoms--which embraces most of all these games--Shogun 2 shines in keeping historically accurate, while providing both entertainment, and quick-paced strategy.

TL;DR

-Agents have cutscenes for some actions. These can be both hilarious and frustrating when RNGesus strikes.
-Campaign map is beautifully designed, and easy to navigate.
-Fights are extremely quick paced; and can be very interesting with each clan's setup.
-The game requires literally a toaster to run; it is very needless for what it gives.

However,
-Losing is very costly in this. Lose an army and you can lose a campaign immediately.
-On the first point, early game is a game of not messing up. Mess up once, and you likely need a restart.
-Rise of the Samurai is a bit of an inbetween DLC. It can be somewhat meh.
-There's no more support by Total War for this game, so don't expect new content or hotfixes/balancing.

I recommend this game, but just barely. Certain game mechanics are maddening, but the immersion is worth the experience.

Pros:
-The game is gorgeous. Every aspect of the game is stunning to look at and listen to, and you'll find yourself manually fighting battles you could auto-resolve, just for another chance to see your brightly-colored samurai charging into the ranks of the enemy with their katanas glinting in the sun. The campaign is equally beautiful, and the art style of the period has been embraced by the developers to an unprecedented degree for this series, and creates a great sense of immersion.
-The addition of skill trees to generals and agents lets you tailor each one to fulfill specific roles.
-The time limit for the grand campaign is much tighter than previous games, which keeps you on your toes.

Cons:
-Realm Divide. Reaching a certain level of power on the campaign map triggers the Realm Divide mechanic, a huge, permanent debuff to diplomatic relations. This ensures that within a few turns, every other faction will declare war on you, even your closest allies, and no one will ever be willing to make peace, even if you successfully become Shogun. This completely nullifies trade and diplomacy, two central game mechanics. It also makes becoming Shogun before the endgame pointless.
-The harsh food and financial systems ensure that I never saw high-level buildings or units in most of my playthroughs.

Is it worth the current full price ($30)? To be honest, yes. I must admit, even though some of the game mechanics are enough to drive me out of my mind, it does make winning feel like a great achievement. And the level of immersion is enchanting.

Shogun 2 is one of the best Total War games. 

The game lacks the faction diversity, fantasy heroes and map scale of games like Rome 2, Empire or Warhammer TW. However, it makes up for this with great graphics/art, performance, difficulty, and depth 

The game looks amazing even years after release Unlike most TW games, the individual soldiers in this game do not look deformed. Their armor look realistic and the amount of blood actually fits the samurai aesthetic. The campaign and battle map both look incredible and remain functional. 

The game performed really well even on release. This cannot be said of most games in the TW collection. The game runs well on a potato. 

The game has a very challenging late game on higher difficulties. On hard and higher the AI is well funded and aggressive. The late game is made difficult by a mechanic known as "Realm Divide". This mechanic has every AI declare war on the player and never surrender. Most TW games become boring because the player ends up steam rolling in the late game. This mechanic makes completing a campaign a challenge worth completing. 

All of the factions in Shogun 2 are the same but this hides depth. This issue actually improves the multiplayer because players cannot predict their opponent’s army in multiplayer. Unlike other TW games, Shogun 2 does not have a meta that forces players to play in a certain way. In single player the issue of faction diversity is resolved with bonuses. These bonuses encourage new play-styles, while also making all options available. The multiplayer features an objective based system that effectively stops all camping. 

Shogun 2 is a beautiful and balanced game. It runs well and has a challenging single player experience.

The last good strategy game by Creative Assembly. No simplified army management, no artificial difficulty increases (AI is actually one of the most challenging in Total War games), (mostly) everything in this game works and the experience is frustration-free.

I don't understand how people think this is the best TW game. Firstly, the setting of the game in 19th century Japan is. . . nice. I personally don't like Japanese history before the 20th century because it is honestly just Japanese history, there is very little interaction with the rest of the world or even Asia (outside of Korea and China occasionally). But, that's just me. 

As a game itself, the setting offers an exceptionally small and unsatisfying campaign. I find that uniting Japan under the Emperor or Shogun is just slightly less enjoyable than conquering the world or conquering Europe. It's a very confined setting. 

In terms of combat, you have Japanese people with guns and Japanese people with swords. Surprisingly, the people with guns tend to win more often than not. The roster of units in the game is just pathetic when compared to other TW titles, again, a side effect of the isolated setting. Every faction is more or less the same minus the division between Imperial and Shogunate factions. Fighting battles isn't horrible. Cavalry are easy to use and maneuverable, the infantry AI isn't as brain dead as Napoleon's, but you still have the lack of diverse units and the fact that guns will win 90% of the time dampening each battle you play.
The base game is good, but I love the Fall of the Samurai add-on especially the naval combat

tied for the best Total War game ever made, in my opinion. Especially if you count Rise and Fall of the Samurai in as well.

A very interesting strategy game where every decision counts. The player has at his disposal several clans to play where each one has its own difficulty.

The real battle mode is a feature that I really liked, where sometimes the probability of success that the PC shows does not mean anything.

Throughout the turns the player can have several units depending on what he chooses in each province, where each one has its advantage and disadvantage, as well agents. The player can also do dipolomacy and alliances with other clans, being able to help or not when they have in war.

This game contains a skill tree for agents and generals whenever level up, where the player can customize at his will.

However there are some bugs that in life did not occur as for example the Spear Infantry units in the castle do not attack through the holes when the enemy is climbing the wall and sometimes the units are stopped without any action even if the player has given.

But even though I never won one time, I loved playing this game. For those who are curious and never played I invite you to play this game.

Another great Total War title! The campaign stretches the Japanese Daimyo provinces during the Sengoku period. You can play a campaign with 2 people (coop or head to head) or singleplayer. If you are really into campaign play there are good free mods available where (100!) more nations, new castles and other game mechanics are included. Playing all the different factions keeps fun. All the factions have different units to use, some have even european weapons. You can use monks and ninja to convert the populace or convert or kill characters. The end goal will be to capture the main capital and a certain amount of provinces. The game developers introduced a mechanic 'realm divide' for the moment you really get to strong, at which point everyone will declare war on you (even long-term allies and vassals). This will give a new challenge to survive. I personally don't like the unthrustworthy aliances in this game, where every good relationship (also without realm divide) will deteriorate after some time. I would advice to use one of the available mods to fix this. 

Online battles are possible (1v1/4v4) but less common in this game. It takes long to find a quick match, except for evenings or weekend hours. Big difference in my opinion with other Total War titles will be the chaotic element in battles. Its really hard to adjust strategies when the melee battles have started because of the fastness of it. 

Apart from quick matches there is a clan competition map, where clans/steam groups can fight over provinces in Japan. As a clan member you have to fight battles to win points, the clan with the most points wins the territory and will get a higher tier rating every week. Clan competition is still active but battles are only fought at the evening hours/weekends. 

You should definitely buy this game (on sale!) because of its beautiful campaign. And if you have a friend to play with i would advice the coop campaign on hard/ legendary difficulty. :)

Total War: SHOGUN 2


Pros -

#1.Still decent graphics for 2020

#2.Difficult to become shogun on normal difficulty.It is not easy and that is good.

#3.Many units and upgrades

#4.Your strategy is very important

#5.I like the music

#6.There is Multiplayer but I never tried it


Cons-


#1.My biggest problem with this game is that you can have the best army and still get killed by their assassin and it can kill all the progress and time you put into the game to get to that point.

I am not even calling it unrealistic it is just lame when it happens.I understand we can do it back to them but I wish they were not so OP when maxed out.


#2.The time limit to become shogun

I had this same problem with Empire total war. I dont like the main game having a time limit.I understand that in real life there is time limits as we die of old age and that there can be a certain about of time to do things.

It does not really apply to either game though as if you/your people/country are trying to take over everything even if you personally die it does not mean your people/country are going to stop doing it and they have to still stop you.

I understand the time limit speeds things along but I would of removed it and made it more like Rome 2 where there is no time limit like that.


#3.The AI can be stupid

This is how all total war games are but it should be said when it happens.This is why some players only do multiplayer battles only.


#4.That everyone turns on you when the shogun makes you the enemy


This just isnt realistic.I understand that it can make the game harder and more of a challenge and some like that but if someone was always your ally/friend and one day the shogun says that we are now their enemy for them to just agree with that could get their whole civilization destroyed by us.

It would be like declaring war against a friend and knowing he could burn your cities to the ground easily but the shogun told you to so you have to.



The Bottom Line -


Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a fun turn based strategy game.I got enjoyment out of it but I still like Rome 2 more.

I would get SHOGUN 2 on a steam deal and they even do free weekends with it sometimes.

Watch some youtube gameplay of it if you still not sure.

I bought a physical copy of this game, shortly after its release, nearly a decade ago. I was never able to play it due to the hardware limitations of my laptop (12 year old me was technologically ignorant at the time). Seeing the game on Steam, after losing the physical copy of the game through various moves, made me ecstatic. I could finally experience a game I have longed to play since my childhood.

Without hesitation, I purchased the game, along with all of the DLC. I am now 27 hours in, and I am still learning the ropes, BUT I am extremely pleased with the game, and it is just as fun as I had imagined it was when I was 12. Definitely worth the ~$20 I spent on it while on sale.

10/10 Would Recommend.

I am rather partial to Shogun 2, this game started my interest in historically based strategy games, which led to the discovery of my favorite game, Hearts of Iron 4. However, Shogun 2 is not the easiest to use game. The Total War series is never very friendly to newcomers, more so when it comes to the earlier games. I would highly recommend the game to anyone ready to dedicate some time to learning the intricacy of a TW game, but stay away if you're just looking for an easy battle simulator. 
A good test of this is to ask yourself is if you will take the time to do the campaigns. I myself don't often do them, but I found I learned much from even a few battles in campaign. If you're just looking, again, for a battle sim rather than a campaign, the Total War series is not for you. 
If none of this applies to you or you have advance knowledge of the Total War series, pick this game up for your collection. It's worth the $30 for sure

I've got Shogun 2 for free during the quarantine giveaways, I've became an addict since, even bought all the DLCs (including Rise and Fall of the Samurai). That says all of a legendary 10 years old game.

Shogun 2 is the pinnacle of RTS game play and design. It's relatively simple, fun, and rewarding even if it lacks a little when it comes to the political and diplomatic aspects. I've sank over 1000 hours into this game over multiple play-throughs and DLC missions and I recommend it very highly. See below for more a more in-depth look. 8.5/10

The Shogun 2 experience is a little jagged to start with. The tutorial does a very good job of explaining the very basics of the game. Sword beats spear, spear beats cavalry, cavalry beats non-spear infantry. Bow and gun units are great at a distance but get shredded by melee troops. All units are vulnerable to flank and rear attacks. Samurai are better than peasant forces. Morale and stamina all play a part in the combat effectiveness of units over time and if you're attacking or defending determine strategy and assets for each army. 

It all sounds pretty simple, but the game doesn't teach you how to manage or properly use more specialized units or their abilities. Ninjas and cannons are all wild cards and unless you experiment and do the research yourself, and you can seriously neglect cavalry or naval units and their development. Aside from war, the country your faction controls need infrastructure and development as well, and factors like buildings, agents, faction religion, and honor aren't explained through game play. Instead, you're left to discover these nuances yourself.

Another detraction is that there is a simple and shallow political aspect to consider. Each faction is represented by a warlord's (daimyo) family and generals. As your territory expands through conquest you come in contact with other clans and their agents. The way each clan reacts and interacts is dependent on factors much like the populace and territory you control, with honor, religion, and other factors calculated in. You can influence these factors by arranging trade deals, marriages, making payments and bribes, or conquering factions and making them vassals. 

The downside to this is that often there is little you can do to keep relations civil with other factions once a certain point is reached. If you become too powerful the other clans will unite against you. However, many factions will turn on you at the drop of a hat in the original game, no matter what you do or how far you progress. For instance, if you encounter a clan late game, chances are they will never accept trade or peace requests, even if you dwarf them in all capacity. I've personally been in the midst of assaulting a clan's final stronghold and requested peace and trade only to have them spit in my face. Mods can fix and alleviate this to some extent, but it's an issue and hassle. Likewise, clans that have been my ally through trade, military, and marriage from the start of my campaign turn on my without fail once I hit a campaign checkpoint, regardless. 

Likewise, in battle, the AI is all over the place. You'll find that some factions have impossibly sized armies or navies despite the fact they should lack the resources to manage their field and upkeep costs. Also, the AI will deliberately throw armies at you if you defend, leading to strategies where you can cheese your way through the game with low level units and a few strong ranged units to thin the ranks. Also, the disparity between enemy units and your own can be extreme. I've seen my units crack and flee when they hit 50% and never regroup; in turn, I've seen enemy units out in the field hold their ground and delay my line against impossible odds that should have shredded them twice as fast with less casualties sustained.

A few other minor gripes is that naval engagements are downright broken when it comes to boarding, you can't customize the look of your generals, your eligible sons can take to the field as young as 14 or 24, all depending on RNG, and smaller clans know exactly how and when to strike to make things difficult in the end game. Still, I really enjoyed this game, and if you can play co-op with a friend in a campaign, I highly recommend you do so. It becomes a tag-team fun fest with each of you making different units, exchanging them, and attacking strategically. 

As for the DLC "Rise of the Samurai", I rate it as ok. 6/10. The new units aren't explained well and the clan management becomes more tedious as the buildings and infrastructure become more convoluded needlessly. "Fall of the Samurai", is another matter. Set in the advent of the industrial revolution that brought the Shougnate and feudal eras to their knees, it's incredibly fun balancing traditional units versus more modern gun-toting armies and fighting to keep the shogun in power or restoring the Emperor to power. 8/10.

Shogun 2, coupled with it's DLC is a great experience. It lacks a lot of the more overly complicated aspects Rome II and Atilla suffered from, and it feels more satisfying to field armies and understanding your strength and weaknesses. However, the political tools are lacking and the AI's either zealous blood thirst or stupidity hinder the overall experience.

A very solid Total War game with probably the most impressive battle animations, especially for it's time. Definitely worth playing. 8/10

Pros
+Fun battles where you have to use tactics to win, and the AI is hard (for me at least) to cheese.
+Wide variety of units, from simple ashigaru, to hardcore warrior monks.
+Maintaining your economy is simple, which makes it easier to manage the campaign map
+Noobs will probably learn the ins and outs easily

Cons
-Naval battles are often clunky
-Gun units are pretty bad, and usually only clans that specialize in them can use them effectively
-Alliances can actually do more harm than good, as they drag you into wars you don't need to fight, and they often sit out on wars you need help with.
-You may need to buy some DLC to get the full experience

9/10 Totally worth your money.

The game is highly interesting and absolutely fascinating.
However, despite on Legendary mode, enemy movements are still very predictable and there are rarely any suprise tactic coming from them.
The Fall of Samurai is my favourite. I strongly recommend Tosa (Tosa rifleman) and Choshu (Kaihetai). Their specialised forces are by far more superior than other units. Tosa rifleman are more vulnerable to artillery and bombardment due to the lack in numbers, however their accuracy (recruited with specialised buildings) and high reloading rate, as well as further firing range, makes them both insane as castle defence and siege. Usually 4-5 Tosa Rifleman is capable of holding a castle when facing 1-2 full armies with medium strength opponents. 6-8 Tosa rifleman is capable of fending off an army predominantly made up of Imperial or Shogunate infantry. I strongly recommend placing 4-6 Tosa rifleman as a standard defence. Sometime each unit is capable of killing 800+ enemies in battles, making them a fantastic army to achieve Heroic Victory (way to improve Honour for your Daimyo).

it's 2020 and it is still the best total war game out there.

TLDR Amazing game, the single-player campaign is keeping me busy for ages even years down the track

Highlights:

-Genuinely difficult even towards the end game, It takes longer than in other TW titles before you steamroll everyone
-High difficulty doesn't mean the AI cheats. There are slight tweaks to morale and costs at higher levels but it's not like in some TW games where you feel that AI peasants can take down your expensive knights because of cheat boosts or that they spawn armies that they couldn't afford, it's just that the AI is more aggressive and makes better decisions that challenge you
-Amazing atmosphere and graphics keeping up with today's standards, the cherry blossoms floating on battlefields in spring, the Japanese language voice acting, the pop ups with choices to make about your clan and economy, the bloody sieges that end with defenders fighting to the last man before being brutally gutted, all build a great world
-Replayability, which might seem strange considering each clan has nearly all the same units available but they do each have slight boosts to a specific units. It might not seem like a lot but it motivates you to build more infantry focused as Shimazu, have deadly cavalry stacks as Takeda or blow things up with the Hojo. The enemies in each part of the map also change how you respond and every campaign will surprise you by which factions become dominant

A con is that the naval battles are slow. The only other negative is not strictly with game quality but that there are some great DLCs that have a bit of a high price point for the age of the game, but it's still a very complete game without them, and it's hard to say no to expanding it even more.

If you're interested in learning how to survive a legendary campaign I stream at random hours but I try to explain my thought process, would love to have you!
https://www.twitch.tv/somewhathawkward

Excellent game, with some tiny issues here and there.  

Notably; sea combat is pretty lackluster (but appreciated), some performance / crashing issues, some huge sieges take a lot longer then what it needs to be,  and sometimes units get stuck / forget what to do.  

Other than that, Single player is still really fun.  Also, with the inclusion of Steam Workshop support, you can literally sink hundreds of hours in the single player alone.  Maybe even thousands if you include the campaign mods.  

Multiplayer is a fun distraction & the Avatar system is great. However, There’s a sizable portion of the playerbase, or I just have bad luck, in this multiplayer that abuses the game mechanics.  To the point that it’s frustrating and not fun to play when you get those hardcore, elite abusers of the game.  If you can get into a match with someone that does not abuse the mechanics of the game, it is actually really fun and / or genuinely challenging to go up against people with equal or better skill levels. Even surprised when I get fairly bested.  Ultimately, your mileage will vary depending on the players you go up against.

Co-op campaign is cool, especially when you can get a buddy and either team up or go against each other.  I don't recommend playing with random people though, in my experience, most of them either quit after 10-ish turns or leave when they lose a few units.

I highly recommend this to anyone who is a fan of strategy games, and if you are slightly interested in the feudal Japanese period.  This game is must buy and one of the best Total War games to get.

A fantastic Total War game with plenty of strategic choices to make throughout. The unit roster, though not as varied as other Total War games (since it takes place in a single country) allows for diverse strategies especially when combined with the faction bonuses. The unit balance is also spot on and allows for strategy to count over unit composition, for the most part. The presentation of the game is also very polished and immersive. The campaign map really shines on how many things you can do - province bonuses can really open up different army compositions, and building choices in your initial provinces can set the tone for the rest of the game. 

The game does have a few tedious parts. Naval combat is all right, but the AI isn't the best and chasing down ships on the campaign map gets old pretty fast. AI agent spam also gets boring after realm divide

My most played total war game. Mostly because I'm a weeb. It isn't flawless. There isn't squalor and fertility yet. So farm only depends on how much plain area a province have. And market consumes food instead of creates squalor. And in FoTS it's simply generates money and modernize the faction. There's not enough unique traits and or units to actually change your strategy in campaign. And AI not taking advantage of clan strength or trying to be the first clan with for example, gunpowder or monk unit doesn't help either.

The multiplayer avatar is a nice touch. Realm divide is something that is unique to this game that keeps it interesting. Trying out converting to christian is always fun.  Despite its age it's beautiful looking still. And FoTS was such a refresh, there's mix of the old and modern units, naval bombardments, train tracks, gatling gun, torpedo boats and ironclads.

All in all, I'll be waiting for the next shogun, empire, and medieval. With at least the similar campaign system to Rome II and Attila while keeping the events.I like Shogun 2 for it's uniqueness , but it's old and less polished as the later total war. Currently best historical Japanese-centric strategy game IMO.

Alright; So this will probably be the Longest review I will ever write. Most of them aren't good anyways but eh.. why not?

So I never played Shogun 1, so I read that it's "Better" but honestly it's all opinions however; I love/hate this game, I play on Legendary mode and it's fucking insane. Crazy hard, crazy fun.

Pros; 
The game is one of the most balanced Total war I've played so far. 
Unit cost and recruitment kinda annoys me, but not as much as Rome II's, but it's good and the units are fun to mess with mainly conquering Japan with on Ashigaru armies it's a blast.
Better Economy system in my Opinion, it's easier and alot of fun actually selecting a better economy build rather than just selecting a building to just build. 
Trade and Trade areas; Yeah all the Total wars I've played had trade but only in Rome II and Shogun 2 that I saw trading actually being better on vanilla. There are mods to make it so much better obviously.

Neutral; 
Siege warfare was weird when I started it. The were things I hadn't seen in the game. Mainly that the enemy can CLIMB YOUR FUCKING WALLS. Which is rather not a problem more of a advantage if you have a good amount of archers based in your fort/castle/stronghold's you can take them down pretty easily.

Cons;
Diplomacy; In this total war, I see dilpomacy as a joke no matter what I have done I can never get an ally to stay as an ally or to pay off an enemy to leave me alone, even with max honor for my Daimyo still nothings, but it's honestly not a reason to even get bother by. 
Auto-Resolving; Now this is the only thing that actually bothers me to my core. It's really broken and unfair, I mainly use it on too large of a scale for battling. It's even worse on Sieging which just bothers me to my core even me more. You can obviously by outnumbering your enemy even more than they could you or if you have a good computer that can run 12k v 12k then you have nothing to worry about. 

My Final recommandation: 9/10 If the dilopmacy and auto-resolve were better it would be a 10/10 but not everything can be perfect. 
Also; Who doesn't like Samurais?!

A simple but immersive Total War polished to a mirror shine. Control and movement are smooth, UI is intuitive, art, sound and special effects are fantastic (arrows are actual arrows instead of weird wind trails) and the roster is well rounded and balanced. Shogun II is the last of the older school of Total War games, that has many flaws but they are definitely overshadowed by the benefits.

+ Fall of the Samurai is one of the best DLC's for a Total War game. It provides a new more modern scenario for the player to tackle. Based in the late 1800's, the scenario shows the rapid change of the rules of warfare from the naginata to the modern rifle.
+ Decent performance and art style
+ The Empire Divided mechanic provides sufficient challenge in order to avoid the typical "map-painting" phase of all Total War games.
- Somewhat restricted unit pool

Shogun 2 is a must have for any strategy fan. It's hard, fun and extremely intuitive. You will lose your first campaign and will immediately proceed to play for the next 12 hours straight... It's extremely addictive. And (to me anyways) it never gets old. 

The soundtrack ismarvellous, the soundeffects are outerwordly , the atmosphere is so damn perfect, the animations are still mind blowing, performance issues are almost non existing and the graphics are still gorgeous. 

This is arguably the best game of the Total War series and a must have for fans of japanese culture, fans of strategy games or both.

Ever dreamed of controlling a thousand samurai warriors and zooming in on the battle to see badass historically accurate battle animations?? Ever dreamed of using a group of ninjas to sneak past enemy lines to kill the enemy commander?? Every dreamed of a game set in Feudal Japan after seeing The last samurai and other classics?? Buy the bloody thing already!!

Pros: Too much to list. + If you dislike something there is a mod to fix it that can be installed by clicking a button on the workshop

Cons (not fixable with mods): Japanese phrases sound painfully ridiculous for anyone that speaks japanese. The tutorial doesn't explain much and naval battles are waaaaaaayy tooooo looooong. Also autoresolve will lose you a battle, that if you fought it, you'd easily win. 

Conclusion: Besides the upcoming Ghosts of Tsushima, this is the best tribute to Asian Military History ever developed in video games. You won't find a better pre 20th century japanese themed game even in your dreams. If you like Japan, you will like this game. If you like epic battles, you will like this game. If you like to be challenged. you will like this game. 

Shogun 2 is a near perfect game and imo the best TOTAL WAR game ever conceived and to be conceived. Pick this up at full price or at a discount, but don't miss out of this masterpiece.

Fantastic real time strategy game set in historic Japan with great aesthetic.  There's two aspects to this game:  the overland campaign map where the player manages his/her empire by building infrastructure, managing income taxes, engaging in diplomacy, and of course, producing and upgrading military units for conquest.  This is the strategic component of the game.  

The other part is the tactical battle map where the player fights his/her enemies.  These maps are dynamic and the geography is based on where you chose to fight on the campaign map.  The player can ambush their opponents, engage in siege battles, or even fight in naval battles.  Command hundreds, if not thousands, of samurai warriors, monks, archers, etc; each unit of which is animated individually with wonderfully choreographed movements! 

There're many different Japanese clans to choose from and several campaign options, depending on what you are interested in.  Most of the clans have unique abilities that make them stand out from the others, in addition to their geographical starting points.  

I have not played the multiplayer portion of this game, but I understand that it is rather good and remains somewhat popular, even today.  Especially with the recent Steam sale (free) that was introduced in 2020.

That said, overall I would say the game has aged rather well.  When it was released, this was the most polished Total War game to date, and it shows, even today.  

My primary criticism focuses on the AI, which, beyond hard difficulty, essentially has to massively cheat in order to keep up with the player.  It is decent enough though, that most players, especially newer ones, will find it very challenging and rewarding on the Normal/Hard levels.  

The next issue I have with the game is the fact that it was programmed for 32-bit computer systems, and as such, is incapable of taking advantage of the higher memory of modern video cards or hyper threading technology (can only use up to 4 physical CPU cores).  By default, the game will only recognize around 2GB of VRAM, but is capable of using up to 4GB; to enable this, simply locate the "preferences.script.txt" file and find the "gfx_video_memory 0;" line, and replace the "0;" with "-2000" so it should look like: 
 "gfx_video_memory -2000;" This will allow the game to use the maximum memory it is capable of using.

Even with this, the game can be quite slow in loading, with the first splash screen at the start taking a minute or two even on modern computers.  Battles can also take about thirty seconds to load as well, but it isn't too much of a problem, really.  If it is, you can run the game on Direct X 9 to decrease the loading time by over half. 

So that's it!  Do I recommend this game?  Absolutely!  Even in 2020?  Heck yes!  It is one of the greatest real time strategy games ever made and provides endless hours of entertainment.  I hope this review was helpful.  Have a nice day.

Shogun 2 is simply an extremely refined and polished game, personaly only Napoleon and Age of Charlemagne(Attila expansion) come sightly close in my eyes. 
One of the few Total War games that i can trully enjoy without the need of any mods, because of its high level of autenticity and historical accuracy in comparison with other TW tittles. 

- The time period and world zone both feel very refreshing as they barely have been touched by any other game before, even previous Total War games(with exeption of Shogun 1). 

- The art work/UI and music/sound are hands down some of the more immersive and better looking/sounding ones in the whole gaming industry in my opinion. Hell even the graphics still look great so many years after.

- The layout of the campaign map gives the AI a decent fighting chance... almost making it look as if it was competent. 

- The unit composition altough seemingly "samy" for all factions, make balance much less of an issue and still leaves a lot of room for diversity and customization(specially on multiplayer). 

- The inclusion of the RPG leveling system for agents and generals gives agency to the players and adds replayability.

- The Avatar Conquest multiplayer it's incredibly engaging and immersive giving each player an unprecedent level customization and personalization over his general, individual units and basicaly the whole army.

There is more to be said, but i think you get the idea... Shogun 2 does a lot of things very well and has an special charm that most Total War games(specially recent ones) fail to capture.

No game is not without flaws tho... most can be found in the multiplayer part of the game; i quote myself:

[quote=Yellow;1735468693692217920][quote=CA Grace]We were aware of issues with the SHOGUN II multiplayer [/quote]

Well if we gonna talk about issues regarding the multiplayer: 

1st: 
It goes without saying that paid DLC Units should had never been allowed in a competitive multiplayer game. 
Those who buy Rise of the Samurai, Sengoku Jidai, Saints and Heroes or the Ikko Ikko DLC all get more powerful and cost efficient units, not to mention a lot of very powerful exclusive retainers! Thus putting anyone who does not pay for the DLCs at a handicap. 
Different time period units should not have been mixed toguether neither, not only does this makes balancing even harder, but also takes away from immersion.

2nd: 
On the retainers topic; They ALL should have been easier to unlock by being directly linked to Territories on the Avatar Map, eventually a few special ones linked to Archivements. None should have been linked to random post battle drops, much less to FULL armor sets where obtaining each individual piece is itself based on RNG. One can play a million battles and still be as unlucky as to not get some of the arguably most important retainers, leaving you with a handicap on the multiplayer based purely on luck. 
I don't see the point neither on having what basically are "Tiered Retainers" (same function just better bonus). Let alone paid DLC retainers. 

3rd:
Capping units... This should have been done with all units in my opinion. No one should be allowed to field an entire army of the same exact unit, making certain retainers extremely OP and making said build very hard to counter with anything other than an specialized anti-build, thus further increasing the luck element, where battles are won already on the army selection screen.
All units should have been capped at around 6 (some at even less), as well as having a Unit-Class cap too, like for example max 10 calv, max 10 swords, etc, etc thus forcing melee spammers and in particular cav spammers to at least mix up their units a little; A unit and class cap would also automatically help balance out certain retainers selection. 

4th:
New players disadvantage. A new player with only ashigaru units unlocked (even if said new player is very skillful) has almost 0 chance to win a battle vs a more leveled up player (even if said player is less skillful), as the ashigaru units will simply rout as soon as the fight start. 
In my opinion all basic samurai units (bow, yari, katana, and yari cav) should have been available from level 0 to all players. This would even up the field early on and give everyone a fairer chance. Clan specialization should instead be about unlocking higher tier (specialized) units and upgrades, not starting ones. 

5th:
The inclusion of dojos on the different maps is overall a great idea, as it prevents camping and red lining. However not all dojos are created equal and their positioning and randomness make for some unfair situations sometimes, when one dojo of arguably less importance is closer to one player, while another dojo of arguably higher value is closer to the other player. 
All dojos should simply be equally accessible to both players at the start of the game, being it ultimately up to said players to focus or not on capturing or neutralizing them. 
On the same topic, Bow Dojo should give both accuracy and reload speed, and do NOT give ammo-resupply for 2 reasons:
-  Most games end so fast that you hardly ever run out of ammo, making the ammo resupply mechanic (and even the extended ammo upgrades) rather pointless most of the time. 
- In the special case of the enemy spamming cav and bow cav, it becomes the complete opposite, this dojo and its resupply ability becomes OP. To counter a cav rush with a balanced army you are basically forced to go for the hills and forest in order to have a fighting chance vs said cheese army, however, since the bow dojo gives infinite ammo resupply then we are sadly forced in stead to try and neutralize it and thus end up out in the open near the dojo where we are an easy target, the alternative is to simply ignore it and go to the woods and die from infinite arrows or lose anyway because of the dojo capture timer.

6th: 
Naval battles on vanilla Shogun 2 are a mess. Yet they are necessary in order to unlock all land regions (thus all units and retainers) on the Avatar Conquest map. 
I think this was a mistake; Siege battles are neither required nor ranked, why then make Naval ones both things, when they are arguably worse than Siege?! Don't get me wrong I don't think they should be removed, just make them not ranked, and let us move move our avatar to the islands regardless of water territories being unlocked or not.

7th:
Why allow Public Groups to be selected as Clans? This makes the whole Clan Competition feature rather pointless as zerg clans have a clear advantage over smaller private ones. Small steps to alleviate this were taken such as the implementation of losing points by losing battles and such, but that ain't enough. 
Only private groups should have counted as Clans from the beginning, and only Officers (owners) of said groups should have been able to activate them and select clan specialisation in game. There should have been an option to disband the group as a clan, and/or of changing clan specialization!

8th:
Another thing greatly missing is the option to reset veteran skills like we can do with our general. This would allow players to be more experimental with their units and builds, and reduce the amount of grind. As well as to add another clan token sink.

9th:
Movement speed is way too fast, and time to kill extremely low, resulting in most matches lasting less than 5 minutes. There is little room for tactics and strategy, and too much focus on pure micro and luck (army composition). 

10th:
Special abilities. They work for General and Heroes, but i don't think they should be a part of regular units. I would much rather see elite/top tier units just have access to special formations and/or some passive aura-debuffs/buffs.
This change would actually help with the previous point, as by toning down the power-cap of certain units we would balance them sightly; as well as end up making battles a tad slowed as result...

If you can't claim the game because you own FoTS, try to contact support.

I won't link it here as I don't know the rules for linking outside websites, however it has been posted on their subreddit.

It's an unfortunate bug with steam that hasn't been fixed, however support should be able to help you claim the game.

EDIT: There is a fix going around that worked for me. Open 2 tabs of your preferred browser and go to the steam store with those, make sure you are signed out. Now, have one that you will NOT sign in with on the game's store and sign in with the other. After the other tab is signed in, use the one that is signed out to claim the game.
After that, it should add the game to your account!

I did not find this on my own, however this should be useful to anyone having issues claiming the game.

I like it. Chosokabe are my favorite. I play fairly modded, so anything I dislike is fixed.(The lack of console cheats I found annoying at 1st, but a cheat mod has sufficed) Main problems; archers have no idea what guard mode means. They just randomly start approaching (under fire) things well within range. They fire at whatever they want to & will repeatedly ignore orders.(even with fire at will off) Sometimes units in general will just do random things you don't tell them to. (Scream"WTF are you doing?! NOOOO!"& "JUST STAND & SHOOT, GORRAMMIT!" at the screen a lot) 
 But, other than those minor annoyances, it's a pretty fun Total War. Now that it's free I wish I waited...get it NOW before they change their minds!(oops too late it's over) It was still worth the 75% off I think I got it for. I also got Rise of the Samurai at the time & a bunch of clan packs. Don't like Rise as much. Didn't get FotS because I don't like guns in Total War. "Too much noise, too much smoke, very bad smell." Thank God for the person who made the mod that removes the cannon sound from archers caused by other mods. Gimme flaming arrows any day, looks much cooler, burns the fort & arrow towers. Also, love the way the dudes writhe around in agony after being Boromired with multiple arrows. The last 1 or 2 are really funny with 100 arrows in them.(That's gotta hurt)
 I have to agree with others about not needing generals in every army being nice. Love having huge stacks just laying around waiting to swarm like hornets when some clan has the unmitigated audacity to attack my divinely blessed(aka severely cheating, otherwise what good's being a god?) chosen people. They quickly learn the meaning of blitzkrieg.
 The Shameless Endless Movement mod is awesome. Perfect for monopolizing all the foreign trade ports, & attacking multiple targets per turn. Thanks to Steam for having the workshop open on this 1. Without cheats I'd be bankrupt & running a deficit by turn 5; now my troops EARN money instead of costing upkeep. Keep churning out 6 units a turn in every fort/port & I'm soon an all powerful millionaire. Oh, & endless food supply; priceless. Nothing but build & stomp. And that's how you play as a god, not just some weak, pitiful human clan leader.(Dang, if only you could hear the lamentation of the women...)

After 10 years, Shogun 2 is still the best Total War game out there. CA definitely peaked with this game. You might like one TW game or another more than this, but the end product, even completely vanilla, of Shogun 2 is their finest work.

Beautiful art direction, accessible UI, responsive AI movement, and dynamic (if not exactly fair) balancing all make Shogun 2 a stand-out experience. I recommend just getting this game now, booting up the base campaign, choosing a warlord with your favorite colors, and exploring everything the game can do. Even if you fail, the first few turns are quick and painless, especially with a modern PC or laptop. The battles are quick if you're not used to the speed of later Total War games, so they can feel punishing if you don't know what you're doing. But I recommend diving in regardless, you'll quickly learn how to outwit the AI--they've never been particularly bright.

If you like multiplayer, I remember Avatar Conquest being the only time I was actually into competitive multiplayer in a Total War game; but it's been years since AC was super populated. Who knows? Maybe the new players will bring it back to life.

If you like the experience and want to expand things, consider the Fall of the Samurai DLC first if you like even more fast-paced, gunpowder-centered fights. And if you want to tweak the gameplay there are a ton of mods you can try out. DarthMod and Master of Strategy are both excellent choices. Take advantage of the free-to-keep offer and enjoy!

This version of Total War only has one major problem: The Map.
Total War is intended as a strategy game, but the map and the way the provinces are layed out, it's very linear; not much more than few provinces side-by-side in one big line.

Aside from that, the game is the "latest and greatest" Total War compared to all those the came before it, but for me, that map is just too limited to be interesting, so Napolean (Europe and part of Asia) and Empires (Eastern Americas and much of Europe) are much more interesting and fun games because of their map layout.

In many ways, I can't play this for very long without thinking it's unfortinate in this case that his game is based on actual history, or rather, moreso geography...

I know most people would kind of freak if they made a game about historic Japanese warriors spreading across Eurasia, or some alien planet, so I get that they couldn't make a proper history-based game based on the era without the "problem" of Japan's Island/Islands being layed out in pretty much a straight north-south line that doesn't lend itself well to complex strategies, but that said, maybe they should have simply gone for another historic era because the simplicity of the map really did limit my enjoyment of this game significantly.

Superb. This is a game that I can play over and over and over and over again. Sure it gets repetitive, but if I want to play a total war game, this is the one for me.

I highly recommend it! But make sure your computer can handle Shogun 2! If you can handle Rome 2 onward, you should be fine :D

Hello, annon, and thank you for reading.

Having played and enjoyed every title in the franchise; The rudimentary nature of medieval Japanese warfare causes Total War: Shogun 2 to be the easiest version to *learn* within the series (next to its even more simplistic predecessor).
The variation of clans, and their well-balanced specialties allow for wonderful replay value, as well as flexibility toward providing various flavors of game-play styles to enjoy, means that you will also log at least 200 hours as I have into this game.
The DLC campaigns are each totally distinct games with their own sets of rules and units in order to cater to the radically different periods of Japan; so you have a variety of options for levels of technology, and units to play around with.

You can have 28 Us Marines, annon.
You may use them to siege things.

I personally love both the core campaign, as well as Fall of the Samurai - while Rise of the Samurai seems much more challenging, as it feels like more of a culture war... pfft - fire and steel, all the way.

TLDR:
10/10 - would establish myself as Shogun, and then cast out the smelly French and Dutch to pave way for the ultimate weeaboos wet dream of 28 US Marines and a bunch of Samurai laying siege to Ram Ranch, chasing out the Liberal/Globalist Imperialists in order to maintain Tradition, Order, and Integrity within the sovereign United Provinces of Yamato SEVERAL more times. RIDE THE TIGER, BRAH!

The confusion is that Fall of the Samurai is a standalone game. The Shogun 2 base game is also standalone. What the game developers did was streamline the launcher and game .exe to run The Shogun 2 base game, Rise of the Samurai, and Fall of the Samurai all together without requiring seperate installs or game .exe's. So even though you have 2 games that are 'standalone' they are both incorporated the same game launcher and game .exe... Hence, when you buy the base game mode, Steam will update the launcher and .exe to add the base game mode to the main menu you've been using to play Fall of the Samurai.

Steam does not differentiate between game modes using the same launcher, so it will say you already 'own' the game- but you do not.

For it's time, this game is a masterpiece. But with Creative Assembly and Sega creating faction/race-specific research trees, units (not just Ikko Ikki Ashigaru), mechanics, 'stances' cities with set sizes (instead of all them having Citadel potential), a more expansive counter-cycle (Spearmen --> Horses --> Archers --> Spearmen, for Shogun 2) this game is severely outdated.

Let's compare DLC. Just to show how outdated this game is by Warhammer 2.

Otomo Clan Pack DLC ($5) adds a new faction.
[list]
[*]5 'new' units. 1 of them being a Naval unit and it's not the Nanban Trade ship (Otomo's primary Naval power source), simply put, it's useless. Otomo Matchlock Ashigaru, this unit is literally just Matchlock Ashigaru with +5 to reload and accuracy. Portuguese Tercos, these are actually new units in terms of design and name. They're matchlock infantry with good melee and armor stats, pretty cool. Matchlock Samurai, have the same gimmick as Matchlock Ashi. And to finish off with Donderbuss Cav (unique to Otomo) this is an Otomo specific unit and it's new. So you get basically 2 new units out of 5. Score: 4/10

[*]New Buildings. Leased land (give up Daimyo honour for 4500 gold), this is only useful early. Otomo economy is amazing due to Nanban ports. I have only used this once and it was in Legendary. This isn't useless, but it's not useful. The Christianity Chain, actually Otomo's most useful building for conquering, believe it or not. Converting enemy provinces to Christianity makes them unhappy with their Shinto-Buddhist ruler, vice-versa with Otomo. The Missionary can incite a revolt assuming the populace is close to unhappy (which religion differences can cause this). Rebellions on legendary are strong, especially if you can win a battle against the enemy's primary army, they'll struggle with it and possibly lose. Score 8/10

[*]Faction trait. Yeah it exists, not much to it. Score meh/10

[*]Actually playing it. Otomo is a dreadful campaign. Military allies in this game are USELESS, don't even make them. They don't get the repercussions you do for breaking them and for nearly 100% of the factions, you'll have a -60 diplomatic penalty for being Christian, making trade, peace, and avoiding war a nightmare. It's a challenge and there is hours to be had trying to beat it or even survive. Score 8/10

[*] DLC score: 6/10 content is decent, but it makes claims to try and justify the 5 dollar price tag that it shouldn't have.
[/list]

Warhammer 2 DLC ($9) - The Prophet and the Warlock (other similar priced DLCs can vary in quality, primarily Hunter and the Beast)

[list]
[*]2 New Legendary Lords. Ikit Claw and Tehenhauin. Ikit Claw is disgusting, Skaven's best lord. Ikit has a crazy skill tree that corrects almost any pitfalls that are present to begin with. He works really well on a Doomwheel mount spamming Warp Lightning. But there's a lot to Ikit that I don't even know fully. Tehenhauin is a hard to pilot lord with some pretty interesting bonuses, Lore of Beasts, a decent melee fighter (can beat some Lords in melee, but relies on Lore of Beasts buffs to correct pitfalls), and good mounts. 9/10

[*]Clan Skryre and Cult of Sotek factions added. Skryre has the Forbidden workshop mechanic added which is BROKEN, they also bring in a set of crazy good units that Skaven needs to survive (Warplock Jezzails, Doom-Flayers, Ratling Guns). Cult of Sotek brings in a whole lot of new units and a mechanic called "Sacrificial Offerings". They bring in 3 new monsters, another unit of flying cavalry, Red Crested Skinks (armor-piercing melee which early game Lizardmen lacked), and Salamander Hunting Packs which are crazy strong in the early game. Their SO mechanic gives them rewards they can buy with the offerings that they get from battles and missions, these can be special units (Regiments of Renown), stat buffs, army abilities, followers/banners (equipable to a character, some are gross specifically 20% reduced upkeep). Both factions are presented their own unique challenges. 9/10

[*]Two New additional lord types. This is less interesting but, Skaven get Warlock Masters and Lizardmen get Red Crested Skink Chiefs. meh/10

[*]Nine new battlefield units. Already mentioned, these are the meat of the DLC. 10/10

[*]Skryre Doomrocket and Great Invocation of Sotek. Doomrocket is BROKEN, it's a nuke, get an enemy army to group on some Clanrats (that you can spawn like 7 times a battle), get 1k kills from the nuke and guarantee a win in a tight battle. Great Invocation of Sotek is not as broken, but it's a strong Wind ability, can rip through units and again secure a victory. 8/10

[*]New Regiments of Renown. It's pretty good, just some good units to grab when you don't want to spend the time recruiting or can't. 8/10
[/list]

The difference in DLC is astonishing. There are also DLCs that add RACES to the game, not just expanding on a race or adding a faction with the same tech tree, units, buildings, etc. Tomb Kings, Vampire Coast, Beastmen, Wood Elves, and Chaos Warriors. ALL OF THESE RACES IN THE DLC AND ALL RACES IN THE GAME HAVE DIFFERENT SKILL TREES.

Shogun 2 is the better one of the three for me, and it's 9 years old now. 9/10 recommend for any RTS fans. But if you're into base-building this may miss your mark because the juice of this game is in the huge army battles.

I loved Rome: Total War and played it ad nauseum. I've sunk way too many hours into Empire: TW and Medieval 2: TW.

So, with that in mind: this game is no improvement on previous games in the series. The enemy AI is still stupidly easy to beat, both sending inferior forces against you and managing them poorly in battle. You still need to fight every battle yourself to get the best outcome because the auto-calculate fight will never perform to scratch; this leads to a lot of tedious little battles. This is exacerbated by poor load times.

So you sit and wait for the fight to load, demolish some poor dumb peasant soldiers, sit and wait for the campaign map to load. Over and over.

There's apparently multiplayer "drop in battle" capability, allowing human players to take over campaign AI opponents in battle, but there are several problems here:
[list]
[*]If nobody's on at the same time you're playing, you get no battle. I haven't fought in a single one for that reason.
[*]As a drop-in player, you're going to get poor fights because the campaign AI is still stupid and sends out inferior armies. Taking command of two units of peasant spearmen and one of peasant archers against six samurai units is a lost cause, and no fun.
[*]As a campaign player with drop-in switched on, you run the risk of people screwing with you, just giving your army the runaround until time expires, rather than a proper stand-up fight. They've got nothing to lose by simply trolling you.
[/list]
There have been TEN games in the Total War series, and the AI has not improved since the first one. The novelty of a new setting is not enough to overcome this crippling deficiency. The heart and soul of Total War games is the battles, and the battles simply aren't fun once you realise just how bad the AI is.

If you've never played a Total War game before, you'll probably have an absolute blast. If you've already played TW games, don't waste your time - this is nothing new.

LORE
Total War: SHOGUN 2 is about Japanese clans waging all sorts of ancient warfare upon each other. It includes an encyclopedia with quotes and content, contributing to this theme.

PLAY
It features two types of play, both related to each other. The first requires making large-scale, turn-based decisions. The other covers small-scale, tactical warfare.
Winning involves expanding a clan it's influence, while supporting an economy to maintain and outfit it's army.
Fights reward winning a battle, which in turn strengthens an army unit.

SKILL
It has adjustable difficulties.
When it is played without turns, armies are influenced by circumstances, which are determined during it's play in turns.
Different clans, and both human-, and computer opponents encourage replaying it.

HELP REQUESTED!!!!

I'm running the game on Windows 10, and i've previously been able to run Rome: Total War and Medieval II Total War without any incidents, but Shogun II is the first to be unable to launch. I'd like some help, as i've gone so far as to update flash and directx to the latest possible versions, yet remain unable to play the game... please help!!

SOLUTION // EDIT:

Basically McAffee was recognising Shogun 2 as a virus / potential virus and forcing a shutdown once it launched. The easy fix was to add the ".exe" file to the list of exceptions in the McAffee firewall, which allowed me to launch and play the game. To get to this ".exe" file, simply right-click your shortcut on desktop and select "Go to file location."
Not my favorite setting, but it's objectively the best Total War game to date

Battles - 4/5
Naval battles - 2/5
Campaign - 5/5
Atmosphere - 5/5
DLCs - 5/5

- More concentrated at battle tactics than on economics or politics like Paradox games. It is there but it's all smaller, more compact, clear and easily understandable. There are historical characters here, however you will start the campaign playing as their fathers, and the real sengoku heroes will be born (spawn) later. (with randomized armor, which is shame)

- Battles are the real core here. You need to pay attention to weaknesses and strenghts of each unit and plan your tactics accordingly. In some more difficult terrain the AI sometimes acts stupid and does not do what it is told to, so you need to pay extra attention there. Siege maps seem a bit empty compared to the newer Total Wars, but they are like that so your troops wouldn't get stuck at fences and trees all the time. (I've tried moded maps and they do so all the time) Naval battles are a pain to do. The AI is really stupid here. It won't do exactly what you want it to do and sometimes two of your ships will ram into each other and block their way for no reason. Luckily the enemy AI does it as well. They are fun only when you have slightly higher numbers or slightly stronger ships, which makes them winable. 

- The historical battles are more fun. Except the naval one. They are not all historically accurate though. Usually when you play as someone else than Oda or Tokugawa.

- The DLC are good. New clans with new mechanics, new interesting units and The Fall of the Samurai completely transforms the game with new almost everything.

Well, if my hours in this game do not speak for itself, let me do so. If you are a fan of the Total War franchise, and also like a good historical mix of ancient and more modern, then this game is for you. Between the Rise of the Samurai campaign, the Shogun 2 Campaign, and the Fall of the Samurai Campaign, there is always something new to discover. I always find myself coming back to this and honestly I should have wrote this review sooner (before 674 hours of play). 

Pros:
A good mix of melee and archaic ranged battles; Also modern ranged combat
A game deep enough to get lost in, but shallow enough for someone new to the franchise to grasp
An easy to understand economic function, as well as a variety of ways to go about it.
Pretty much the entire game

Cons (or Suggestions??):
Naval battles are kind of hard to grasp, since I myself still do not ever engage without auto resolve
I would have appreciated more DLC on the expansion of more clans or modern units from the West

I would say that this game is well worth the money I paid for it, and would buy a 3rd iteration without hesitation. Buy the game, enjoy it, and thank me later!

This game is mega fun.  Learn Japanese history, experience the advisor's super meme voice, and get your a** kicked by Realm Divide.  

I passed a Japanese history class in university using some of the knowledge I learned from this game.  There is quite a bit of good, well-researched detail, both in game mechanics and lore that makes this game very enjoyable to an amateur historian like myself.  

Is this the best Total War?  Not by a long shot.  Economics is rather cut-and-dry, have a few military districts and stick a market in every other settlement.  Peasant spam the AI's "elite" samurai armies, those aristocrats' lower population and barely improved stats mean that all eventually will fall beneath the ashigaru tide.  You can sell military access to the AI and they stupidly keep paying you for the privilege.

However, the units have solid niches and a good combined-arms military force can keep things interesting as you unify Japan.  Plus, each faction you play definitely is able to win.  Obviously, some are easier than others, as Shimazu katana samurai are worth three yari ashigaru, while the Otomo's matchlock mastery means you can bring 18th century battle tactics to the 16th century.  Your opponents brought a sword to a gunfight.  It does not end well for them.

Plus, the DLC are all great expansions to the game.  Fall of the Samurai (FOTS) is the closest we have ever gotten to a Total War modern war experience and it delivers.  Some people say using guns is unfair.  Well, guess what - in war, if you are fighting fair, then you aren't trying hard enough.  Welcome to the modern world.  There's a reason we aren't walking around with pikes anymore.  

You get to teach that lesson to a lot of factions and it never gets old, in my opinion.  Great game, if you haven't gotten in yet, wait for it to go on sale.

Easily one of the best historical Total War games and given the scope of time the game and its expansions cover, it's very insightful into the history of Japan. Fall of the Samurai is easily my favorite expansion pack since Forces of Corruption for Star Wars: Empire at War because not only are Gatling and Armstrong guns big memes and I love them, but it also puts you in the shoes of a rapidly changing Japan as you take your clan on a journey from the spear and bow to early modern armies and fleets that would bring about the beginning of a new order. Given Japan's status as a cutting edge modern country and a cultural exporter second only to the United States, its history is worth learning about and you'll actually learn a lot through doing in a weird way.

Shogun 2 is the best of the Total War games, newer or older.  Before S2, TW games are too graphically outdated and have too little polish.  Ever since S2, all Total War games have done something which drives me crazy - they prevent armies from being broken down into smaller units without an expensive leader to be in command of the smaller unit.  This makes it very difficult to cover your territories without either tons of leaders or having to run around the map with your too few giant armies.  Total War Shogun 2 is the best blend of the new and the old, it has great balance, just the right amount of detail in all phases of the game.

There's a lot of Total War games these days. The greatest difference are the "where's," and "when's," of the battles. You can play the game as the ancient Romans if you buy Total War: Rome, as an example. You can play as a Chinese Dynasty, or in a Fantasy setting like found in the War Hammer world. Really too many choices to mention.
The game play doesn't deviate from it's core in any of these games, and believe me that's a good thing, because it's masterful and evolved, but it's still the same from game to game no matter what the age of the edition. 

What shines (imo) in Total War: Shogun 2, is the Japanese Culture in that 1650 A.D. era is just so stunningly beautiful. Yes the architecture, and loading screens, and costumes...all of that is stunning. However, it's also the things you can't see, like Bushido, and a warriors honour, and the cleverness of tactics (eg ninja spies).
Even the random title screen opening graphic, which may just show a dojo, or a boat, while it plays this beautiful gentle Japanese music from that era. This game is still beautiful today, and even a modest gaming PC, with a current GP will be able to run everything on ultra.
What can I say, I love this game, and a lot of that is a reflection on how I feel about Japanese culture from that era, and even how I feel about it today. This is a special game if you feel me.
