 I will say one small or maybe big flaw depending on views. 2 simple words. "LEASED LAND". What is leased land you may ask. Well let me enlighten you, leased land is a building that the Otomo can build for no cost. In return the Otomo get a one time little sum of money (4500 koku to be exact) and that building slot is given away to the Portuguese. FOREVER. Thats right once its built no more building slot. If the Otomo are Ai and you conquer that land well SORRY BUD BUT YOUR SHIT OUTTA LUCK. You dont get the money cus the money was given to the Otomo but you have to deal with the consequences. Real fun thing when your hundreds of turns deep into a campaign and you take over Kyushu to find A BUILDING SLOT IN EVERY PROVINCE TAKEN UP BY SCUMMY EUROPEANS(no offense to Europeans) AND YOUR STUCK WITH A USELESS BUILDING. Its real frustrating but fortunately it can be fixed by mods. Now besides that and a few other small things, this game is still the best one and is easily my most recommendable one.

Total war Shogun 2 is a great Total war game.The battles are fast,Fun and balanced,unless it is max difficulty then it is your rank 4 army Vs two rank 9 armies.Also the unit verity is a good amount you have a few choices when it come's to Swords,Spears,Bows and Horseman,guns are Matchlock Asigaru,Imported matchlock Asigaru,Gun monks or if you have the Otomo clan dlc Portagese Tercos.The Seiges are meh for the Attaker and fun for the defender.Building Verity is fine.


FOTS:If you like Massive death lines of guns and cannons then this is for you.the unit verity is large,lots of guns,cannons,Melee and bows.the building verity is better than the base game.


MODS: the mods make the games 100% better you could have a mod that gives you infinet money,no unrest,more units and MINIGUNS.
In conclusion Total War Shogun 2 is a great game

This is game is simply brilliant. All of the strategies and different ways of playing are so well made, that I can't even believe that its developers thought so well about it. The ground combat is really nice, including different types of units, all of the clans being slightly better at something. The naval combat might not be as good as after Total war versions, but it is still nice to see those japanese type of ships fighting. Even if you don't like the japanese ships so much, you could play with Otomo and start getting big Portuguese ships. The "nanban" is the thing which I like the most. You can literally choose if you want to progress to greater and more modern ways of power or compress and evolve with the one that you already have. The family tree is simple yet geniusly arranged. Alliances and betrayals are very common here. Everything happens fast, unlike other Total War games. Try it out, you will definetly not regret it.

I've played Total War games from the first Shogun title, released ages ago. This is definitely my favorite grand strategy series, and Shogun 2 is one of my favorite editions in that series. Still a handsome game, deep strategy options, lots of tense moments on the battlefield and on the strategy map. Some other long time fans will tend to point out flaws in the AI. Yeah, all that, you can say it, and if you're looking for the utmost nail-biting, micromanagement strategic experience there are other options. But in my view Creative Assembly's approach probably hits a sweet spot, and unless you want to have to obsess about a game to master it, I think the balance here between resource planning and live tactics and the challenge of each is the correct one, and good enough for most strategy gamers to enjoy, at the very least worthy of a favorable remark.

I purchased this game long time ago, but played only recently. This game offers excellent strategy and warfare experience, it's a very detailed and interesting. However this game also has some CRUCIAL FLAWS, most notably this:

1) Diplomacy is totally broken. Other factions treat you unfriendly for no reasons and it's very hard to get trade agreements with other factions.   

2) Realm Divide event - when you capture 10-15 provinces, all other factions suddenly declare war on you and you can not survive. This is the major flaw of the game. Not fun at all. Basically after you capture a number of provinces you can not continue gameplay.

3) Time limitations - time is very limited, especially in Fall of Samurai. You have a small number of turns to achieve goals.

4) No in game manual - manual for this game contains only 13 pages instead of 300-400 pages because of complexity of the game.

I can recommend this game only partially, and for the early stages of gameplay. The game is really good at the start, but after Realm Divide event it's literally unplayable. I don't know why developers ruined this game with broken diplomacy and limitations. 

Majority of the unofficial mods for this game don't work so dont bother to install them.

Buy this game when on sale, because of its flaws it's not worth more than 10 - 15 EUR.

I have another account which probably has more like 600 to maybe 800+ hours so take that into account when reading this review.
Total War Shogun 2 is an excellent strategy game which in the base game can be your typical total war game but based in Japan, or if you have the Fall of the Samurai expansion turns the traditional total war game into a hybrid of Empire/Napoleon and introduces more modern firearms and artillery which is the most destructive it's been in the series able to wipe out sometimes a quarter to half a squad with a single round. 
Naval combat is also pretty good in FOTS, the ironclad giants like the HMS Warrior or the sniper L'ocean class . These giants are able to take on incredible odds and make you rule the seas if you can afford them.
All in all I would give this game a chance, it may be getting up in age but hey that just means it should be easier to run.

[h1] The epitome of Total War. [/h1]

[i]Keep in mind I have every DLC.[/i]

- Three campaign eras spanning across 1000 years of Japanese history, from the age of the graceful katana to the age of the merciless, breach-loading rifle. Each campaign has its own faction roster, technology trees, and unique gameplay mechanics. Also features two-player multiplayer campaign support.
- Tactical battles that you know and love from Total War at their best. Countless units to choose from, with custom battles supporting every era simultaneously in both singleplayer and multiplayer. Despite the huge technological differences in the eras, you'll be surprised just how ridiculously balanced the units really are. The trusty bow and spear CAN beat the modern army with proper leadership, which makes this game absolutely delightful. Naval battles are also present in the game.
- Breathtaking graphics on both the battlefield and campaign map. Battles are superbly cinematic. Battlefields can be played in any season and any weather. Troop animations are gorgeous and melee combat animations are the best in Total War that I have seen.
- Unit reactivity to orders feels instantaneous and unit movement and transitions are exceptionally fluid.
- Astonishing mod support and a strong modding presence on the Steam Workshop, where you can find mods for campaign as well as multiplayer. I have made several mods and custom maps myself!
- Great audio ranging from the soundtracks to the sounds of battle.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#1 out of 555)... it's time for Total War: Shogun 2

I kind of hate Shogun 2. I've been playing Total War games since the demo disc for the first Shogun in PC Gamer, way back when--I fell in love immediately. And Shogun 2 is, arguably, the very best entry in the franchise. It's good. Really, really good. Phenomenally good. And the Fall of the Samurai expansion allows us to experience the surprisingly-engaging gunpowder-age combat introduced in Empire, while still retaining the fantastic traditional medieval combat in the base game. 

Don't get me wrong, it's not perfect--naval combat is a bit of a mess, diplomacy is as wonky as ever, and the lack of the throne room or any similar roleplay-style systems is a bit disappointing. But it's still one of the best strategy games out there--nevermind among the best looking.

But, see, Shogun 2 isn't simply the best Total War game out there--it's also the last good Total War game out there. It's the one game by which every subsequent Total War is judged, and they invariably fall far, far, far short. It's really depressing, honestly. I'm sitting here, writing this, desperately hoping the upcoming Three Kingdoms will finally buck this trend (after all, Shogun 2's brilliance came after Empire's catastrophe) but I am not optimistic.

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

Additionally, we were aware of issues with the SHOGUN II multiplayer servers and have been working on a fix to allow players to continue to battle for Japan online. This fix should now be live.

review: Even years later, this is probably the most beautiful Total War game. The art style, interface, and design all reflect the period to make this game really just feel right. The only complaints you will really hear about this game vs other Total War titles is the limited scope of troops (being Feudal Japan), but it is less of a problem then you think. There are unique units to each faction (typically 1), along with a fair number of troop types with some overlap that all have their own unique flavor. The expansions either bring you forward or backwards in time, with entirely new rosters of units. The Fall of the Samurai is a particularly good expansion, blending traditional Samurai-era Japanese troops with more modern musket and cannon armed armies.

It's easy to see why there is so much love for Shogun II. The mechanics have been modified and refined, the graphics, UI, and overall presentation also took big steps compared to the previous TW games. The new features are fitting and bring a lot to the TW formula. And the smaller map and various rival mechanics make for a more focused and intense Total War experience. Combat is melee-heavy and a blast to watch.

Unfortunately, the game is still - 9 years from launch - extremely unstable. Crashes during battles are very common, to the point that I've lost hours worth of progress in my short time with the game. I've had more crashes in 10 hours with Shogun II than I did in 200 hours with TW Warhammer II. 

I've done the normal troubleshooting and updating, I've tried the advice on the forums and elsewhere. Doesn't matter which settings I use. Every battle is a toss up, and it seems like more often than not the game waits until I'm moments away from a hard-fought victory before it crashes to desktop. I can't recommend a game this unreliable, no matter how fine the core gameplay.

After a few (lol) hundred more hours, I figured I'd review Shogun 2 again in more detail, and this time, on its own merits rather than heavily comparing it to older Total War titles more than as necessary.

[h1]BATTLES[/h1]

Shogun 2 is still a gem in the Total War series. Its real time battles look gorgeous and control very well, if a bit more fast-paced for those who might prefer the older style of Rome 1 and Medieval 2 where careful positioning and drawn-out engagements are the appeal of the games. That said, the scale is still there, so is the importance of deliberate unit positioning and outwitting your opponent.

Sure, it's got that same formula you expect in TW games: RPS where swords beat spears, spears beat cavalry, cavalry runs over bows, bows cut everyone down until they get too close, and modern guns and cannons ruin everything. But where you place your troops, how you time your attacks, the morale of your men and how fatigued they are compared to the enemy can still win you a seemingly impossible but incredibly satisfying victory, even if your unit composition isn't the most ideal. My Avatar Conquest win-loss ratio remains terrible in this game, but I've never not had fun with the different ways other players maneuver their troops on the field.

[h1]MULTIPLAYER[/h1]

Speaking of which, Avatar Conquest. This is probably the most fun I've had with a multiplayer mode in any strategy game I've played. I suck at it, but I adore it, and I wish just as many people played it as there used to be. There's still some, they just happen to be few and in different time zones. It's almost embarrassing how much time I've spent customizing my general, since there's so many options to unlock as you get achievements and gain levels (both as you unlock more regions of the Avatar Conquest map, some grinds, and even from the campaign). The only thing I wish they got to iron out was being able to see what an enemy general looked like in a battle replay. Eventually it just defaults back to a normal skin, so you can't relive a battle with a rando or a friend and see how their general looked like at the time.

[h1]PRESENTATION[/h1]

But what I will never get over is the detail. The huge armies, the glints on weaponry, the variety of armor being worn by the soldiers, the weather effects, the falling cherry blossom leaves during spring battles, the blood-soaked snow during winter, the lighting, the distant temples and towns in the various maps, and those gorgeous castles in the siege battles, it all looks so good. For an older game, Creative Assembly did an amazing job presenting feudal Japan in as gorgeous a way as they did.

The fact that the units and agents speak Japanese helps with the illusion, too, unlike the game narrators, which, if I recall correctly, are Japanese voice actors seemingly forced at gunpoint to speak English. At least, that’s how I think the recording sessions went. The campiness of it adds to the charm. I'm sure you're all thinking of that same, iconic line. “OUR MEN ARE RUNNING FROM THE BATTLEFIELD. A SHAMEFUL DISPLAY!” Sure, the cartoonish blood effects and the way everything shines a little too much when it's raining is meme-worthy, but there's a lot of aspects in the visuals and sound that make the battles absolutely gorgeous to play and watch to this day.

[h1]CAMPAIGNS[/h1]

But of course, you can't talk about a Total War game without talking about the campaign mode. Given Shogun 2’s laser focus on one country in conflict, there’s a lot of polish with the campaign that I would argue wasn’t present in previous titles that focused on entire continents. That said, I'll focus on the original Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai campaigns only. I will admit I've yet to finish Rise of the Samurai's campaign. It just doesn't hold my attention the way the original and Fall of the Samurai campaigns do. It's not because of the history surrounding it, it just wasn't presented in a way that was compelling, and even early on, some of its mechanics, especially the reskinned and repurposed agents aren't very clear in how they affect the game. I still plan to finish it, but not until I've had at least one more playthrough of one of the other better campaigns.

The Shogun 2 campaign allows you to play a whole host of different clans that start off in their historical home provinces in feudal Japan. Each general has certain buffs to their army with a little bit of historical flavor to it. For example, the Shimazu clan of Satsuma province zealously follow the bushido code and therefore have superior sword-wielding samurai, or my personal favorite, the Uesugi, who are devote Buddhists, and therefore have superior warrior monks. Yes. Warrior monks. That's how the game adds variety to what is admittedly not a very diverse set of units. We are, after all, talking about what is essentially a country-wide civil war rather than different nations fighting one another as previous Total War games were.

Diplomacy in the original Shogun 2 campaign is a little bit of a joke. Alliances don't really matter when there's a set point in the game when you've reached a level of wealth and power where everyone is bound to turn against you. It's called the Realm Divide. Is it historical? Not in the slightest. Is it fun though? I'd say yes. It's an absolute mess by the second half where everyone hates you and you have to get to Kyoto and take it over for a few turns, but there's still tons of little details and situations affecting character traits that make each playthrough engaging.

As for Fall of the Samurai, well, this one I'd say is the best and meatiest among the few Total War games I've played. Fall of the Samurai is set during the Boshin War that led to the Meiji Restoration. Here, you can play using a selection of notable clans that played major roles during this conflict on different sides: allying either with the shogun or with the emperor. What’s interesting is that the nature of the conflict affects which troops and agents your clan would benefit the most from fielding, as well as which disciplines and technologies you choose to research. Shogunate forces have a whole host of new units with both old school samurai weaponry as well as modern firearms. Same goes for the imperialists. Battles are much more varied and chaotic when guns, cannons, naval bombardment, and even elite European infantry are added to the mix.

This campaign also irons out some of the issues that the original had. Diplomacy matters more here. You want allies siding with whoever you’ve thrown in your support for, and the Realm Divide mechanic finally makes sense when it’s shogunate clans against imperialist clans aiming to reunify the country under one banner. But there is an interesting third option when the Realm Divide arrives: throwing both sides away and attempting to unify Japan yourself independent of either the shogun or the emperor. Essentially, you’re recreating the Realm Divide of the original campaign while there’s also still a major conflict going on. Absolute chaos. Total. War. I love that that’s an option to win the campaign. That is a daimyo with cajones made of steel folded over 1000 times.

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]

Despite some of its minor issues, Shogun 2 endeavored to be a proper sequel to the series' origins. This is definitely my favorite Total War game, perhaps one of my favorite strategy games, and I cannot recommend it enough for anyone interested in a mix of grand strategy and real time strategy with immense scale that’s set in an iconic and volatile period in Japan’s history. Even with the disaster of Rome 2’s release since, the successes of Total War’s dip into fantasy with Warhammer, and now, the rise of Total War: Three Kingdoms, Shogun 2’s leaps for the franchise shouldn’t be forgotten.

I'll be reviewing this game in 2 parts; Shogun 2 + ROTS & Fall of the Samurai. Also, this will based on vanilla experience.

Shogun 2
If you play any Total War franchise before, you'll be familiar with the gameplay already. If this is your first entry to the Total War series, then you won't be disappointed. The game is set during the Sengoku Jidai period of Japan. If you like Japanese history, this will be an interesting one. The combat system is excellent and play as any faction as you want to relieve the dream of becoming a Shogun and unite Japan once more like how Oda Nobunaga did. Overall, I like the gameplay and element of the game. ROTS has the same mechanic as Shogun 2, but the setting is set 100 years prior before the main game which is during the Genpei period.

FOTS
If you play Empire or Napoleon, then this game will be familiar to you. The difference between FOTS and Shogun 2 is instead of capturing Kyoto and becoming Shogun, your missing is to unify Japan under the Emperor's banner (Imperial) or Shogun's banner (Shogunate). The setting is set during Boshin War, a few decades after the main game. It also introduces gunpowder units to the game. The combat mechanic is impressive but like Empire, artillery is the king of the battlefield. Also, gunpowder units can massacre a full unit of samurai army in a few minutes. It's fun and enjoyable in the least.

In conclusion, I enjoy all the game. Despite it's not actually historically accurate, but the historical element is there, and I love it. If you read about Sun Tzu's Art of War, it will help you during your gameplay tremendously as this game implements it well.

First, don't get me wrong. I actually like this game, it's fun.

However, this game is very hard once you hit the endgame. So basically, when you have like 15-18 provinces, everyone start declaring war on you. When I said everyone, it is basically EVERYONE, including your allies and your vassals, no matter what you do, they will attack you. They will attack waves by waves and when you are busy defending the front line from enemy troops, there will be some clans that will dispatch their troops on your back with their ships. You are forced to retreat your troops and defend the back. Trying to defend your front line with some troops and left some to defend the back? No you can't, except you're really expert on this game, First wave will be deadly, enemy will attack with their full samurai army and I can guaranteed that you can't hold them with only few troops. Not even mentioning naval battles...

The other part which makes endgame hard as well is your money. You get income by trade income, trading with other clans, building and upgrading things and taxes, and you're spending money in military, basically the more troops you have, the more expensive they will be. And last to mention, samurai (high quality troops) costs twice more the upkeep price than ashigaru (low quality troops). In endgame, you cannot trade with anyone, and you can generate money only from what you have. With lower income, you are forced to have your troops filled with lots of ashigaru to prevent your income from going negative.

Then you have happiness, in this game you need to prevent the happiness from going negative, or the province will rebel. In endgame, when you need to capture like 7-10 provinces more to get victory, maintaining this happiness in newly captured province is really hard. You will usually have -4 happiness already when you capturing enemy province. And if it was belong to some clans (ikko ikki, otomo) you need to deal with religion differences, that will furthermore decreasing your happiness in that province. High taxes also hurt your happiness, so don't try to even set your taxes to high in endgame. Of course this problem can be easily solved by putting troops in that province. But if you have like 7 provinces with negative happiness and you need to garrison those provinces with some troops while you are actually run out of troops in the front line what can you do??? You need to remember that in endgame, everyone will attack you. Placing some troops in your provinces gonna hurt your income so much and it will be a wasteful resources.

The other important thing is that this game have a time limit. You basically need to achieve victory on 1675. Adding more difficulty to the game
========================================
So basically, this game is really fun. But once you hit that endgame, you will be f***ed up. I will not recommend this game if you're not used to play higher difficulty on other strategy games

Total War are world-conquer games in which you have to capture provinces, 
by taking their fortress, and make them part of your Reign.
These are some great strategy games and this is one of the best in the series in my opinion.
It is very entertaining to conquer Japan in the Age of the Samurai.
The Naval Battles are also entertaining, but somewhat useless,
because you can have the greatest fleet, but if you are beaten on land you still lose.
If you played other TW games before it might be hard to adjust yourself to some of the main differences.
One of them would be that there are no shields which is why arrows are more effective
or that walls of fortresses can be climbed.

Even though the main game "Shogun 2" is standing in the shadows of its stand-alone DLC
"Fall of the Samurai", it is many hours of fun and I genuinely enjoyed it.

The MP is as good as dead.

If you enjoyed the original Shogun total war, then it's likely you'll also enjoy Shogun 2. The campaign is an enjoyable and challenging experience that will have you plotting your path to victory in many ways, and enjoy yourself on the way there. The AI in combat is quite smart so be prepared for a challenge. I will sum up the good and bad to help you decide if the game is worth playing or not.

Good: Beautiful music & graphics
           A wide range of different units, allowing a diverse array of strategies in combat.
           End turn wait times are relatively quick compared to other total war games.
           Fully customisable multiplayer mode.
           Multiplayer uses a ranking system allowing you to gain more feats and units as you finish a battle.

Bad: Diplomacy AI is bad/unintelligent
        Load times can be an issue.
        Cavalry movement is unrealistic and doesn't obey the laws of physics. (Able to charge forward at full momentum and              stop dead in their tracks and turn the other way instantly.)
        Multiplayer is ruined by DLC units making it unfair for those who do not wish to purchase extra content.
        Morale system is stupidly broken, allowing you to rout units instantly if piling morale debuffs consecutively.

On the whole the game is great if you enjoy total war campaigns, but it can get repetitive if you play often, and you may find multiplayer enjoyable albeit a little unfair and agrravating at times. Despite this, I had a lot of fun playing multiplayer, making friends along the way. Thanks for the good times.

8/10

My all-time favorite game. Learn the history of the Warring States Period of Japan. Learn how to be a cunning General and command your people to victory! Learn how to balance an economy, military, and social happiness while conquering Japan. Beautiful battles. Beautiful maps. Most importantly...fun.

P.S. The multiplayer for Total War is probably at it's most peak in this installment. Other Total War titles haven't quite captured what Shogun was able to create in terms of multiplayer achievement and replayability.

Certainly among the very strongest of the Total War Franchise, part of which may be ascribed to its scope: a relatively narrow geographic focus, timescale of less than a century, but also great depth of strategy. Anyone looking for the combination of historical strategy and engaging real-time combat need look no further. 

Technical requirements are fairly "mid-range" at this point (2020): my 2012 non-gaming laptop can handle it but runs the risk of overheating, making an external screen a necessity; but likely anything a reasonable amount of memory from 2014 or later can handle this without issue.

I've played every Total War game in the series except Three Kingdoms. I've enjoyed every title for what they are, but hands down this is the best overall game in the entire portfolio. From the aesthetics of the art and map, to the beautiful battles for Japanese fortresses this game is close to flawless in my eyes. I've thoroughly enjoyed the vanilla campaign and Fall of the Samurai, but what really kept my interest is the amount of mods the community has put together this past decade. I've exhausted what seems every possible scenario in the game, but I keep coming back for more showdowns to become Shogun. No other Total War game comes close to Shogun in my opinion. 10/10

Hard to state better what has already been said. Shogun 2 was a remake of what had been my favorite game in the series and my entry point to it. It bore the legacy of its predecessor with perfect grace, and has assumed its position as my new favorite in the series.

It has its share of burs - not every unit has a place, not every clan ended up being that good, diplomacy still feels like an afterthought with plenty of cheese, and so on - but as a whole package, I truly believe Shogun 2 touches the heart of the Total War formula and brings it forward in its best light. This is still, I believe, the perfection of what this series aspires to be. I have enjoyed all of my time with it, and I'm sure I will continue enjoying my time in the future, and I can say with sincerity that you, dear reader, will not be disappointed with your time in it as well. I can only hope this game can touch you as it has touched me and bring you as much joy.

To this date this remains to be the Best Total War game in the series.
Things by which I favor this over others:

* Unit variety (Not too many but also not too few)

* Unit balance (with the concept of basic unit and expensive special units its easy to grasp yet hard to master. And special units are not overpowered versions basic units. Rather they all have a specialized purpose and will lose to basic units if not used correctly). 

* Setting (sengoku jidai setting is perfect to totalwar game.)

* Replayability (with the number of clans and the interesting motivations between each there is much to explore and experiment in the campaign mode. Each AI clan has their own behaviour which makes each major clan feel like an unique opponent)

* Map design (This game allows many tactical maneuvers while most other Total Wargame maps have one to two significant strategic options. Coming up with plans to conquer Kyoto and smash opposition makes you truly feel like aspiring damyo)

I could go on, but these are my main points on why this game is significantly better then any other TW. Now some day we might get something even better with newer graphics, even better AI and combat mechanics but until that day this will remain my absolute recommendation.

This game is insanely addictive and really can give the player a tiered level of difficulty that is best suited to each player. The rock paper scissors rule still rings true between sword, spear, and bow units which provides the general with an additional challenge of how to stack their lines during battle. 

As for the aspects of growth of towns, again kudos. The dichotomy of growth between castles and farmlands forces the player to adhere to a "somewhat" strict building style (as opposed to building an opposing castle as quick as humanly possible) and to really keep in mind what the direct goal of their clan is at that moment in time. 

As a whole, the game immerses you in a world centuries removed. As soon as that opening cutscene begins, I know I'm no longer me: I am a Daimyo, and my people's existence in the future as a viable clan hangs in the balance with every turn that passes. And it is with that feeling that I give the highest praise to the devs. If you can create a game so immersive that it can remove the player from reality...that takes true ability and passion. 

11/10, I have recommended this to friends and will continue to say that this is possibly the best installment of the Total War series to date; not to say that Rome II wasn't brilliant in its own right, but this game really put focus on me as a general, admiral, and statesman in equal measure that I haven't been able to replicate in any other facet.
If Total War games are your idea of fun, then this is a can't miss title.

[h1]Great TW game that gets boring after a while[/h1]
Not the game's fault tho, but the setting itself. Shogun 2 is very polished and I love how everything works. Pretty graphics, efficient performance, interesting politics, and most of all, the economy. I love how the economy is affected by so many things, making it possible to be filthy rich without having many provinces and vice versa. Also, the provinces now have specialties.

[h1]Why it gets boring[/h1]
The boring part happens during combat, and it's the setting's fault. The game has a great battle system, even better than usual, but there's not many unit variants. However that's not the main reason. The way the Japanese fought is boring. The bulk of armies are light infantry (bow and spear). The melee infantry don't use shields, so they die easily to archers. The heavier samurai don't fare much better either. There's no heavy cavalry to charge down archers too. They're all light, and thus also die easily to archers. The main melee weapons used being long spears further limit your ability to play cavalry, and cavalry is the most dynamic unit type, so not playing them removes a huge chunk of your fun.

[h1]Sieges[/h1]
This shared weakness to archers also make sieges pathetically easy for the attacker. Japanese castles don't have thick high walls like the rest of the world. Archers can literally shoot above them, obliterating the shieldless infantry inside, so sieges depend on who has more archers. Also the same with open battles, only the archers need to be protected more. The siege weapons are lame and unnecessary, because you can just storm a castle in one turn without the need to build siege engines to get over walls. This also means you no longer can break sieges with outside force.

[h1]Role play?[/h1]
I'm also not a fan of the role playing aspect of the game. You gain traits by leveling up. In Medieval 2 you gain traits depending on what you do, so you can create a terrifying general by being merciless. In Shogun 2, you need to go down a skill tree, and the intimidation skill is way below. Ironically, more role playing freedom limits role playing instead.
That being said, it's a great game while it's still new and fresh. Worth the price.

But this is actually an older game so we have to live with that, I suppose. Overall, however, typical Total War - well thought through, well balanced, a great product.

I've been playing the Total War series for as long as I can remember. My first was Total War: Shogun, back in the 90's, then Medieval, then Rome, then I took a big break from it, I ended up joining the Army, and getting deployed to Afghanistan back in 2011. I bought a gaming laptop before leaving and bought Total War: Shogun 2 to keep me entertained. My deployment was equal parts chaos and equal part boredom especially when we weren't in "fighting season" and the Taliban went back into Pakistan. There is nothing to do. Go on patrol, come back, lift weights, go for a run, train,  shower, eat chow, and then nothing. This game kept me occupied. I had logged many hours on it during our down times. I had watched so many movies over there, and the only thing keeping me sane was Shogun 2. It was great to see how far the series had come. So, I am a fan of the Total war series.

Sadly, my gaming laptop had busted during transport from deployment to home. I forgot about the game and years later noticed they had it for my school/work laptop (Mac) and I have to say, not what I expected. Keep in mind, it is a Mac, and they really aren't known for their gaming. So it's difficult to develop games for them (unless it's a mobile game). I didn't buy the mac for gaming, it was for developing, school, and work. It's more of a productivity computer than an entertainment computer. So, if you have a gaming PC and are into strategy, get this game. If you have a Mac, do what I did, keep the Mac for work/school/developing, etc. but do not use it for gaming, save up for a desktop gaming pc and keep the entertainment there. 

I have bought a gaming PC and I'm excited to get into the Total wars again. Especially no that there are more like Warhammer, and China. I've been waiting for China for ever. But that's my review and suggestions. Great game, just don't buy it for Mac like I did, get a gaming PC, your experience will be much better.

You need a million fixes to get this working these days, and I can barely get it fully functional at all. I had to; Use a screen resolution fix program, a mouse cursor lock program, had to go into the scripts and turn off screen resizing ( if you don't it becomes misaligned on windowed fullscreen). I then found out the ui scale is too large and is cut off on the bottom of the screen and there is no way of resizing it on a 2550 x 1440p monitor, so I don't understand why they have a windowed fullscreen mode if it doesn't work.
Honestly this is a disgrace for a game in 2019, I understand its an older game but I shouldn't have to work this hard for a game on a professional store front. If you aren't prepared to support the game so it at least works on modern hardware, take it off the store front. They are happy to take your money though, of course they are lol. Look at all the bullshit DLC you need for the game too. The fact that they still have the audacity to sell you "blood effects" for £2.50 is absolutely shameful and they still do it in newer titles too. 

If you report these problems on CA forums you are met with bullshit "we know" responses but never any fixes years later. There is nothing worse than patronising non answers, they obviously think customers are brain dead and beyond stupid. There's nothing more insulting. 
If you really want to try this game make sure you either play it on a 1080p monitor, or play it on fullscreen mode on a higher resolution. Playing on windowed fullscreen you will need to do a million fixes, and its not worth the trouble in my opinion, and it's all for nothing if you own any screen higher than 1080p. The UI doesn't scale well and it will have to look like total dog shit, so you can see all the ui elements.
 If you want to pick this up, for the love of god buy it on a 75% off summer sale or something, I can't stress that enough. It's titles like this make me regret supporting games altogether, the shear contempt they have for their own customers is a fucking joke. Just fix the game so I can play it properly and have positive things to say about it.

The turn based mixed with the real time strategy elements is as always perfectly balanced. You get to manage over your realm in turns, while fighting in real time. The fighting part is divided into battles on land and sea, and of course the sieges. The management part is fairly difficult, as you have to balance your economy to your evergrowing military might. You don't have as much variety in the troops as you're used to, but every unit has its value and both significant strenghts and weaknesses, so you have to balance your army as well. There also are 4 different types of agents that can either boost your army and settlements or weaken your enemy. Different factions with different bonuses.
Also includes 3 different religions.
In my opinion the best total war game to date, even though it has a few minor problems.
Definite must-buy

I'll be honest, having been introduced to Total War with Rome I, and then faithfully following the series as it got more ambitious and epic with every iteration, culminating with the release of Empire: Total War, Darthmod, and the possibility of worldwide domination, going back to this comparatively microscopic campaign in feudal Japan felt like a massive step backwards. I [b] hated [/b] this game when it was released, but still bought it out of loyalty to Creative Assembly. For the first weeks, and even months, I could only play this game sporadically, I was constantly frustrated by the small campaign map, the lack of unit diversity (this game has been rightfully called 'Total War: Yari Ashigaru', or 'Yari Ashigaru Simulator'), the over-reliance rock-paper-scissors style gameplay, the massive limitations to building slots, castle upgrading, unit upgrading.

Well, it's been almost a full decade since release, and I've had about a thousand hours with it (and I'm not a massive gamer - that really is a lot for me). If you can't tell, I've become a huge fan of this game, it's delicately balanced and rewarding game design won me over. Before Shogun 2, playing Total War for me was all about the power fantasy, massing huge armies and crushing the AI, but after the release of this game, I really started to see it as a [i] proper game [/i]. I love to fail in Shogun 2. In terms of balance, pacing, challenge, AI performance and overall polish, it's my go-to in the Total War series, especially on the harder dificulty settings. Whenever I play other Total War games, or even other strategy games, I just keep coming back to this oldie. I can't help it, it's a masterpiece. I play it once every week, at the least. I can't seem to stay away from it for long. Mind you, I've not played the Warhammer or Three Kingdoms games, mostly because I don't enjoy the fantasy / mythology setting as much in Total War.

Shogun 2 indeed lacks the epic feel that the Grand Campaigns of Napoleon, Rome I & II, Medieval II and Empire had (and I suppose WH and 3K too), but more than makes up for it with the tightest campaign mechanics out there, by far - the AI is more effective because of the streamlined campaign choices, they're agressive, decisive and fast - every battle matters, every unit you can recruit, rank up and preserve, every building slot you can get access to, every agent you get and rank up, every high ranking general is crucial. More often than not, on the harder difficulty settings, one single turn wasted can be the difference between winning or losing a key battle, and also the campaign. Losing your only experienced army with that 4-star general is often a death sentence in hard, or very hard, difficulty, but you can still roleplay with your doomed clan, defend you castles to the last man against the vast experienced enemy stacks, raid their lands, make them pay as you go down. Brutal - love it. Play this game.

Total War: Shogun 2 is my favorite Total War game that I own, and it is also one of my favorite games in general. like most Total War games, Shogun 2 involves planning and strategy, and knowing what gives you the advantage in battle. for land battles, Shogun 2 offers a ton of maps. some of the maps are not too diverse, but they are still fun to play. The siege maps each have their own unique advantage or disadvantage, and their designs are beautiful. The developers put so much detail in each soldier, and the combat animations are really enjoyable to watch. Shogun 2 is a game that you should definitely buy, especially if you are a fan of the Total War series, and even if you just enjoy this era of Japanese history.

1 - Basic Game:

One of the best video games ever made! In the Top 10.

The single player campaign is the remake of Shogun1, but brings unquestionable and significant graphical-strategical improvements.
Compared to the previous Total War has been perfected in the diplomacy and in the relationship with other factions, in the management of agents and of your family members, as well as for the technological evolution of clans.
It fits very well in a medieval Japan ambientation and the strategy, although in my opinion less diversified than Rome (between one faction and another), is very well done and realistic.

The real strength of this total war chapter was the multiplayer, well conceived, with direct battles or 2 players campaign option and thanks to the possibility of creating a game avatar and the presence of multiplayer clans to figth with.
[b][u]After 7 years, however, the comunity is at its minimum and affected by the presence of cheaters in too many games. Plus, recently, servers were down and the avatar conquest section is dead such as the coop campaign.[/u][/b]

Some nostalgic from Shogun 1 like me, will regret the paper map of Japan on a table inside the "command room" and the pawns of the armies. Sometimes the simple things are the most beautiful!

2 - Fall of the Samurai expansion:

Renews the game in strategy and diplomacy. It changes historical epoch and revises the conflict in a more modern way.
Firearms, railways, trade with western countries and give a touch from "The Last Samurai".
This expansion want to divide the original campaign and the two historical periods taking better care of the environment and ambientation compared on what was for Shogun1 and so makes it more realistic.
The only expansion-DLC that is worth to be bougth! This version of Shogun 2 is the one I prefered in the multiplayer section.

You will be into the civil war between Shogunate and the Emperor factions. You will have to choose which way to stay with and whether to prefer the old way following the shogunate or if you will follow the emperor; alternatively you can iven try to declare your independence.
The presence of firearms obviously brings a very similar strategy to what we saw in Empires, but more dynamic and engaging thanks to the combination of range and melee units, managing to give a fair balance.
Strategy and landscape will have a great importance.

For the land battles there was the possibility in the multiplayer to play the two mixed versions and being able to compare the armies and the strategies of the two historical periods. It is not said that the armies with firearms will be the ones that will win.

Rating: 8.5 / 10 (with multiplayer was a 9.5/10)
Some annoying multiplayer bugs. Too many cheaters in multiplayer mode.
To much DLC's clan pack. Servers were down for long time and so not aviable for the multiplayer.
Under the sales yuo will find the basic game plus the dlc fots at 15 euro. In my opinion to much with out the multiplayer.

So coming back after posting my initial review which was about 50 hours game time, and now I've got a couple notches on my belt and a lot new releases of total war, I can say without a doubt this game is probably one of the best I've ever had the chance to play. 
    Total War Shogun 2 is an outstanding game that doesn't clobber you with the min maxing of the towns as the other games do, it's simple precise and forgiving if you mess up. Research isn't a real big hassle at all, it's also simple two trees, one is for fighting and the other is for civil upgrades and agent abilities, basically building passives and money. The game play is what you would expect in a total war game not going to go too much into it, but the units themselves are excellent. The variety isn't as intense as the other games though like Warhammer, but it gives you enough to play around with, including the special clan units and especially when you play Fall of the Samurai. Boat combat is technically simple, either burn the ships, board the ships, or kill all the people, it gets more fun in Fall though as you get cannon ships and torpedo ships.Trading is really a small trade boost, but grading the rare ports are usually a MUST for the money they rake in. Including Mods they usually make the game way more fun, as do mods do. Some mods may fix niches and make the game more challenging as the game itself can be a little easy. 
    Overall coming back to this game made me reevaluate how well this game was. It had great content and great game play and still can hold up when compared to some of the newer total wars. It's a game that I can play endlessly time and time again as I had done so without the feeling of boredom or unfairness as other games. 
    (12/10) A timeless masterpiece

I've played many hours of this game and it's one of my favourite in the Total War series. 

Parts I enjoy - Unlike some games, I have a chance to win seemingly hopeless battles by using superior tactics and terrain, diplomacy is relatively streamlined - no need for annoying messenger units, and the other game systems work well and are balanced (economy, espionage, research, etc.). 

Parts I didn't enjoy - The naval combat felt more like a chore, but that may be more my preference. Siege battles were a joke - the AI is so bad. I once had a massive AI army destroy itself on one of my barely defended towns as their leader and heir dismounted and attempted to scale my walls. They both died and the other units scattered easily to be cut down by a couple of light cavalry. It was a massacre. I feel like I'm cheating whenever I play out siege battles and I usually try to fight outside, or I autoresolve. 

Overall 8/10, I re-install it every few months and I always have fun playing it.

SHAMEFUL DISPLAY!

A great game has a great beginning, it starts you off in a beautiful cinematic of two samurai dueling, then after a betrayal an all out war starts, giving you a taste of the warfare to come.
It's your typical Total War game, you pick a faction, build up your army and cities and survive for as long as possible or conquer everything, battles are intense too as you have people climbing castles, falling off, firing hundreds of volleys of arrows or bullets at each other and burning castles, it's classic TW fun.
The only real issue here is that the AI can be dumb at times, going through all sorts of complicated loops in order to exit a gate 50 feet in front of them.

A huge positive to this game is the amount of DLC you get, Rise of the Samurai and Fall are both amazing additions to the game that add their own unique stories and contributions to historical battles, Rise takes place centuries before the main game, you pick from three major clans as well as keeping your vassals loyal, and you battle it out until the new leader is decided.
Fall of the Samurai is different, taking place during the Boshin war, you can either play as a pro Shogun faction or be an Imperialist, it also gets deeper if you choose to accept aid from western countries, similar to the base game, you can recruit veterans, get guns, even get assistance from them in the way of naval help or money if you allow them to set up shop.

The final point will be historical battles, they are very well done with good cinematics to set up the theme, you play as either the historical winner or try to rewrite it through a surprise victory, such as the Ikko-Ikki surviving the castle siege that eventually destroyed their numbers, or try to rewrite the final battle of the Sengoku era and defeat Tokugawa on the battlefield.

My final rating is 9/10, dealing with some annoying bugs, this is a very beautiful game that was well made, besides the meme value from your war adviser constantly yelling at you the combat is thrilling and the geopolitics are fun to move around.

I would point out the few nitpicks that most people (justifiably) dislike, like agent gameplay or Realm Divide, but if you know about them you can easily pay a quick visit onto the Steam Workshop and get any number of well-made mods that either fix these issues or add hundreds of hours worth of content.
My only recommendation would be to avoid the Rise of the Samurai DLC. It's not that its low-quality,it's just really boring.

This is a nation building game with a changing level of focus. Like the rest of the Total War franchise, during times of war armies are controlled on a per unit basis in real time to great effect. The gameplay is excellently executed and is arguably one of the best in the series. The GUI design in terms of the art style and general feel is better than the others. The politics of the game forces a national level war on you when you get too powerful which sees the final step of a gradually increasing threat level as factions are slowly eliminated in the bid for power. Pretending to be an angry Japanese man also has its appeal.

Shogun 2 is definitely up there with the best of the Total War games. In terms of gameplay it feels a lot like the first Rome, which is still the gold standard for Total War games - But where normally Creative Assemblys games are broken on release and then get fixed afterwards, like Empire, in this case Shogun 2 worked fine on release, but since then they've continued to add stuff that makes the game crash for no good reason.

In my case I can't change my options or quit the game without a fatal error, and it seems like a lot of people are having similar problems.

That's really not acceptable for any game, let alone a major commercial release, so I'd recommend playing something with better support and better stability.

This is the Total War game that finally got me into the series. I still have a soft spot for it, even after witnessing the glory of Total War: Warhammer 2. In comparison it feels naturally clunkier, being an 8-year old game by now, and it lacks the variety and strategic options later games have. But even to this day, if a friend wants me to play this in co-op, i'll gladly take them up on the offer.

You have 12 factions to play with. Out of the 12, 3 are DLC and thus need an extra investment to gain access to. They don't differ from what they offer in terms of troops or such pretty much at all. The primary difference between them is obviously the starting location, and then what unit types they specialize in or what domestic thing they're good at. Then they have access to unique versions of their favored unit type, like Shimazu, being a Katana-specialized faction, has access to Shimazu Katana Samurai, that are stronger all-around compared to regular Katana Samurai. Later DLC's added 1-2 actual unique units to the factions, but I fail to recall if these were paid DLC's or whether they're accessible in the base game.

Campaign gameplay is instantly familiar to Total War veterans. It takes place in feudal Japan, where gunpowder is only just being introduced to the island. There's roughly 65 territories to conquer, with about 50-60 factions in total. The primary goal is to capture Kyoto at the middle of the map and hold it for a year to become a Shogun, then capture however many provinces your chosen campaign requires, ranging from half to pretty much the entire Japan. You got your generals with simple skill tree's to lead the troops, though in this game new generals are either born into your family or recruited via random events. You cannot just up and hire them from an infinitely regenerated list of faceless dudes like in say TW: Warhammer. Also as a sidenote, for anyone coming from newer games to this, you can move armies around without a general leading them, though you should not try to fight battles without a general leading the army (although if you win, this may prompt a random event to hire yourself a new general, supposedly the de-facto leader of that battle getting promoted for his martial and strategic prowess which is a nice touch).

Battles are the same as they are in other historical TW's. Every army stack can hold 20 units, and you can have other stacks reinforce each other for even more units in the field, as has been in every other game. There's not really much I can think of to say here, tbh. Its Total War, its real time strategy battles with your basic Sword and Spear infantry, Archers and either Sword or Spear cavalry, with their own rock-paper-scissor relationship to each other. Additional unit types include the siege weapons which work like before, just bombarding people with hurty things, gunpowder units that turn any other units to mince meat ESPECIALLY if they are defending a city from a wall, but get squished to fine paste if they get forced into melee by almost anything else in the game, and then there's Ninja units that throw very nasty bombs for massive damage (NOTE: The bombs, if thrown while defending from a wall, will deal damage to the wall as well and end up blowing the entire section of the wall up. Its funny at first but then you realize you just lost a mass of units to this and then it stops being funny).

If you shell out extra dough, you'll get access to two additional campaigns, Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. Rise is Shogun 2 but with more peasants and less Samurai on the field (havent played this much tbh), and Fall is much more gunpowder and much less Samurai on the field. In my experience Fall of the Samurai was fine to play through once, but it felt like the AI did not know what the heck to do with or against the gunpowder units which is bit of an issue when 75% of the game is now fought with gunpowder units.

I love the game but will absolutely agree it has issues. Shogun 2 has Naval combat in it as well now, which was touted as a key new feature that everyone should love. In actuality, in my own personal opinion, i've found the maintenance and dealing with the Navy to be an absolute pain in the ass and a definite stain in an otherwise great strategy title. The AI is absolutely relentless in harassing your ports and smol navies with it's own impossibly large fleets, and when an AI comes over to blockade your port, SURPRISE ALL OF YOUR INCOME IS NOW GONE! Yes, majority of your income will most of the time end up being via trade routes by the sea, and AI will not only know where the most valuable trade port is, it will ABSOLUTELY sneak in a single ship to blockade it at the worst of times to make sure you go bankrupt. I hate the navy gameplay in this, and do not miss it's absence in Warhammer 2 in any way.

Another big thing that i've slowly grown to be irked by is the end-game. When you either conquer Kyoto or get enough infamy in the world, an event will trigger called Realm Divide. Dread that name, because the moment Realm Divide happens, every single existing faction in the game (even your co-op ally, which is slightly amusing) gets a modifier that makes them get more and more unfriendly towards you every turn, until everyone is unified against you in war. At this point all of the diplomacy is thrown out the window, because nobody will ever make peace with you anymore, no matter how trusted allies you used to be throughout the entire game (except the co-op ally since you cannot break alliance with them). This sucks, because it greatly diminishes the importance of diplomacy throughout the entire campaign. You end up only kinda forming temporary truces with people just to buy yourself enough time to backstab them before they end up backstabbing you. I love to form alliances with factions and go through absolute hell with them side-by-side to finally grab that hard-earned victory at the end of the campaign, but that is just not a thing you can do in this game.

In conclusion, and as a TL;DR: 8/10, I can recommend checking it out if you are a Total War lover. Its still a nice game that I enjoy playing now and then even to this day. Hate the navy and dislike the diplomacy, lament the lack of variety and options later games have, but do enjoy everything else about it. It has that charm to it, as well as many fond memories.

I completed 3 campaigns in shogun 2 and I am still very frustrated with this game.
I played Rome 1, Medieval 2, Empire, Napoleon, Rome 2, with no problems but this is a big dissapointment.

Your economy is really really limited, even at a relatively late stage of the game >15 provinces you can barely afford 2 full armies, the development of the cities is very slow, rising an army is also slower than in previous games.

The technology tree takes a lot of time to complete and is not particularly useful.

Your limited ability to recruit armies combined with the big size of the map makes really difficult to decide wars, you can lose 2 or 3 provinces in a row in one side of the map because you dont have enough troops to defend them and simultaneously conquer 2 or 3 provinces in a row in the other side of the map because your enemy has the same problem too.

I have the impression that the terrain is strange too, in previous game most of the battles were in open terrain, now looks like every battle has a lot of hills and trees in the middle of the field.

Let's remember that the point of this saga was to have epic battles, however all the limitations above basically stopped this.

I just played my first play through of Shogun 2 where I conquered all of Japan and it was really fun. I admit that when Empire first released in its buggy state, I uninstalled it, threw it away and ignored Napoleon and Shogun 2 when they were released. Years later I bought Shogun 2 when it was 75% discounted, but couldn't motivate myself to play it since medieval Japan didn't interest me and I was used to playing Medieval 2 Total War and RTW2. 
I had just finished a play through of Attila which I found disappointed and uninstalled it, when I then decided to install this game and give it a try.  
It's a very well made game and it even made me wonder what happened with Rome Total War 2 since this game seemed to have so much more to it. There are little cinematics for all kinds of things. When a unit type is created for the first time, a cinematic shows them and explains what they do, when you assassinate targets using ninjas, there are more cinematics for them.
The battles are actually pretty and I like seeing the battlemap, whereas in the other games I had started to view manual battles as a chore and would usually auto resolve them. 
What else can I say....
I had heard Realm Divide and was under the impression that ALL factions would declare war on you once you hit realm divide, but it wasn't true and two factions, the Shoni and Chokosabe stayed allied to me the entire game, even after having -200 reputation with them from realm divide. This is likely because my faction (Shimazu) and they were Christian while we were at war with three Buddhist factions.
The only glitch I saw at times were the cannon ships that would at times attempt to go towards an enemy ship instead of just firing at them. 
I'm certainly going to have other play throughs as other factions and will try Fall of the Samurai soon enough, but after playing this, I understand why it's one of the or even the highest rated Total War games out there.

(English is not my native language so there may be some mistakes and misspellings).This is by far one of the best CA's games, im fascinated with japanese culture and traditions, sengoku era is my most beloved one due to the heroic times where samurai would pay with their own life just to save their honour. This game gives you this feeling of power, when you lead your army of samurai men to battle you feel like each and every one of them ready to give their life for you. Battles are really atmospheric, its almost like youre there commanding your men on the frontline, i would definitely recommend this piece of art to everyone who has some interest in medieval strategy games. Yet there are some buggs and things that are really annoying, for example when you shoot your cannon and it hits that tiny-itty-bitty tree, that could be torn appart with a single stroke of a sword, but this piece of wood easily stops your cannonball, another thing to mention is how stupid AI sometimes act, seriously, even on Legendary difficulty they blindly go at you, no strategy, just straightforward all-out fight. And the most annoying is unit controlling, when they choose the fastest but the most dangerous way, i had a fight in a city and my katana unit decided not to go around the house as i told them to, but to walk through the cavalry unit that was around the corner of the said house, those moments are the most annoying. But enough for bad things, the game is really good, it feels satisfying to play it even with these dumb buggs and undeveloped AI. TWS2 is not just good, its a great piece of art that still needs improvement, thankfully there are mods that make your gameplay experience better, but its not enough, unfortunately, we need an official bugg fixing patch, and with all that said, im gonna end it here. Would rate it 8/10.

Wonderful game, I genuinely enjoy it.

The gui is one of the best of the series. It's clean, and simple. No flashy graphics, but it still remains beautiful.

The music is very aesthetically pleasing. I often find myself humming along to Cherry Blossom.

The action is the best in the series. It is clean and simple, but with room for advanced maneuvers and tactics (such as positioning matchlock soldiers in rows on hills to increase the amount of lead being fired down field.) The horses tend to be a bit... weird for me. They'll go do whatever the hell they want, regardless of order or stance.

The naval battles: Still wack. It's better than Empire and Rome 2, but still really shit. The AI rarely ever misses a volley on my ships (in FotS). The AI ships also rarely retreat. Meanwhile, the moment one of my crew trips over a bucket, I'm down to just a gunboat even if I outnumber the enemy.

The campaign map is fairly solid. It's gorgeous, and the layout of the roads and towns leads to some great ambush potential.

My only gripe is the AI. It goes from really stupid to Big Brain Time randomly. The harder difficulties only increase in difficulty by literally boosting the damage, economy, and attributes of the enemy which is pretty cheap. It's fine if you can overlook that aspect, but it feels like if I lose, it's far beyond my control so what's really the point? One false move and you can lose in two turns within a year.
Also, I hate navy battles.

I've followed the total war games, since beta, I enjoy them very much. So much so, I want more in depth layers of strategy. I'm still  trying to figure out how the infantry knows to run out from under the naval bombardment.. Please fix that. Please give us more control of the Generals lives..Give us personal development, make it so I can feel like I'm the General, that when I, as the General make an informed choice, I also have a list of possible outcomes, so I don't find my General with drug problem after employing a random mission doctor ect.. Give me more control of the terrain selection for battles.. Let me pick my Ambush location..let me select where I build the small strongholds.  Let me promote my other Generals from the ranks, so I make my Generals, loyalty based on service and time,.. bigger maps, these things add depth to a wonderful game, but these changes would also lend a level of depth that would bring players back over and over again.. Smart people what smart games..but most of all they want the fantasy of being that General, and being able to change history because of their own strategy. That will always bring them back.

So, great game; had a lot of fun, but I'm giving a no to recommending due to a few things I found really annoying and silly.

Naval fights and everything about them, pretty much anything to do with ships is awful. The AI spamming 100, one ship navies around the map to raid your trade and blockade ports 50 times each turn is just stupid. As if I am going to spend 30 mins going after all these one ship navies so that they can simply retreat and do it all over again next turn, they will also retreat into deep sea forcing you to go there as well to finish them. Ship battles are extremely boring and tedious and clunky, you will want to auto-resolve most of them, however; the calculations for the outcome of auto-resolving ship battles are stupid. You will always lose ships/have heavy losses to ships even when you have an EXTREME advantage, you then need to send your navy all the way home to replenish it, no auto-replenish for navies.
 
In Rise of the Samurai, the prices for the abilities of agents is absolutely ludicrous. I beat Shogun 2 and RotS on Legendary, not once will you be using agents abilities, they are far too stupidly expensive.

The last big problem I noticed in RotS is needing agents to sit in all the cities you take to convert their allegiance, also tedious, annoying, time consuming and stupid. Without an agent in a freshly taken city you will need an ENTIRE army to stay garrisoned in said city for SEVERAL turns to keep control of the city.

Anyway, other than that; I still enjoyed the game a lot. These things I've explained are just bad enough to ruin the whole experience.

For the uninitiated, Total War is a series of hybrid strategy games where you control a faction in some part of the world and end up going to war with most, if not all, of your neighbors as you vie for power. This is done by building stuff in your cities, and moving armies around the strategic map - you fight other armies in the real-time battle mode.

Shogun 2 is one of the best Total War games overall. I'm not even sure what else I can say about it that hasn't been said a million times - the setting is realized almost perfectly, it looks absolutely great, the music is ear porn, multiplayer is the most involved in the series by far, the campaign map is a marvel of balance (remarkable because it's literally just Japan's mountain passes making the AI maneuver its armies decently), and there's a ton of replay value.

Well, okay, most Total War games have some sort of replay value. Shogun 2 stands out from them by having a believable method of total map domination, because you're not conquering entire continents like in other TW games: you're conquering most of Japan, which was a thing that Tokugawa Ieyasu actually historically did.

There's an achievement for reaching the #1 multiplayer ranking, and multiplayer isn't exactly a spring chicken after all these years, so if you're an achievement-oriented person you should give that a think. Other than that, if your computer's got the chops, and if you're a fan of strategy games, I'd recommend this to you.
8 Years later, still playing it consistently over the other newer titles. It's THAT good.

This is one of if not the best game in the Total War franchise. With a nice balance between range and melee, to the outstanding maps and campaign. This is the first total war (and maybe the last) to truly get rid of the mob fighting system, you can follow one soldier around the whole battle as he kicks, stabs, blocks, and dodges swords. It makes your good units feel, well, a lot better than the rest. It has some cartoonish graphics that sometimes pulls away from the game. It has a unique campaign system based upon 2 idealogies, the American traders, and the traditional Shogun. You can chose your allegiance which creates 2 different unit types and skill-trees. You can literally block out the sun with arrows, literally. My 2nd favorite Total War game, worth it at any price on the store right now. Hands down must have.

One of the best Total War games out there and a favourite of mine together with Medieval 2 Total War

+ interesting era to play in

+ good variety between clans

+ much more in depth since it covers only 1 country (unlike for example Medieval 2 Total War where it covers whole Europe and parts of Africa, Asia and America)

+ great DLCs

+ agents are fun, work like rock paper scissors for each other.

+ "talent" trees are actually fun and impactful

+ Avatar conquest was very good multiplayer mode

+ very strategical map - you have many options to block roads, ambush your enemies, raid their properties, sabotage their armies and much much more

+ smaller map actually benefits the game - if you know the terrain you can outplay your opponent with ease

+ ingame encyklopedia is very detailed and very useful

+ diplomacy in this game actually makes sense most of the time

+ Realm divide provides challenge in late game

+ introduction of guns makes a difference

+ can be very challenging 

+ memes

- some clans are a lot better than others

- I dont like that enemy units can climb walls by themselves, making gates kind of obsolete

Let me start by saying that I love the Total War series. I also love Japanese culture and history. This unoptimized trash doesn't do either justice. In fact, Total War: Shogun 2 is literally the worst game in the entire franchise. Hard to believe? Let me convince you.

1) Shogun 2 is completely unoptimized. It struggles on 4K displays, stutters when "too many" units are on the screen at the same time, etc. Also, its lighting effects are uglier than Total War: Napoleon's, which came out beforehand.

2) The game suffers from horrendous AI and an incredible number of bugs. Bugs have always been a problem for the series, but they seem to be at their worst here.

3) It's unbalanced. Certain units are WAY too overpowered in this game. A single set of light cavalry, for instance, was able to stand an entire battle against my general, mounted katana cavalry, and two yari ashigaru units. Are you kidding me? In a game like Total War: Napoleon, you can turn the tide of a battle with good tactics, even if you're vastly outnumbered. Here, the game is more dependent on unit types and dice rolls. Give me a break.

4) More on the unbalancing issue - certain clans are doomed for failure. As the Mori clan, I had five clans declare war on me for no reason. Trying to give gifts or forge alliances was impossible, as was ending the wars. As the Shimazu clan, however, I steamrolled over the entire island. This is terrible game design.

5) The music is lacklustre. Honestly, the music has hit an all-time low for the entire series.

6) The game lacks the wealth of content compared to previous entries in the series. Seriously, one or two campaigns are enough to experience everything in the game.

7) Overpriced garbage DLC. Seriously, you're going to make me pay for blood and a handful of unit types? Your greed knows no bounds, Creative Assembly.

Don't buy this junk. Stick to pretty much any other Total War game.

No matter how fun this game is there is no denying that this is an obtuse, bloated mess of a product.

Loading times.
From its launch years ago I have gone through maybe six or seven computers and in that time not a single one of them have ever left me satisfied at this game horrendous load times, from starting the game which can take upwards to five minutes to loading save files which can seemingly take ages.

Overworld.
Much of the game is rigid to the point of tiresome and allows seemingly no flexibility in development with the only viable meta being developing farms and moneymaking buildings then slogging forward and claiming new territories  and repeating ad-infinitum so you'll waste nearly half the game building infrastructure and not even playing the parts the game was designed around.

Combat.
The combat is clunky and unwieldy with the computer A.I able to move perfectly and micromanage in such a way that makes it frustrating to fight against made even more so when commanding units becomes a finicky and tedious leaving the only viable option as bum rushing with cheap expendable units.

Redundant and useless units.
Artillery units are bordering on useless in near on 90% of the matches and are completely useless until leveled sufficiently making them an expensive waste of resources.

Gun units unless you are Otomo take 4 turns to produce, can't shoot over units and only have two-thirds the range of archers,  and are only really useful defending which can just be filled by cheaper more useful units, add into the fact that half the time the gunners will seemingly ignore charging enemies because of an invisible dip or bump in the land making any effective use of the gun pointless.

Late game units are also almost pointless to own or use as by the time you have them you either don't need them as you've claimed half or more of the map or you've lost so hard and are against such overwhelming odds that a couple overpriced late game units just get swamped by cheap cannon fodder, this can also be doubly true for cavalry as the cheapest starting unit can counter and swarm something that cost upwards of five time the price and 3-4 turns to make.

Computer opponents.
The A.I cheats and is often not subtle about it, in my time playing this game I've came across several glaring occasions when it is particularly noteworthy.
-Five turns into a game and the computer having a stack of twelve units, the lowest experience of them being level 4 and some being level 6.
-An opponent with only a single territory who after declaring war manages to build an army of 14 stacks from being only two units the previous turn.
the Auto-resolve battle function somehow deciding that my army consisting of two generals, four Yari samurai, six Shimazu Katana samurai with superior weapons and armour and four bow ashigaru would suffer a crippling defeat against a single Yari ashigaru and bow ashigaru, to put into perspective when I auto-resolved I lost nearly half my forces and my Daimyo but when I commanded myself I lost less then five soldiers.
This game really makes you feel like you’re Japan 10/10
