I bought the game for 24.99 and I think it was an okay game, the graphics were good and such, but there was one problem.. It costs way too much for a total war game, I mean 25 pounds? In my opinion the game is worth 14.99. But not including that, the game was good.

It's one of those games you boot up at 10am in the morning wanting to unify Japan and have a fantastic gaming session meticulously planning out your turns managing taxes, scouting enemy territory, sending out assassination orders, converting the religion of your enemies, raising armies/navies, boosting economic growth, and  maintaining diplomatic relations. 

Once your plan is in motion you execute it by moving your forces to conquer territory with the option of commanding up to thousands of units at a time on the battlefield, putting them in formation and carrying out your battle plans such as weak centre into envelopment or hammer and anvil. Guys with long pointy sticks beat guys on horses who beat the ones that shoot arrows. Oh and there are dudes who have guns.

Each turn will take careful planning and you must think about the possible repercussions of your moves such as being ambushed while moving an army through a forest, being attacked on an undefended section of your territory, uprising from disgruntled citizens within your provinces, allies turning to enemies or the loss of a key province with all your important buildings. There's a lot of think about each turn which makes each gaming session so rewarding when your plans fall into motion and become successful. 

Just when you're about to switch off you tell yourself maybe you'll play one more turn... the turn happens and you convince yourself you'll play another after that. Next thing you know it's 2pm the next day but you're ever so much closer to conquering all of Japan for yourself.
Extremely fun. Felt good dominating all of Japan.

A great strategy game that is a mix of turn-based and RTS gameplay, with more emphasis on the later.

The "Overworld" shows the full world map and is turn-based. Manage cities, tax rates, citizen happiness, army recruitment, research, etc. This is also where general army movement is done, combining and moving units from one general area to another. When your forces enter the area of an enemy or vice versa, you get taken to a battle map and the RTS parts of the game kick in. (You can also auto-resolve battles if you don't want to). The turn-based actions are very streamlined compared to, say, Civilization, as all of these mechanics are less complicated across the board. There are only two campaign scenarios available in this version, the base game and Rise of the Samurai. While you can play as different clans, the object of each scenario is always the same. In the base game you control one of several factions, trying to gain control of your local region and Kyoto. Rise of the Samurai is different, has more focus on diplomacy, and I don't really know what I'm doing there.

Total War (as a series) has, in my mind, the best RTS mechanics availalbe. There are no reasources to manage as you do all of that on the overworld. There are no build orders or unit recruitment, because again, you do that on the overworld. All the focus is on the units and how they are positioned. Futhermore (and this is most important to me) you can actually set up proper battle lines for your army instead of having a sloppy clump of space marines or a single file line of zerglings when you order a unit to go someplace. These factors combine to create an RTS that is actually intuitively combat focused instead of grindy attrition where placing a building 10 seconds late could doom you entirely. Unfortunately, the campaign's battle maps are largely the same: spare scatterings of trees and hills for field battles, or a simple single wall fort. There are ways to upgrade fort walls, but most likely you aren't going to be fighting many battles there. The units, however, are quite diverse. Besides simple bow, spear, and calvary units, there are also a wide variety of specialty units including siege weapons, bow calvary, fire arrows, bomb throwers, ninjas, No-Dachi infantry (which is VERY good at charging downhill but is terrible at defending), all at different technology levels and training. 

There are also Historical Battles, which do not have a campaign map but instead focus on amazing RTS scenarios. They feature a lot larger units, incredibly more detailed battle maps, and more varried objectives. If the RTS battles in the campaign mode were this good I probably wouldn't play anything else for the next month. 

While I can't compare this to previous Total War games, I have heard that the AI is smarter in this version. I personally haven't had any problems. 

NOTE: FALL OF THE SAMURAI IS NOT INCLUDED. IT HAS ITS OWN STEAM PAGE AND NEEDS TO BE PURCHACED SEPARATELY, EVEN IF YOU BOUGHT THE BUNDLE. Historical Battles for Fall of the Samurai are included in the bundle if you want a taste of what that game is like, though, and they're just as high quality as the other Historical Battles. 

I got this game on sale for $15, but I honestly feel like this game is worth more like $40-50.

For those who are new to Total War games:

-there's a feel of historical accuracy. No other game series I've tried comes even close to anything like that experience. If you like stories, you'll easily get immersed into these games.
-the generals you have - particularly in Shogun 2 - are like the heroes you have in some other games in that you increase their abilities bit by bit. This adds to the playability.
-the battles are in 3D with fully alterable viewpoint. This means you don't easily get the afterimage in your dreams, no matter how much you play. Some cards tend to stick, though: I can recall Shimazu Takahisa's portrait very easily, for instance - but this is nothing like the afterimages you get in games with repeating views. This means you can play as much as I have and not go crazy (much).
-there are actual strategic possibilities, and the game is interesting enough even if you play it at a level that gives you some edge over the AI.
-the game has not been dumbed down anywhere that I see. This is rare indeed.
-the idea that the game deals with one era only certifies that there can be no such problems as the CIV series has - there you might battle helicopters with catapults, which makes me sprain my jaw.
-turn based strategy with real time battles is definitely the way to go, and TW games have that. No unnecessary stress.

(Here there was a bit where I compare Total War Napoleon with Shogun 2. I think Shogun 2 is simply better. Smoother gameplay, somehow. More believable for some reason. Also better than Empire, or Medieval 2. What's keeping Medieval 3? I hope they'll make it soon!)

What else? Battles are entertaining, the character development system is good, overall a very good game with a lot of strategic possibilities.

The idea of mods is a good one, but most of them (the way I read the descriptions) just change the rules. What's the point of that? The rules are good now. If a professional studio with quite a few good games to their credit has cooked them up, what would make me believe I can come up with better ones?

Just bought Fall of the Samurai, by the way. Seems pretty good: there's even better feel of historical accuracy than in Shogun 2 main game.

All in all, I would give this game points according to the Shimazu loyalty scale: 9 out of 6.

To me, this is the best installment of the franchise to this day. First of all, the map is a nice change to the (mostly) Europe-dominated maps of the previous Total War games which in itself comes with many other diversions from what we had been used to. The feudal era in Japan during the Sengoku Jidai period although not fundamentally different from its European counterpart, has key differences  which are very accurately depicted in the game. During that period, the Land of the Rising Sun was scourged with distrust, unrest and constant fighting amongst the rival Daimyos, and this game provides just that. You cannot just rely on brute strength anymore to conquer them all. Diplomacy is your strongest weapon in the beginning, agents carry you through the late stages of your campaign and without these two your chances of achieving victory are severely hampered. This fact, along with the Realm Divide event (a.k.a. everyone hates you and wants to kill you because you are very strong) makes me believe that the developers actually put a lot of effort in making the game more challenging, even in easy difficulty, while making the way in which the game becomes challenging as historically accurate as possible and finally, it shows me that they wanted to deviate from the norm of "Make doomstacks, kill everything". No. In Shogun 2, stacks mean nothing if they are not supported by agents, or if diplomacy fails you and you are getting attacked from everywhere. Meanwhile, from the aesthetic point of view, the game looks and sounds beautiful, (as beautiful as war may ever look and sound but you get the point) once again depicting all aspects of 16th century Japan to the highest possible degree, and even though unit pools might be small and a bit repetitive, unique faction traits ensure that you will have a wide variety of possible armies to field, depending on your clan's strengths. I definitely recommend this game to any fan of the franchise.

Well, unlike most of the total war games, this one is a little different. And by this I mean its difficulty. In other titles you'll face quite a similar scenario. You begin the campaign in a more or less challenging starting position, expand, consolidate and expand again. Sooner or later you become so powerful, that nobody means a serious threat anymore. And the campaign becomes a little boring as you steamroll over everyone and everything. Just a matter of time till you win the game. I personally stopped playing maybe dozens of  them because of this.

Well, this game doesn't let you expand so quickly like in the other total wars due to its feature called realm divide. People who are new to the game will mostly discover it the hard way (including myself). It makes the campaign feel challenging even in midgame and lategame. Long term planning and preparation is very rewarding.

Shogun 2 and its expansion Fall of the samurai is so far the best Total war game and one of the best strategy games of all time. Great Avatar conquest system in multiplayer. Nothing. As for single player I find it really good as well. As far as I remember it is the first game where food system was implemened. So you get not just money but also food as the resource you always need to check and watch thoroughly. Also I really like coalition system as you grow strong and everyone else are turning against you even your vassals and allies. This feature makes you plan your strategy really caferully trying not to overextend too much. Overall I recomend this game to all RTS fans, it's totally worth its money.

A truly challenging but thoroughly enjoyable gaming experience. Total War: Shogun 2 has you take control of a clan in feudal Japan as you battle for domination to become the 'shogun'. This is an excellent addition to the Total War franchise.

In feudal Japan, pick your clan and begin your campaign to triumph over all enemies. The turn-based strategy portions of the game have you focus on diplomacy and military movement while the real-time strategy style is reserved for the combat. The combat is fantastic both at land and at sea. The naval combat is certainly easier to learn than in Empire: Total War but I would not necessarily say it was better. The game is very, very difficult so expect to be outwitted and overpowered by the other clans if you are not careful. I found the whole game to be punishingly difficult at times at that was even on the low difficulty settings. The graphics in the game are absolutely brilliant and the environments look alive. The sound is excellent too and really gives it an authentic Japanese feel.

Total War: Shogun 2 is a terrific game that I definitely recommend to strategy game fans and anybody that likes history. Personally, I still like Empire: Total War more due to the setting but the gameplay in both is spectacular. I would have maybe made the lower difficulties easier because I think the game has a very steep learning curve for the turn-based elements. I only have the base game at the minute but will probably get Fall of the Samurai at some point so I will review that separately.

NOTE: If you do not have a high-spec machine, you may be locked out of accessing high graphics settings. You have to correct some hidden files on your computer to allow you to select high graphics settings.

I may not be from the 16th century, but I was BORN a SAMURAI. 
Thankfully, I am not subject to the whims of a blowhard "master", nor are the people subject to a feudal cast system (unless you count minimum wage). For these reasons and more, I HIGHLY recommend Total War Shogun. I love all the Total War games, and some of the naval gameplay and a few of the "economic" features in this game may be lacking (the castle building is not at all customizable) but the battles are generally a fun exercise in slaughter. 
When it comes to "turn style" strategy, these games have higher than average graphics, but that's not saying much. (have you looked closely at the no-face soldiers? eerie). With all that said, Buy this, Play this, and become Shogun.

A solid addition to the Total War franchise with more realism. It suffers a bit from unit same-ness and tedious RTS especially in the higher difficulties, but provides a pretty good balance between the excitement of battle and the drudgery of building economic and morale support to fight such battles. The expansions provide much needed increases in non-battle abilities that still allow you to conquer your neighbors. General abilities have a reasonable level of real-world application, though a majority of them take place in the RTS maps and as I state above, the RTS gets really tedious in the higher difficulties. Not only are your opponents able to churn out massive stacks in fewer turns, but your units' morale basically crumble as soon as a tip of a weapon is pointed in their general direction. However, if you can get a good handle on your economy, you can churn out 2 full stack armies and forgo the RTS aspect in its entirety, which is nice.

The DLC factions are very much worth it when on sale, in my opinion. I generally haven't bought them outside them, as I've had enough to do with the factions I had before a sale rolled around. Their new styles or mechanics (the Ikko Ikki are a unique religion and can expand outside of fighting a war with their monks, but are hated by much of Japan, the Otomo are Christian at the start, and already have the penultimate foreign trade port, and almost all Hattori units are unique, having vanguard deployment and can sneak around easier) are all interesting enough to warrant a buck fifty on a sale.

Definitely get Fall of the Samurai, as well. Everything I've said here applies to it as well.

This is the best Total War game to date. Though not as expansive as later titles like Rome 2 or Warhammer, Shogun 2 makes up for it by meticulously executing every single aspect of gameplay and presentation. Character skill trees and their retainer system offers a lot of variety and choice when leveling up characters, settlement building has actual meaning and impact and battles themselves are exquisite, managing to avoid the tendency of later titles to devolve into riot-like pits. Though battles are not as fast-paced as in Warhammer or Three Kingdoms, this is in my opinion definitely a bonus, as unit movement and deployment have more impact due to the slower pace of gameplay.

I recommend Shogun 2 for anyone who is interested in getting into the genre or is familiar with Total Wars but has managed to let this one slip through. Certainly a 5/5 experience.

Total War : Shogun 2, is in my own opinion one of the best total war games that i have ever played, while I've only played Attila, Warhammer 1 and 2, Empires, and a bit of Medieval (during my childhood) this total war game gives me a feeling which none of these other, "TW" games can produce. 

* I have bought almost all of the, "DLC" for Shogun 2, however it is not needed to enjoy the game, but if i were to state one must have, "DLC" it would be fall of the samurai (which can also be played without the base game) because of how it welds 2 different styles of gameplay together while keeping base-game core mechanics the same, and increasing general enjoyment.  

Pros
- Great combat, which in addition pulls you into the battlefield, making you the player feel like a commanding officer, just like a  general in command of thousands of warriors. While the other, "TW" games have this quality, Shogun 2 is simply at the very top of this category, in my opinion other, "TW" games feel, "light" in contrast to Shogun 2.

- The levels, upgrades, or tier of units does not determine how strong an army is, to clarify you the quality of units does not determine the outcome of a battle, the way a player uses a unit whether it's good or bad determines the winner. The perfect example for this pro would be the Yari Ashigaru (The first and most basic units you get) could beat any or most cavalry units, samurai units, etc if used right, but could easily still get there ass handed to them if used normally.

- The graphics, pretty good even by today's standards for a game published in 2011.

- A personal preference for me would be map size it does not feel overwhelming to new players and is easy to understand where you need to go, what you need to do, or instantly find action, while some may not like how small the shogun 2 map is or the fact the European powers are pretty much non-existent, I believe it emphasizes combat while not detracting from a, "TW" game would be. 

- This game just like it's predecessors, but unlike some of it's successors makes you take risks when constructing buildings in the grand campaign, (More prevalent in the fall of the samurai DLC) i say this is a pro as it puts more weight or value onto the buildings rather than providing positive modifiers for essentially nothing. (I'm looking at you Warhammer)

Cons
- Path finding, this is a problem which you'll face in many other, "TW" games and RTS games but it's still a problem nonetheless, This is seen in either siege battles or in large land battles, what will commonly be seen would be units stopping for long periods of time for no reason, running single file through gates, and not knowing where to go inside a fort. (Post edit: sometimes AI ships may ram into walls and do nothing)

- (Personal issue) There is a LONG and i do mean LONG loading time to enter into the game itself, this may not be the games fault and may be due to my own hardware given that i use a HDD to load up this game rather than an SSD.

- (Issue which some users may face) The avatar conquest screen has been known for crashing to some users, after varying periods of time in the main conquest map, after moving your board piece several times, or clicking onto too many menu screens the game may crash for no apparent reason. (Avatar Conquest is essentially the pvp or combat focused multiplayer mode)

- The naval battles are super boring due to it's slow nature and controls which provide a feeling of nothing, as you feel so far away from the actual battle.

- (DLC related con) line infantry from fall of the samurai, cant move when firing by rank while matchlocks with the same ability can, i believe that both should be able to move while these abilities are active, but temporarily disabling the ranked fire until the units destination is reached. (This is a very minor and possibly personal issue) +DLC for clans which have minimal difference to other clans is just plain scummy.

-Verdict-
This game maybe slow to people who play MOBA's or FPS games, etc.... But i believe that if you like RTS without unit creation on the battlefield with only pure unit control and strategy (basically if you like a strategy game) this is probably a game which you should buy as it provides that umpth you want in the battlefield with minimal compromise and some of the best unit balance in the Total War line-up.

I was new to the Total War franchise when I began this game, and it is safe to say that this game still stacks up, even as it approaches a decade since its release. Easy to learn, hard to master. Spears stop Cavalry, a good Cavalry charge stops sword infantry, and swords beat spears. A lot of simple concepts and rules, but added together turn this into something amazing, which is why the multiplayer lobbies still host a fair number of players even after all this time. In fact, it's multiplayer where the "Sun Tzu" elements really shine, and no amount of single player can match the feeling of triumph after besting a strong opponent after a string of defeats.

I would definitely recommend both the base game, and its DLC "Fall of the Samurai" for Total War and strategy junkies everywhere.

Total War is a series I have a love/hate relationship for. On one hand, the games are insanely addicting, encapsulating, and memorable. On the other hand, sometimes they can be infuriatingly frustrating, with cheating AI, and worst of all: The design team, Creative Assembly, are horrible with both pricing and especially with DLC pay walls. Even more so since they merged with Sega. Something about Japanese game companies, I swear, they NEVER lower their prices and they hate putting products on sale. Hell, Rome 2 is still $60 full price, a game that came out in 2013. No one else gets away with that sh*t.

Anyway, what does all that have to do with Shogun 2? Well, I think it was the last Total War game where the price point, total DLC, and core gameplay meet a perfect ratio or value. This makes Shogun 2 the PERFECT entrypoint in the series, with the more classic town development system, yet control and battle mechanics that aren't as dated as some of the older games. That, and to be honest, the Japanese setting is just cool.

So, what is Total War? It's a series that is half political/economic/military development and management sim, set in a turn based gamemode (think Civilization), with the battles taking place in real time where you manage armies that number in the thousands (think Age of Empires or StarCraft). The two modes complement each other extremely well, and you get some of the most immersive, epic (in terms of campaign length), and demanding hardcore strategy you can possibly get (Sorry, the Paradox games like Europa Universalis and Crusader Kings is just too slow and overly complex.)

The core gameplay takes place during the 16th and 17th century during the Waring States period of Japan, where you will rely on peasant armies with some samurai backup. My favorite thing to do though is to deal with the Portuguese and Dutch, convert to Christianity, manufacture guns and artillery, and have the entire country collectively hate me. The goal is to let the existing, declining Ashikaga Shogunate know that they suck and to take their place, all the while proving to the other clans that you deserve to be Shogun and they don't, and if they have a problem with it, then they can step up and die in a losing battle. Awesome game.

The 2 DLC packs take place during the 11th and 12th century in the Genpei War, and the 19th century during the Boshin War, respectively. That means that in the Genpei War one you have little in the way of an effective military and have to rely more on political control, coercion, and manipulation (it's the weaker of the two. Still interesting, just strange and different), and in the Boshin War DLC, you'll have to rely heavily on switching up to rifle line warfare with artillery back up and strong navies, unless of course you want to stay more traditional, and prove that you can shrug off the west's influence without relying on the west's technical modernity and culture. Honestly, from what I can tell, most people prefer Fall of the Samurai to the maingame, even. It is pretty cool, I'd say I like both equally.

Anyway, it's probably one of my favorite PC games of all time, definitely in my top 10. I played even more hours before I got a Steam copy back when the game was new and I was living out of the country. I'd say all in all, I've probably put in around 350, maybe even 400 hours into this game, making it the most time I've put into any game ever. Now THAT is a recommendation.

Protip: If you really think the AI is that weak-sauce, get the Darthmod. It actually improves quite a bit of the game overall, but tbh, I think even without the game is still pretty solid.

So I went back and have been playing a little bit more Shogun 2 recently and realised I haven't done a review yet.

In comparison to most of the other Total War games , I'll say that Shogun 2 stands out as one of Creative Assembly's best titles, historical or fantasy. The game allows you to take up the helm of one of the warring clans of feudal Japan, vying for ultimate power to become Shogun and have your dynasty rule the country.

The game is still beautiful after many years of being released, down to the unique Japanese style of the art, the haunting music (Jeff Van Dyck was composer, enough said), and the clean/minimalist UI. The immersion of Shogun 2 really captures the feel of the Sengoku Jidai period and reminded me of one of my childhood favourites, Nobunaga's Ambition on NES/SNES. 

Due to the game being limited to Japan, there is a distinct lack of diversity with units and clans. Most of the time, the game play of each clan ends up being similar to any other. Sure, there are bonuses to each daimyo's clan but they are mostly unnoticeable. The beginning of the game seems to set the pace to a much slower Total War experience, with the ease of gobbling up your neighbours. This is when the real game begins. All of your work to establish alliances and creep your eventful way toward Kyoto is rewarded with Realm Divide. This is where the entire country is thrown against you by the Shogun in a last ditch attempt to keep your butt from ruling. Within turns, every last clan will declare war on you and throw themselves against you. Total War.

Multiplayer nowadays is mostly limited to coop. There was a unique and interesting avatar system for playing multiplayer battles but that has mostly dried up now. Still, playing with a friend in Total War is always enjoyable.

Shogun 2, has some other limitations. It has a very weak diplomacy system with very limited options. Once realm divide happens, throw it out the window completely. 

Sieges are very basic. The castles of 16th century Japan weren't like the much large European ones of the similar time. As a result, most of the "sieges" boil down to swarms of soldiers crawling up the sides of the walls and swamping the defenders. Both sides peppering each other with arrows. Not much strategy there.

Naval battles were an improvement in some ways over Empire, but the time period in Japan did have a rather limited array of options for navies. After a few naval battles, you might find yourself just autoresolving them.


Overall, the game is still very enjoyable. My ranking below:

Graphics: 8.5/10
Gameplay: 8.5/10
Sound: 9.5/10
Replayability: 9/10
DLC: 8.5/10

Overall: 88/100

A must buy for Total War historical fans. Even if you're unsure of the time period, the streamlined and less sprawling game will enchant you for many hours. The 300+ hours I have already enjoyed are definitely well spent.

Very fun game, more so if you have friends to play with in multiplayer sessions (Land/Sea/Siege battles), the game itself holds the basics of the art of war, where terrain (if you are on top of a hill this will affect the course of the battle and fatigue of troops), climate (rain, fog, snow can demoralize troops), and other tactics (flaming arrows, rifles, cannons, general's proximity & ability) that involve morale boost or demoralizing an army, will influence the odds of every battle. Sure DLC's do help starting players especially in Multiplayer, but even so after a few levels, there are always means to an end, and even losing battles grants you XP for your Avatar Conquest of your general (skills, bonuses, and cosmetics) and/or Veteran Units (with their own skills tree) that are created from basic units.

From all the Total War games i've played, this one is the one i get back to the most.

[h1] Why have I delayed a review for this game? [/h1]

The most out of the box polished Total War to date. User interface, music, game mechanics, and more importantly, challenge. It all blends well into this game. 

The Expansion Fall of the Samurai offers even more substantial content if you're someone who enjoys the musket period transition into rifles as I do. A conflict of tradition and modern ideas arises in Japan with this expansion which introduces new challenges. 

Rise of the Samurai is interesting as well, but it is not for most people as it relies more on campaign diplomacy and different approach to overall strategy. 

Most people complain about unit variety in Shogun 2, but I think the unit variety present is just enough in both the base game and the major FOTS expansion as it gives enough tactical fidelity without it being convoluted with units. There are other total wars for that. 

[h1] Neutral: [/h1]

Lots of siege battles. Personally, it's fine and I find myself fighting both land and sieges willingly. 

Naval Combat in base game is interesting for me but for many it's boring as they were fighting platforms on water essentially. 
FOTS has some of the best Naval battles however. 

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

As with all Total Wars, AI can make some questionable decisions on the battle map. However, this Total War offers one of the most interesting and challenging out of the box. It is up to the individual to limit the cheese factor against it when discovering its weaknesses or choose to exploit it. 

Some minor bugs but offers the most polish compared to other Total Wars

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]

As with any of the Total Wars, you should base your decision on which Time period you are interested in the most. These are not historically accurate games but instead give you the "atmosphere" of the time. Go into that mindset and feel the times from there. Learn from other sources. ;) Use these games and enjoy them slowly and you will be rewarded with immersion. Even buggy titles like Empire Total War are still great in my opinion because they offer excitement, strategy, and tactics in Civ-like one more turn format. Shogun 2 and the expansions is my favorite Total War followed by Medieval II and Rome I. To me, Shogun 2 is where Creative Assembly came together and went back to its roots and understood itself best. The newer Titles, (Rome 2 and onward) cannot keep me interested with the uninteresting mechanics. (Example, Tech in Shogun 2 is rewarding and interesting while in the newer titles most bonuses are superficial stuff such as "+10% melee defense") 

P.S. I wanted this review to be more detailed and objective as possible. In time, I might come back to achieve this. As of right now and due to time limitations, this is mostly my biased viewpoint and my own opinion on this title and the series as a whole. Take it as you will and thank you for reading.

This is the third total war I have played after rome 1 and med 2. I would say that the battle ai is much improved compared to those two earlier games, but still very bad compared to a competent human player. Also I would say that the siege battles lack considerable depth compared to those two games, although that probably helps the ai out and also avoids the massive path finding issues those two games had in cities and forts. Overall this is a fun and challenging game, but the vast majority of the challenge comes from allowing the ai to pull massive armies out of its butt on higher difficulty levels.

Considering it lacks the variety of units that Total War: Warhammer 2 has this game is so close to being my favourite in the franchise. I'm no japanophile  so for me it's not the setting or samurai that make it great, it's the maps and gameplay both in and out of battle.  Where as other total war games can make the management of settlements tricky, here it is well designed and simple allowing you to focus on the battles which play out very different from the other TW games. This is mainly because the ai engage eachother directly in sword fights instead of just taking it in turns hacking. This can make for a great spectacle as you watch a single samurai cut down man after man. The crowning moment for me was a sole survivor from a unit of retainer samurai managing to make 2 full units of yari ashigaru run after chopping through 12 of them. This and well crafted balanced maps are what make this game an absolute gem of a strategy game.

I only have fall of the samurai (with included DLC:s) so that is what I’m going to review here. 

I feel like the game is too strict. What I mean is that I don’t feel like you can go about things in different ways without making it harder on yourself. The units are way too few with little to no variation. I felt no difference in how the clans played.

The biggest flaw is how the campaign is time restricted in a way that forces you to rush rather than play it in your own time. I had to constantly take over new cities to make it just in time. 

The boat battles are extremely boring as well. 

Maybe the game is better if you have everything and not just fall of the samurai but I think you can get a better Total war game either way, like the new one for china (three kingdoms).

There seems to be a subset of players of this game where an update in September 2011 caused the campaign map to be shrouded in heavy fog. Unfortunately I'm one of those. It was apparently some feature CA decided to enable for low-end PCs. I don't have a low end PC. I have searched in vain for a solution and found nothing helpful. I did find a thread in the TW forum where the CA responses to this specific complaint seemed cynical and disinterested. 

I tried to ignore the fog and pushed through to the mid stages of a couple of campaigns, but in the end the strain on my eyes and rising exasperation ended further progress. 

I see no reason to recommend this game.

RNG and boredom.

Someone is removing all the negative reviews of this garbage game.
But why would they do that?
This game is made by CREATIVE ASSEMBLY, that is already a big reason to dump this title.
So, here we go.

Is it a strategy game? The developers claim it to be so. But in fact we get a scuffed turn-based clicking simulator.

Gameplay: 

Game lacks of mechanics, you literally do only 2-3 things the whole game.
Every action you do is countered by undeveloped AI, leaving you without options to use tactics or strategy. 
There is no such a definition as "playing" applied to this game, you just do whatever you can at a moment.

Diplomacy is very back stabby, even if you do everything perfectly, you will be attacked by spies or unpleased neighbours. 
The battles AI is garbage which makes them easier but only when you have numerical superiority. 
With no garrison it's almost impossible to put up a "resistance" against 25 stack armies. 
No matter how good you are at controlling your units make sure your troops are not in the minority because you will probably lose.

Battles are boring, unbalanced.

The second you move your army from your capital to take another province or fight an army, war gets declared on you by enemies that you see for the first time. This leads to your capital being immediately taken. 
Can't even try to fight back because it will take unlimited number of turns. 
Once you tend to control your provinces, all of the sudden the rebels popup and some random event with attacking army happens. And now you have 3 fronts. You move for a second to go north and your capital is taken and you are not allowed to fight back. Don't forget that all that time you also get attacked by spies.

Some old whiteknights of this franchise are saying that this game should be hard because all the previous games are almost the same. That is a pathetic excuse.

Graphics are ugly. Game is poorly optimized, lagging at maximum settings even if you are using a modern PC.

1/10

This game is just a very boring simulator burdened with unpleasant tiresome mechanics.

Can't Imagine playing this "game" more than a couple of hours.

Shogun 2 is one of the best in the Total War Franchise, if you like Samurai or the sengoku jidai ( the age of war), this game is definitely a good pick.

The turned based aspect of the game is nothing compared to CIV, but when you can get your units fighting on a battleground that's when the game shine, and it pretty much lives to it's name, is TOTAL WAR after all, and that is what the game is based upon, if you want diplomacy, alliances or anything that isn't war, well don't pick this up, ally’s will most likely betray just because they get an arbitrary number at a point in the game.

Total war games can be great, if they can improve the AI and make it not cheat as much, the turn based game play has still a lot to evolve, but the combat (even though the AI in this mode is still rather poor) is what makes this game shine, and its rewarding to defend a castle while heavily outnumbered.

Shogun 2 is one off the best games in the total war franchise, it just still had all the downfalls of that franchise.

This game was by FAR my favorite for the longest time, but coming back to it after a couple months away, I find that it has been horrifically broken.
In Rise of the Samurai, bow levy, the earliest unit of bow unit will easily beat off naginata attendants (The second level of spear unit) while in a situation where they are being attacked in the back, downhill, and they are winded. If anyone knows literally anything about this game, that situation is basically a guaranteed win between almost any 2 units of the same level. Not to mention your units will seemingly run away at the first signs of combat the second it happens, no matter the situation. Also, war will get declared on you out of the blue by random clans that are incredibly weak and sometimes have no more than three units, not counting their generals.
In Shogun 2 vanilla, I've seen light cav teleport behind my lines and kill off all of my bow units and not ever route despite being attacked on all sides by spear units. Despite the broken combat system mechanics in Vanilla it is by far the most balanced.
Fall of the Samurai my only real critique is that the campaign clans are faaaar too aggressive. I've never really had a problem with the broken system where these clans with only one settlement pump out max stack armies back to back to back, because it was kinda fun to beat them, but in this campaign, everyone seems to be trying to one up the Civilization's Gandhi and they will break long standing trade agreements and alliances just to declare a war that not even they are prepared for. This aggression has recently been amped up in all the campaigns, but is especially prevalent in this one.

TL:DR:
Game broke through recent-ish patches, can still be fun until you encounter the bugs though.

Once the best game in Total War series. Still one of the best. And definitely the best RTS of those set in feudal/boshin Japan.

TW Shogun 2  offers great replayability and variety. Unlike Warhammer, In Shogun there is no OP hero units or monsters, so its all up to whose tactics are superior. This, perhaps, is one and only TW game where tactics matters over units quality.  E.g. you cannot push through spear wall with cavalry no matter how advanced it is, and so on. You can have real epic standoffs against owerwhelming forces if you use your brain (or humiliating defeats if you dont).

The main campaign is meh (IMO), but FoTS(Fall of the Samirai DLC campaign) is a true masterpiece must have with this game.  It has the most realistic RTS lineabttles of 19th century ever.

Ofc, this game is best played with mods. My top-3 must-have list:

1)Darthmod + units for darthmod for both main campaign and FoTS. Adds LOTS of unit variety and makes firearms to have realistic (increased) range.
2)Granary mod for main campaign. (without it food will be a real nuicance).
3)Sinking threshold for both main campaign and FoTS (devs removed ships sinking feature in one of updates for reason unknown. this mod brings the awesomness of dynamic sinking back).

Overall: 10/10 best RTS feudal/boshin Japan simulator.

A rare gem amongst perhaps the only few Total War games that had substantially benefited from the use of the Warscape Engine. In fact it could be stated, that the individual duels that propagated the romanticised clashes between Samurai Warriors and common-folk were brought alive solely due to the Warscape Engine. That said, there are of course subjective pros and cons to the game that are relative to what someone might or might not had expected of the release with knowledge prior to purchasing the product. Though I had personally found myself immersed in the setting of Feudal Japan to such a great extent that I think this game could well be amongst one of the best from the Total War Franchise.

Slightly puzzled at seeing no reviews for this game all of a sudden. Also my own play time on this game runs to hundreds of hours not just the paltry 8 it now lists. Still all that aside felt this game deserves a bit of love, and if you were to pick up one Total War title during this week's sale, I could not recommend a better choice, especially for newcomers to the series. I've got all the historical titles since Rome but somehow this has ended up being my go to game. The tutorials are great for players who have never played a TW game before as well as understanding the mechanics unique to this game's setting.  It is just a very well executed game that got it right. Not sure the Total War series has hit the highs this game hit since (I've never been into the Warhammer fantasy stuff so can't comment on those). When it was released I was a bit sceptical as felt it would be hard to keep me focused on the relatively small geographic area the game encompasses compared to previous titles, but was surprised at how engaged I became with it. Plain and simple it is probably Total War's best next gen game to date, and with China next on the menu and showing great promise this could be the perfect introduction at a bargain basement price this week to whet your appetite for Three Kingdoms. Buy the collection you won't regret it!

Well, this is the only Total War game I've ever played. I honestly only bought it because I dig samurai. So, keep in mind that I'm a judging this game from a newbie's perspective. First, the graphics in this game are actually still quite good despite the game's age. It can still punish a system, especially if you're playing at higher resolutions with larger units (I'm saying this as a 2080ti owner in 2019). Furthermore, the game unfortunately doesn't provide players with a way to adjust the UI size, so at 4K, the text is almost unreadable. I'm sure there's a mod out there that'll fix this problem, though. I've found that playing at 1440p gives me the best experience, anyway. The text is just big enough and the frame rate hold up pretty well at that resolution. 

Other than that, the gameplay variety is excellent. There is plenty of business to take care of between battles, be it political dealings, trade talks, or providing provisions for each settlement. The battles themselves are a blast and, at times, can require you to really use your brain and think tactically. As someone who had never played this type of game beforehand, I found everything to be absolutely overwhelming at first, but once I got the hang of it, I couldn't stop playing. This is one of the only games in my library that never gets deleted from my computer, and considering the fact that I have about 250 games here on Steam, that's really saying something.

Of all the Total War Franchise, I think Shogun 2 has the best overall feel. The battles are massive, the building/management stuff are pretty okay, the economics/finances are pretty good (it gets more and more fragile as you progress through a game, especially in high difficulties), and most importantly the DLCs bring a different but still fun flavour to the original game. Special mention to the FoTS DLC as it totally brought a clash between the traditional melee-bow focused army compositions against the firearm-cannon focused army compositions, depicted as the central theme in the Boshin War. I have only found the tech tree-research aspect of the game rather lackluster, especially with the very small bonuses each research component might bring even into the late-game tech-tree. FoTS also lack more "individualised/unique" units to the factions, especially those that could make or break a game (except for the very strong and fairly-early game Choshu unit, the Kihetai, or the Jozai's Yugiketai if not for its' max deployed unit cap).

tl;dr: a very worthwhile game, buy it if it's on a discount (especially bundled packages) or buy them full price since it's not that expensive nowadays (March 2019).

Let me say first I played this series since inception so I am probably one of those who thinks Creative Assembly shits rainbows. That said, I fell hard for Shogun 2. It's not the most accurate with Hatakeyama's location, sure. It can be unbearable to see your best general breakaway from the clan and declare himself independent. It's the kind of game on higher difficulties that will potentially make you rage hard. Still when you match wits with other players in drop in campaign battles. When all you have are those moments where you see the fact your going to be bled dry from a battle you can't run from and you say, "Well, I will make them hurt for this loss I have to take," you get a rush. When you capture Kyoto and get the Great Guard and the Nihon Maru and start trouncing people during Realm divide, it's priceless. Seven years out and I still come back to this gem of a game. Maybe I feel like a few of the Major Clans are weak (Ikko Ikki comes to mind) do to whatever reason. However for as many hours as I have logged in the series Shogun 2 is my most beloved. The way you can get up close and see your general run down fleeing forces when you don't have any light cavarly is utterly satisfying. All in all I would highly recommend this game to new fans of the series. Just remember. Metsuke beats Ninja, Ninja beats Monk, Monk beats Metsuke.

I'm finally getting around to doing this....

So I've given CA a LOT of stick recently over their newer titles and felt it was about time I gave this game the plaudits it deserves. It's awesome, start to finish captures exactly what I want a TW game to be. I can slowly but surely craft my perfect generals and agents until they become unstoppable, battles are dynamic and always fun. The AI is capable of putting up a significant fight when on higher difficulties. 

The co-op campaigns are good and the game pace is managed very well. 

The technology aspects are good, but with a caveat that if you're playing on lower difficulties there's a good to strong likelihood that you'll win the game before reaching the bottom 2 layers of the tree itself.

The only minor gripes I have with the game are as follows:
 Agents are sometimes TOO powerful. If you haven't been nurturing at least 1 good ninja or metsuke from the beginning of the game and someone else has you will really struggle.
The morale mechanics in battle can go a bit awry. I've had examples of 200-300 ashigaru running away from 50 samurai. Which isn't completely insane, but what is insane is I was assaulting a town.... and my ashigaru decided to flee THROUGH the samurai they were supposedly running from (and still outnumbered 4-1)

Honestly though, I'm nitpicking... this game is still worth the price of any AAA title to this day and I'd happily pay it.

Total War: Three Kingdoms is imminent, so I tried to check out the only other Total War game that I got 8 years ago.

Fun anecdotal: Shogun 2 was one of the two games which caused an acute addiction symptom back then where I was unable to stop playing, apart from eating and sleeping.  The other game was L4D2.  However unlike L4D2, Shogun 2 really is showing its age, both in terms of graphics and in gameplay.

I assume the reason the game asked me to install Adobe Flash Player was to play the pre-rendered clips.  Let’s just say I’m not fond of those blurry and blocky low-res videos.  The 2D oriental-styled graphical elements are as timeless as one can expect; and for the same reason, the 3D graphics isn’t impressive by today’s standard as in 2011.

One of the main selling points of the game was seeing real-time rendered units killing each other on battlefield.  It could be a thing, if not for the camera controls are absolutely user-hostile.  Anyone would expect right click on ground and drag mouse, plus the mouse wheel, would be the standard and succinct method to control the camera, but nope; for some arcane reason I’m forced to use WASD keys to move camera, two additional keys to rotate, etc.

I don’t know how I endured this bullshit 8 years ago, but I certainly would do that now, and would not recommend anyone to delve into this madness.

This is mostly personal preference: I often something’s fundamentally lacking in turn-based strategy games.  Still if you’re into this genre, I don’t see why you’d choose this game over newer Total War games, or even the Civilisation series.

Total War: Shogun 2 stands as my favorite Total War until this day.  I transition between playing Warhammer 2 and Shogun 2 when I want to go back to a more serious historically accurate game.  From the beautiful deep quotations from poems, books,  and real life speeches about war that you see on the loading screen to the designs of the map and individual military units,  Shogun 2 is a masterpiece and a work of art with amazing gameplay.  The unit animations in battle are spectacular and awe inspiring watching them engage in brutal sword fights.  The DLC expansion packs add tons of replay value with a campaign based on the historical and exciting RIse of Samurais and another with a campaign on the sad but action packed real world modernization of Feudal Japan that led to the Fall of the Samurais.  There is also loads of amazing community made mods that change the game to your liking.  All in all it is a must buy for strategy and history fans!  I sure hope they make Shogun 3 eventually.

I started playing the Total War series with their first game, Shogun, so I may be a little biased towards the company. I love their games. This is one of the oldest games they have that is still plays as a modern Total War title. The base game is fun and simple enough to learn (for a Total War game). Units are fairly simple to figure out and they fixed the issue of food shortages long ago so it is much more managable. They even brought back the silly assassination videos which is a nice touch. This is not my favorite Total War game, but it is still a great way to wet your feet into the series, especially if you like the Japanese theme. The Fall of the Samauri DLC is also worth getting as it is very different from the base game. More like if they made Civil War Total War, but with more samurai swords.

One thing I would love to see in all the Total War games is being able to use generals and support characters as their own 1-man units like you can in Warhammer Total War. That was the single best addition to the series in years, and I would love for them to implement that into their other games.

If you'd like to take only one thing from this review; Shogun 2 is an absolutely beautiful game. 

In my opinion, the strong suit of this game is its art, audio and aesthetic. The game itself plays pretty much as the end-stage evolution of the pre-Rome 2 Total War games, without the army tradition and province systems. The graphics are starting to get a little dated, the character models look funky doing some movements (particularly visible during the generals' speeches when people throw their arms into the air), but in my opinion the art and the aesthetic makes it easy to look past this. The art and aesthetic (for someone uninitiated like myself) seem to be from the exact time period in Japan when this game plays out. Unit cards and building cards all look like art from the period (again, from someone not well-read on this particular subject), and they're pretty to look at while you read the in-game encyclopedia entries on them.

The background music is appropriate for the setting. It's relaxing when you're in the campaign map, and sets the mood before and during battles. I have one minor gripe with it, though: one of the soundtracks before a battle is using a Hang (a UFO-shaped musical instrument), which I found to be an odd choice. The voice-acting is memorable and at times funny, with a somewhat caricature-like japanese accent to the spoken english. 

As a strategy game, there's some learning curve, but is not nearly as steep as with games like Europa Universalis 4 or Hearts of Iron III. The unit roosters are the same for every clan, save for some unique units and special units made available only to certain factions. This is a strong reduction in unit diversity compared to previous and subsequent entries to the series and can be seen as quite simplistic, however this plays out in a strongly rock-paper-scissors manner and I found it to be no less engaging compared to other TW games. 

This game has some DLC's. It's not quite as bad as the worst in the current gaming industry, though I recall there was some resistance to the DLC policy regarding this game. None of the DLC's are vital to your enjoyment of the game, in my opinion. There are two expansions, Rise of the Samurai (covers the time period of ~1200AD) and Fall of the Samurai (Boshin War), the latter of which is stand-alone and is often regarded as the better of the two. Both games alter their art-style and aesthetic, with RotS building- and unit-cards still look painted, although in a different style (fitting of the time period, I assume?), while the FotS cards look like ye olde pictures and portraits. Personally, I found this very tasteful and really drives home the feeling that the art and aesthetic is what makes this game. For me, at least. 

The game came out in 2011 and I think it holds up to today's standards great. If it's worth the full price or just 50% of it; I won't be the judge. The bottom line is that this game is enjoyable, visually beautiful and worth playing.

Thank you for reading.

End-note: I haven't played the multiplayer matchmaker at all, though it seems to be far less active now than a few years ago. Somehow, there's still a chat room named "HOT SEX CHAT" or "HOT ASHIGARU CHAT" or something in the matchmaker, which has been there since about launch. The few times I've been in the matchmaking lobby, there has always been such a chat (it's very tongue-in-cheek).

This game is fantastic. All I can say right now is get it. It goes on sale somewhat frequently so wait for those, but it is easily worth the full price of the game. The graphics have signifacntly improved from Napoleon and even my crap laptop can handle the full scale battles (though it is on minimum graphic settings, it doesn't look that bad). They have cutscenes for ninja missions now when they attempt to assassinate enemies which are great but after a few times you just end up skipping them. You can choose to play around 8-10 different clans, each with their own flag, colors, and unique units, all of which are cool (except for the Uesugi clan). The land battles are great and engaging as always, but the naval battles still aren't interesting and I end up autoresolving them. In comparison to Napoleon, you now have better garrisoned troops, but you also have much less of them, so you can actually rely on them to hold a section of the wall. There are also fighting animations which weren't really relevant in Empire and you can zoom in and watch two soldiers have a duel. All in all, this game is fantastic and I would highly reccomend.

This game's got me back into Total War when I heard of it. I had played Shogon: Total War when it first came out, but missed out on Med I, Med II, and heard of the early troubles with Empire so I skipped that till I heard of this game. I couln't wait so I got Med II, Empire, and Napoleon and played them, modded them, and when Shogun 2 finally arrived I was very happy with it. It is possbily the best Total War game up to that time, and with Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai it has some of the best expansion outside of Warhammer and Warhammer II. If you are interested in the period, or Total War games in general, I'd reccomend checking it out.

Note that it uses the system of earlier Warscape games where most units don't have HP, rather than the system use by Rome II and later games. The battlefields are large and it has a richness in features that were streamlined or eliminated in later games. It does lack the depth of tech tree, and depth of skill tree, and other thing that a Warhammer player would be used to, but overall I'd say it is the best historical themed Total War title. There are still some bugs but most can be fixed with modding, I think in the last patch they messed up naval battle AI, but its been a while since I palyed. 

The game did have the best naval battles with Fall of the Samurai it allows you take command of 19th century steam powered ship, including the 1860 HMS Warrior, and other famous ironclads. Lots of fun and completly different from Line of Battle Age of Sail encounters or the boarding actions of Rome II. Though you can end up caputaring a heavily armed Galleon in the base game with such tactics. Lots of fun.

A very mixed bag of a game. On the one hand it is probably the best game in the Total War franchise, right there with the Total War: Warhammer series of games. On the other hand, like all the total war games since Empire, there is a wall where your enjoyment will stop. Some happen more quickly (Empire) than others (Shogun 2). At a certain point, this game will feel limited and you're going to be thirsting for more, but outside of mods it just won't be there. Moreover, an update 'revising' the diplomacy has all but broken the diplomacy system. This revision feels unfinished and honestly untested by the development team. You will love this game, but unless you want to delve into mods, you will probably start ranging elsewhere looking for the experience this game hints at but is presently unable to deliver.

Honestly one of my favorite games of all time. After playing a number of the Total War games, I've found this one to shine out over the others in a lot of ways.

First off, just to get the bad out of the way first, units are basically a reskin of one another for each faction. Ashigaru are going to be relatively the same for the Uesugi as they are for the Takeda and so on and so forth. You won't find a ton of uniquely designed units, and if that's your thing, then pick up Warhammer instead.

There's no rat people, no lizardmen, no undead. Just men, most of which are reskined for each faction.

Still, I think this is the one that the franchise got right in a lot of ways. Diversity of units is a small price to pay for what you get here, and really, there're still plenty of different units to choose from. Singular units, though reskinned, can still be vastly different from one another based on a number of factors such as your faction, technology level, general and even what buildings you have in the province they were produced in. 

Now, what's good about this game? Well, for starters, if you're a fan of Sengoku Jidai and medeival japanese culture like me, this game's for you. Not many games allow you to take the feild in huge force as one of the leading daimyo of the era or raise a less prominent one to glory. There's plenty of factions, each with their own unique benefits. Navies also feel somewhat meaningful in this particular installment, and if you're crafty, you can manopolize foreign trade completely. 

Most importantly, at least in my opinion, there's a good balance between war and infrastructure in this game which I feel is highly lacking in the titles that came after. The UI i liked far more than any of the other Total War games, and it felt like there were more meaningful buildings to choose from when improving provinces. The heroes in this game also feel a bit more fleshed out, and though it can get annoying later on in the game, there's little cut scenes you can watch as your ninja makes an assassination attempt, or you geisha. 

I really enjoyed this game a lot and highly recommend it. Replayability is great, giving you a chance to play as the guy who kicked your butt in previous game. Not to mention, it's set in japan. Japan! Ninjas and Samurai! Just buy it, it's like $12 for the whole thing when on sale, including all DLC except for Fall of the Samurai. You're going to spend three times that on one hollow expansion for a newer Total War game anyway, so just pick this one up!

[h1]This game, despite releasing in early 2011, still holds up as a great game today.[/h1]Let that be the first statement I make towards this legend of a game. It still holds up well today so if you're considering buying it, let it be known above all that it is still worth the cash today. Now, I feel I must preface this review with the fact that I'm a newcomer to the Total War series. This is my first game with the title of Total War. So, what do I think? Well, you should already know that I can very much recommend it as I enjoyed it immensely. The amount of viable strategies to crushing the enemy, in addition to the various tactics available during battle, give a surprising amount of depth and replayability to the game. There are so many, in fact, that I won't even bother listing them here. I'm sure you could search Youtube and easily find some tutorials. Instead, I shall focus on other aspects of the game. Now, as a newcomer, it was very easy to know what general direction to go in - Literally and figuratively - after the first 5 turns. I started out as the Shimazu, a clan with increased katana capabilities as well as conveniently residing on a peninsula. I chose them because I heard that they were a good starter clan for beginners so begin your game with this in mind. The graphics (which can make use of DX11) pretty much hold up except for ONE THING. The facial models of the armies and, even worse, the generals are completely horrendous. I'm sure they were outdated even by 2011 standards. However, as the faces are not usually seen during battle, this can be forgiven. The map style of ancient Japan on even older parchment looks ~UBER~ rad, and, once revealed, will show a high-res. depiction of the area which, might I add, is mighty cool! The unit variety is comprehensive and quite dense with many different types of units in existence. However, you will have to construct buildings in your conquered cities in order to be able to produce these units. You will also have to research the unit in order to create the building with which you can produce them. Oh yeah! you heard, there's a research system in place in order to improve your growing empire. It can improve your clan in two ways, military and economy. Both are necessary to an effective empire. This is all just touching the surface on the basics of this game. There are many slight nuances and details to the mechanics of the game that it's simply easier if you [u]just go buy it.[/u] [i]Go on! Do it! You know you want to![/i]

I don't think it's very controversial to say this is arguably the best historical Total War, and one of best games in the grand strategy genre.  

The turn based campaign is complex without being bloated by needless elements. The map of Japan is beautiful and evocative with great music. The game achieves a great depth in the turn based campaign while retaining purity of design, which is very rare.  The real time battles are very strategic,  every faction has the same units mostly with a few exceptions, so battles will often be very even and you will have to rely on your tactics in the battle rather than you're knowledge of complex unit rosters like in warhammer. This could lead to repetiveness, but the RTS gameplay is by itself solid and enjoyable so the simple rosters accentuate a strength of the series in this case.

Shogun 2 is not a game that does or aspires to do everything, but it does what it does extemely well.  A very good pick if you are interested in a strategy game or in the Total War series.

Rurouni Kenshin: Meiji Swordsman Romantic Story (Japanese: るろうに剣心 -明治剣客浪漫譚- Hepburn: Rurōni Kenshin -Meiji Kenkaku Roman Tan-),[a] also known as Samurai X, is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Nobuhiro Watsuki. The story begins during the 11th year of the Meiji period in Japan (1878) and follows a former assassin from the Bakumatsu, known as Hitokiri Battosai. After his work against the bakufu, Hitokiri Battosai disappears to become Himura Kenshin: a wandering swordsman who protects the people of Japan with a vow to never take another life. Watsuki wrote the series upon his desire to make a shōnen manga different from the other ones that were published at the time, with Kenshin being a former assassin and the story taking a more serious tone as it continued. The manga revolves around themes of atonement, peace, and romance.

The manga initially appeared in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from April 1994 to September 1999. The complete work consists of 28 tankōbon volumes, while years later it was reprinted into twenty-two kanzenban volumes. Studio Gallop, Studio Deen and SPE Visual Works adapted the manga into an anime series which aired in Japan from January 10, 1996 to September 8, 1998. Besides an animated feature film, two series of original video animations (OVAs) were also produced. The first adapted stories from the manga that were not featured in the anime, while the second was a sequel to the manga. Several art and guidebooks for Rurouni Kenshin have been published and writer Kaoru Shizuka has authored three official light novels which were published by Shueisha. Many video games have also been released for the PlayStation, PlayStation 2, and PlayStation Portable consoles. A successful live-action theatrical film adaptation was released in 2012, with limited international screenings.

I just finished the campaign (a second time? I don't remember playing it the first time.)

The game is very beautifully done, the animation, the artwork, the mechanics, the battles... all very positive. But there are some key choices the developer made which completely sapped the fun out of a normal campaign for me.

1: The time limit. You have 240 turns to win the campaign. You can continue playing after, but you won't win. Compared to Rome, I felt this time limit was way too short, and my entire time playing the campaign felt like I was rushing. This would be fine, if there was the option to change the turn limit or play without a constraint of time. But there isn't, not without modding. That is an option that should be in game.

2: Realm divide. After a certain point of prestige, your clan triggers Realm Divide, which increasingly makes EVERY other clan war you. I had one very good ally, and they warred me after about 4 turns. Everyone else was already at war with me. This mechanic made the last 80 or so turns of my campaign absolutely no fun, and made vassals absolutely redundant. 90% of my time was spent fixing sabotaged settlements, micromanaging every penny, driving off constant trade route raids and enemy raids, and watching every single general and agent of mine die repeatedly to the 200 enemy agents. This is a real issue with the game. I understand it's a challenge, but there is a line between challenge and painful torture. Seriously, I had about 15 provinces left to capture including tokyo, and the entire game just went stale for the 80 turns left it took me to win.

The biggest issue I had with realm divide though was the agent spam. Around tokyo I constantly had more than 20 enemy agents. I could not keep a single general or agent alive or build infrastructure, which completely removed any immersion I had in the game being invested in my "clan" or my generals, which was one of my favourite aspects of Rome Total War. Not to mention I couldn't benefit from any generals skills or traits, so I completely ditched generals altogether, and won without them.

Begrudgingly I will give this game a positive review, but I am not very satisfied.

Shogun 2 combines two of my favorite things into one delightful package; it masterfully blends the Total War games' rightfully renowned strategy gameplay with an experience set in grorious Nippon that allows me to shamefully celebrate what weeabo trash I am. If you enjoy other Total War titles, I would highly recommend Shogun 2. Though substantially shorter and with a smaller map than titles like Empire or Rome 2, the ever-present combination of empire management and battle tactics is as engaging as ever. Add to that the fact that the soldiers saying simple Japanese phrases I can understand makes me feel like a cultured man of the world, and I can't help from recommending this title.

Total War: Shogun 2 is currently the pinnacle of RTS and turn-based strategy games, and by far the best in the Total War franchise. Hearkening back to the series' origins in Feudal Japan, Shogun 2 does more than just improve upon the formula used in previous installments, but instead innovates in all areas. Fans of Total War are in two groups with this game: those who love it, and those who haven't played it yet.

Pros:
- Excellent RTS tactical gameplay with a huge variety of units and abilities available to suit a number of playstyles. Combined with interesting and at many times challenging terrain in order to prevent battles from devolving into melee moshpits, and you have a strategy game in which you truly feel like a Sengoku general.
- Gorgeous graphics. Whilst not the most "photo-realistic" in this genre, they are wonderfully styalised and highly cinematic, making replays a joy to behold.
- Expertly crafted map of Japan and surrounding islands, combined with multiple starting points and clans provide a huge amount of replayability.
- Well-balanced Multiplayer and brilliantly implemented "Avatar Conquest" modes that make online play even more enjoyable thanks to clan systems and (once again) near endless replayability.
- Detailed Encyclopedia and Historical Battles for those who wish to delve deeper into the history of the Sengoku Jidai period.
- Easy modding capabilities for even further refinement (if deemed appropriate).

Cons:
- Lack of truly meaningful variety between clan units.
- AI suffers from the same below average quality of other installments in the franchise, with Diplomacy sometimes becoming impossible due to overly aggressive AI clans.
- Apart from the two major DLCs (Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai) many parts of the game seem "lopped off" in an effort to make more money (I'm looking squarely at you Blood Pack).

All in all, Shogun 2 is a definite recommendation for any fans of strategy games, and it may even be the greatest example of the genre.

I've owned this game for years and honestly, it is one of the most fun games I have ever played. My friend recently got the game, and we did a multiplayer co-op campaign and it is truly amazing. The graphics of the game are very dated, but the atmosphere is still strong. I am a FoTS player, and the game is downright hilarious. The voice acting is among the best that I have ever heard, and it has left my friend and I cracking up constantly over the terrible Jinglish. While I rarley hear them, the "SHAMEFEURL DISPRAY!!!"'s and "DAMN LILY-LIVERED COWARDS" are the best of them all. Once when I was playing with a large amount of artillery and was bombarding the enemy castle like the Death Korps of Krieg, and one of the AI units said "We will not-a surviva dis," and it was then that I fell back in love with this absolute masterpiece. Is the game perfect? Hell no! I have seen some bricks that are smarter than the AI, and it has crashed on our campaign twice. The game lacks balance, the Armstrong Guns break the game completley, so I just rush their production. These cannons subjugate all who dare defy your wrath. This game is a meme, and should be loved as such. It is a good game, but it has its flaws, however these flaws do in no way hurt the games rating in my opinion. This game is a 10/10 if you enjoy strategy, but this game is played best in a Co-Op campaign.
It's a solid game even after 7 years! I'd say it's my favorite Total War game to date

There's one simple phrase that can explain this wonderful strategy game:
Easy to learn, hard to master.
The game has a nice balance between the real-time strategy, in the form of battles, and the turn-based gameplay, in the form of the top-down map.
There's a lot of different factions to choose them and all of them vary in difficulty, making it so that you have a hard time getting bored with the game. Each one of the factions has special units, perks, and starting positions. The game itself takes place during the 'Sengoku' era in Japanese history where the then current shogun was losing influence over the different warlords in the country and the country fell into a civil war where the warlords fought each other in search of influence and power. The ultimate goal of the game is to take over the capital, Kyoto, and become the official shogun under the emperor. The goal in this game is a bit special because instead of aiming for world dominance, in this game it's more local; you're just trying to unite Japan under your banner.

All in all: An amazing strategy game that has a perfect balance between the two subgenres; Real-time and Turn-based.

It is unfortunatly a step back from Napoleon and Empire and only adds one thing superior, a more interesting time period and geographic location. If you are planning on trying the Total War series I would advice you start with either Midieval 2 or Napoleon and definitely not this.

As well, I just played the Rise of the Samurai DLC and its was complete trash. Filled with bugs and a dumbed down version of the base game, which is a dissapointing title in the series anyway. This only furthers my opinion that this is one the weakest Total War's made yet and should honestly be avoided.
Used Red Shell Spyware , Beware!
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

Great game. Spent many hours trying to create the best value for money army composition to beat it on the hardest difficulty and have finally achieved that.

Pros
Decent AI with a couple of issues mentioned below. Good music and graphics, runs smoothly on my new laptop. Just when you feel safe, someone stabs you in the back and declares war on you along with all their allies which keeps it very challenging and entertaining. I also like the realm divide element where the whole of Japan declares war on you after you get too big as prevents you steam rolling through the later game with ease.

Cons
Some units seem to be a lot more useful than others relative to their cost. Ideally this could have been balanced a bit better and I sometimes find it a bit fiddly towards the later part of the game to manage everything. The AI in general is okay although they don't seem to be good at flanking you and on sieges they tend to allow you to decimate every unit of theirs with your archers stationed outside.

I've played every single Total War from Shogun to Warhammer 2 and this is by far the diamond in the rough. My hours on record is maybe 25% of my actual game time.
Due to recent actions and business practices taken by the company, it is with a heavy heart that I can no longer support Creative Assembly and the Total War franchise as a whole.

Several steps forward for the series, but a couple of steps back. Naval battles are better (but perhaps still unnecessary), feels highly polished and tested, the civilization-like advancement research and upgrades are great, diplomacy feels better. Detractors are that unit variation has decreased (reasonable, as we're talking about a very homogenous culture divided into faction; also likely contributed to the polished feel) and that all sieges are now almost exactly the same, with castle level being the only variation. Once again, this probably reduced the number of potential bugs, but you miss the character of each individual city from every game. Fall of the Samurai is amazing, and is exactly how this series should handle firearms.
