TLDR: Great Total War game, arguably the best one in my opinion.

One of the best total war games in my opinion. Really liked how diverse the range of difficulties, events and game play experiences are. Defeat can loom around the corner at any second whilst just one decision can get you victory. Whilst you get caught up in wars and peace treaties you can find your dynasty has died out or an enemy Metsuke has turned all your provinces into christian rebel states. So far I have written a generic total war review. If you hadn't clicked on the title saying *Shogun 2* you wouldn't have been able to know what total war game I was talking about. This is the part that makes Shogun 2  stand out from all the other total war games. I have three contentions. 1. The art style is incredible. Instead of engdulging in 3d graphics for everything to try and make their game look cool and modern CA did a good job of creating 2d art for the game that is just incredible. This is the primary reason for why the game stands the, although short, test of time. Sure the characters sometimes lose all colour and go white in the diplomatic mode, sure the gore looks terrible, but these critiques are the most minor of things. Shogun 2 immerses you with what a Japanese Daimyo would have felt all those years ago fighting on the front lines against overwhelming odds with your loyalties and the loyalties of others still unsure contrasted with the formal, tea drinking art admiring side of being a daimyo that seems a completely foreign reality.  2. History, for anyone who enjoys being an armchair history this game is a well executed version of any other historical game. It portrays perfectly the time period whilst still retaining some of the potentially immersion breaking gameplay aspects. Having the Date clan Roflstomp the entirety of Japan single handedly is fine because it's just the way total war games are, as is having settlements be just empty fortresses in sieges. Personnally what I can't get is having there be one castle and just a couple buildings in each province. Yes having many more buildings per province would become unmanagable by turn 2 or so but why can't total war make a game that is a little less cartoonish in this aspect and properly represnt the Japanese countryside. This nitpick is probably not applicable to most players but personnally this is what I really hate about total war games. I do like how there are historically events that pop up as you play through which is why I recommend playing the domination campaign as you struggle against christian expansion by spamming monks in all your cities where christian has spread like the plague. Personnally when Realm Divide comes along my enjoyment of the game slowly comes grinding to a halt as clans just all declare war on you similtaneously like a group of diehard Corbyn voters when they find out you're a Brexiteer. I was coming up to realm divide with only one ally, the Imagawa clan, who were also the strongest clan, they decided to take Kyoto just three turns before Realm divide meaning my only ally was gone. Immediately I was a small clan in control of just less than 1/4 of Japan with no allies. IT DOESN'T WORK LIKE THAT. Total War please make a different way of keeping the difficulty up when the end of the game comes along. 3. Gameplay. What sort of a review/mostly positive rant would this be if I didn't mention gameplay. The naval battles are so much more oriented about skill in this game than in others, let's take Napoleon as an example. Naval battles don't rely on the direction of the wind (for the most part) most ships don't use sails. They are oar based. What a breath of fresh are this is. In Napoleon I am hopeless at Naval battles due in part to the fact that I don't really ever have the wind on my side. In this game you don't hold your breath to see the compass thing at the start of a battle. You rarely ever look at it. Each boat has it's own way of fighting which includes even more factors among that. For once naval battles are purely skill based, so much so that you can defeat a hard Ai against overwhelming odds with easy if you are experienced enough. I've only completed one campaign and I failed to trade at all with other clans or even outside nations. I still used my navies for disrupting other peoples trade draining their treasuries through continuously destroying their navies and using my navies to safely transport my armies half way around Japan to attack random clans that declared war on me because a vassal of mine got attacked by a guy who was allied with a guy who was allied with a guy. That brings me to vassals. The Ai didn't make any vassals in my game but the one time when I decided to make one was when this one province kept changing hands between me and the Imagawa and as a result became tactically invaluable due to it's postion but completely ingovernable due to no infrastructure and appalling public order. So I made a Vassal. It makes itself an army they said. It gives you a unit they said. It fights your enemies they said. You don't have to govern it they said. How wrong I was to click Vassal. I had just made peace with a clan allied to the Imagawa who had a border with me just outside Kyoto which I controlled. We had massive armies just sitting on the border not strong enough to attack each other but unable to go and help out elsewhere because as soon as the army left the opposing force could sweep right in. So I made a Vassal of the territory I had just captured. Immediately the Imagawa invaded my Vassal. You can't Garrison a city owned by your Vassal and what's worse is that the Imagawa walking into my Vassal made my Vassal call me into a war against the Imagawa(who I was already at war with) and the clan I had just made peace with. aahhhhhhhhh. just kill me. I had absent mindedly given my ownly heir to the clan to make peace and so my lineage was wiped out because of the stupid Vassal. Just don't. Don't use Vassals even if it seems like a good idea. Land battles are just as good as in any other total war games. Although as you get into late game easy difficulty games you can single out and destroy enemies as their armies are split up and defeat them using only autoresolve in stark contrast to hard difficulty games where the enemy will only attack you when they outnumber you. Each to their own I guess, personally I like a mixture of both styles of play, unfortunately there is no in between mode for people like me. Strategy in the campaign view is nice but needs a lot of experience. They are just so many options. I have -1 food there are lot's of buildings and lots of arts I can master to help me with this. Which should I choose? With just over 40 hrs, not much for a total war game for me but I was just so eager to make this review, I still don't know the most optimal way of getting myself out of situations or even just knowing what buildings to build or upgrade. Economy is done very well in this game although trading could have a bit more integration into the interface to facilitate knowing how valuable trade really is and knowing whether sacrificing many ships to preserve trade is necessary. Great game I highly recommend it. Afgahnny sheep man out.

Just love this game and all its expansions.  It really holds up and looks nice.  I prefer Empire's naval battles, but the land battles with the Samurai and naval bombardment in Fall of The Samurai is bloody epic.  Not to mention the samurai/yari battles are fantastic. History is always important to learn, preserve, and understand.  I know Japan/Asia wasn't necessarily to blame for a lot of the atrocities its people went through in the early history of the East and West.  Misunderstandings and extremely unfair trade deals.  To say these people weren't exploited in the not-so-distant past wouldn't be false, but history has a way of painting us all in a bad light at times.  Sometimes it's even glamorous, guns, bows, arrows, and all - the wild west, etc.  It hasn't always been an oil painting; there has been blood spilled on the canvas, but we are still here and able to thrive/grow together.  Is it folly to believe there won't be war ever again?  It may be like saying winter will cease and the spring flower will always be in bloom.  Still, I cling onto it, [the thought of peace] knowing how much we keep focusing and looking back at our epic stories of heroics and battles won and lost.  Some love war and live by the shadow of a sword without shame.  It is their truth and it is powerful to behold, lest they change their mind and see courage expressed in a differen't way.  The hope is we keep our wars in our games and history books and don't repeat the same mistakes our ancestors made.  Sometimes we must relent, drop our cloak, and follow Old Ben.  We must turn our proverbial cheek and be cast down; to become stronger in a way even the most glorious victory cannot.  It's fun in a game, but there are soldiers out there giving their lives right now defending our home/way of life/standard of living.  I keep asking myself, why does it have to be this way?  Can't we bring them home?  What's holding us back from leaving the past behind?  What sign or miracle are we waiting for?  I think even the greatest commanders, soldiers, and leaders of people and nations ask themselves the same hard questions when they make the choices most of us would be afraid to make.  I don't sit in judgement, as much as I stew with uncomfortahble questions.  

Ultimately, we must preserve others cultures as much as we embrace our own to further cooperation.  If you're rhetoric is racist or you support this sort of thinking, you need only open up the history book, scripture, and see the error in promoting death instead of life.  Diversity is common wisdom, knowledge and essential for our survival.

I digress.  

This is probably my favorite Total War game.  It's polished and full of content.  Hundred upon hundreds of hours of gameplay if you're so inclined. My favorite feature are the agent and general abilities.  The AI simply doesn't stand a chance against the charm and wit of your agents in the field.  General traits and abilities are useful as ever.  They also really focused upon this 'hero' feature in Warhammer I've heard - still need to try that one out, but I'm slow at this gaming thing these days. I hope the newer games also have improved the campaign AI and its choices.  It's not uncommon to see a full stack of men meandering about the map like they lost a set of keys or left their wallet at home.  "FOR THE SHOGUNATE.... WAIT!  HALT MEN!   THE MIGHTY DAIMYO HAS TO GO HOME FOR A SPELL.  HE LEFT HIS FAVORITE SADDLE AT HOME AND WISHES TO TAKE A LONG NAP.  WE SHALL CONTINUE THIS MARCH AGAINST THE EMPIRE LATER."  

To be fair, war is hell, and there's a lot of great things to paint and enjoy instead.  Sometimes I think the best kept secret in the world are those little moments when we remember to smile. 
 The rust melts away and the person underneath peeks out and shines for a moment.  Death?  No, merely waking from a dream.  So it goes.

(Bring back general speeches before battle!  Medieval Total War 2 had the most epic, blood curtling, beautiful inspiring writing.  Hmm.)

You know, for a game released way back in 2011, Shogun 2 really holds up as one of the best TW games produced thus far. It has everything you could want out of a TW game: perfect music, great visual aesthetics, perfectly balanced game mechanics, amazing DLC, etc. 

It's really hard to find a serious problem with the game, other than an occasional bug (which are very few and far between). It seems like the developers really ironed out most of the bugs in the game.

Total War: Shogun 2 is a fantastic grand strategy game in which the player takes on the role of one small, humble clan of their choosing, and working their way to become Shogun of Japan. To do this, you shall conquer your enemies, trade with and protect your allies, spare your rivals and turn them into vassals, peacefully occupy captured cities or raze them to the ground for mass profit, commit terrible dishonerable acts of subterfuge and assassination, show great generosity and fight alongside loyal allied clans, keep to the good old traditional ways or take in the culture and technologies of the western traders... whatever it takes to become Shogun.

But be wary, for every other clan also has their own ambitions and plots, their own schemes to claim their place as Shogun. When the time of Realm Divide comes, only your most closest of allies shall stay at your side, but even then they shall not stay content with what little lands they have been left with. ...Mostly because the actual diplomicy aspect is a bit schizophrenic, allying with other clans along with your own and then declaring war on one of your other allies forcing you to choose between going to war with one and betraying the other, causing you to lose honor, and so on and so on down the daisychain of alliances... Actually, treat everyone as an enemy and leave no vassals, for they too may try to fight against you later on. Allies are temporary cease-fire cases at best.

As for combat, you will start with basic peasant fighters with spears and bow, aquiring bonuses to existing units and developing brand new units entirely through the two tech trees, such as giving the ability to use fire arrows for your archers, new types of cavalry like bow horsemen or katana cavalry, the ability to build and replenish siege engines and near-endgame cannons. Your appointed generals shall keep your men inline and disciplined, helping to prevent your soldiers from fleeing the battle, allowing even the weakest and most cowardly of men to fight like lions, to say nothing of the soldiers who would prefer the honor of death over the shame of retreat. But, battles are not just open field slaughters, there are many siege battles to take part in, castles to storm and capture.

Night battles allow a more crafty general to use the cover of darkness to bring forth ninjas and open the castle gates to allow your soldiers inside, or capture archery towers to rain arrows down upon your foes. ...Or just, capture the whole castle after spending around 45 seconds in the capture circle uncontested, thus winning the battle in that instant.

There's also the choice of waiting on the right weather conditions, such as waiting for the rains to pass and allow you to more effectively use your matchlock guns and fire arrows, or attacking during the rain to deny your enemy the same such advantage, or using the fog to hide your forces for a more effective ambush.

The naval combat isn't a slouch either, featuring boats large and small and hosting large numbers of marine warriors and archers. Smaller vessals best used for quickly entering the fray, whilst larger ships lumber forth and engage in boarding actions against dissabled ships. And of course, being made of wood, this is where that fire arrow ability becomes particularly dangerous, as ships may catch fire and force the crew to either cease combat and engage in repairs, or risk sinking. Late game units may even be equiped with copper plating if the right building is built, or matchlocks if a western power is engaging in trade.

The two tech trees have you decide whether to focus on economy and civic bonuses, or to focus on your military might. Or just, stradle the middle for a bit of a balance, develop both your armies and your clan roughly evenly, it all depends on the playstyle of your choosing.

The soundtrack is wonderful, calm flutes and string instruments during times of peace, tense drums and sharper wind instruments for violent encounters, etc. The artwork for the loading screens largely coming from actual pieces of Japanese artworks, complete with various gameplay hints, famous quotes, or simple poems for the loading screens. 

All in all, I highly recommend getting this game, especially with it's Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai expansion packs. Not quite so much for the individual clan DLC but whatever. If you can get the base game + expansions on sale in a bundle, do so. ...Or not.

This is the best Real Time Strategy and Turn Based Strategy game I have ever played. It took me 1000 hours to learn the game and to therefore learn the Total War Franchise. This game is easily the best TW ever made (though I have not played Warhammer II). I have 5000 hours on this game and only 50 on Rome II total war. The developers removed many features that make this game great (Family Tree, experience in units, an avatar multiplayer map, collectable retainers, etc.) from following Total War titles. 
The only thing I can complain about this game is that it is difficult to learn and the intricacies of winning a battle (i.e. what unit beats what, reload speed, what unit army is best, etc.) are not easily figured out and not at all obvious, This is not a game for casual players. There are some imbalances in the multiplayer, like a one star general has a great advantage over a 10 star general: since the 1 star general has much more funds for soldiers due to the lower cost of fielding the 1 star general. Nothing is perfect. 
I think CA should really copy their masterpiece and quit trying to please casual gamers by dumbing down the gameplay mechanics and streamlining those interesting features that draw me in.

I don't know if Creative Assembly are directly deleting reviews but they are certainly flagging negative reviews (such as mine) as 'abusive'. Presumably this is in order to get Steam to delete them. Original (OUTDATED) review below:

I really want to give this game a thumbs up as I wholehearthedly think that it is a great game that deserves every player it can get, yet I can't get myself to do it. The fact is that CA is cheating the buyers.

Avatar conquest mode servers (basically Shogun 2 multiplayer) has been taken down since two months ago, yet CA haven't informed any potential buyers about this. This means that if you purchase this game, it will likely be soely single player or co-op with a friend. The fact that they aren't even hinting about this change on their Steam forum is scam in my book. They also tried to install RedChell spyware with all of their titles. Altough some say it was harmless, I sure think its shady of them to install it without informing the user in no way whatsoever. They have removed it now, but only after the massive backlash that they got from it.

So basically, if you don't mind not having access to multiplayer, go ahead and buy. But the fact that the price hasn't changed a bit to make it fair for people that were too late to experience it is greedy in my opinion, and I honestly don't think CA deserves that extra support until they reimplement it, or at the very least, put a warning on their forum. If they change this, I'll gladly change my review, but as of now, I suggest to wait it out and see if the situation improve before buying.

This game is the reason ive always hated Rome 2

- Campaign is too simplified for a Total War game. Regional buildings and castle buildings are consolidated and there can only be one building per city. This is irritating as it spreads specialized troops very thinly across your territory and takes away a huge micromanagment element from your regional economy.

- Not enough unit variety. The only variety apart from colour variation and embles lies with faction bonuses which makes battles feel stale, repetitive and boring after a short amount of time.

- Generals are too important. If a General is taken down it is an assured route and loss. Losing a general should not make or break a battle.

- Sieges lack any semblance of tactical approach. Almost all units can scale walls and there is no siege equipment available to speak of.

- The game is poorly optimized with long loading times even on gear that far exceed the recommended specs.

This is a great game and probably one of the best, if not the very best, Total War games. It oozes finesse, style, and has the all the core elements that are sometimes missing from other iterations of total war games. 

I noticed a lot of bad reviews by a bunch of people upset at female generals for Rome II citing its SJW / inaccurate but seem to fail to realize these are just video games. Comapred to other elements of Total War games that have existed since the beginning of the franchise, some historically inaccurate female generals aren't even that bad. All total war games require leaving reality at the door because they all will shit all over known recorded history because depending on a player's choice, history will be completely ripped apart and thrown out the window. Think about what these games allow to happen, you could have the Takeda Clan taking over all of Japan (With a living Takeda Shingen) instead of the Oda/ Tokugawa clans or a empire of Gaul ruling over all of Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East, or some other random kingdom, empire, nation rising to the top of the world that never happened in real life. Total War games are power fantasies, they allow us the joy and challenge of being the leaders in famous periods of history. So if including some female characters cross the line for you then maybe these games are not for you. There are likely more 'realistic and historically accurate' games out there but I bet they stuggle to be as fun and free as these games are. Because it gives the player so much freedom to recreate history in any way they wish. 

I also just want to point out, CA mentioned that if female generals bother you, just mod them out. Every single Total War game has so many mods that I am surprised if that mod doesn't actually already exist. I just wanted to get this off my chest because I saw so many downvotes and so much immaturity I felt like I needed to say this. I know this probably won't change any minds but I hope to reassure people who are interested in the game that Shogun II is a great game and that you should ignore this recent review bombs as they are not actually reflective of this game and are simply trying to attack CA, and there are other things that you could more rightly attack them for. I don't love CA actually, bad releases on the last few games (Looking at your Rome II), buggy games, too many DLC's (SPARTA IS NOT PART OF THE BASE GAME WHAT?!), etc but this female general kerfuffle is just plain bullshit. Oh no it ruins historical accuracy! What historical accuracy geeus christ man. Just fuck off.

Shogun I TW- opened the door for decent RT battles between mixed armies of Infantry, Missile Troops, and Cavalry.

Rome TW I- opened the door for  the RT battles, WITH, Defense and Assault of realistic wall (Stone Wall), defended Cities.  The cities, themselves have buildings and streets (and by translation), different totals of occupants (people-population-men, women, & children).  Stone Walls were defended from their Ramparts (the top part of their walls).

We the purchasers, the gamers, had the pleasure of throwing articles down upon the attacking bad guys, or assaulting with ladders and rams the bad guys defending the bad city.

Rome I, and the following Midieval TW II, display realisticish worlds, with towns and cities, with POPULATIONS.  Computor Warfare and Conquest reached new heights.  

Now is not the place to mention (but I will), that MTW-II was too easy, and the British with their secure location, and their Longbows with stakes were unbeatable during the Middle Ages.  I won one game while blindfolded - - you get the point.

The Key Point;

After RT-I and MTW-II, the TW developers committed computor genocide, and eliminated the PEOPLE - and their Cities from their games (I'll comment on the awful Rome-II at the end).  In Empire, which targets the dawn era for massive European Urban development, excludes all.

In Shogun II, Japan has no people.  No Population.  No Cities.  All the developers offer are Forts - with wall a soldier can run up on, as if he was on flat ground.  The excuse is that, because of the tendency to earthquakes in Japan, (witness Fukushima's ongoing Nuclear disaster), that only Walls that are not Walls could be built, and certainly not cities.  Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and Hiroshima did not exist.  Truman had no one to use his Nukes on in 1945.  Those who believe that Japanese Forts have walls one can run-up on, thereby leaving no necessity for building Walls -in the first place- and, of course, therefore, cities and their occupants may be eliminated - as well, have not visited Japan.

In Shogun II, and Empire, The TW Developers retreated from the premise of the TW games, that of providing a somewhat realistic experience for the WARGAMER.  They have eliminated walls and cities and populations.  They have retreated from the early excellence that was RTW-I, where to defeat the Romans - as the Greeks, or even the Carthaginians, is a tacky pleasure.  Winning as the Carthaginians is a bit of work.  Play on Hard with no cheating, is quite fun.   The decent balance of RTW-I has not been equaled.

Shogun II has some beautiful artwork.  The Naval battles are decent.  But, one city state may support up to 2 stacks of Troops, that they clearly cannot financially support. So balance in Shogun II is also sacrificed.  The first Shogun, even with its age and limitations, - is much more fun.  Why have the Developers retreated?   My guess is that they saved $money on the development of the game, by hiring fewer Programmers.  They believe that the gamers are so addicted to Gaming, that they will buy almost anything, whether it is good, or mediocure.  Resembles our American citizens on election time.

The elimination of cities in Shogun II, reduces the game to a mediocure RISK.  Risk was, also, much more fun.  Japan without people? - without cities?

Rome II, which contains some potential toward measuring Culture,and its role in Ancient Civilization, is, simply, pathetic.  Only one city in 3 has walls (already constructed), and no other cities may build walls?  Syracuse without Walls?  How happy that would have made the Athenians.

God Bless!

Keep Playing!

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

review: The best total war game I have ever played! Set during the Sengoku Jidai period (age of warring states) (1467-1568) in Japan, their are many clans at war with each other to conquer Japan. This game really is a total war game as you literally have a battle royale with every faction on the map, plenty of units to play, and beautiful graphics to go along with the game. The A.I is also well balanced so their shouldn't be too many problems on that end either. Overall, I highly recommend this game for beginners and experts of the total war series alike because everyone can enjoy this game, especially if you love Japanese history.

[This review is from a Fall of the Samurai player]

Things I Like: 
- It's Japan. It's Samurai. 
- Weather actually effects things.
- Reminds me of The Last Samurai.
- The controlls for commanding troops are really useful and easy to use. 
- You can eventually make your own faction, breaking off from the Shogunate, for example, and trying to take Japan by yourself without a team victory!
- Music and sound are great and on point. 
- It still has those crappy TW in-game videos that we all love, to show a change or progress in time. 
- The graphics are great too
- Did I mention the Samurai?!?

Things I Don't Like: 
- The time limit to complete the main objective (this might be gone after breaking off from your faction. Will check later and edit this part)
- More units could be added but this isn't essential at all. There is a plentiful variety but I would like some of the same units with different weapons. Mainly just because the Samurai are so cool looking. Just an army of those please!

That's it. The game is great. If you're thinking Total War, get this one!

General: 

Rating: T
Price: $29.99
Genre: Real Time Strategy, Turn Based Strategy, Historical
Time played: 89.9 Hours

Warfare set in Feudal Japan, control the armies and lands of your clan and crush all who oppose you on land and sea. Real time strategy at it’s best. 


Gameplay - 10 

In Shogun II, you take control of one of the 10 clans who are fighting over Japan. A mixture of turn based and real time strategy, you view your lands in the world map and command your armies on the battlefield. In the world map you can determine what needs to be built in each province you control, you only have so many building slots and have to build some troops require several different buildings. You also build your armies and naval fleets from the world map, moving them into conflicts with other armies brings you to the battlefield. Last but not least is your extra units, ninja, monks etc. They can be used against villages/towns armies and generals. Each has their own ability and requirements to recruit. 

The battlefield is where you pit your tactics against those of a AI enemy, you can also auto-resolve the fights, but you tend to lose a lot more troops that way and lose some fights that you could have won (make sure you quick save before doing that).  Each unit has its own level of experience and as they fight they get stronger and better at fighting.   Morale also plays a big role in battle, if you lose too many troops it can cause your men to pancik and flee the battle.  This also works against the enemy so keep it in mind. 

There really is too many things to explain about the game, the battles are real time and can be paused to plan your next move or a bathroom break.  The game despite the name isn’t just about Total War.  There’s a lot more than just the battles, although there is a battle mode, the logistical side of it is quite complex as well.  You have to worry about the different seasons, building up your provinces to support your military and navy, keeping people happy and of course producing enough money for everything you want/need. 



Story -  10

This is the story of the Feudal era of Japan, in all its glory (and gory). It’s historical, although you could change history depending on who you play. 
Music - 8

Nice and relaxing seems to fit the era.  No real complaints. Though I can’t say I remember any particular part of it. 


Graphics - 9

The game is from 2011 but still has some great graphics, not as good as the more recent Total War games obviously but it has still has staying power. 



Controls - 10(mouse/keyboard)

The controls are pretty straightforward and having played plenty of games like this they feel natural.  If might be possible to play with a controller, but i wouldn’t recommend it. 


Repeatability - 10

The game is solid and I never get tired of the battles, as the game progresses and you begin getting more and more powerful units the game just gets better.  You can try any of the 10 clans, each with their own strengths and weaknesses which can greatly change your playstyle. 


Multiplayer - N/A


I tried to play some of the Multiplayer, only got into the Avatar mode and could only play against AI.  Not sure if this is still playable online. 

Initial Thoughts: 

I got this game after already playing Total War: Shogun I and Total War: Rome.  I already knew what to expect but still enjoyed the game immensely. 


Soma Says: 

Ah total war, one of my favorite series. I guess I’m kinda biased since I own most of the Total War games and enjoy playing all of them.  This game is right up my alley, it’s a perfect blend of turn based/real time strategy.  I can’t recommend it enough.

On this green, grassy field he lay. A peasant ashigaru. The cracks of muskets and the screams of men thundered all around him. His yari spear, dropped a few feet away from him, was trodden on by fellow men of Tokugawa as they charged into the fire. He could see the sashimono banners of the hatamoto, who rallied the men in the midst of the smoke. He peered at the defences on that hill. Smoke clouded his vision from seeing the soldiers, but the flashes of their matchlocks and the terrifying yells of their warriors marked out the enemy retainers of Ishida Mitsunari.

Blood flowed like rivers from bullet holes, staining his black ashigaru armour. It oozed around an arrow stuck in his forearm, like boiling tea in a kettle. In pain, he tried to remove the arrowhead. Grasping it with his weak right hand, he attempted to dislodge it from his arm. Gritting his teeth, he tried with all his might to pry out the arrow, but to no avail.

He gave up with the arrow. His arm was going numb anyway. The pain lessened a bit, and the man breathed heavily as he rolled over onto his back. No one around him would pick him up. They were too preoccupied.
The man, the lowly wounded ashigaru, was just one small pawn on this chessboard. It didn’t matter if he died. It did not concern anyone.

All around him, bullets and arrows whizzed like lightning. He could descry the orders of the officers, rallying men to fight to the last, with katanas raised in the air. Alas, he saw many drop from the relentless storm of projectiles, whittling down their armour. On the other side, the man weakly heard the screams of the Ashida, being torn to shreds by samurai and spearmen. 

He had thought he would go down a warrior. When this fight started, he hungered for honor and blood. And now here he lay, dying before ever slaying a single enemy.
“Heh.” he weakly muttered, noting the ironies of death. Of honor.

He coughed a little blood on his neck now, and his mind palsied, becoming more and more inert.

He felt a cold sensation rising in his spine. His breathing slowed. He was no longer jittering from his wounds. He couldn’t even feel them anymore. His strength withered away, and he could no longer keep his eyes open. 

All those sounds, the screams, the slashes, the smoke in his eyes. He didn’t care anymore. Slowly, the blasts all around him, the noise of carnage, faded away as peace, finally, peace, came to him. He started to smile a bit now. He would probably never open his eyes again in this mortal world, and he sensed his spirit slowly drifting to the next. He accepted that.

Maybe he’d join his family in the afterlife now. And see them as they were, before the samurai raid on their farm. When he joined the army, it was out of a desire to avenge them. To slay the ones who took his family from him.
Now, on that green, grassy field, as he withered away, he harbored no revenge. It just didn’t matter to him anymore.

Now that he can finally be with them again.

He could see it already in front of him. Blue, beautiful skies. White, puffy clouds like rice balls in the air. Rolling, green hills around him. A deer, grazing on a few branches from blossoming sakura trees. Just a little bit away, he saw the quaint farm. He saw his family, smiling in joy, and he ran to them through the meadows. He saw his little brother and sister, playing with their bamboo toys. He saw mother, in her kimono, weaving a basket. Father was ploughing the field. He had only to run a little more to be with them now. That little farmstead, so quaint, where time paused at the serenity of life…

But a whizzing arrow over his head brought him back to his senses, destroying his little vision.
A minute passed. And then another. The man was lying on his back, dying, bleeding. Blood drained from his face, whitening it like a towel. But that did not weaken his little smile. 

Another minute passed.
He could hear nothing now. Nothing from anything. He could sense nothing but the placidity of time.

“And now, I shall join you.”
And there he lay, giving a last, deep breath on that green, grassy field.

Alright, I have over 1200 hours spent in this game so bear with me, this is going to take a moment. Long story short, its an amazing game. One of the best in my opinion if you want large unit style combat over the single unit styles of most rts games such as Starcraft.

Shogun 2 has a fairly simple unit structure where there are peasants (ashigaru), samurai, and monks. The peasants basically suck. The samurai are a general upgrade all round on the peasants, and the monks are slightly stronger than the samurai while having peasant level armor.

Its setup in a very simplistic rock-paper-scissors system. Swords beat infantry. Spears beat cavalry, and cavalry wrecks archers. Naginata are hybrid swords/spears so do relatively well in both applications. Naginata samurai also have the highest armor in the game making them nearly immune to missile troops. This versatility makes naginata likely the most over powered unit in the vanilla game.

Mods are great for the game. Ive probably written over a dozen for myself alone from diplomacy tweaks, to unit size and strength modifiers, or even changing the garrison composition of various stages of castles. As you get better you can ramp up the difficulty by modding the game to just about however you like.

As for cons…. This game does NOT use multi threads. Why the devs recommend a dual or quad core cpu is beyond me. The game will use a single thread to 100%, and will use 2 other threads at around 5% each. I assume the dual 5% usage is some background processes because the numbers never spike up. Often times in sieges unit sizes will grow to immense proportions 10,000+ units fielded. You might be expecting that you will suffer terrible frame rates or stuttering. While stuttering may happen if your gpu cant keep up, the bigger issue is the units becoming unresponsive. Unresponsive as in you give them an order to move from one spot to another, and it might take anywhere from 30 seconds to 3 minutes for the unit to start moving, and even longer to get all the men back in formation because part of the unit may stand in place and not move with the rest of their brothers in arms. The faster your cpu the less problems youll see from this. I went from a base 3.8ghz to a 4.3 overclock and noticed that the units were still responsive at larger fielded sizes than before, but anything over 6k fielded still result in some delay of response even at those speeds. I personally didn’t mind it up to around 10k where units just straight became so unresponsive, that they had better be where I want them to be the whole fight, because they aint freakin moving for me. If your rocking a 3-3.5ghz 10+ thread…. Well your probably going to struggle to even play with 4-5k men fielded because it wont leverage all those wonderful threads. Avg army sizes for non modded games are around 2-2.5k per army. You can field a max of 2 full armies at a time, and the enemy can attack with up to 4 armies but only 2 fielded max per clan. So if two clans attack your castle and each have 2 army stacks they can field all 4 armies at once. Youd better have your defenders set where you want them because they aint guna respond to commands even at vanilla unit sizes. If you mod unit sizes to increase them like I do…. Well fps will again depend on ur gpu(s) but units will still become unresponsive because of how little it can leverage your cpu.

In conclusion, this is likely my favorit total war game, and favorit strategy game to date. I love the unit style battles. The unit composition and city development is simple and intuitive, but God do I ever wish this game would leverage more of my system so its not so bogged down during those massive epic battles that I love so much. Ill just hope when they finally get around to releasing shogun 3 that it will make full use of all the core and then I can really ramp up the unit sizes to field 40 or even 50k troops in a battle (assuming my gpus don’t explode in a puff of smoke trying to render all that)!
The second best total war after Medieval total war II kingdoms. Drop the mic.

Do you like micromanaging things hard core? Than this is definitely a game for you.

It gets really tedious really fast. Your trying to line up your archers while the enemy blitzs you. You get yout troops out and the whole enemy starts to pinwheel to the right to slip around your melee fighters and get to your general. So you have to realign again. meanwhile the computer is grabbing its horse mounted guys and swinging the other way so you have to pinwheel to the left and keep trying to rotate your armies to keep lined up. 

Or you're in a MASS battle where all your troops are in the middle. Its a goddamn clusterf!$k. But the enemy still singles out your general and kills him. Slaughtering the morale of your troops.

Realistically, yes. This is what you would expect in war. However, I would also expect a little more competency from my soldiers in war. Like, "Oh shit, my general is being attacked. The friggen heart and soul of all this. I'm diverting my attention from this fu!#king bowman to make sure my general survives." Even the trade routes aren't automated. You have to manual ly direct your trade ship back and forth. Its less than fun.

Even mid-game I was finding myself overwhelmed by all the stuff I had to keep in mind. There's literally like 30 groups of units on the field and I'm supposed to monitor each and every one of them. It was less than fun. Its a cool concept. Cause I really dug "Kingdom Under Fire". This took all the wrong aspects of that game, and put it into this one.

This is a huge game, both in the scope of gameplay and in the size of the files. This is my first exposure to the Total War Series, and I am impressed. You controls the blocks of soldier types around the battle field, for strategic planning, and then zoom to the tactical level, to see each soldier is battling tooth and nail.

I am enjoying this game on ubuntu linux 16.04 with radeon mesa graphic drivers. Feral Interactive did a great job creating a flawless experience, with high quality graphics running very smoothly, on my midrange graphics card.

The only reason that I would not recommend this game is the required amount of player interest. Are you a huge fan of the historical timeperiod of the Shogun? Do you dream about being the commander of a great Japanese army? This game delivers that experience, but, at the moment, I am finding the experience a bit dry, since I am not presently in the mood for it. Should this be interesting to you, then the game will be like a living museum, where you will be learning a huge amount about the enjoyable gameplay.

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

review:
This game is one of the best Total War Games I have ever played and I had no regrets buying the blood & Gore and Otomo DLC pack. Also its good to note that you should proabably buy this on a steam sale because 40$ was a bit pricey for a 2010 game. Also the things I wish they could've added was more clans to play: Ashikaga Shogunate, Honma and etc. (I know that the Ikko Ikki and Hattori clans are DLC and I have not played them yet so its up to you guys to purchase them or not) (Also to solve this steam has great mods)! Gameplay is excellent a must have in the Total War Franchise.

Edit: I bought all the DLC and I have to say that its worth the extra gameplay and the price (Except Rise of The Samurai its pretty awful and lackluster) The Ikko Ikki and Hattori Clan Packs are great and fun to play around with. Get Fall of The Samurai; it spices up the gameplay in more ways than Napoleon did to Empire. Multiplayer campaigns are a blast with your buds, but good luck 100%ing this game especially with the beat the CA staff member.

review:
Overall:  5/5    (Based on Enjoying Total War Style Games)  

If you're new to the series or want to try one out, this one I recommend.  
It's a little simpler to manage everything and turns pass faster than other entries. 


5/5 Gameplay:  
I'm definitely a fan of the gameplay style Total War games bring.  Shogun 2 has some interesting unit features like Ninja's that scale walls quickly and employ stealth on the battlefield.  Siege battles are fun when attacking or defending.  I can't recall if it's the General's bodygaurd or Samurai retainers (Strong Garrison Unit) that fight to the death and will not route.  Those dudes are badass and delivers the feeling of honor the Samurai portrayed.   I like that in Shogun 2 you can move units around without a General and ships are constructed in the province interface when selecing the ports vs needing to recruit in the city exclusively.  

5/5 Atmosphere and Art:  
Shogun 2 gives access to fascinating time periods and atmosphere.  The atmosphere this game generates is amazing.  The voiceovers, art, music, and sound effects contribute well to the overall theme.    

5/5 Performance:  
Game runs great now (1080 GTX) and ran great back then (7850 HD).

This is a vary good Total war game. To this day the graphics are vary pretty with some mods that make it even more so. Units are a little more responsive compared to older games. Navel battle is far better then Empire, however still a bit annoying. Combat has a good feel to it and most units have their place in the game, there's not to many useless ones. Diplomacy is a bit more advanced where alliances mean something. Realm divided is a vary good change making some new challenge to the map. N


However the game suffers from generals being far to soft and easily killable. Agents, as they are vary useful and fun to use are expendable for the most part. Gunpowder is a hit and miss thing with this game, can either do a lot or get your own men killed. Trade nodes are vary over-powered and once you catch most, you are secondly sound with opposition being vary low even in the hardest difficulties. The Tec-Tree is nice but can be a pain to advance at times. A lot of bonuses in the game tend to be worthless or tend to be to small to effect much. The AI is however vary predictable in combat making it vary easy to fight even on Legendary. 

Despite its problems, not all listed. Its still a vary fun Total war game to play. These problems for the most part still president in all Total war games, so take that as you will.
Of all the total war games I have always felt Shogun 2 has the best 'impacts' when units collided.

I love this game. I kept on playing this game including the FOTS. I recommend this game for those who knows & who do not know total war series.

I'd say it's the best of the modern Total Wars, though those games haven't necessarily set a high standard in recent times.

The feudal Japan setting is great; it's an interesting time period — where firearms were starting to come into increasingly-widespread use, but the bushido way still was in full force. The campaign is way better than more recent entries in the series, and it just has that sort of "arcade" feel of the old total wars. Very exciting, but the vanilla version of the game has very little unit diversity. In fact, I'd say this game has the least amount of unit types among any game in the series and is a bit too "rock, paper, scissors".

It's got a LOT of technical issues. Despite being well over the recommended specs and running the benchmarks, the game engine tends to run like crap and become a slideshow in spots. Setting up custom battles can also be a pain as it will undo your settings if you realize that you want to switch sides or something, and there doesn't seem to be an option to rematch a battle. The game will also keep running in the background unless I exit via the campaign mode; really annoying having to ctrl+alt+delete just to quit a game! Further, it can crash without explanation during replays.

Recommeded, but only just. I hear the expansion is great, though. Regardless, the game is worth playing not so much because it's a totally great game, but because it's the least bad of the newer, historical TWs.

All enemy armies walked straight through them for the next provinces of mine.
Sucks when the last savepoint was 20 rounds before that. 
And I wonder why a bug, where your army and agent can be stuck beside a province after conquering it, wasn´t fixed yet. I don´t think I am the only one, who had such a bug in the 7 years of this game being published.....

Red Shell issues with game and developer response.

CA statement: "Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware."

Concern:  Common defination of spyware goes as follow:  Software that enables a user to obtain covert information about another's computer activities by transmitting data covertly from their hard drive.


CA statement: "It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home"

Concern:  Again this fits well with common definations of spyware and its one of the most common uses for such software.  See http://www.bbc.co.uk/webwise/guides/about-spyware  as an example.  Red Shell is hidden 3rd party program that the user is not made aware of on installation.  The value of the data or what it is for has no bearing on this.  This also leaves unanswered the question of what Red Shell is capable of and if the third party handling it gathers any additional information that it does not share with its customer.  In an era of information leaks and data hacks this can be important and doubly so since this is software that piggy backs off a different installation.  Software installed without your knowledge is not the same as a cookie that you can block.


CA statement: "However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it."

Concern: This shows a clear lack of respect for CA´s customers.  CA maintains that they did nothing wrong and puts the onus of the problem on customers being difficult to reassure rather then on the fact that CA should have sought consent for this information gathering.  


If CA does not think there was anything wrong with this behavior, how are we supposed to trust them not to repeat it?
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

I love this game to death, I don't have as many hours as some other people do but my god this game was a great introduction to total war for me. This is the first total war i ever played and within the first few days i had racked up 70 hours. I haven't played as much because I generaly don't have that much time but I wish I did. The game is very easy to pick up even if you are new to total war and it is going to be a challenge to play on the hardest difficulty if you are a veteran total war player. This game helped me understand other total war games which would have been very hard for me to grasp. The tutorial is a part of every game which I usually hate because I figure out what I am supposed to do before the game wants me to, which can bug it. But thistutorial is fantastic, and it didn't make me lose attention or bore me by its simplicity, it was right on target. The base game is in my opinion the best part. the fall of the samurai DLC is good, but I much prefer the base. Rise of the samurai wasn't worth the money, it may just be me, or that the base game raised my expectations to high. But I would not have bought it if I had known. The "clan packs" are most certainly a fantastic addition to the game especially on sale. For once you cannot use the argument "should have been in the base game", because if the base game wants to be historicly accurate, then no, they shouldn't be in the base game. They bring parts of the sengoku jidai which were in the background closer to the spotlight. The blood pack should have been in the base game (aha you see how this agrument fits?). If this game is on sale then congratulations you just got a one way ticket to party central. If this game is not on sale then buy it now or wait until it is on sale. People will whine and complain about DLC's but compared to the other bull that's happening with more recent games this is nothing. I recommend you buy the Shogun 2 Collection if it's on sale because that is a lot of content for a very low price. If it isn't, eeeeeh. Hold off. Regardless this game is fantastic, and it's hard for me to believe it's seven years old.

I caught wind that my oldest and most loyal general was planning to defect, so I ordered him to commit seppuku to preserve his honor. The fool left with half my army in the night, marching towards the lands of his new lord, the treacherous great lord hatakeyama. We ran them down like dogs, and slaughtered the cowards who deserved even less than that, but the general, and not one other man, survived the onslaught. One man with a horse? My armies couldn't catch him, so I sent my most talented assassin. At the ripe age of 63, he had single handedly shifted the tide of war in japan in my favor more times than I (aparently) had loyal men in my armies. But, he succeeded only in wounding that snake, who slithered back to the hatakeyama capitol halfway accross the country. I would not be made a fool. I burned cities, slaughtereed thousands, overthrew a 200 year old dynasty and declared myself ruler of the charred wasteland I left in my wake... And I never saw him again.

I prefer this game to other Total War games.  The interface is very organized and the Japanese style looks so good.  The battles feel a little more structured and legible.  In other Total War games, battles usually degenerate into one big blob of same colored soldiers and I prefer this.
The tactics are mostly a simple rock-paper-scissors strength/weakness system with a few units that change it up.   The strategy are where this game really shines to me:  the seiges, the different agents, the city management, diplomacy.  There is a lot of depth here and while being good at battles is a key component, you can easily lose to someone who saves up money and uses agents well.  I really wish there was a campaign mode that supported more than two players.
Spyware in my game, I guess it's more likely than I thought.

So wow. What ab amazing game to start off with the TW franchise. Probably the second best game in the series, only behind Med 2, this game is a strategy gamer's playground. First let's start with the Campaign, where most people will play this game. Pros:
* This game has the single hardest campaign of any total war game, mainly due to the addition of the Realm Divide Feature, which finally makes End game a challenge. In any total war after, Rome 2, Warhammer, Atlilla ect, there comes a point at which you are so powerful you can simply stomp every other faction into the dirt. Not in this game. By mid game you will be one of 5-6 Powerful clans, able to field a mix of Samurai and Ashigaru armies, and by late Game, you will be left to deal with 1-2 other Superpowers. For example in my recent Shimazu campaign, when I finally made it to Kyoto and was crowned shogun, every other clan in the game declared war on me, save for my 4 vassal clans I had put between Kyoto and other clans as a buffer. The mightest of my enemies, the Hojo and the Ikko Ikki, had about 17 provinces each, and many powerful and experienced Armies, while the Mori, who had fled to the island of Shikoku, were harrasing my naval trade lines and causing great stress for my economy. Being put on the defensive by the Ikko and Hojo, I snuck an invasion force of 3 Armies composed mainly of Katana and Naginata Samurai, crushing the Mori and securing my naval ports. However, the Takeda clan, exiled to the island of Sado north of the Hojo, had the Black ship, a mighty Portuguese galleon armed with 24 cannon, which smashed through my naval attempts to land behind the hojo, taking out an entire army and one of my 5 Star Generals. Sending Ninjas and Monks to provoke rebellions in the Hojo's lands to distract them, I turned 6 of my Armies to the Ikko Ikki, Crushing them at their capital of Kaga, and wiping out their mighty Nagninata warrior monk armies. I sunk the Takeda owned Black ship by swarming it with over 3 fleets, comprised of Fire bomb Kobayas, Medium and Heavy Bunes, and even my personal shogunate flagship of the Nihon Maru, which allowed me to land on Sado and kill the Takeda clan. Plowing through Hojo lands from all sides, the final battle came outside the small settlement of Mikawa, where 5 full Hojo stacks met 5 Full stacks of my own in open battle. There were over 10,000 men on each side, and it took 5 battles to finally resolve the war. The AI on legendary is far better than normal in open field combat, and it took alot of effort to match the swarms of Katana and Yari Samurai, who were furiously assaulting my lines under support of European cannon. But I had recently recruited a unit of Shimazu heavy gunners, who broke up every charge into my lines. By the end of the battles, 2 of my generals lay dead, and much of my army was destroyed, but the Hojo lost everything, and with the annexation of their final city, I won the game and estabished my shogunate.
Any game that can make something like that feel real and immersive deserves a 10/10, and the amount of polish on this game is surreal. Absoulutely worth it

This is the best Total War game... if you like smaller maps, a more intimate campaign and a different (from European based total wars) combat style. There are no shields, gunpowder is late game in base shogun 2 and there is little to no focus on siege units. Every faction has a role and is distinct from one another. The Otomo (a dlc clan) has gunpowder from turn one, the Takeda has amazing cavalry, the Hojo get improved siege units and the holy firerockets, this goes onn for every faction. The start of each campaign is mostly the same, this changes in the midgame and the lategame where you get access to your clan specific units which are for the most part fun to play with. You get to experience all the different factions and playstyles relatively quickly since the campaign map isn't gigantic. This makes for a more intimate campaign where you know most of the other clans after a few playthroughs. There are also some historical battles, but I personally only played one and didn't like it. Trust me when I say that you'll get your money's worth out of this game because i'm at 100 hours and i have only finished 4 playthroughs of the base game, and 1 from Fall of the samurai (which you should also get).

I love this game, gameplay changes with your choice of clan. Everytime i play it is a different game while still staying the same. I recommend this game if you like strategy games.

One of the Best Total War Games out there.

I can't really say that I know enough about the in-depths of the game to speak to that crowd, but I'll give my opinion of SHOGUN 2. The one complaint that comes to mind about the game is the set campaign length, I understand that due to the time period the game takes place in, certain things happened in real life that pushed the premise of the game itself out of the "norm" in the sense of how it relates to real life, however it's just a game and I'd really like a "no time limit" campaign, but that isn't a huge problem. The game itself is beautiful for when it was made and for the style of the game. I haven't played many of the Total War games, but have played Total War: Rome(barely) and Total War: Rome 2(40+ hours), so playing SHOGUN 2 is still a learning curve for me, but very enjoyable. Combat in SHOGUN 2 on any difficulty, the AI plays generally the same. Learning the mechanics of how to make the AI make moves that benefit you is fun and challenging at times. For example, if you're the "attackers", the AI will go for the nearest hill to it and sit there on top. However by positioning yourself in a specific way and "baiting" a unit here and there off the mountain you can eventually cause them to do a full push on you or push in yourself even with far weaker units than that of the AI. The multiplayer side of things is fairly "dead", I guess it'll depend on when you usually play, haven't played much of the multiplayer myself for two reasons, first being I'm still learning the game and don't want to get curb stomped too hard. The other is the fact that the people that still play multiplayer matches is few and far between, but I can for sure tell you it's not entirely dead and you can definitely still get a match often enough to not feel like you're waiting around for years on end. Has a cool system to it for leveling and what not, customize your own Daimyo and what not, levels and skills. It's a rework of the campaign skill trees and what not. I could go on a bit more about the game itself and some other quirks it has here and there, but if you've played Total War games before you'll probably be able to identify them pretty quickly once you begin playing.

One of the best games in the series. The campaign is very satisfying in this game and features a good mix of units that make for entertaining battles. The economics of this game are a little different than last previous entries and may take some getting used to. Specifically, you now have to watch the food supply of your faction as a whole.

Campaign AI is vastly improved compared to previous games, as is battle AI. While not really that challenging on normal difficulty, they at least don't make incredibly stupid decisions anymore. The enemy will actually take advantage of isolated units or flanks in battle now.

The only negative thing I have to say about this game is the naval combat. It is boring due to the fact that most naval combat revolves around parking ships next to each other and boarding them. It's all just a matter of numbers, not strategy. But this is a product of the game's setting and the technology available.

Overall, keeps the best things from previous games, throws in a few new ideas, and fixes some old problems. (Like having units actually use walls properly.)

It is too silent then you hear it : BANZAIII !!!! Thousands of men charge into your defensive positions sounds of blades hitting eachother, fire arrows raining down on your men, rain hitting your face. Then you give orders to your cavalry to attack from behind no one survives.

I've played 7 of the 13 games in this series and I can honestly say I think this is the best ballanced and most fun game in the series. If you're into grand strategy that is perhaps a little more cassual than Europa Universalis and Hearts of Iron this is quite possibly your new favourite game.

Many consider this to be one of, if not the best Total War games of all time. I am in the camp that agrees at how fantastic this game is, as it is my second favorite Total War to date.

The campaign map is more or less like the other Total Wars, except it is a huge recreation of feudal Japan with only that country in play. However it is not the campaign map that should concern you.

The multiplayer in this game is revolutionary, buy it solely for its multiplayer. Avatar conquest is the msot ingengious item Creative Assembly ever invented, and it is in fact a travesty that it has not made another appearance. What is Avatar Conquest? It is in fact this concept where you customize and name a general, can upgrade them from earning experience, and customize and unlock new troops through the map. The map acts as a recreation of a military map, where you move an idol back and forth to mark where you want your army to conquest. If you win a battle, the province where the idol is on is a place you win, and each province has a new unlockable; be it new cavalry archer or infantry unit, armor for your general, or retainers.

Retainers are a new invenetion that allow you to give buffs to your army, or debuffs to the the enemy army, and this is to better shape your combat playstyle.

All in all, the single greatest Total War multiplayer experience, and if you are a Total War fan then this is a must.

[h1] [i] Simply enough , the best game of the Total War franchise . [/i] [/h1]

I remember being 9 years old playing Civilization 4 on my Nintendo DS. It was the first military/political strategy game to really grab my attention and consume my life (as Sid Meier's games have done to many players). But I instantly wanted more; I was quickly off on a quest to find more strategy games. This is how I found the Total War series. I quickly gathered enough cash to purchase the Total War: Rome Anthology which I instantly fell in love with. I remeber sitting there watching that glorious opening cutscene for the first time and hearing that epic music. I played that game religiously and I only wish I had had Steam at the time to record the hours I had invested becasue I would not be surprised if it would be at least double the amount of hours I have invested in the later game Total War: Shogun 2. 
I was around 12 years old when Shogun 2 was released and I also purchased that off the interent and its box is another one of my most prized possessions. After really diving into Rome, I never really found another Total War game that itched the itch I had for strategy games. I had tried Medieval 2 and Empire and didn't really see much to rave over. Shogun 2 is a different story. This game absoluetely blew my mind back in the day and was another one of those games that consumed my life. Playing hours on end daily, deep into the night. This game not only has a stellar campaign and multiple worthwhile DLCs (Although this was the start if CA scamming players with a lot of unit DLCs and whatnot) but it had an active and fun online multiplayer which really changed the game for me. Going back, the graphics aren't as crisp as I had remembered but that's typical of older games. Everything looks and feels very smooth and polished and is overall a joy to intereact with regardless. I am still in love with this game's art style and in game graphics. 
I recommend anyone reading this game to download and try it out for themselves and for any fan of strategy games to try this real gem from Creative Assembly and the Total War franchise. 
I don't mess around with the newer titles as much and see no reason too with timeless classics like this.

[h1]Verdict: 6/10 [/h1]

I realise it sounds stupid to not recommend a game I have played 175+ hours. However, I just have to. 

On the plus side, visuals are nice and after several updates, the game is rock solid. The time frame is appealing, and one can play several factions.

On the minus side, I will only mention a few of many. Few different units for each faction, which makes replayability suffer. Ridiculous commerce system. Continues previus dumb trend on multiple building locations in a single province, which CANNOT be selected in a single screen, and therefore greatly improves micromanagement...

And the WORST of all, a complete lack of tactical concept in battle. This is a point and click simulator. Choose one of your units, point to an enemy unit and hope for the best. There is really nothing you can do. Each unit is composed of over a hundred Usain Bolts on steroids that can run 400 metres in under 20 seconds, maybe 15 on a good day.

Since half the game is the resolution of battles at the tactical level, I cannot recommend this game.

this game was really great and only hald of the bad things were as bad as you can imagine, and i have over 200 hours in the game
good things:
- the units were cool and useful.
- the sieges are very fun to play even in custom battle to test how big of an army you can defend against.
- historical battles were interesting.
- even if there was not that big amount of units to choose from the units used were useful and had balanced stats.
- heroes were really good but not overpowered against other infantry units ( except maybe ashigaru but they are useless anyway except as meatshields, holding the enemy at bay in pike wall formation, and against cavalry).
- a lot of castles to choose from in siege battles.
- factions were specialized for different units like Shimazu had better katana samurai and Oda had better ashigaru units.
- the rise of the samurai DLC has a lot more ships to choose from.
- the rise of the samurai DLC has ship battles that are a lot more fun than in the normal shogun.
- the police or whatever they were named were really useful when bribing armies even if it cost a lot.

bad things:
- when you are fighting a siege with a lot of units in the battlefield your units don't want to get onto the walls to shoot at the enemies and if you told them to do that they would just stand there frozen until you gave them a different order that did not involve walls.
- if you wanted to tell your troops to scale a wall in a big battle with many units they will just stand in front of the wall while getting shot until you give them another order that doesn't involve walls.
- if a big battle happened somewhere in the battlefield the bodies started rotating in the ground and it slowes down the performance.
- allies were pretty much useless because they only gathered an army and stood around their own castle until the war has ended.
- if an enemy declared a war against you they will just gather an army and sit around in their own country.
- enemies never disband any troops in the campaign and there might be an army with half of the enemies are horsemen and the other half is archers.
- the rise of the samurai DLC has useless units and a low amount of units to choose from.
- the rise of the samurai DLC's campaign is very boring.
- the ninjas (agents) were only good for delaying enemy armies and killing their generals
- i never got to have any geishas in the 7 campaigns i played because the geishas are really late in the game and when i got the chance to have geishas the game had already ended

Bought Total War Shogun 2 a few days ago. Found it on sale and as a second option, there as a second collection together with the Fall of the Samurai DLC.

After a LONG download, with Brazil's f-ed up slow & expensive internet (on EVERY provider), I find only the Fall of the Samurai campaign is available.

Hmmm, isn't that odd? I'm pretty sure I bought "Shogun 2: Fall of the Samurai COLLECTION", which, as the name indicates, should, as a normal game collection does: The Original Game + Fall of the Samurai DLC's

I unistalled only all the DLC's. Oh, The game still opens, so I do own a copy of the gam?. But it now has no campaigns at all.

I do believe that is false advertising, as in no visible place was ever stated this was supposed to be a standalone and the only place I was able to found the information that that collection was actually a standalone was in an old forum thread and it seems this malpractice has been happening for quite a while.

As Brazil not only has shitty internet, we also have a really shitty legal system, even though I am pretty sure this is clearly a case of "False/Misleading Advertisement", it is still pretty easy for me to just ask for a refund and forget about you.

The fun story is, I actually already like this game and wanted to buy it because my brother gave away his original CD copy to a friend years ago and I was really dying to buy it and play again, not any DLC, the game. 

When you are quite a depressive person is kind of a big deal, amirite?

So, if I can dissuade you from buying this game, please do.
Malpractice should be met with a bad review to let others know people have been wronged and maybe deny a bit of the money which there clearly is greed for, to the point of trickery in advertisement.

Here is my review, now give me my money back.

Over the years, one issue has cropped up countless times: Stability. 

This game crashes, but only during battles. You can't save during battles, only on the campaign map. When battles are sometimes very closely fought and can take up to 30 mins - 1hr, the game crashing at the end of, just after, or while loading after a battle, is extremely frustrating. 

Any game which has such a glaring issue with no solution I can't justify giving this a positive review. For all the great times I've had in this game, however infrequent they are, those crashes always come at the worst possible time, and usually I can't be bothered to play the game again for months afterwards I'm so angered by it. It just totally ruins the game for me. I spend every battle nervous, anxious, in the back of my mind knowing I might be doing all of this for nothing. Any fun in this game is utterly ruined by the abject horrendous anxiety the coding causes.
Waste of money.

An improvement in every single way over the original. The graphics are better, the units more diverse, the battlefields move and feel better, everything feels more realistic. 

For the uninitiated, the game has you play as one of several Daimyo of the Sengoku Jidai, the age of the country at war, where dozens, even hundreds of lords, big and small, fought over control of the whole country. Your job is to conquer, and thus unify, Japan, through mostly military might, subterfuge, and assassinations, though having a few vassals helps too. The game is fairly respectful of the timeline and events in the real Sengoku Jidai, including the introduction of personal firearms from the Europeans. 

As with all grand strategy games, there is a lot of managing to do. Cities, armies, agents, not to mention keeping an eye on all the other Daimyo you can, can seem overwhelming at first, but once you get over that initial hump there is a great game underneath.

There is good reason this is regarded as one of the best enteries into the TW series (best if not for the current warcraft games 3 generations ahead of this game). The atmoshphere, units, campaign, battle, agents, lore and every single aspect of this game is refined to beautiful detail. It's very rare that a TW game lets you down but this? this is hands down easily one of the best games ever made to date. 

You wont be dissapointed buying this game and every DLC avalible, the combat system can be tricky to get a hold of for some but the 10,000 a side battles are so rewarding. The roar of matchlocks and cannon hurling through the battlefield touches the soul as waves of levy infantry to try swarm your line infantry, the sound of swords clashing and the katana kachi execution animations as you sneak some groups over the rear of the castle wall leave you awe struck. 

If you are an RTS/stragety fan then this game should be in your library otherwise you should commit senpoku out of the shame of neglecting it.

If you are deciding between which Total War to buy as a new comer or started late in the series, look no further. This is hands down my favorite Total War game. The setting is interesting, the campaign is great, the unit selection is vast and balanced very well. Graphics still hold up well and this game will still give a modern system a decent workout during massive custom battles. I always come back to this game because the newer games are boring in comparison to me. They paced the campaign very well, I never really reach a point where I'm sitting on my hands for multiple turns just to be able to progress a tiny bit more towards final victory, like in Attilla for example. With the Three Kingdoms themed game coming this fall, my multiyear haitus from the Total War series is coming to an end and to shake off the rust I'm coming back to this classic. I love this game, if it wasn't for Company of Heroes, I could say without doubt there isn't a single strategy game I ever played that equals it. Don't let this game pass you by, play it while it's still somewhat modern.

I bought the original Shogun Total War in 2000 when I was a teenager and my goodness, I fell in love with it instantly. Now that I've set up a modern gaming PC I decided to go back and buy this one. I know I'm years late to the party but it really doesn't disappoint, if you're still looking to buy it in 2018. It's everything I loved about the original when I was a kid and then some. One of the most dramatic differences to me is the ability in the real time battle mode to zoom down into the action and watch the characters collide in epic clashes reminiscent of films like Bravehart. Amazing. I know fans of the Total War series were gradually introduced to this feature over the years but for me it has been a long time coming. I still get chills playing this some time. Highly recommended to turn based/real time strategy fans.
