If youre looking for your first exposure to Total War, I would recommend checking out Rome II. Shogun 2 is great, but there are some quality of life things in Rome II I wish it had. The biggest being able to control the tax rate on individual settlements. 
There are inherent problems with the Total War gameplay. In Rome II you basically load up on calvary and steamroll through the campaign. The same goes for Shogun 2 with cannons. 10 cannons and a couple support troops to guard them will win almost every battle.
Because of this I highly recommend upping the difficulty or avoiding that type of play style. Instead of playing to win, play to make things interesting. One of the most enjoyable parts of my campaign playthrough was losing a battle after going through undefeated basically. Coming up with a strategy to take back the land I had lost was a challenge and downright fun. So dont get into the groove with your combat troops. Switch it up to make it interesting.

I cant really comment on the multiplayer. I played a couple of matches, so there is definitely still a small player base to matchmake with.

all factions and troops are exactly the same. you finish off one of them and the next one you fight has the same troops in the same proportions. maybe one or the other have an archer unit with some extra aim or cavalry with some more charge that is it as far as variation goes. 

tax has been simplified so its faction wide insead of being able to set differing rates per city. im not sure if that is new addition to the series or has been around for a while but its a step backwards from the earlier editions ive played. 

 no more retraning a unit to gain better armour or replace lost men they just regain a few casualties a turn. as long as you spread out your losses you can take on even medium sized forces and effectively take no losses as they will all have been replaced the next turn. again i dont know if its new but it takes a big chunk out of the complexity of managing an army

i found it kind of buggy and glitchy. from units not being loaded onto boats to bad pathfinding to parts of units getting killed for no reason. not only that i had a few freezes needing a forced close. 

this is more a nitpic than anything else but it really annoyed me, if you loot a city after taking it you loose honour. honour affects citys map wide and plays a factor in how loyal your generals are. so if you raid 1 or 2 cities you instantly find all your regions getting unhappy and get your generals swapping sides on you. it is such a massive drawback to do even a small ammount of it that they might as well have just not bothered to put it into the game. 

another annoying thing the ingame encyclopedia it has all the dlc included but it does not tell you it is dlc. 
"oo that looks like a nice upgrade to my standard archers, i am supposed to be the archer clan afterall. i think i'll try and make a few of them". 
after going through 2 new skills on the tech tree making my city bigger to house the needed building and then building it and upgrading it i find out ive just wasted 15 turns and a bunch of money. 

im not a dedicated follower of the total war series. ive played some in the past but i skip some and dont get them as soon as they are on sale, this has felt like a real step backwards to what they used to be. its a pity, ive been looking at the warhammer games they have been doing the last few years thinking i might pick them up during a sale maybe but after playing this im having second thoughts. knowing the dlc is needed not optional and they might have stripped out much of the nuance i remeber fondly.

It is my first Total War game and I have to admit I had a really rough start with it. First I installed it, played it and after two hours of a really boring and long-winded tutorial I gave up and uninstalled it. After TW:Warhammer came out I remembered that I have this game and tried it again with the same result and then I uninstalled it again. It felt too bloated, too complex, too long-winded and boring for me, also the controls just sucked.

Man, was I wrong. 

For some reason I came back a third time and then it clicked! Yes, the controls still suck imho but after getting used to them and getting into the flow of the game I just realized how amazing and beautiful it is. The art-style, the cinematics, the sound, the graphics, the layers of strategy, the feeling when your army assaults the enemy - all this is just amazing. One of the best strategy games ever. By far the best in the series, Total War: Shogun 2 represents everything the developers got right before they started to lose track with Rome II and Attila. Without the bugs, complexity and lack of optimization of its successors, and improving on all of the issues from its predecessors, Total War: Shogun 2 has a a simple UI with clear cut and well balanced unit types. It has just enough variety to vary tactics and have progression, but not enough to unnecessarily complicate the game for no good reason. Graphically, it is extremely well put together. The gameplay is satisfying, the turn-based map in conjunction with large, real-time battles make for a very intuitive and fluid experience. 

It's DLCs were a very welcomed add-on that added a new dimension to my gameplay should I so choose to use it. The Rise of the Samurai expansion retains only the core mechanics while pretty much changing every element within the same game, being a very worthy expansion. Fall of the Samurai completely revamps the map and mechanics of the game to reflect the era and it is basically a whole different game. Back when DLCs used to mean something, this was how they were like, and how they were supposed to be. 

This game makes for an excellent single player experience. The difficulty can be tailored to how you want it to be, be it as a game to relax and unwind, or as a challenge to put your skills to the test. 

For those who want more variety, complexity, and/or more options in gameplay, wait for CA to release a better game than what they have been producing after Shogun 2. For those who need more of an adrenaline rush, play the top online games instead, like PUBG. For those who want story, try Fallout. If you enjoy micro-managing finances and logistics, play Hearts of Iron. If you are not a fan of the genre even after playing this game, then there is no hope for you to change your mind. Total War: Shogun 2 is the perfect game for making you feel like a great general claiming land for your own clan and defeating your enemies. 

This is a game I can play until I die. Leave me alone on an island with a good computer and a copy of Total War: Shogun 2 and the only other things I will need in life are water, food and a chance to reproduce. I can then die happy.

It feels strange to say this is my least favorite Total War game since I have over 100 hours on five of them but for me the steps taken forward in the preceding games in both the overworld control and combat were taken back here. The game is still incredibly polished and I don't have the bug issues you'll find in Attila or Rome 2 but the mechanics are were most of my issues are found. The increased focus on naval combat almost entirely shapes the game, land control is meaningless when the AI or your human opponents will just quickly sail around and raid your older lands. This wouldn't be an issue if having a large navy made it nearly impossible to build a land army which is required to expand. Combined with less than enjoyable naval combat than found in previous games and it leads to more frustration than enjoyment.

One of better total war games in the series. Online mode has some depth with you being able to spec a skill tree for your general as well as the vet upgrades to the regular units. The story mode is also good.

TL;DR at bottom

The. Best. Total War game to ever grace this Earth (So far, that is). 

What makes it fun is the deviation from most major wars or time periods that Total War is usually known for. Even though every Total War game is diverse in it's setting and different and fun units to play around with, this one has Samurai, and has one of the best time periods to make a Total War game about. The struggle for Japan, clans fighting and turning on each other for total domination of all of the country. Although the naval combat is slow, the land battles and sieges is where the game truly shines.

Pros:
- Land Battles and Sieges
- Stunning visuals that still look good today
- Campaigns
- Multiplayer

Cons:
- Naval Combat

yeah, that's about it for me.

TL;DR: The game is absolutely amazing. Must have for any RTS lover.

Tip: Buy the blood pack for cooler moments.

Probably the most "perfect" Total War game there is. Shogun 2 plays it safe by keeping the scale and focus small; there isn't much variety between nations, and the map's tiny by Total War standards. That being said this game is extremely fine-tuned, and the balance between economy, land military, and naval power is razor-honed. The Realm Divide mechanic is absolutely beautiful; in most Total War games, once you blob to a certain extent, the game is basically over; the Realm Divide mechanic triggers once you get too large, and essentially turns all of Japan against you, meaning that instead of a slow grind to world conquest once you get too large, the game consists of you carefully tip-toeing, grabbing the important land, then preparing for the inevitable GO GO GO! of Realm Divide, ending with you capturing Kyoto, and totally avoiding the boring grind of end-game Total War.

This is a sequel to the first game in the series, set in the  16th century Japan. That means you’re only ever warring over the islands of Japan itself. So there’s no global empire to worry about, just a shogun to impress and ultimately overthrow.

[b][i]Total War: SHOGUN 2[/i][/b] doesn’t do anything differently than previous Total War offerings. The main campaign game is split between a turn-based map of Japan, with battles being resolved in real-time unless you decide to skip them and have them auto-resolved by the computer.

[b][i]Total War: SHOGUN 2[/i][/b] is a brilliant reinvention of the series that maintains the epic of scale of battles and yet increases the accessibility and focus.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Stunning graphics
- Great period detail
- Multiplayer

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Naval combat is boring
- Too much civil management during the end game.

[h1]9/10[/h1]

A lot of people really like this game, so I think I should explain why I'm giving it a thumbs down.  The key is in how the AI works.  I've only played this game for a few hours and can already game the AI pretty hard with a variety of tacics.  From what I can tell, advancing in difficulty does not increase the skill of AI opponents, it merely gives them a variety of unfair advantages and expects you to play harder to get around them. 
I don't find this particularly fun in a grand strategy game.  I don't like face stomping easy AI opponents that are on equal terms as me.  I also don't like thinking of really smart/clever moves only to have that work negated because the AI opponent is able to cheat.  Unfortunatly that's pretty much what this game is about.
Not trying to cut down or berate people who enjoy that sort of thing.  But you should know what you are getting into before you buy.

This game is pretty amazing. I think my favorite part about it is that neither you nor the enemies are encouraged to field full stacks of armies, leading to fun battles. There isn't too much unit variety early on, which makes utilizing things like terrain, cover, abilities and clan-specific advantages key to surviving the early game. The mid-to-late game maintains its challenge by throwing everything and the kitchen sink at you, so I hope you prepared a warchest before the Realm Divide.

Definitely recommend. It holds up well here in 2017.

Total War shogun 2 is a stratagie game where you start out as a war lord in Japan, you slowly destroy other tribes and eventually gain the title of Shogun, aka the leader of Japan. And as you destroy more and more tribes the more Shogun starts to notice you and your growing tribe. It's a good game but It's not the type of game you should play when other people are around. I don't mean that in the sense that there is hentai or porn, I mean in the sense that this game is boring to watch but fun to play.

Although I've haven't done it yet, I love trying to take over Japan and become the Shogun. My games generally involved me getting an army of over 1,000 men and them storming the country but they eventually make a dephaset so I lose money then raise the taxes and then there is a rebellion but screw them, I have an army of a thousand people and they have what, two hundred bowmen? I love the style of Japanesse artwork (Not in the sense of anime style, more in the sense of The Great Wave) and their ancient culture, even if they stole most of it from China. The way this game works is amazing, the AI isn't stupid and some times I feel like they are better than me at the game. I remember one time I had this huge battle with another empire and over a thousand troops died and then the warlord of the other tribe was like "that battle was a tragidy on both sides, the fighting needs to stop." But I was like "No" and I destroyed his empire. 

It's really fun and I would suggest it to anyone who wants to get into the stratgie genere or all ready likes it. It's a stressful game but you can elimenate your stress by elimenating the other tribes. Also, the game has a bug where when you fight a battle and it's foggy, the frame the fog starts out as at the begining of the battle never changes, and it becomes this annoying foreground. My score, 8/10

Total War: Shogun 2 is one of my favorite games of all time, I cannot recommend it enough.

The Good:
+The music, visuals, voice acting, and even flavor text all exude a wonderful samurai aesthetic.
+The gameplay is a great mix of turn-based provincial management and real-time battles.
+All the units counter each other and battles feel extremely rewarding.

The Bad:
-The different playable clans feel samey.
-The most unique clans are locked behind microtransactions.
-Naval battles leave a lot to be desired.

Bottom Line:
I cannot stress just how good this game, I have spent so many evenings playing "just one more turn" and finally gotten spooked by the rising sun. If you like grand strategy games then get Total War: Shogun 2!

Shogun 2 is top quality in terms of graphics, sounds, and gameplay. Diversity is great too. Easily playable for more than 100 hours, each clan has its own unique units, and features. The process of understanding the role of agents, buildings, terrains, weather, and units is awesome. Although recommended, some flaws should not pass unchecked. Consider this before buying, and be prepared to bear, since it will be kind of frustrating [read on only if you don't mind knowing game mechanics before playing. If you want to explore by yourself, stop here]. First is a feat called Realm Divide. It's supposed to keep game balanced after having certain number of provinces, because you will be too powerful to the clans in front of you. Got surprised when whole Japan declared war against me first time. This mechanic fails since puts even your allies against you at some point. All good diplomacy work will wither in time. Even weak vassals will turn against you for no reason. Even if you become Shogun before capturing the number of provinces required to make it active, Realm Divide will apply as negative diplomacy turn by turn. It would be cool if you could order those against you to commit seppuku, for example. Or to order allies to hunt your enemies, as Ashikaga shogunate does. Second problem is difficulty on hard mode and beyond. Overall game mechanics do not apply to AI. It will be allowed to have a full navy and/or a stack army while retaining only one poor province, for example. Agents will fail with high chances too. Third is the game exploits needed to win on hard mode, like selling military access, which makes evident that you're playing a machine, and spoils fun. Other than bearing these, game feels pretty good and certainly worth buying.

RIP Shimazu Yoshihiro

Warning: This game (Total War: SHOGUN 2) makes the user experience severe addiction to playing non-stop. To prevent this play it with a timer, 2 hours max recommended.

[h1] What is Total War: Shogun 2? [/h1]

If you've never played a Total War game before, you're going to be managing two layers of the game. The first is the map, in which you'll conduct diplomatic actions with your neighbors, construct cities, train troops and set political policies. The second layer is the battlefield, where you'll take your trained troops and generals into battle and hope they come out the other side as victors. 

The goal of the game will be to take most of Japan including the capital. The full campaign and fast campaign change how much 'most' covers, but they're functionally the same.


[h1] Let's talk about the battlefield. [/h1]

Are you the sort of player that really enjoys carefully plotting out where your units should be placed, when they should engage vs hold their ground and look for holes in the defense of your foes to force them to route away from combat? Then this is half the game for you.

In other Total War games, you had a dearth of units to choose from. In this game, all factions have the same units, with the exception of a unit only that faction can create. From better peasant archers to better assassins, there is something each faction excels at. These units form a rock-paper-scissors type dynamic, but more focused than in previous games. Because of this, the battlefield feels like combat resolves quicker than in other Total War games.

There are three types of battles: land battles, sea battles and sieges. Land battles use your land troops, and have you fight to the death or until one side routes off the battlefield. Sea battles are very similar, except they use boats. Sieges have you assaulting forts, keeps and castles in an attempt to take them for your own. While naval combat wasn't introduced in this iteration of the game, this was the first game where it wasn't a chore to deal with.


[h1] What's the deal with the map part of the game? [/h1]

While you'll be cutting a bloody swath on your way to becoming emperor, there's still quite a bit you'll need to take care of OFF the battlefield. From promoting your generals with new abilities to replenishing your troops, there's no end to the things you'll need to manage within your borders.

Of course, that's not where the map ends (unless you've won, then your borders ARE where that ends) and so you're going to need to manage politics to keep allies happy. Unless you plan to conquer Japan alone (which is something you can attempt, it's just hard) you're going to need help. Of course, eventually friends become foes or vassals, but the map screen allows you to manage this as well. I was fond of having lots of assassins for this purpose.


[h1] So who is Shogun 2 for? [/h1]

While all fans might enjoy the game, I feel that this iteration of the series was the best jumping on point for new players. So if you've ever held interest in a Total War game but felt intimidated by the scope of it, Shogun 2 is probably the best place to start.

If only one side of things interested you then you might want to look elsewhere. If you liked the idea of the battlefield, check out other RTS games like Supreme Commander or Starcraft II. If the map screen interested you, check out grand strategy games like Europa Universalis 4 or Crusader Kings II.


[h1] Oh what about all the DLC? [/h1]

So there's a lot of DLC. There are three new factions and while they're not essential, I do think they add a lot to the game.  There are also three unit packs and I feel that they're quite balanced, but they're really not needed. However, if you (like me) missed the unit variety in other Total War games, they go a long way towards fixing that.

Finally the "Rise of the Samurai" campaign. If you play and enjoy the main game, this will add a lot to your play time. The units it adds change up gameplay significantly in both the map and on the battlefield. The new factions are very different from the others and the campaign itself takes place at a very different time which is great. This DLC should be on your list of things to get to enhance the game.


[h1] What about "Fall of the Samurai"? [/h1]

A standalone expansion. It doesn't care if you own the original game, and you're not missing anything if you don't buy it. It's taking place during the 19th century, has a larger focus on guns, and has it's own DLC. That being said, it's highly regarded so if you enjoy this game it's entirely likely you'll like that one as well.

I don't technically own this game. The obvious question is; how am I writing a review? The answer is baffling. In my reciepts, I have a reciept for only the fall of the samurai DLC for shogun 2. However, If I go to my steam library, I am shown that I own shogun 2, with the fall of the samurai DLC. However, if I start the game and look at the campaigns, the shogun 2 campaign is locked, and only the DLC campaign is available, despite steam thinking that I own the full game. How? Why? The how seems simple; apparently, when you buy fall of the samurai, you get a stripped-out version of shogun 2, except whatever lazy bastards put the game on steam didn't bother making it its own discrete entity. The why is what I'm still stuck on. Apparently, the people who made the game wanted it to be possible to buy just the rise of the samurai without the base game, the idea being that people who just bought rise of the samurai would then turn around and give them more money for the other campaigns. However, I have no clue how to buy the main game now, since steam thinks I already own it. I could try buying a second copy and using that key instead, but I'm wary of spending $30 on what's essentially a bet on whether that would actually work. The game itself is pretty good, and don't get me wrong; I got what I paid for, but I'll be a little more wary of buying from this publisher again.

Shogun 2 Total War is one of the jewels on the crown that is the Total War franchise. Rich in history and instilled with real military strategy, this game seamlessly blends so many aspects of leading a clan across three different time periods. If you are interested in plainly in Samurai or are a player of other Total War games, this game will enthrall you and keep you captivated with its unique gameplay style. Not only will you learn the layout of Japan and its different regions but you will also gain an in-depth knowledge of the historical time period you are playing in. From the name of individual units to various technologies you research, the game is imbued in historical accuracy. There are some small cosmetic aspects of the game that coule be improved but at the core this is a great video game and it has much to offer in terms of providing engaging fun, replayabilitiy and the hisotircal transfer of knowledge.

Samurai, Ninja, Daimyo, Sengoku Jidai, Sekigahara, and Japan. This is the beginning of Shogun Total War. The game takes place in Medieval Japan, where the rule of the Ashikaga Shogunate is waning to the arguably more powerful warlords, known as Daimyo. This, however is not the game we will discuss. It's sequel, Shogun 2 Total War, is considered the last great game made by Creative Assembly in 2014. But is this game worth it? Well, my answer is yes, as I have well over 700 hours into it, and today I shall share why that is the case. So stay tuned as we walk through the greatness that is Total War Shogun 2.

The war for control of the Japanese Shogunate has gone on for well over 100 years. In this game, you have the chance to take one of nine clans to greatness with your sights set upon the capital, Kyoto. The obstacles in your way include the great clans and the Shogun himself, as well as his small clans following him. This real time strategy game requires a deal of creativity and luck as the AI have a slight advantage on higher difficulties like the 15% tax increase gained on legendary. 

This is essentially not too bad as it makes the game far more dynamic, forcing you to rethink strategies you originally thought was understandably misinformed, and create a counterbalance of troop stations to meet the demands of the people under threat. 

The buildings and public order situations are nothing new to the Total War games and are balanced for the most part. This was also the first Total War game I played with the skill and research trees, and I say that it was a fantastic inclusion for the Total War series as before this I thoroughly enjoyed the Civilization series for a similar reason. 

The agents return for more death and public order control. The assassin is the ninja,and the special police is the metsuke, and the priest from medieval 2 returns and monks are their Japanese counterpart. The agents are a all useful but not entirely necessary. You are able to manage without any agents; it might be slightly more interesting and viewer entertaining if your armies are unable to move three turns in a row however.

While all of this was basic, I appreciate your time for checking out this video and reading this post. I thoroughly enjoyed all the times I have played this game as there were times I took entire castles with only 4 of my units on the battlefield. The staple real-time strategy battlefield ultimately gave me the most fun. The political game made me feel like it could have been expanded upon, but I was very satisfied in that department overall. The trade nodes located at various positions on the map are a very ingenious way to force me to actually invest in a navy. At no point in the game was I thinking war was impossible, as I knew that sometimes I had to take advantage of my alliances to prepare for a new war in a different direction or against said allies. 

In these troubling times, we must look to our own for victory. These words hold true in all Total War games. But a much better statement is actually from across the sea, “Put your men in a position from wince there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight.” -Sun Tzu The Art of War.

I've played Shogun, Rome (all expansions), Medieval, Empire, Napoleon, Medieval II (all expansions), and now Shogun 2.  It is the best TW game.

The single player campaign has an excellent dynamic between rival clans and poses some challenge at times (could be more difficult).  The geography of Japan makes the overland strategy inherently enjoyable.

The multiplayer gaming adds a great layer, as human intelligence and strategy makes for far more difficult battles.  Humans can drop into campaign battles, by the way.

The UI is simplified and the graphics are beautiful years after release.  The family and general system is interesting; would have been nice if veteran units could emerge in singleplayer the way they do in multiplayer.

The poems and quotes shown on the battle load screens are as beautiful and thought provoking as every other TW game.

The best TW game there is. Pros and Cons compared to other TW games:
+ epic setting
+ beautiful art and music (if you like ancient Japan)
+ generally a game thats quite nice to look at, both on the campaign map and in battle (rich in colour)
+ complex game mechanics make it interesting (honour, balanced research tree making decisions hard, province management)
+ many unique units for each clan
+ hero units add to the epicness
+ the DLC are great, especially Fall of the Samurai

- relatively small map. If you want bigger maps TW Attila is the way
- feel like TW Attila is more complex due to extensive family/clan management, unique faction mechanics, diverse maps
- naval battles are hard to control, at least for me
- diplomacy is still not as good as in CIV or EU

pros heavily outwigh cons though. cons were nitpicking, really

If you ever played Total War games, you've probable heard of legendary Shogun, father of the series.

If you look into steam forums of this game, you'll find that it's infested with various bugs, such us your units dying without reason, and many others. I'm not gonna collect them here, just describe the ones I encountered in coop with my friend. I've split them into two categories.

Fucking annoying:
[list]
[*]Coop group binding - so imagine you starting a battle, say you take right flank and your buddy is on the left. You set the formations, bind the groups. Now, if you use same keys as your coop partner (ex "1") your units will highlight when you press it, but they won't listen for your command, they'll listen to your partner commands. And wise-versa, creating literal chaos on the battlefield.
[*]Dialogue windows (aka pre battle info, diplomacy) randomly opening up for wrong player.
[*]Minor coop restrictions - you can not choose weather when attacking, you can not pursue routing enemy forces, battle just instantly ends. It may sound like something pretty neglectable, but imagine situation where you need to destroy a fleet composed of 1 (ONE) ship. You attack, take casualties and sustain damage, shoot the fucker, he craps his pants, and run. Battle instantly ends, fucker retreats with full health, but you lost some crew and guns. WHAT THE FUCK. Then repeat it 3-4 times till RNG gives you one-shot-kill on him. And prepare to do this A LOT, since AI thinks it's a good strategy to spam 1-ship-fleets all day long.
[/list]
Fucking game-breaking:
[list]
[*]De-synch - so basically expect that at some point your game will warp into parallel universe, where you only think that you play beside your friend, but in fact you play with AI imposing your friend, and same on the other side. Units on global map will be in different spots for you two, composition of armies and fleet will differ, result of auto-resolve battles and so on. At some point your game will stuck, for instance if your buddy attacks an army, and in your "universe" that army is out of reach. In this case game will freeze, non of you will be able to do anything apart from forced quit via ALT+F4. Why this even a thing, why in all heavens it was implemented... Fucked if I know. To fix this, you need to take save file from host, and send it to client to override existing one.
[*]Campaign camera movement bug - another random "surprise". In short, at some random point your camera will basically stuck. No WASD movement, no screen edges with mouse, nothing. Well, to be fair you still can click on the minimap, but it's... Inconvenient to say the least. And you can not fix it via in-game means. Reload, restart, nothing will help. In order to fix this, I was forsed to use cheat engine to unpack save file and modify it.
[/list]

I don't know what else I could say. This bullshit is fucking horrendous. I'm not saying you shouldn't buy this game at any circumstances. It's fun to play. But be prepared to encounter shitload of annoying and game breaking bugs.

Fix your shit CA, you are selling a broken game for more than 5 years for fucks sake.

P.S.: Oh, and BTW, buying SHOGUN 2 - Fall of the Samurai will NOT grant you SHOGUN 2. Steam will say that you own it, but in fact you're not, you still have to buy it separately. Not complaining, just pointing out strange glitch in steam store.

If you're a fan of the Total War Series, then this review is worth reading.

This game is a bit different to what you're used to:

First up, I have a mid-level setup, and the game has a tendency to lag mildly, regardless of which graphics settings you use.
The unit sizes are larger then any other Total-War game I have played, and the soldiers do not fight in formation as a legionary-cohort would, with an emphasis on individual 1v1 combat, making it difficult to maintain a consistent battle-line.
battle tactics also differ, as there is little in the way of tactical formations which you may be reliant on in other Total War games.
In siege-warfare games, you may be used to the enemy either blowing a hole in your wall at certain points, or assaulting them with siege towers, making for a predictable attack which you can properly respond too. Japanese units in Shogun 2 however will instead opt to literally climb a castles walls, making it far more difficult to predict exactly where the enemy assault will land, and forcing the defender to spread defenders liberally across all walls in an attempt to protect all possible attack points. In essence: there are no tactical choke points, and gates are of no consideration and are only used when defenders wish to leave the castle, being bypassed by attackers altogether.

In terms of Gameplay: Shogun 2 has much in common with Total War: Rome 2. Unit control is as intuitive and responsive as Rome 2, with non of the slugishness, glitching around walls or outright refusal to follow orders as can be experienced in Total War: Medieval 2.
There is also far less diversity of units available in Shogun 2, although there are a dozen or so Japanese factions to select from, each with their own skillset, all units are simply recoloured to signify allegience with no faction-specific units.

Shogun 2 is not a bad game, but I much prefer Rome 2 by comparison. The gameplay is however... different, and any tactics you have developed in other Total War games, are not transferable to Shogun 2 due t the unique Japanese fighting style.

SHOGUN 2: Total War is - and is likely to remain as - one of the all-time greatest strategy games ever made.

Now, SEGA hasn't disappointed players with their line of Total War games; they've always been realistic, they've always been pleasing to the eye, and playing a Total War title has always been satisfying. Hell, Medieval II still holds up well despite the weird unit-mushing thing. But SHOGUN 2 takes the cake.

First things first; this game is about Samurai. SHOGUN 2's main campaign takes place during an integral part of Japan's history, in the 16th century following the Onin War. The country's land was held by numerous Clans, all of which wanted their Daimyo to become Shogun. There are two heads of Japanese government at this time - the Emperor, who was more of a figurehead, and the Shogun, who acted as Japan's de facto ruler and supreme commander of their military. In case you're still unaware of why this timeframe is important: Oda Nobunaga's in this game.

The player controls their clan on a military, political and economic level on the world map, which is turn-based like every other Total War campaign. All Clans start with 1-3 territories under their control, with the end goal being to control the majority of Japan, and the province of Kyoto where the seat of the Shogunate lies. Your faction's leader and other leader units like Generals have RPG-style progression, where they gain levels and have big, branching skill trees to suit their role. Not only do generals and the Daimyo progress, but all special units do, like your Ninja, the subterfuge unit. The early campaign is extremely tense, with rivals on every side that are all fighting one another simultaneously. That being said, the Campaign only gets harder the more provinces you hold, as other Clans can - and always do - unite against you to prevent you from progressing closer to becoming Shogun within the alloted timeframe. It's the same formula as every other grand campaign, but I find it to be much more tense, and in turn more exciting.

The good shit's in the real time battles. The devs put a lot of time into making eye-candy battle areas. They're unmistakeably Japanese environments, complete with distant mountains and volcanoes, Sakura blossoms and needless fog. I wouldn't throw Samurai at eachother in any other environment. My one gripe would be that the siege environments can get a little stale after the first few times you do it, making me want to auto-resolve most siege battles unless the numbers are stacked. Speaking of stacked - attacking a fort is WAY harder than defending it, as it should be. In Medieval II, for example, sieging a castle could be really easy at times. I always have to consider my options carefully when attacking a fort in SHOGUN 2. (At least, if you play on any difficulty higher than normal)

When your army clashes with the enemy, the sight is awe-inspiring. Unit fights are so dynamic in this game - always zoom in when you get the chance! Individual soldiers out of a unit of hundreds will find their own guy to fight, with fluid animations and satisfying kills. I play with the blood pack DLC, so whenever I get the chance, I zoom in close to see two groups of Samurai clash in a charge, resulting in a display of needless violence that sprays blood on my screen. Blood stains the grass, heads roll about and men squirm on the ground. Out of all the Total War games I've played so far, the only title that has proved to be as cinematic as this game was Warhammer, which came out YEARS after this game, and even then I'd say it's comparable.

Some people say you have to like Japan to really like this game. I disagree! Samurai are universally cool. Anybody with an adoration for angry men with swords should play SHOGUN 2. This will remain in my heart of hearts as the greatest RTS title ever made for PC.

When I got this game I knew nothing about the history of Japan before they got nuked, and I wasn't sure if I'd like it because to me Rome and Medieval looked much more familiar and cooler.

I was completely wrong.  Shogun is an amazing take on a part of history basically never done in games and it's epic.  The UI and many aspects of the game are based on Japanese art/style and it looks and feels great.  There's something about the battles that feels fluid and intense, and the way individual units fight when you zoom in.  This isn't like Rome, where you can get a formation of pikemen up and become more or less invincible in a narrow street.  There are no shields, a ton of soldiers per unit, and Shogun is all about momentum and mass attacks.  It's different in the best possible way and I'd recommend this to any fan of Total War or strategy in general.

Also, this is the origin of the "S..SHAMEFUR DISPRAY!!!" meme, I love the voice acting

It's an awesome game.  Buy it when it's on sale and grab a ton of the DLC, the single player is fun and repeatable.  Beat the game?  Try a different faction, campaign, or difficulty.  Winning an Ironman of this is tough, but rewarding.

Gameplay is balanced. Multitudes of mods. Gorgeous effects and lighting and an almost cinematic feel. Lots of eras to play in including gunpowder era. AI isn't terrible but it can be updated with mods very very very easily. 

It's so good that even now there's a multiplayer player base.

A couple years ago I bought this game, as I had previously played Rome, Medieval 2 and Empire and loved all 3 of them. Shogun 2 had some pretty good reviews and when I began playing it, I had some good first impressions on it, but after a dozen hours it really felt like a chore, a drain and an outright boring♥♥♥♥♥tease. I thought it was overrated and one of the worst Total War games to date.

I stopped playing the game for a year and I recently returned to it, to see if my opinion of it would change, and it definately hasnt.

This feels like a watered down, tedious and less entertaining version of Napoleon which in-itself was quite a flawed game, it feels like this because despite the illusion of expansion, the map is very linear; regions connect through very tight and narrow passage ways with only a couple deviating forest routes, but doing any of that really doesnt matter because the AI also blows massive dicc.

The AI is downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Empire level stupid, though at least in Empire it was often unpredictable and would pull of really unexpected moves on the campaign map. Like how the Marathas overthrew the Ottomans and colonized Quebec in one of my campaigns.

Its overly aggressive and predictable - you'll beat a faction and within the next 3 turns the new bordering faction will go like 'HUUUUUUUUUUUUEEEEER' and declare war on you - on the same turn - sending every single ♥♥♥♥ing peasant with a spear they can into your often superior garrison, and a reinforcing army; leaving thier entire nation completely unguarded.

Playing as the Otomo I took the entire left island simply by flanking the enemy and bumrushing all of thier totally undefended cities.

I suppose the reason behind the enormous garrison is because the Devs knew the AI were moronically suicidal, Banzai-ing directly into the enemy without any forward planning or defending against others.

This becomes evident later in the game where a faction will become uber powerful, dominating a quarter of the map but after doing multiple 'HUUUUUUUUUUUUEEEEER' a lesser faction will slip in and take all of thier castles.

No faction, unless they are guarded by a natural position, like the north or the far west will last long enough to reach 12 regions, they will 'HUUUUUUUUUUUUEEEEER' themselves to thier own ♥♥♥♥ing grave.

Its pretty sad that the modder known as 'Darth Vader', known for his 'Darthmod' creates more intelligent AI with the games engine than what the multi-million dollar Creative Assembly can do.

This is, for me, the best Total War game ever made. Its unit choices, given the historical context, can be terribly bland, but this was fixed with a lot of the additional, legendary units and makes the game unusually balanced. For me, the only other Total War games that come close to the performance, aesthetics, and chess-like nature of Shogun 2 are the original Rome, and Medieval 2 (I haven't played Medieval 1, don't shoot!). Everything since this (Rome 2, Warhammer) have been just OK. That, coupled with the new release strategy have really turned me off their other games (i.e. declining quality and increasing price). I'll happily stick with this incredible game for the next decade.

I'm a big fan of the Total War series and I don't usually write reviews but this is probably one of my favorites out of all of them. 

It's a pretty challenging game with a steaper learning curve, but it's much more rewarding when you do well, and I liked the siege battles more in this game than any of the other Total War games. 1000 samurai archers defending a fortress surrounded by 2000-4000 enemy troops is awesome.

Definitely worth buying if you're interested in Samurai, strategy games, or the Total War games.

Shogun 2 is the best in the series. Its pretty much where they got all of the mechanics nearly perfected. Game was extremely well balanced and you had tons of options for stategy.

Shogun 2 is a turn based strategy game set during the Japanese civil war. It is a very fun empire building type game. The in game graphics are really good and the battles are fun and tactical. With two awesome expansion packs (one set in the late 19th century, if you like the Napoleonic era, I recommend you pick up the fall of the Samurai expansion), Total War, Shogun 2, is a great game, especially if you like the Samurai Sengoku Period. However, Steam workshop mods are often necessary to shake the game up a bit. 

Features: 
-Steam workshop
-DLC's 
-Grand campaign map
-Highly detailed real time battles
-Historical scenarios
-Multiplayer campaign

Rating: 4.4/5 a very fun game, but has a good share of flaws and eventual boredom.

Easily my favorite game in the Total War franchise. The strategic AI isn't TOO bad, and the battles are absolutely breathtaking. Battle AI is some of the best the franchise has to offer, and naval combat is more refined in this game compared to its debut in Empire: Total War. A lot of love went into this game, and I can appreciate that.

The DLC is solid and well-worth it. Fall of the Samurai is by far my favorite: that campaign in and of itself is hands down the best gunpowder-era combat the franchise has to offer. Combine that with mod support and you have a recipe for awesome that you don't find in too many strategy games. 9/10 would form a republic and get gang-raped again.

Total War is my favorite strategy franchise. I've played most of the games and it all started with Shogun 2. This entry in the series, unlike the rest, is very simplistic. You can pick it up and learn how to play in just a few hours. Although that's a good thing, it's also because compared to other TW Games, Shogun 2 lacks diplomatic complexity. Japan is controlled by the Shogunate, and if you try to rise to power (by conquering) you are heavily penalized. Causing your oldest alliances, newest factions, and virtually everyone to unite against you. The game is suppose to punish factions for breaking alliances. But if you try to exchange hostages, give payments, or conduct arrange marriages (in exchange for peace), the opposing faction will immediately break all treaties on the very next turn. While still maintaining their former alliances and even rising in power. One of the most broken things in Shogun 2 is the system that allows enemies to generate armies. It doesn't matter if you have defeated your enemy's main force, killed his Daimyo, and crippled his economy. Your enemy will regenerate a FULL FORCE within 6 turns or less. It makes the game impossible to play on any difficulty. Same goes for rebellions. If rebels organize, armies are almost always at the MAX 20 Cards. Not cheap basic units either, powerful specially skilled units. 

 I would recommend a more refined game in the series like, ROME II, Atilia, or Warhammer.

In my opinion, one of the best total war games. The combat is excellent, as one would expect from a total war game. And really, isnt that what we all crave? We are but animals, despite our wanting otherwise. There is a reason most games are violent, as a species we must be comfortable with killing and being killed or we would not be where we are today. And for most, that comfort can easily cross over to enjoyment if the threat is fictional, it exercises a specific part of our mind that we as an organism have relied on since we were tiny little rat like mammals. Simial in fact to puppies and kittens play fighting, essentialy practicing to kill. Those that find it fun practice, those that practice become prepared, and those that are prepared survive.

One of the best Total War games, the creators really went back to thier roots. Easy government system leaving you free to wage WAR, with very little in the way of tab juggleing. Naval battles are slightly (very slightly) better then previous total war games, and the different factions are similar enough to easily transition from one to the next, yet different enough to merit multiple playthroughs. Great game.

The ONLY interest thing about the game is the historical setting. 

The gameplay is a shitty mess: even after having played the game game a lot you can end up with no idea on how to actually play it. 
Considering that when I played Medieval Total War 1 long time ago I found out the same many issues that affects this game I'm compelled to believe that these issues are known and IGNORED by the company behind the games.
Even the great mods out there can't fix all of the pesky problems that infest this game.

So here a non-comprehensive list of reasons to mark  TW - SHOGUN 2 as a very bad game, and why you would prefer to watch a documentary about Japanese History instead.

About the Campaign Mode

- Normal difficulty favours the player economically and economy is all.
- There is no different game difficulty: higher difficulties are achieved by handicap on player economy and boost on enemy troupe stats, and AI being exaggeratedly aggressive on the player, meanwhile lower difficulties are tuned exactly the opposite way. 
- Unit encyclopedia is slow (Why on earth is based on Internet Explorer for ?)
- Economy must be understood clearly to play effectively, however the trading system is obscure.
- Naval battles are boring, obscure and useless: nothing comes out from conquering and holding the seas, just wasted money and upkeep. Even when you secure trade routes it is too costly to conquer and hold it. Even when you do the enemy can simply raid your route or block the port.
- Damages to fleets won't recover over time which forces you to spend even more money for repairs. Also they can only be repaired in a port of your own. 
- Campaign scenario is ALWAYS the same for each faction: no matter what you do you will have no way to ally with the neighbour who is scripted to attack you.
- Advanced cannot created until you have the required building. This usually means holding a trade route or a specific territory (when you will be able to create the building you'll be against the whole nation).  unit/buildings cannot be created until you have the necessary technology. Once you have all these prerequisite you must be able to afford the troupe.
- Streets are the curse of the game. They will be used by both allied units and enemy units to advance more rapidly. When you naively upgrade streets you are just putting a target mark on you land.
- You can NOT decide the leading general (the one who gets more experience) when more are present.
- If the leading general is the Shogun you can't bribe the army, the AI exploit this always since losing the shogun has NO side effect.
- Agents are overpowered and are in fact restricted to the number of 5. for a total of 20 agents who can stop armies from taking actions, incite revolts, kill other agents, assassinate generals, bribe enemy armies.
- Buddhist monk Agents are useless: the odds of inciting a revolt against another buddhist shogun will be too low.
- Castle have standard units that spawn up when attacked and are free of cost and upkeep, meaning that when capturing an enemy castle you will need a greater amount of troupes based on the enemy castle level.

About the Battle Mode

- AI is dumb but so dumb that you might easily win a lost castle defence thanks to AI chasing you general all around the citadel.
- Unit formations are acquired by technologies: Without, your pike-men will never know how to form a square that is not easy to flank.
- Cavalry is USELESS. too costly and easily countered by the easiest and earliest unit troupe: pike-men.
- Flanking and attacks on behind are messed up attacking an advanced with cheap units when having the advantages of 
     -- higher ground 
     -- enemy attacked from the flanks
     -- enemy attacked from behind
   could still end up in losing, cause enemy units will still go down slowly and meanwhile your troupes will lose morale due to high losses.
- Morale system is just a joke: get on early units and morale won't be an issue anymore.
- Higher ground does not affect archery range.
- Units that you forget to move and are attacked by archers will never fight unless you order them to.
- Warcraft III had an "attack move" action which was simple and yet effective: go there, if you encounter enemy within range attack it. In this game if you issue a move command on units under attack, they will try to avoid the fighting and will instead get slathered trying to keep moving.

[h1] SPRING 1559[/h1]

Oda Nobuhide sat upon his throne, wondering what to do next. With the recent defeat of the Takeda, his empire has entered a golden age of prosperity. Yet he realizes he must be careful of his next move, for it may cast doom upon the entire Oda Clan. To the East lie the Hojo and the Hatakeyama, Oda Nobuhides main focus for now. While the Hatakeyama will not put up much of a fight, the Hojo are the biggest threat he knows of. To the West lies the Hatano and the Sakai, who squabble over the territory close to Kyoto.


Than there is the Shogun himself. The Ashikaga Shogunate has grown weary of the Oda Clan's exploits, as his influence will continue to diminish if he leaves the Oda to do whatever they want. Nobuhide realizes the threat the Shogun poses, as all of Japan will unite under his banner to destroy all he has built. Nobuhide's son, Oda Nobunaga, has always awaited the day he would prove his worth in battle, and that day draws closer by the second.


The Oda have tough times ahead, but they will endure. They have always endured, and always will endure.

I have played many strategy games in my time just like this one. But the Total War series by far has been the most fun and easy to play series out there. Even games like Civilization have a decent learning curve involved even with the tutorial. But for Shogun, the simple and easy controls along with the great tutorial make this game a great experience.

PROS:
*Cool scenes for assasinations and other in-game events
*Simple and easy to use controls
*Balanced units
*Realistic sieges (The person defending a castle isn't OP)
*Ninjas and Metsuke are very fun to use
*Decent AI depending on the difficulty level
*Seasons that change both the overworold and the battle map
*Different battle conditons


CONS:
*Very few people play multiplayer in my experience 
*Only a few historical battles
* Ship gameplay atleast for me was very boring and annoying when i had to get into battles
*Allied AI fighting with you during ship battles tends to mess up and not do anything even after your ships are destroyed, forcing you to concede defeat
*AI sometimes doesn't take in the bigger picture, making for unpleasant encounters

Thats it, all in all i love this game and i am going to continue to play it in the future.

If you are like me, a lover of RTS but one that sucks at them, this review is for you. I bought this game back in 2011, I've never had a gaming PC, so I play this game on the lowest graphic and all those things that I will not pretend to know. I am also a casual gamer, that is why I only have 169 hrs played. However, if there is a game I wish I could play all day and without the penalty of having low capacity for the game (I can't play with huge armies, for example), is this. I love it, the fact that you have to go from province to province and capture them or make them your vasals, is an amazing mechanic, not only that, you have to be a political leader as well as a warlord. At first sight all of this sounds and looks simple, but it is not, I you are like me, you will head on to the game, thinking that it is similar to Age of Empires or any base building RTS. It is not, the fact that you have a huge army of ashigarus does not guarantee that you will win against an army of warrior monks or samurais. I know that this review is really simple an has "noob" and "casual" written all over it, but as I stated in the beginning, this is a review for people like me. 

I cannot recommend this game enough. If you enjoy war/political history and in top of that have an interest for Japanese culture, then this game is for you, provided that you also like RTS games.

This game is simply amazing!

According  to my steam i only have 3 hours, but besides steam i have around 50-80 hours, compared to most people which enjoy this game i am the biggest noob since i dont play this constantly.

Anyways here is a review for this and a bit of a backstory.
So originaly found this game cause of a relative, he showed me lots of games and because of him im into gaming now even he only plays time to time.

So here is the description of the game.
IT IS A TOTAL WAR, this company in my opinion has the best strategy games, and usually follow the same mechanics (plus new ones with each creation) so makes people get easily adapted to the game. For newcomers of this 'series', this is the best choice because it has the simplest ui which helps a lot.

So it has campaigns  ( with different clans), online which is very simular to campaign, custom battles and you can play massive historical battles (it shows HOW MUCH REASERCH they have into these games). The campaign is super good (plus the ui) and each clan has their own strengths and aswell is mostly historical accurate (like Takeda is efficient with cavalry).

Cant say anything about online because i dont play it, custom battles are fun and allows you to experiment certain units before investing in campaign and the historical are interesting and you learn history.

The system of diplomacy (big part of campaign and online which allows you to manage resources and create enemies or allies or others)is easy to understand and intuitive.
Units are interesting and varied, i saw a comment stating its impressive  how many units they created which i agree, but is good.

Objective s and provinces are accurate. Last total war with agent cutscenes (agents are like characters which help you achieve things).
Another favorite aspect of mine of this game is the MUSIC, one of the best of games, you get so into the game specially the battles.

Overhaul, even isnt my favorite game style, its the game which made me a persson into japanese culture and i love it
8/10, totally recomend it.

[u][h1]This game is so addictive.
It's the most realistic and balanced Total War game I've ever played.[/h1][/u]

[h1]Balance: 8/10[/h1]

Ashigaru are actually as good as Samurai but too bad many new players don't know that.
This is because they have weak stats but that doesn't mean anything. Their arrows are weak but they have more soldiers in one unit so that means that there's more arrows. Monks are viewed as strong soldiers. They have less soldiers than samurai but stronger stats. The only good type of monks are bow warrior monks, as they are really strong. Naginata warrior monks are just naginata samurai but with slightly more melee stats and moderately less armour.

[h1]Graphics: 9/10[/h1]

Excellent graphics for a game that's this old. Even weak PCs or laptops can run this game 30-70fps on medium graphics. The ultra graphics are also very nice and there's also DirectX11 graphic settings.

[h1]Gameplay: 9/10[/h1]

Campaign is good because you are a daimyo of your clan. You are fighting other samurai clans to become the shogunate but you also have to fight the current shogunate in order to do this. The shogunate obviously has a very advanced army. You can buy DLC as well to play as more clans and some of these DLCs also add more units for you to use in avatar conquest ( a multiplayer gamemode)

[h1]Online gameplay: 9/10[/h1]

Multiplayer. There's two different types of multiplayer: Avatar conquest and Multiplayer campaign. 
Multiplayer campaign is straight forward it's basically campaign (this also uses the DLC you bought) and you can also do Co-op campaign or Head to Head campaign. Avatar conquest is basically just online battles except you have to capture dojos on the map to unlock more units.

[h1]Loading screens?: 10/10[/h1]

I know this is a rather odd topic to review about in a game but the loading screens are great. They contain quotes from real samurai and also Sun Tzu. It also has Japanese death poems (my personal favourite) and tips about the game.

[u][h1]This concludes my Total War: SHOGUN 2 review[/h1][/u]

As I creep up on completing 1000 hours on this game, I feel this is a good time to review it. As one can tell, I love playing this game. I have been into strategy games for a long time and this one is great because it has so much to offer. Turn based strategy mixed with real-time strategy at its best. It is a lot of fun to play different clans and experience the Sengoku Jidai period of Japanese history. A lot of reviews here have already elucidated a lot about the game so I won't go into the details. For me the replay value has been worth the investment. After a certain stage in the game, it does become monotonous for any clan but you have put in so much effort getting to that point that it just makes sense to complete it. Overall, just from a replay value perspective, I feel compelled to give it a 5/5.
goooooooooooooooooooooooooooood

This is much like your classic Total War game, though this takes place in Japan. 

Graphics are quite stunning, and the campaign interface is fairly easy to use. I liked that there were less variables to worry about, (not having to think about sanitation is nice) though that's also a personal opinion of mine. Only real annoyance is that the campaign feels fairly repetitive, no matter what clan you choose. 

Battles are fast-paced, but ridiculously fast such as in Total War Warhammer; I find that troops take a much longer time to break than in other games, but are also less likely to return to the battle once they break. The battle interface is clean, and simple for anyone to use. 

Overall, Shogun 2 is a solid addition to the Total War series, it's by no means spectacular, but any Total War fan will enjoy this game.

One of my all-time favorites, I didn't find it all that hard to get used to, most bugs are easily fixed (If you even encounter any) and if you like turn based strategy and/or RTS battles, you're gonna like this one. Another great thing is that you can play co-op campaign with your friends, a thing which I find is lacking in a lot of newer games. A really cool thing about this game is that even with thousands of units on the field, you can still zoom in and see the individual fights.

A little downside would be that the AI acts weird every once in a while, almost letting you win, like one time when I sieged a castle and was about to lose and suddenly, the enemy general ran into the open, only to be charged by my yari, shattering the winning enemy forces that remained. So, the AI basically gave up the match for some reason.
There are samurai, there are also gatling guns.

If you've never played a total war game before, like tactics/politics/conseuquences in your games, like history, or just think this game might interest you. I'm going to tell you now to BUY IT. I've logged 20 hours on this since I got it a few days ago because its so addicting. It's incredibly easy to sink yourself into the campaign and become quickly attached to certain generals and provinces. It's incredibly well done and thought out. 

The one issue you should be aware of going in fresh is that the learning curve is STEEP if you've never played an RTS extensively before. It will be awkward and you will probably get your asskicked like twice in easy campaign before you get the hang of positioning, battle strategies, economy structure etc. but once you get the hang of it boy is it rewarding.

I admit that I don't really like this game that much and never plan to play it again.
Why recommend it then? It is a great title if you like the Total War style of games and the samurai era of Japan. I enjoyed that era and the game played as well as any other Total War title but the lack of diversity in the units bothered me (everyone is Japanese so all the units are pretty much the same just a different color.)

Also, the campaign, being centered around that feudal Japanese era, is way too fast paced for what I like out of a Total War campaign and I couldn't really enjoy it as much as I had hoped.

I still think Total War fans should at least try it out and decide for themselves.

What made Shogun 2 great was not a diverse roster... it's basically 1.5 rosters per entire campaign, with most units shared across all sides while a unique unit or two is given to individual factions.

What made Shogun 2 great was not flawless siege design... every single unit, even militia, can climb walls, though this at least means you don't have the infamous '3,000 men throwing torches at a single gate' flaw of Rome 2.

What made Shogun 2 great was that it kept at a narrow focus and paid attention to the details along the way. Cinematic clips for winning... fantastic art for load screens... a map that has meaningful chokepoints, ambush spots, and strategic resources and buildings. Rather than try to create numerous different unit rosters and then sprinkle them across a huge map, Shogun 2 did more with less and paid great detail to what content it provided. 

Rome 2 failed, conversely, because it tried to be bigger than what the developers had time to actually create. This was a mind-blowing flaw, given that Empire failed for the same reason.

Shogun 2 is thus that inexplicable success between two identical failures. Rather than try and have half the entire world on the map screen, Shogun 2 stuck to civil wars in Japan and did fantastically. Rather than have 100+ 'different' units, Shogun 2 had maybe a couple dozen. 

It still shocks me that Empire failed the way it did, then every lesson was learned and Shogun 2 was so good, and then every lesson forgotten and Rome 2 built with the same flawed ideas of Empire. Even with all the changes in the development team and behind the scenes, it's as though no one ever looked at the past and realized that maybe Rome 2 shouldn't be quite so big.

Shogun 2, together with Civ V, represent one of the best eras in Steam strategy gaming of all time, an era running roughly from 2008-2014. 

Shogun 2 is definitely worth a go, and while many Total War fans have probably over-rated it a slight bit, it's still one of the best games in the series, as well as a fantastic game in general.
One of the best in Total War series.

Total War Shogun 2 is one of those RTS games that they just got right, there is a lot to do even in the expansion packs and the game covers a very wide range of eras with battles to be fought in all manners of ways.

While the AI may be lackcluster which is nothing new in RTS world, its certainly not the worst out there and with mods the AI can be challenging to some degree. 
However the ability to play cooperative or two player matchup on the campaign map is in itself really cool if you have the time.
Quite frankly you be spending most of your time in battles and not on the campaign map.

The sheer playability in this game is astonishing, you can do anything from turning Japan into a Christian theocracy to leading fanatical Ikko Ikki to take the power. 
You can even make armies consist solely of matchlocks and fight against traditionalist Samurai and perhaps even win a battle. 

There are so many possibilities and so many ways of doing things, its truly one of a kind sandbox game, you shape your own story and there is a lot to do even on the campaign map, an economy to build and armies to recruit, its not just battling. Which makes the Total War franchise so unique in itself. 

After all these years, its still my favourite Total War game and I am astonished how well the graphics holds up even the old Medieval 2 still holds up in graphical department today. 
Play alone, play together or play against other humans, its all up to you in Total War Shogun 2.
10/10 Would buy again.

[h1]A strategist that respects his self, must have this game in his library.[/h1]

Harsh words, harsh truth, if you don't have this masterpiece in your collection, [b]you are not worthy of playing strategy games[/b]. Shogun 2, in my humble opinion, is the last completed, balanced and well-made TW game that was released. While Rome 2 and Atilla are good on their own ends, they are miles away from this gem of the genre (not to add they where a bit of a mess upon release).

Shogun 2 takes place in the same time period as Shogun 1, the [i]Sengoku Jidai[/i], the age of the country at war as they said. By 1545, the current Shogunate's power has dwindled, leaving the clans of Japan at each other's throats in a struggle for supremacy. Your task is to increase the power of your clan, expand your influence and conquer Kyoto to become the new Shogun. The Japanese martial culture is a fascinating subject for many people (me included) and it's a wonder to see it in action.

Shogun's armies and maps look astonishing. Each unit has incredible levels of detail, like a demon mask here, a moustache there, a crescent-shaped helm and many more. The soldiers look diverse in a way we never before saw in massive scale battles. CA raised the bar too much, with amazing season-specific effects and splendid work with the textures, especially the rain. The music feels traditional, epic, and downright dashing. It will accompany you in every battle, victory or defeat, fitting the pace of the battle and you might find yourself searching it on youtube afterwards (I strongly reccomend [b]Yoisa, Now and Zen, Ona Hei and more[/b]). It's an orgasm, especially for fans of folk japanese music. The accents and intonations of your advisors and on the map are also incredible, especially in the heat of battle. You can almost see them spittle as they scream [b]"OUR TROOPS ARE RUNNING FROM THE BATTLEFIELD! A SHAMEFUL DISPLAY!"[/b]

As always in the TW games, you got two phases: [b]the turn-based phase, and the battle phase.[/b] In the first phase, you manage your clan and make your decisions as each season plays out, and in the second one you lead your armies to glorious victory or humiliating defeat.

In the early stages of the campaign, diplomacy is a key factor. Even more so on higher difficulties, where the AI is merciless in its demands both on you and the other clans. It gives them a sense of personality: they can break relationships as easily as they come to you bearing gifts and asking for arrangements. Alliances feel fragile as every [i]Daimyo[/i] wishes to become [i]Shogun[/i], and everyone is enemy to everyone. But your "trustworthy" allies are the least of your concerns: the AI will not hesitate tou backstab you and capture your capital, if it finds no resistance. These kind of surprise attacks and army landings on your shores make the game special: [b]you never know where and when an attack will come from[/b]. When it comes to battles, [b][u]just play it on Hard[/u][/b]. In early levels, the AI is too easy to beat, forming small armies and making many mistakes in its deployment. But in Hard, it's a whole new story. The AI tries to flank you with cavalry, it's more aggresive, it bides its time and looks for weak spots in your formation. The game is merciless to you on higher settings, and you must be careful as you wage war against it.

On the downside, as much as I'm trying to find flaws, only one comes to mind: [b]unit diversity[/b]. Buying the DLCs gives you some extra, unique for each factions units, but in the end (and the basic version), every clan has the same ashigaru, the same samurai, the same monks. They differ in attack and defence, depending on the clan's traits. It gets a bit repetitive and somewhat tiring after a while, but I'm willing to look past it.

Shogun 2 is the Total War series at its best moments, and boasts the most outrageous helmets in martial history. [i]Daimyō no tame![/i]

[h1]Unique Factor: Replayability:[/h1] [b]9.5/10[/b]

[h1]OVERALL: [u]9.5/10[/u][/h1]

The Linux version of this game is much more stable than the windows version. I have not yet experienced a crash. Feral has done a very good job on it. This includes playing rise of the samurai which has always been in my experience game breakinly buggy to the point I just never bothered with it.

This being my first and only Total War game, I'm a huge fan.  I think of this as an equal blend of games like Civizilation and real time strategy.  You spend most of your time in a top down world view, expanding your empire, adjusting taxes, etc.  However you can also participate in battles and get your hands dirty by setting up your troops and directing them through battle.  This is always optional.  I usually auto resolve most battles but will take charge if I'm storming a castle and territory is at stake.  You won't get as much detail as you'd get in either genre, but there is enough of both that it amounts to a really great experience with many factions to play as.  A solid choice if you're looking for a strategy game.

While not a huge step forward in the Total War series like Empire was, Shogun 2 is a solid game for those that enjoyed the previous titles.
 
For those new to the series, virtually all Total War games play in a similar way. About 50% of the game is spent on a massive turn-based campaign map reminiscent of Risk, while the other 50% is spent in battles where you command your armies in real-time (although you can automatically resolve these). There aren’t too many games I can compare the Total War series with, although if forced to compare I guess I’d say that it’s a more mainstream version of the Hearts of Iron series.
 
Definitely worth trying if you enjoy 4X strategy games like Civilization or Sins of a Solar Empire.

This was probably my favorite in the series so far and that includes all titles up to rome II. Love using the range units so in this one it was great to sit back and just rain down arrows on the enemy and zoom in close to them and watch as they got pincushioned. Great details like guys writhing around a bit on the groud with 5 arrows in them before finally dying (though they count as dead and is just for ambience) and seeing the 700 arrows sticking out of the ground , wooden barricades and the enemy was great. Also really loved the little videos they had for assassin actions that are removed in the new ones.   

The things that really drive me crazy in this series of games are 

1. Constant upkeep fee's keeping you from building a super army for fear it will suck your income dry, because it will! I miss having a limited number of forts you could garrison in, and not pay upkeep fee's. 

2. Increasingly powerful garrison armies for defender, which is basically an army that you dont pay upkeep on, it just comes with castle and defends it if its attacked. Problem is you are pretty much always the attacker so its just annoying. In rome II its even worse, you roll up on a town with 3 units in there thinking you have a pretty good shot with your full stack of 20, and there are so many garrisoned units you are given a 0% probability of victory.

3. Imposing time limit win coniditions. I dont like having only until Year XX to win, i want to be able to take it as slow as i like and build up my cities a bit instead of just blitzkrieging across the map to victory. Same goes with battle timer (though there is a feature to turn this off). I would prefer to see the enemie have rations and how much they choose to bring dictates time in battle. 

all in all the best looking title for grand battles out there. Total war games are great fun, my favorite battles always involve 100's of fires arrows raining down in unison or catapults from an older game in series fired over castle walls and right into the middle of that squad now on fire running around screaming lol.

I had really hoped Shogun 2 would just be an updated version of Shogun, with true 3D graphics. 

What I got instead was an extremely annoying, wonky title where battles were very little fun, units on both sides moved and died way too fast, and lost morale too quickly. The multi-tiered castle-villages were back and it seemed really cool at first, but Shogun 2 actively prevents you from playing the game the way you want to play it, a problem which unfortunately found it's way into Rome  2 as well. 

You play as one of the Shogun's daimyo's, in charge of whatever samurai clan you choose. Everything is cool at first except that the game is very deliberately intended to restrict your expansion and options, using ridiculous arbitrary limits i.e food limits. If you expand too fast, your people starve and you can't afford to build any new units, despite the fact that you may literally control half of the entire country of Japan. At this point, the Emperor will order your death and EVERY clan remaining on the map will instantly attack you. Every clan will march their armies, within 1 turn, even if they came from the opposite end of Japan, straight into your capital. Even if you win legendary, epic victories against them, defending your castle village from hordes of elite units using some crappy ashagaru spearmen, the game will cheapen those victories as it tosses multiple factions worth of fresh 20 stack armies at you until you lose because you have literally 8 men.

Without mods, this game is an abject failure to recapture what made the original good. Even the little things like the cutscenes when you send ninja's out to kill someone lose their meaning, as they always fail. Many annoying things about the game have since been patched and tweaked, but still this game and it's endless army of DLC is a blight on the franchise.

If you don't own the game and are looking for a Shogun Total War type of experience, you would do much better to buy the standalone expansion Fall of the Samurai. It's basically like The Last Samurai the game. It takes place during the Bakumatsu era i.e the beginning of the Meiji restoration, during which the Satsuma Rebellion happened (the inspiration for that movie). 

It features most of the same gameplay and units, without the moronic food limit, and with far better single player and multiplayer mechanics, like being able to transport armies by train to the front lines, become a protector of a client state, and fight battles where you can use your otherwise useless fleets of battleships to provide artillery support once you've cleaned up the sea and can bring them to bay. And you don't need the main game to play it. Still, Shogun 2 is worth giving a couple of tries, if you prefer the stagnant plodding required to gain power "just fast enough."
One of the best in the Total War series.

I've recently come back to this title after not playing it in a while and it remains one of the most complete and polished Total War titles in the series. It still looks good, runs well, and has all those little features (family tree, lovable agents) that veterans of the franchise have missed in more recent releases. Some years after initial release, I still highly recommend the game to any fan of strategic, historical games. Dive in with the Uesugi Clan, get Kenshin (the God of War) to the front line, bring up those Bow Warrior Monks, and rain righteous destruction on your enemies!

The Creative Assembly team did so well with this game that it raised expectations significantly, and serious questions were asked when Empire and Rome II managed to miss their mark so dramatically. The franchise seems back on track with a successful outing with the Warhammer series, but if you have a hankering for old-school, historical Total War, this is certainly the place for you!

TBH, I actually prefer Rome 2. 

The unit variety in this game is seriously lacking. Multiplayer is good tho, but it is terribly unbalanced when playing against people with FoTS. 

Buy on sale.

I would recommend the game, but only on sale ($30-40 for ALL of the game & DLC, including Fall of the Samurai).

Why? Because the pricing is done in a way that is just irritating and unless you read it closely you'll buy half a game for what you thought was the whole game. 

Aside from that, Shogun 2 is great game, with decent visuals, audio and gameplay. I enjoyed playing it as a Total War game, in particular the combat had a fresh, dynamic edge about it.

Finally, the game does have some minor issues with the game mechanics/general stability, but modders have fixed most of these, so I would recommend getting some for this game.

I bought the game under a week ago and have already logged 16 hours. I love how balanced the game is. It is one of the best TW games in the entire franchise. I will most likely be purchasing all of the DLC as well. 10/10 would recommend to a friend.
