This is my favorite game in the Total War series. I absolutely love the amount of detail that's been put into everything from the actual character models/environment to the way honor systems, character assets (such as Ninjas, Geishas, secret police, etc.) and decisions work. It even has some neat political systems that actively effect your game, along with agricultural and social advancements. The gameplay is very nice and it also features a wonderful soundtrack to get you into that Samurai spirit. The amount of AI that can partake in battles is also very cool (literally in the thousands) and the DLC's are great and unique as well. 

The DLC's can also be tangled in with the each other and the regular game's units when creating a custom battle. The only negative is that you must purchase a DLC pack that enables gore and blood (which they purposely did to keep the game from being rated M. However, it is very cheap and does add a good look to it, should you choose to purchase). This game can be extremely long depending on how you set the camphain and which clan (of many good included options with additional DLC clans as well) which can make for literally hundreds of hours of playing. I have played Medieval II, Shogun II, and Rome II for over 100 hours each at least. Each game is spectacular. Shogun II is specatular. Although this review will focus on the bad, it needs to be stated before that to me this game is almost perfect. There are only 3 things that bother me, and really it's only 2 major things. Without these annoyances I would rate this game with a perfect score of 5/5.

There is a part in the game, which to me signifies the change from mid-game to end-game, where you have taken over enough territory of Japan that every single other clan almost unifies against you. This feels like a cheap way to make the end-game harder. All of your alliances magically turn to crap, destroying a huge part of the game to me. Instead of navigating Japan through strategic wars, peace treaties, alliances, etc the game just becomes you vs the world. Although many would plot against you, the entire country wouldn't become one like one force dedicated to eradicating you, moreso then even rival clans. That kills the realism, which is what the Total War franchise thrives on.
-0.5

The game will magically add "stacks" to the map, which means that the computer spawns generals with armies out of thin air. As far as I know this is done to add difficulty, but I view it again as cheap. I do not know if Medieval II and Rome II do this, as I have not heard or seen any evidence of them doing so. This automatically makes Shogun II the worst of the 3 games I've played. I am drawn to the franchise because of realism, and as far as I know that there has never been an army that was literally created out of thin air.
-0.5

The family tree aspect of Medieval II is gone. Well maybe not gone, but reduced. This is so minor when reviewing the enite game, but I am a tad irked that this system is not as good as Medieval II's.
-0.1

This game gets a score of 3.9/5.

I feel bad giving it that low of a score, because like I said I feel like it is almost a perfect game. However I hold Total War games to a higher standard, and comparing Shogun II to both Medieval II or Rome II I believe it is noticably lesser than either. However I have logged 100+ hours into this game, and if you are at all interested in commanding armies, or the Japanese Samurai culture, BUY THIS GAME!

Shogun 2 was my initial introduction to the Total War series and boy have they set the bar high.  I bought this game almost 6 years ago and am approaching 500 hours of total playing time and still love every second of it.  If not for about a 3 to 4 year relative dead period because of pharmacy school I'd easily have eclipsed over 1000 hours.

Its a great game that has a diverse number of options to go down whether it be army compositon, diplomacy, use agents, skill trees, etc as the list goes on.  Combat is also fun to watch and not terribly difficult to master as its not as micro intensive as some other RTS games are like Starcraft 2 which is great if you are not terribly skilled (I was Gold on SC2 and then hit a massive skill wall).

All in all this game got me introduced to the Total War series and has caused me to play other titles before and after its release but I still prefer this game above all the rest.  Its even got me interested in the Civ series which I will also be trying out as well.  Its a great game and I would recommend this to anyone looking to try out an RTS or Turn based strategy game whether they be a new to the genres or are a veteran.

Alright my original review was over simplified and really didn't express how good of a Total War game this is. 
I am a huge Japanese history nerd, but even then Shogun 2 is a shinning example of a good Total War game. Lately Total War has been releasing extremely buggy and simply broken games. I own Rome 2 and whilst I would love to play it again I literally can't because my game has broken entirely. My faith in Total War as a company has dropped to an extreme low. However whilst their newer titles have been disappointing I feel like I can still come back to Shogun 2 and enjoy the Total War experience. Shogun 2 will continue to be a staple of Total War games despite how horrible recent titles have been and I recommend this for any fan of strategy games and I especially recommend this to people who are fans of Japanese history. Not to mention this game actually runs!

Shogun 2 is, by far, the only decent TW game that has been made using Warscape engine. The AI gives a challenge in the campaign map a big chunk of the time, province development and realm prosperity saw some really nice improvements like food supplies (vanilla and ROTS only), limited building slots, taxation level penalties and trade enrichment. Diplomacy is required to survive and you will be doing more than just declaring/getting declared wars; you need trade as much as taxes. 

There's also an incredible sense of balance for all clans, given that they all have the same units and all clans differ in that some of these units have their name and are slightly more powerful. This is a big no-no for people who have played other titles and enjoyed the diversity that each faction gave; in fact playing with different factions in Shogun 2 might feel repetitive. I honestly prefer this, since Creative Assembly has proven that they tend to make some factions with extremely OP units and some factions with terrible ones when they put too many of them in a game.

Having said this, this game is not perfect. Here's why:

- Warscape engine. Really, almost every negative aspect will be related to this terrible piece of software.

- 1v1 and blobbing. If you've played Medieval 2 and RTW, you know what it means to see your units spreading out, pushing or getting pushed by the sheer mass of bodies they're fighting. Shogun 2 has none of that. You're going to get constantly trapped in sieges when fighting in a gate with your katana wielding masters against 1 unit of the weakest, exhausted of melee units because units do not have mass in this game. It's ugly to look at, and it hinders gameplay.

- Sieges. Supposed to be dynamic and innovative from your usual "storm the walls and fight in the streets" approach from the other TW games. But thanks to the blobbing, it's a nightmare to fight and requires constant AI abusing or an insulting amount of troops to get just one stronghold. (lowest of castle level)
- (vanilla-ROTS) Ranged units are like homing missile launchers. You don't even need artillery to capture a castle, just the best of archers who can shoot with god-like precision above 15 meters of stone wall and some decent melee units.

- Lack of a castle-preview mechanic. It's impossible to form a strategy and say what kind of troops/how many would it require to protect a province if I can't see the castle in question.

- AI, although the best of all TW games so far, it's still incredibly stupid sometimes. In legendary difficulty, when defending a siege, they'll keep a quarter of their troops in an area where there aren't even enemies around and let their castle be taken by timer; when attacking, they'll send 50% of their troops to scale the same part of the wall. They also tend to spam useless artillery units (in FOTS, even if they can make Parrott/Armstrong guns, they'll make wooden cannons instead).

- Difficulty settings. Directly connected to the above point; the developers knew that they couldn't make a proper AI that could actually give you a strategic and tactical challenge, so they instead gave them insane bonuses the higher the difficulty. Their troops fight better, their economy lets them have 2 full armies even with just one province. This doesn't improve your experience at all or rewards a master strategist, it just forces you to find more ways to abuse the AI.

- Unit pathfinding and individual AI for regiments is terrible as it always has been. You'll suffer it more in FOTS, where 1 soldier who got stuck somewhere makes the entire unit not able to shoot.

- Terrible optimization. Unless you got an SSD capable of storing the almost 20GB of this game, expect the game to take around 2 minutes to boot and almost a minute to load one battle. Don't get excited, however, because with an SSD these loading times get reduced to half.

P.D.: Almost all of these issues could be fixed if CA just completely botched Warscape and spent more resources on the AI department. But they won't, and they're still developing and releasing games having learned nothing of their flaws. So I heartily recommend this game because, despite it's flaws, it's the only decent modern Total War game you're going to get in years to come. It's fun, in a very casual way. Just don't expect deep strategy gameplay.

I play computer games since some years. Nowadays, I'm quite choosy when I pick the game to play, because I don't have all the free time I had when I was a teenager. For this reason, I want to maximize my gaming experience, that means (1) playing a very difficult and challenging game, and (2) playing a game that lasts a lot of time on the long run. 

Looking back to the games I've played in the last 10 years, I can cluster them into three categories, according to the number of hourse played before the game gets boring:

- Casual games: less than 10 hours played
- Ok games: between 10 and 30 hours played.

and 

 - The Games: 100+ hours played.

Now, there is no need to say that Shogun 2 Total War falls in the last category, that is The Games. I have 140+ hourse played with Steam connected, but I'm betting to have at least 5 times this value played with Steam Offline.

This game is perfect: hard and punishing on Legendary difficulty, but at the same time incredibly rewarding when you win a battle that was against all odds, just because you are good at the game. Immensly irritating when your Geisha gets busted by a stupid Metsuke, and evilly satisfying when your ninja manages to kill the hatred enemy's daimyo, or your monk incites a buddhist revolt in the provinces of your christian challengers. Let's not speak about multiple and variegate army composition, because I would speak for years. IMHO, one of the best games ever created, both in terms of gaming experience, storical accuracy and long term playability.

TL;DR

Virtually every weak point in Napoleon: Total War is addressed, and the game has become better and faster than its predecessors. However...There is one crippling problem.

HATEFUL A.I. I almost felt the computer staring down at me with hate.

The Artifical Intelligence is so damn spiteful that tiny clans will do their best to hit you in the shins even though the retribution will be painful and destructive. You WILL win the game, oh yes, but you will rarely enjoy it. 

A vassal clan will betray and ruin your agriculture buildings, even though they'll be obliterated the next turn for the offence. Even after Realm Divide hits, a.k.a SHTF-Era, your vassals will spread to take over railway territories and NEVER EVER build anything on them, mismanaging as much as they can and wander off just.to.spite.you. and deny you the railroad. And they will do their best to block economic growth and get themselves willingly killed and taken over by the enemy AI.

Just to spite you.

The high speed steam ships mean that the enemy will, kamikaze towards your shores just to deprive you of a trade route or shut down a port, and thus cost you a good amount of coin and time. And since it's the good old "Mr. No Effort in Micromanagement" AI, expect the smartest ships to pinpoint your best trade routes and slip past your defenses outdoing NORAD just to hit and annoy you with 10 minutes of repair-intercept work. Every. Turn. Actual Japanese captains would have more self-preservation instincts than the AI ships who know they are going to die horribly. Expect playing Coast Guard vs. Cubans EVERY DAMN TURN.

Same with amphibious invasions. Thank the Gods the provinces have designated disembark-only shores with such an AI.

And the targeting. Sweet God, why would an actual enemy army suddenly surge past my 4 vassals, 2 allies, risk death on sea just to land a huge f***ing force to damage my most vulnerable, rich province, diverting my forces back to desperately intercept, fail, intercept and kill by a hair's length, and spend months to repair the damage?

Mind you, I was approaching his last city and taking the undermanned city made the army disintegrate. I won, but there was no enjoyment, it's like some dirty street urchin from Fikirtepe who hits you in the nuts and runs around, throwing stinging rocks at you until you corner the little laughing gypsy and smash his face so hard he'll land in intensive care. The victory will give you no joy and only loss. (A friend did it, not me)

Strategy wise, the enemy is more spiteful then A.M of "I have no mouth and I must scream."

Tactics: Slightly better, MIND YOU SLIGHTLY,  because although the enemy attacks well, it needs to work on maneouvring. So far weak flank attacks by cavalry gets wrecked by some infantry turning and shooting, and the enemy AI goes full BANZAI to get his family killed, his army running away, only to be rebels and damage every bit of your new lands. They will lose, and they will ruin your feelings of triumph.

I swear, the game crashed when I cornered the last backside-thorn ship that had ruined my trade income. It's as if the AI is malevolent beyond mere programming.

Playing this game is like chasing down demon-possessed evil little children trying to kill you with too small knives, until you either snap from rage and cheat yourself into endless cash (not that it would even help!) or corner the buggers, only them to commit suicide just to deny you the pleasure of gutting some evil Satan's Spawn child from Hell.

Just play pitched battles with your friends and move on.

Dear Steam Rollers,

This writting is a review about Total War : Shogun2. From the writter's perspective, a thumb up is not enough to promote the game itself for various reasons. This is due to the over performance of the game itself.

Pro (+) :
+ The graphic runs smoothly without any bugs nor glitches to be found in my first 20 hours of playing.
+ The graphic can be easily configured for they provide details on all aspects.
+ The game promote historical value of how a nation is formed, usefull education is still taking place.
+ The details provided about each unit, building, and everything else are provided in its Encyclopedia, without any broken links. The level of attention to details can't be found in any other games yet to the date by the writer of the review.
+ Controls are relatively easy for beginners (The first 2 playing hours gets new players as Normal difficulty players).
+ Autosave feature is active, in case players make messed up decisions.

Con (-):
- The AI(s) can prove challenging even for expert strategist players.
- The loading screen between Global Map and province battle is quite long, but acceptable.
- Censorships on certain parts of the game.

Overally the game is over performing for a discounted price. The writer is recommending this game as "a must have strategy game" for all genre of players. Thank you for reading the review and have a good day.

Shogun 2 marked the return of the Total War series back into an era mainly focused on traditional weapons after several games centered around line infantry. Upon release, many people claimed that the series had returned to its "roots" despite the usual CA bugfest that occurs initially, though if I recall Shogun 2 wasn't as bad as Empire. I think it definitely helped that Shogun 2 focused on a single culture rather than the huge overarching scope of Empire. 

For me this is the only Total War entry that I can play the vanilla campaign on without huge overhaul mods unlike Rome or Medieval 2. This doesn't mean Shogun 2 is shy of issues and for this review I'd like to focus on the negatives of the game. Shogun 2 utilizes the same engine as Empire, Napoleon, and future TW titles: the Warscape Engine. This engine is terrible when it comes to formations and individual troop weight. More often than not, you'll find your soldiers blobbing up and sliding all over like jelly. The only times these would happen in Rome or Medieval 2 would be when units tried to force their way through a formation of enemy troops but even then there was weight to it. Soldiers pushed back, it wasn't easy to get your entire formation through a wall of troops. There's also the issue of kill animations. Many times your soldiers will engage each other in 1 vs. 1 combat resulting in animations that push the opposing soldier deep into a formation or everyone just attacking one by one. Some people defend this because "It's samurai, they had honor based combat, it fits the setting". This isn't an accurate view. During the Sengoku Jidai period these original views of battle were being broken down and mass mobilized campaigns replaced the organized "honor duels" of the early samurai. I also have big issue with morale in this game which harkens back to Rome: Total War days when a Roman legion charging into a formation of German infantry would rout them within seconds. Fast combat disallows strategy. This goes against the very genre of the game series but if you look at the recent successes of games like Warhammer, there are a lot of people that prefer this system. 

Beyond these complaints I still find the campaign fun to do and I've finished a few victory conditions for a couple factions, more than I can say for the campaigns of Rome or Medieval 2. For multiplayer I've heard great things about Avatar Conquest but being a introvert pleb I find very few people to play with on that mode. It doesn't help that I bought and played this game past its prime. The only thing I could say that I wished they added to this game is a DLC/expansion that was set during the Imjin War. But alas that historical event still evokes patriotic sentiment throughout East Asia and also SEGA is a company based in Japan.  

Overall Shogun 2 was a worthy entry into the series and resurrected fan confidence toward CA after the perils of Empire. But at the same time it was a foreshadowing of the issues that would pervade Rome 2's gameplay due to its engine. The jelly-like formations of troops could not be justified during the age of Western Antiquity.

Back at release, you'd need a very expensive beast of a computer to run this game with all its graphical options turned to max.
Now, most people can enjoy Shogun 2's epic battles as they were intended: Viewed from ground level, with the interface turned off, watching cavalry ram into bowmen, yari ashigaru trapping the cavalry, hundreds of arrows raining down, blood splattering everywhere, someone has set fire to the gates, troops with katana are climbing the walls.

Works pretty well in co-op, though you'll be spending some time waiting for turns on the campaign map until both players get used to the game mechanics and interface (then turn times can get quite short).
When you start a battle, you can hand over control of selected units to your co-op partner, allowing both players to take part in the battle even if only one of you is fielding an army.

My main issue with this game is the battels started to become very fast and arcade like.  I say started because this style of battle never went away in the new games.  Basically what I mean is the the battles go way to fast.  They can be over in less than ten minutes which is some what ridiculous.  I love playing battle multiplayer and thats waht I spent most of my time doing in the other games but this made the battles less fun.  They are also based on a rock paper scissors style.  Basically spears beat horses, swords beat spears, and horses beat swords.  Too streamline for people who like nice tactical battles.  However, the streamline easy to learn nature of these battles makes it a good game to start playing the series with.  The battles also look beautiful and the fighting is so fun to watch.  I just wish Creative Assembly would make a more real way to fight battles like earlier.  It wouldn't be that hard to do.  In earlier installments they even had a button to make the battle basic if you did want that but still kept the normal battles a feature.  

Now you may be wondering why I gave it the thumbs up but the multiplayer system in this is so well done.  The avatar conquest is such a good way of doing multiplayer battles.  Also, your units gain more experience the mroe they fight making your abttles more meaningful.  The campgain I felt was also pretty good.  I like the idea of the clans and such.  Really captured Japan well.  It's a great beginner game for people new to total war but if you are really here for instense, strategic, battles then you'll probably only play one or two campgains like me.

Greetingsa, my Shōjo and Shonen Aishgarus. This will be a quick feelings infused review from someone who loves to tackle medieval and fantasy typed strategy games. I had played some total war titles. Atilla, Shogun 2, Total War 2 and Napoleon. 
I am told Warhammer is great, as i do love Warhammer i shall get it too, once iget a better PC, and not this silly old  Laptop.

Now to review, and arigatou gozaimas for reading into introductionary line.

Shogun 2 and its DLC titles tackle three different ages of the land of the rising sun, the Japan, in its different ages of Feudality, or to be precise, Shogunate and Empire. 
Rise of the Samurai DLC tackles the years when Samurai warriors were mearly a thing to start, and Naginata spear was something more common than a katana sword. They want to become Senpai.
Shogun 2 tackles the 16th-century feudal Japan, in the aftermath of the Ōnin War during the Ashikaga Shogunate. Many clans fight for ''Emperors'' and Shoguns (the real powers) atention. Senpai notice me or Senpai let me be Senpai.
And Fall of the Samurai DLC takes on the role to represent you with units that were around messing with the last feudal days of Shogun's power, before the Emperor became again the Real Power. 

Or that is, how you actually want to make it. Alternative ends are after all, exactly the point of such games. You are mearly placed into realistical starting positions. Future, is up to you.

Make Japan all christianised? No problem. Create democratic Japan in Fall of Samurai DLC? No problem. 
Political aspect of the game is easy enough but affects the game regardless if you focus on it or not. It offers far less options than Medieval Total War 2 or Atilla do however. Especially in comparisment to later, the Shogun 2 is a shy imotou to her. 

So when you ponder whenever should you buy this game or no, let me help you. The Ai can be really complex even on easy mode. So if you seek challenge, the hardest setting will give you one for sure. For casual players, easy gives enough of brainstorming already.  It is indeed a game worth of having it played. I spent quite a sum of hours playing it, while drawing, while eating and even while cooking. 
No, not that it is a no brainer, but the game's dynamics, of it beein a turn based game, makes it so. 

So if you like turn based game and feudal Japan and you generally want to play something different than is either shooting units only Napoleon or slobered over too much and stale knights - Shogun2 with its DLC's on sale is a definite hit for you! 

10/10 would buy again when on sale. Oh wait. I actually did. And play Co-Op campaign with younger imotou.

It's hard to not endorse this game. It looks good, the battles are usually pretty solid, but the AI is just awful. There is no logic behind the diplomacy with a couple dozen faction leaders basically acting like Civ III Gandhi - turning at the drop of a hat with no precursors, flipping loyalties with no logic, and basically going nuclear all the time. 

That and the single-army-defence strategy other reviewers have mentioned. The factions always just load up one army and press until they leave an entirely undefended country behind them. In the span of 4 turns, one faction will amass a huge area and destroy multiple other groups. 4 turns later, they're dead and another faction has done the exact same thing. 4 turns later, you guessed it. While it's amusing to watch the kind of ridiculous swings in power due to broken logic, it's far less enjoyable to play.

The Total War series returns to it's roots with large-scale melee battles taking priority over gunpowder weaponry, although cannons/flintlocks are also present in the game. This is one of the best, most polished Total War games to date, and it's expansions, Rise/Fall of the Samurai, take a great game and improves upon it. The battle actions are beautifully fluid, and the blood splatter is literally so. Small touches like blossoms in the wind, incredibly varied/detailed models and a haunting soundtrack combined with a much-improved campaign AI and diplomacy system make this title not just a solid entry to the series, but a total knock-out, especially for dedicated fans who had to endure initial patching issues on Medieval II and the epic mess that was Empire. To be fair, Napoleon:TW did indeed fix alot of previous issues and lay the groundwork for this game, but it's here where you see just how impressive a Total War game can be when all the right notes are hit. 

Also, big hint: Get that Black Ship by any means necessary! Your Daimyo will thank you for it.

9.5/10, your library is a shamfur dispray without this top-tier game.

Okay, so first off: I bought this game years ago, for supposedly being the best TotalWar game.
As of writing this review, I have only played one other TW: TW Empire.


This is a good game. No doubt about it. If you want, you can stop reading here. It's well worth 30 bucks. If you don't know anything about Total War, just look it up. They're all the same.

Now, the big question is: [h1] HOW DOES IT COMPARE? [/h1]

If you're anything like me, you love TW games for the amazing potential they have, but you're frustrated by the fact that they seem to screw up the same things, over and over again. It's just.... You know, just.... *sigh* anyways...

Compared to other TW games, this game DOES improve on almost everything. (including common TW problems)

[list]
[*] Nice Graphics. Arguably the best looking TW to date. (Rome 2 blows, same engine anyways)
[*] Different FACES. Not every person is a clone! Instead, there are now about 3 clone varieties. Yay!?!....?
[*] Good Gameflow. The shape of Japan makes it easier to progress, because enemies can't invade from all directions.
[*] decent ANIMATIONS. They actually connect 90% of the time, and look pretty good too.
[*] Nice Units. Simply due to the fact that you have Archers, Melee, Cavalry, Cannons, AND muskets. Just a nice time period, - Compared to Rome (no firearms), or Empire(no archers) - thus, more variety.
[*] Interesting Tech Tree. (Although super imbalanced, as usual)
[*] nice Family management. It's nice to have a family. Makes for fun gameplay.
[*] Nice Japan atmosphere, everything you know from classic japanese culture is here. Ninja, Samurai, Geishas. Music too.
[*] extra stuff. Great art style. Great little movies that show execution attempts, SHAMEFUR DISPRAY!
[*] POLISH, (aka. few bugs, stuff just fits together, high quality feel)
[*] OK AI. That means ok. NO bullshit awful Rome 2. The AI is not retarded. It doesn't fuck up horrendously. Like 50% of TW.
[/list]

HOWEVER..... the game is not the TW you've always wanted. I'm sorry. The TW you've always wanted STILL doesn't exist.

- The AI is still pretty BAD. Just set up your units. Aggro the enemy. Defend. Win. Easy to flank. Stupid random movements. Stupid random charges. Stupid everything. You get the message. Again, I'm sorry. It's just.... *sigh*

- Naval Battles are still BORING. Like in every other TW ever made. The autoresolve is BROKEN for Naval battles, forcing you to battle manually. But then it's really easy, I mean EZ. Still not as EZ as Empire. But still, Boarding OP, as always. Go figure.

- Sieges are sort of boring too. You can just climb every wall, which kinda kills the whole siege thing, IMO.

- Shit does occasionally still happen, although much less frequently. (shit = the usual minor TW shit)

[h1] OVERALL, still a clear recommendation. For Everyone. Iz gud game. [/h1]

A real workout for the frontal lobes.

Strategy, strategy, and more strategy, and then you have to figure out how to defeat your opponent.

There is quite a bit here, moreso than just making a huge army to smash your opponent. The Total War series are highlighted mostly by the amazing combat play, but there are intricate and nuanced strategies you must master with trade agreements, political alliances, and economic management in order for the gods to favor your armies. Total War: Shogun 2 gets pretty much all of this down pat and embodies most of what is great about the series.

You can play as a number of different clans, each with their own bonuses and difficulty levels. You must then carve a path through feudal Japan to become Shogun, but be wary of other clans, the Shogun himself, and pirates on the high seas, all of which will pose serious obstacles to your goal to dominate the country. Only the most patient, determined, and steady of hand (and mind) will be able to do what the other clans cannot and take control of the region through sheer military force.

The graphics (and visuals in general are quite beautiful, and its hard to resist the temptation to pause during a battle to see cinematic shots of armed squads clashing dramatically with each other. The game board is gorgeously designed as well. The sounds are crisp and realistic, the dialogue a bit cheesy at times but otherwise dramatic and impressive.

Overall, strategy enthusiasts will love this and will want to play it again and again.

This game is quite addictive, but the game AI can be a little frustrating. For example, if you play for a long game, and you conquer around half of the required domains, then EVERYONE turns on you. It doesn't matter familial ties, if they are a vassal, trade partner, ally, everyone turns on you. Whereas, the AI can have well over half the domains you would require, and be very prosperous, and nobody feels threatened, holding onto allies and vassals.
The game mechanics itself can be very addictive and bring you back time after time. But, like Civilization, eventually you will have wars declared on you for no reason, regardless of how you try to play. Keeps the action happening, I know, and there's really only so much AI can do at this level, but after a time it makes you question the value of alliances.

That being said, I have played over 200 hours on this game alone. And it will make you work for your victories. It's worth the play, absolutely.

I started playing Total War games when Empire Total War came out. Ever since then it has been one of my favorite franchises. Out of all of the Total Wars though, Shogun 2 is by far my favorite.

Entire teritory map of Japan to conquer with the Clan of your choice. (Shimazu if you aren't a pleb). Build your territories individually when you capture them, to help build larger forces to dominate. Naval combat, Siege Combat, and Land Combat are the typical ways to face your enemy.

You can also face other real players in battle as well, if you want a real challenge.

The Total War series has always been quite unique among strategy games, being one of the very few series in the TBS/RTS Hybrid subgenre, that is both turn based and real time strategy gameplay, something that the TW series has always done well. Total War, and Shogun 2 for that matter, keeps the two types of strategy seperate. You play turn based on tha campaign map, and once you engage in a battle the games all switch to RTS. So, how well does Shogun two handle this concept? Well, you play one of several Daimyo, clan leaders, and your objective is to become Shogun by ousting the Ashikaga Shogunate from Kyoto, the capital. Almost every remaining clan will go nuts when you do this, so first you must grow in power and expand your territory, build up your armies etc.

Gameplay:
+ Customisable game length and challenge

+ Very in-depth campaign where you have to manage food supply, construction, recruitment, research, public order, Religion and more.

+ You can do pretty much everything you could want to do. You can charge in with troops and conquer huge swathes of territory, if you want. You can use diplomacy cleverly to win over clans as allies, if you want (just don't rely on them when you decide to move on Kyoto) You can build up huge amounts of money and create a strong economy, if you want. You can cheese your way to power by killing off your rival's family with Ninjas, Monks and Metsuke (Seriously, how can the enemy secret policemen have my monk executed in MY territory?) Any sensible approach to growing in power can be used, and even approaches that aren't.

+ The AI does not focus you to death in the campaign, and go after people they don't like, as you would expect if it was actually 16th century Japan.

+ In-depth diplomacy: You can declare war/make peace (duh), create alliances and Client states, offer and demand most items, such as money or land, offer trade, and even take hostages and sell them back to someone. The AI's likelyhood of accepting depends on how good a deal it is for them, how much they like you, and how scared they are of you.

+ Relationships: You can easily see in the diplomacy screen how much a clan likes you, and a simple breakdown of why.

+ Public Order makes sense. Christian converts don't like you if your Daimyo is Bhuddist, people don't like high taxes or poor level of hygiene etc.

+ Seasons have different effects, for example, in the Autumn you have more food available because it's the harvest, and troops in enemy territory take losses to the cold in winter.

+ Character development trees for generals and agents that let you specialise them. If you want, you can set a general up to be a good defender, or a good attacker, or a generalist, if you'll pardon the pun. Characters also can aquire good or bad traits or retainers, so don't keep a general sitting around for too long, or he may become lazy. At the same time, don't use him constantly, or he may become full of himself.

+ The AI makes sensible decisions most of the time

+ Realm Divide provides a decent buff to the difficulty near the end of the campaign (Be prepared to be backstabbed, a LOT at this point.)

- As with all TW games it gets a bit too easy near the end

- Agents are incredibly annoying and powerful. Every agent has an ability to remove your own agents or generals, and they can all debuff armies. Some can even take over settlements using the power of huge sums of money. The AI's tendacy to spam agents only amplifies the problem, with armies sometimes being permanently locked in place by movement debuffs. At the very least, you can give generals and agents retainers or skills to negate these somewhat, and specialise agents into anti-agent roles. 

- Territory south of Kyoto (to the left) is very linear, with only two long paths because of the mountains in the centre of that area.

- The campaign naval AI tends to simply raid you and run away if you come close, making expensive boats pointless and naval strategy nothing more than a Benny Hill chase across the sea of Japan

The RTS battles:

+ Large scale and impressive battles

+ Easy to learn, hard to master. The battles are based on a core "Rock-Paper-Scissors" concept. Spears do well against Cavalry, which do well against Swordsmen, who do well against spears. Foot ranged troops do well against anything from range but poorly against anything that catches them *Cough* light cavalry *Cough*. Mounted Ranged are a pain to catch but have low hitting power, apart from mounted Gunpowder but they're the OP exception.

+ Fatigue, Ammunition and Complicated Morale mechanics

+ High ground advantage mechanic

+ Somewhat competent AI that will give a new player a challenge, but struggles against good players.

+ Fun special units, such as fire rockets, ie Rocket Launcher Musket Peasants

+ Weather conditions have an effect on visibility and fatigue

+ SHAMFUR DISPRAY advisor/announcer

+ Very well done multiplayer battles, with a lot of depth in the "Avatar Conquest" mode

+ Very well thought out and balanced multiplayer maps, clearly designed with interesting scenarios in mind

- The multiplayer contains a fair bit of cheese, like Donderbuss cavalry, which can kill and entire army on their own provided there are no enemy musket or cavalry units left.

- Artillery is useless except in seiges because they can't move.

- Naval battles are terrible

- The Naval AI is useless

Graphics, Sound and Optimisation:

+ Looks good from the normal view distance

+ You can zoom into the battles and watch your men fight with the enemy

+ Excellent Soundtrack

+ Literally any gaming PC less than 10 years old could run this game. (Trust me, if my computer can run it, your's most certainly can)

- While good looking at a distance, it look kinda meh up close

- It looks Awful on low graphics settings, but so does just about every game.

Misc:

+ Regularly goes on sale with all DLCs for £10 (75% off)

- Blood is only available in a DLC to lower the age limit.

Overall, a very well done RTS/TBS Hybrid, and one of the best in the series. Would recommend to anyone who likes strategy games

Best total war game ever. I was a bit indifferent with the standard Shogun 2 campaign, but the Fall of the Samurai DLC makes this game better in every possible way. If you liked empire total war and napoleon total war, this DLC is an immensely improved version. It's set in 1868, the Boshin War, where the Shogunate falls to Imperial Japan. There are line infantry, riflemen, cannons... Adding on from Napoleon total war, you can use your ships to bombard the enemy on the campaign map and DURING THE BATTLE. It's amazing. Unless the enemy uses it on you ;).
Pros:
The AI is much better in this game than the previous ones. 
All of the ships are steam powered, so naval battles are faster. 
British, United States, and French troops are avaliable to use. 
Your allies are actually helpful, they may fight with you as you all fight for the Emperorer or Shogunate and they hunt the enemy and take regions. The Imperial army is superor because they use more guns and cannons. This also means you may be fighting two different faction armies in one battle, but maybe some allies will be nearby to help. 
If you have a ship in port that is attacked, the port has cannons on the shore to help you.
You can use a train to transport troops over long distances (if no one is blocking the railroad)
When I play Rome total war, I like to play as Rome. When I play Napoleon total war, I'll play as France, usually. This game does not have an obvious choice... The imperials are easier campaigns and the shogunate campaigns are hard. I have more of a desire to explore the other factions.
Management of provinces is very easy... Unlike Attila where you have to worry about food and disease as well as public order... Realistic? Yes, but very burdensome. 
Cannons in this game are a major improvement from Napoleon total war.
The game is all-around good. I mean, I'm just listing noteworthy pros.

Cons:
Autoresolving ship battles almost always results in an unnecessarily large amount of damage to your ships, no matter if you are an ironclad vs a small wooden 12 gun boat.
Garrisons regenerate immediately. If you attack a settlement and kill almost all of the garrison, but run out of time or barely lose and attack next turn, the entire garrison regenerates while you do not... :P (also means your garrison regenerates too, so let your garrisons die first
You have to play fast enough or you will not unite Japan in time. I do not understand the importance of getting done by a certain time, but I had 1 more year left and needed 7 more provinces, so I had to blitz all of my forces to every enemy province. I got the last province in the winter. 
The armies in this game seem to move quite slowly which may be due to the fact that this campaign spans over just a few years.

If you like empire total war and napoleon total war, you'll love this game.

After playing Mideval Total War and MTW2 for years, I stopped for a while, and started back again with Total War Shogun 2. It is 5 in the morning. I have been playing TWS2: Fall of the Samurai for almost 10 hours straight. I'd like to provide a summary of my experience thus far.

Having started in Satsuma domain, I quickly expanded outward from my two provinces (the southernmost in the main islands). At first, I was near destitute, and my armies were feeble. However, I had a cause: my clan was deeply loyal to the emperor, and two shogunate supporting clans also called my island of Kyushu home. Thankfully, the barbarians began infighting, and one quickly destroyed the other. As I moved northward, I met two more neighboring clans on Kyushu: the Saga and the Hirado. At first they wanted nothing to do with me; I was poor, and a bit of an upstart. The Saga even refused to trade with my clan. Any form of military alliance was out of the question at the time. However, as the Hirado clashed with a shogunate clan which had crossed the Kammon strait into Kyushu, I began to further develop my infrastructure, rapidly developing my infantry and artillery, and building a firm economic base, all while ensuring my populace stayed happy. Soon, just as I was preparing to capture a chain of islands along the western coast of Japan, I was able to secure my first two proper military alliances (I already had a vassal clan, which treacherously attacked me during a period of military access I had allowed so they could move their troops to attack a warring clan), and my newfound friendship with my fellow Kyushu clans was, to say the least, extremely exciting.

Jump forward a few hours — Having advanced from Kyushu onto the main island, conquering and forming new alliances, I am now the Satsuma Imperial Vanguard. My treasury now contains well over two hundred thousand coins. My armies are undefeated. My allies look to me for direction, all of us loyal to the empire, carving a path through shogunate-held Japan.
 
The Hirado never moved far beyond their two provinces in Kyushu, but we maintain very friendly relations, and their navy is an integral part of our campaign; as it stands, they hold a heavily fortified island off the western coast, from which they launch naval raids, and occasionally send large invasion forces to skirmish with the enemy.
The Saga, on the other hand, took strong initiative. They boarded ships and gained territory up and down the south-eastern coastline, and are currently making an ambitious offensive far in the north, having already captured two provinces from the shogunate vanguard and gaining us a valuable foothold deep in enemy territory. 
I've gained new friends too! The powerful Yamago, whose armies continue to seize land from the shogunate; the steadfast Tokushima, consistently repelling enemy attempts to strike into our territory; the witty Tosa, a valuable trade partner that keeps the Imperial Forces' coffers brimming. All that have stood before us have either fallen, or joined our cause.

As I watch my forces cleave through the enemy, flanked on either side by close friends and allies, I cant help but think to myself: holy shit I need to get to sleep.
In my opinion, the best Total War game to date. Fall of the Samurai is an amazing expansion, and adds a lot to the game.

I'll recommend this game a thousand times over, I've played Ages, Starcraft, Civ, Total and Planetary Annhilations, the Strongholds, just about every RTS you could think of except the Warhammer series, (Including Total War Warhammer, I still have Rome 2 to master and Attilla, which I have both just busy on other games.), and I can tell you that the only game that comes close, is 'King Arthur - The Role-playing Wargame', (Except the archers in that game are a little OP to the point where they have a button to make them less OP lol), but any ways, this Total War will take you through the magical land of Japan, and will bring you to the brink of annoyance attempting to win your first campaign. The learning curve is quite hard even for an advanced RTS player like myself, but once you get the Taxes, Political side, and the Battlestage down, and have an understanding of whatcities give you what power ups, it'll be hard to lose, I don't really enjoy online because let's face it, people are d***s, but the offline aspect of the Total War series is simply amazing, if you can manage to beat the computer on the highest difficulty ;).

This is a story, about me and the Mori.


Once, two great nations lived at peace with eachother, and though they waged war against all around them, quickly rising in strength, their alliance was strong. The Mori, masters of the sea had access to many resources, and would gladly trade those resources in for military support. The Hattori, with a booming economy and vast armies needed the resources to help build up their strength even more, and so, both nations prospered. 

Untill one day,  the Mori broke their truce, invading the Tsuitsui clan, a vassal of the great Hattori kingdom. And so the Hattori marched on, into sovereign lands, capturing three cities until the Mori had begged them for mercy. The Mori posed no threat to the powerfull Hattori, yet still, the latter found it in their hearts to let the traitors live. The Hattori formed an Alliance with the Takeda, and the Mori did so with the Shimazu. Though the Mori still owned 12 provinces, with the Hattori owning only 8, the Hattori's swift guerrilla attacks made sure there was no lord, no daimyo, and no heir left to the monarchy. 

The Mori were cut down like dogs, and the Shimazu would soon join them, As the Hattori marched on the Capital, taking it all in under a day's work, the Takeda and Uesuegi tried to stop them, but it was all too late. 

I was victorious, and declared the Mori to be royal cunts.


Seriously

This whole game has absolutle no historic accuracy, not only CA got most clans' specialities wrong, diplomacy and relationships between different factions are also messed up. Some powerful clans didn't even exist in this game, some clans had never been independent are equal to their masters here, and some clans existed in the wrong time. So anyone who plays this game shouldn't expect to learn any historical knowledge from Shogun 2.

CA also made most units look the same. The major differences between each clan is the color of soldiers' uniform, some special clan bonus, and few unique units, but this game is still quite pricy with all DLCs.

Shogun 2 Fall of the Samurai (FOTS), is a fun and engaging game. It combines engaging real time battles and an interesting historical setting for the campaign. As someone new to the Total War Franchise, I found the battles particularly different, but in a good way. Not everything is well explained in the provided encyclopedia, but once you learn what everything is and how to manipulate it, the game is quite fun. Do note, that purchasing FOTS does not allow you to play the original Shogun 2 campaign. FOTS is a standalone expansion.

Great Game. Great Graphics.

The "best" in terms of AI and gameplay but in campaign its total trash. Don't bother with alliances in total war games. In this one something called "Realm Divide" is just a fancy term for everyone will declare war on you and try to kill you. Even if you sucked up to one other nation the whole game through it won't matter because they will hate you whether you are shogun or whatever. Way to much micromanaging and the AI will actively and obviously cheat at many points but atleast they use ships to land on shores in this game unlike in NTW/ETW where the AI was honestly retarded. 

Don't forget to keep nanbans out no matter what!  They are totally worthless and not worth the Christian bastardization on your Asian Nation. You will just end up with late game civil war.

Its a shame that such a cool games campaign is such shit. Realm Divide mechanics are neither fun and are just overly challenging on fucking Normal! There just to much infuriating about the late game campaign to recommend this one unless you really like the setting. I have nearly 100 hours in the game and I can't beat the campaign. By "beat" I mean conqeur all of Japan, since this is how I play Total War games. Was fun ruling the entire world in ETW

I got about 2/3rd of Japan under the Oda banner and was Shogun when Christianity and my panic in needing money and men earlier in the game came in and shit on everything I was having fun with doing.  My entire nation has started getting pissed because apparently Buddhists and Christians just absolutely hate eachother so much that they want to rebel violently against one another. Its just such stupid shit and theres nothing I can realistically do before the revolts will undoubtedly start to come. If I get rid of some divisions of my army the Otomo Homos will come my front but if I do nothing the Christian Terrorists will Terrorize my rear. Im fucked. This is every god damned single attempt I have made at this game, shit just falls apart. The fact the Otomos are just throwing tons of Metsukes,Priests, and Ninja at me and just killing everyone besides my generals makes it impossible for me to fucking do anything about converting the populace.

Its fucked. Theres nothing I can do and this is how every single game ends. Being shogun has no real gain because no one cares that you have Kyoto, in fact that will make them hate you even more. Becoming and allie of the Shogun is also completely worthless because if you hit Realm Divide he will hate you again. Plus he dousn't do anything anyway.

I didn't like it when it came out, and now that its patched up its better but its still a terrible campaign to play in.  Its just not fun after you hit a certain point around Realm Divide. If anything Realm Divide is just an artifical difficulty and is contrary to the game rules before it. Its the "Shit we can't make better enemies and AI that will actually put up a fight, fuck it fam, lets just make the whole country go to war with the player. I'm sure that will be hard" Its like boxing with a brick wall, hard.

I'm sure I'll get some smart asses who will say  "I beat it durr, noob" or some iteration of that to what I will respond that you probably got lucky. Sometimes the AI will get confused and not respond correctly or in time or you just abused some meta game stuff.

One of the most polished Total War games to date, re-playabilty not at his best since basic units are the same for all clans, still there are so many layers of strategy to be applied in every battle or campaign that you'll never run out of fun with this game. Right now probably the best purchase of the serie if on sale. Strongly recommend the DLC Fall of the S., back when a Total War DLC was a stand alone game easily worth the money requested. Even Rise of the Sam is not bad at all. Mods are just awesome. Multiplayer wise just the best of the series with a little RPG element on the Avatar conquest just to increase depht and spectrum of choices. No really OP units to date, even veterans are not OP and a lower rank player can enjoy some great win against them if able to properly exploit the weakness of a more experienced but also more expensive build. 
Talking here just a fan of strategy, used to have a retail copy of Medieval II and that's what I've grown up playing. Best Total War game besides Medieval 2.  
Pros: 
- Multiplayer Campaign, which Medieval 2 does not have
- Good Unit Mesh when fighting, again a plus over Medieval 2
- Excellent Graphics
- Good Agent Interaction and Diplomacy
- Fun Time Period
- BLOOD SPLATTER PACK
- Overall Game feels great and a blast to play

Cons:
- Not Much Unit Diversity
- If you play multiplayer skirmish, or manage to get into a game, only experts play now
- Historical Battles aren't great.

Overall one of my favorite games of all time, and probably the best total war to start with for new players because of the limited unit diversity.  I would buy this game again over any of the other total wars.

I know this review is really late, but I'd like to throw in my two cents. This game is a great insight into Japan's Warring States Period, which involved treachery, honor, and a whole lot of arrows. For all the gamers (and honestly, the majority of people) out there, who are too lazy to sit down and read up on Japanese history, this is an extraordinary oppurtunity to kick ass and learn a thing or two about Japan's hilarious history. The entire Total War franchise has managed to masterfully capture the essence of strategy gaming, and also display a fascinating overview of Japanese history. All in all, I recommend buying and investing time into this game.

the best total war to date

Probably the BEST total War title so far. That includes Rome 2 (which does not come near the quality Shogun 2 has). 

Splash Screen Issue:

Unfortunately, I had a Crash at Splash Screen issue for years. After years of frustration CA tech help figured out it was the web browers plugins. If you cannot start the game I recommend the following: 

1. Uninstall. 
2. Get rid of ALL plugins. Including ad blockers. 
3. Reinstall and verify game cache (just to be sure). The game ran for me. And should run for you. 

About the Game:

The units are interesting. The map is beautiful. And battles are fun to watch. Things make sense. You can be outnumbered but still are willing to watch your lone samurai fight to the death because it is exciting. I cannot say the same thing for Rome 2 or any other total war title. 

The cinematics are on point. Rome 2 got rid of agent cinematics. Shogun 2 reach new hights. They are funny. They tell compelling stories. And they are serious. No matter how many times to use an agent, it is interesting to watch the movie. Shame Rome 2 got rid of them.

It was with great surprise that I played SHOGUN 2 and found it simply one of the best games I ever played.
I did not know what to expect from a Japanese-setting game, perhaps biased from being from Europe.
Quickly I fell in love with this game, because everything in it is close to perfection.

The historical notes, the stunning visuals, the great campaing map and magnificent audio tracks. 
A campaign is most fun to play, and every faction contributes to a totally different game every time you start again.

Definitely play SHOGUN 2, especially if you are a fan of turn-based strategy games.
You will not be disappointed.

Very well executed for a Total War Game, but the time period and area's foreign culture may make it less interesting for those unfamiliar with Japan. The only flaw with this game is the engine that it is built on. While older Total War games ,such as Rome: Total War and Medieval 2: Total War, are built upon an engine that allows armies to properly take a numerical advantage, Shogun 2's engine makes this impossible and replaces it with good animations as soldiers duel each other. This effectively makes Well-trained soldiers more valuable than a mass of decent troops when unit stats become the only thing to determine victory as troops wait in line to duel the enemy.

An exceptionally good strategy game that will hook you for long hours.

If I was going to tell someone to get a Total War game, it would be Shogun 2. There is certainly no better value, I would recommend people wait for the game to be on sale with all the DLC included.

It has hours of replayability, the AIs are better than other Total War games, and the graphics are good enough to compete with Total War games which are 6 years newer. The dueling and battlefield animations are fun to watch. You can customize the names of the units and places. It doesn't have the wonky town system of earlier titles. The "storymode" like avatar system in multiplayer is fun, the maps are varied and interesting, and the pvp is competitive. The style, artwork, and the in-game voices immerse back into the years of the Shogun.  

If I were pressed to think of something lacking, I would say the factions all feel too similar for my tastes. The differences between them really only matter on legendary difficulty.

More than anything though, the game is simply fun to play. I would definitely recommend this game!

It's an amazing game, but there's an issue with this game only using a single core. It's sort of gamebreaking, especially with large armies and the movement drops to a frame per 5 seconds. To be clear, the game itself is not lagging - I can pan the camera around the map at 60fps, and do everything else fine. But the units' movements and attacks themselves are very very slow.

This game is old, very old by game standards. Not ancient, but old. Yet me and my friends find hours of fun in it today. Recently, we started several campaigns, in varying partnerships, and all have been incredible. Teaming up to siege a city of Ronin elites using armies of our peasant filth, winning only with numbers. Planned routes of conquest, sending each other massive loans, and periodically taking out each others ninja's. The fun is never ending, and everytime we open this game, the time just flies, and we soon discover our turns have taken hours, and we now have 6 hours until school starts, but it is all worth it. By far my favorite of the Total War Series, Fuedal Japan has something for everyone, and you should definatly buy this game, especially now that its on sale!

If you've never played a Total War game now is the best time to start. Creative Assembly have gone back to their roots to the place where it all started. Shogun 2 is a highlight of the series, with an excellent, cohesive use of the little details that define each Total War game. Simply put, it never feels as if an element is underdeveloped, or requires a gear shift. Fundamentals like unit balance and progression, seasonal effects, trade, diplomacy, and Agents each fit together as well or better than any other game in the series; the smallest things, such as fog of war, movement, safeguarding your backlines - stuff that just make a strategy game easy to jump into - are especially strong. Though later games have added great ideas, evolving the series from lite wargame to hybrid 4X, I don't miss them when I replay Shogun 2. 

In short, if you're new to Total War or skipped this one, you cannot go wrong with picking it up. Highly recommended.

Easily one of the best Total War games around (if not THE best); To the little details on huge battles to detailed units and just completely beautiful dynamic battlefields (stuff like siege weaponry may leave devastating results). Fantastic artwork, sound and music. The game can feel really fast paced and intense, even though the overview map (the entire map of Japan) is held on turn-based movement. The actual combat may be fought in Real Time (slowest option, as you'll enter the battlefield) or decided by AI (quickest option as you'll only see numbers ticking down). Battles, wars or even territory defenses may be decided by how much you move (or how much you COULDN'T move) your units in the overview map.

Quite honestly, if one is to get into the Total War franchise, this game is a fantastic choice as it'll familiarize the player with the Total War mechanics (in general, like how the overview map is handled) and it'll introduce its unique quirks along the way (specific Shogun 2-bound mechanics, like the turn end time jump).

In short, this is a title for those who like a mix of Turn-based movement and RTS-style combat, as to not mention the historical period. Even though it achieves its 5th birthday as of this writing (and with Total Warhammer out) it is still a very memorable game.

P.S.: Don't forget to get Fall of the Samurai expansion pack, not only it changes how the RTS is played by an entire new way (either via Singleplayer or Multiplayer) it also adds boasting rights (defeating a well armed 'Modern army' or 'Fall of the Samurai army' with a 'Traditional Army' or 'Shogun 2 vanilla army').

Hands down one of the best games I've ever played. I honestly cannot come up with anything to say about this game that would detract from the expirience except the minor imbalance when it comes to naval units. Having a navy in the base game of Shogun 2 isn't very important and usually doesn't dictate much of anything. That being said, Shogun 2 offers an immensely enjoyable gaming expirience. While it may seem daunting at first, Shogun 2's game mechanics clicked for me quickly. Now I could explain the economics, military and political aspects of the gameplay without breaking a sweat. It all just makes sense. The graphics are stunning, the voice-acting is superb and the amount of freedom you're given as a player is fantastic. The expansion that the game does emphasize is Fall of the Samurai, a fairly big step away from Shogun 2's main body and into an almost entirely different style. While I can't say I lean either way on the DLC I can say that anyone who enjoys Shogun 2 and the other Total War games would likely find Fall of the Samurai a very enjoyable expirience on top of the base game. This is also, to my knowledge, the first Total War game to natively include a co-op campaign playable at launch and a customization system for generals which is fantastic. I can't reccomend this game enough but there is one sticky issue. I think Steam's price is a little ridiculous. I'd reccomend anyone who wants to purchase Shogun 2 for the least amount of money possible go to G2A and purchase it via their website. G2A can occasionally have problems but honestly it's around 5 dollars on there last time I checked and I can't say that giving Valve any more money than you absolutely have to is something I condone. 

tl;dr: Amazing game. Fall of the Samurai is definitely something Total War players will likely enjoy. Don't buy on Steam unless you love CA, purchase via G2A for a massive discount if you feel comfortable doing so.

[This review is for TW: Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai.]

My hours played speaks for itself. 1,020+ hrs played and I still come back to this game. Rome II has been out for almost a year and I just couldn't get into it the same way.

I love the 'family tree' feature in this game. Being able to look back at the end of a long campaign, with my Daimyo(clan leader) now 53 yrs old, having started the game when he was 18, it's a great feeling. To remember the past battles, close calls, the sacrifices etc.  It really helps build that immersive connection, so that you actually care about your clan and your armies.

Like all games, this one isn't perfect. The multiplayer could be better. I'm a big stats type of guy with a game like this, and I really felt like the end of game stats weren't as informative as they could have been. For example, when you look back through the history, it says "Won battle on this date", but that's it. I wish it said which general and included all of the stats for that specific army, etc.

If you've never played a game like this, you're in for a treat. Obviously, like every other game you spend money on, you should watch some youtube 'Let's Play' videos to see what's really in store. 

The top-down strategic view is nicely done, coming from the Civ series, it wasn't hard for me to get used to. Having the option to enter the battles in 3d is just fantastic. These battles can be absolutely epic and it's a joy to watch them unfold, especially when you're the underdog.

Now to be honest, I got my ass handed to me during my first campaign. I didn't read any tutorials and I jumped right in without paying much attention to some important bits of info. The starter clans differ in difficulty, for starters. Select auto-management for Taxes at first, this will help in not becoming overwhelmed as you add more cities to your clan's dominion.

That's all for now. Grab this game if you're a Civ fan that has always dreamt of actually entering the battle in 3D!

As far as I'm concerned, this is the height of Creative Assembly's time with the Total War series. Shogun 2 takes the ideas and lessons they've learned from the previous games, including the mistakes of Empire and Napoleon, and have ironed them out to a playable level. In fact, it's more than just playable, it's absolutely amazing. The base game pits you as the leader of one of many clans during feudal Japan who are all striving to become Shogun, the military ruler of Japan. You have to balanced your budget while making sure your people are fed and expanding your territory by conquering your enemies and making allies. Each clan has their own unique traits which you can use to your advantage while taking on the current Shogunate which adds a lot of depth and complexity to the strategies that you can use. Where this game falls short are in a few bugs and one of the two dlc expansions. The biggest complaint that I have about the A.I. in this game is that, being a Total War A.I., it is a bit on the derpy side. Enemy armies will randomly break formation and mill about from time to time, the enemy general will occassionaly try to take a heavily defended settlement with a tiny force, and cav units will always turn and fight if even just one of them gets caught in melee while trying to disengage. It's little bugs like that can make you get frustrated at the game, but not enough to make want to stop playing.

As far as the dlc goes, The Rise of the Samurai was massively underwhelming. All it really added was some new unit types and some new abilities for agents. Otherwise, it was essentially the same map as the base game and didn't change up the gameplay all that much apart from siege battles no longer always being in a castle and being a bit more like sieging small towns in the older games. Despite that disappointment, however, Fall of the Samurai is fantastic. It adds in ranged units, such as line infantry and better variations of it, while still allowing you to build more traditional armies comprised of katanas, yari, and bows. The different time period and different kinds of units completely changes up the gameplay and the strategies of the game, and is arguably more difficult simply because of just how different units can be from faction to faction based on their allegiances.

I would highly recommend that anyone should get this game.

This is possibly the best Total War title in my opinion. I think so because of it's unique (and in dire need of return) Avatar Conquest Multiplayer and replayability in it's campaigns. Each clan has it's own strength, and furthermore have different advantages when it comes to taking over the world map, whether it be through diplomacy, assassination, or all out Total War. 
Even though it lacks in the department of the modding community, not to the mod authors, but the resources they are given to work with and their ability with those resources to change the game. 
I have not encountered a single hacker in all my time playing over the past couple of years, and i can say that the people who play this game often can be very hepful to new players, especially when it comes to composition of the Shogun 2 Armies and Fall of the Samurai Armies in muitplayer. If you like Total War, or any RTS, you should definitely check out this title, it has a lot to offer!

By far my favortie Total War game to date, I've logged around 700 hours and have all dlc. The beauty of Shogun 2 lies not only in splendid graphics, but also in gameplay not seen in many other Total Wars. Unlike alot of the other games Shogun 2 presents a rather uniform recruitment roster with the exception of one or two unique units for each clan (excluding special factions like the Ikko Ikki in Vanilla and Aizu in FOTS). This likeness between factions really puts an emphasis on actual battlefield tactics rather than just having statistically better units (looking at you Rome 2). I would also have to mention that Fall of the Samurai is by far my favorite campaign (and dlc) Total War has yielded and is one of few dlcs in the series that actually adds mechanics not seen in other games (like naval bombardments). Overall I would give Shogun 2 a 9.5/10 with just vanilla and dlcs, but the mod community bumps it up to a 10 with a wide variety of campaign tweaks, unique units, graphic enhancements, etc.

[h1]He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces.
He will win whose army is animated by the same spirit throughout all its ranks.
All warfare is based on deception.
[/h1]

Shogun 2 is an exceptional strategy game that is supported by it's powerful atmosphere as it enters the Sengoku period. It's soundtrack also attempts to tie in a Japanese cultural theme, while also sounding a bit interesting. Graphically, I think the game also looks pretty decent. You're given the objective of taking over Japan in it's days of constant war, to become Shogun. You'll be able to make allies with clans that, historically, would have fought you to the death, like making allies with the Uesugi as the Takeda. There's even a multiplayer campaign mode you can play if you want to conquer Japan with a friend, or against one. It's also quite immersive, thanks to the way the game presents every detail, such as a general's speech before battle, which changes as they grow more experienced.

The game follows the premise of total war, strategy becomes key in most battles.
The rules of the game are simple, break your enemies on the battlefield. 


The main goal isn't to kill everyone, but to be victorious and conquer. You can even watch the carnage on the battlefield, as the melee combat's visuals have greatly improved in the series. There's even naval combat, which also has some immersive details, like the sailors singing a song as the row towards the enemy, or burning the enemy ship and even boarding them. There's a lot of strategy, both on and off of the battlefield. In battle, most of the choice belongs to you, as your men won't give themselves orders. Off the battlefield, you will be making deals with other clans, you will be betrayed by allies, or you will betray them, and you will make unlikely allies in times of war. You will also trade with anyone because you will be poor after everyone tries to murder you. You'll revive clans that have been defeated by conquering their homeland and making them your vassal. You may even be defeated yourself in an attempt to overthrow the Shogunate.

As the player, you are given absolute control over how you secure victory. There is no hand to guide you, other than your own, and you decide everything, like army composition, the strategy you employ, and how you plan to stab the others in back. There is much depth to the many aspects of the game, there's even an encyclopedia that explains the many things about this game, including the history of certain units, the function of skills that may be used in battle, and other various literary material. 


Now, let's get into detail about combat. 
It's fast paced and rewards decisive actions and quick strategic thinking, so there's a ton of micro-management.

Well, unless you pause the game, but then again, there's still a lot of decision making.

The UI makes it easy to understand the strengths and weakness of individual units, so you won't need to do research off the battlefield. Just hovering over the unit tells you what characteristics the unit has, so even novice commanders can play new units to their strengths, and many units provide interesting mechanics that expand on the gameplay. For example, a spear wall neutralizes enemy charges and is particularly deadly to cavalry, but it is incredibly vulnerable from the rear. Nodachi samurai have a lethal charge, but they can't hold out in a sustained battle, and katana samurai are powerful anti-infantry all-rounders. Naginata samurai are heavily armored and are strong against cavalry, but are slower than other units. Ninjas can use stealth and throw bombs, making them perfect battlefield assassins.

The terrain and weather makes an impact on the battlefield too. If it's raining, fire arrows won't work, and more soldiers will slip off the side of castle walls when making a siege. Trees can conceal enemy forces, or perhaps you can use them to set an ambush. Gunpowder units can't fire over terrain like arrows can.

Morale plays a huge role in the Total War series. In fact, it might be one of the most important thing in the series.
Units with low morale will rout, causing chaos for an army. Psychologically breaking the enemy is key for this reason, as it could lead to defeat or victory, as it has in many real battles. A good commander knows when and where to strike, and how to do it as well. This is where that extra layer of complexity comes into the game. A decisive charge, for example, doesn't just kill troops. It breaks the troops in the unit when they see their friend get butchered. When a whole unit routs, other units watch in fear. A good commander exploits that knowledge. He doesn't just break them one by one, he tries his best to break all of them, and under the right conditions, it's very possible. Conditions that [b]you[/b] can set up. 
Now, combine that decisive charge from earlier with a barrage of gunfire to the enemy, and then, combine that with the fact that you've just ambushed and killed the enemy general, and finally, put everything you have at the main force of the enemy and return victorious as you cut down the cowards.

[h1] Welcome to Total War. [/h1]

( End of the review for Total War: Shogun 2. )

Below, I will briefly discuss the DLC, which should help you decide if you want them or not.

[h1]DRAGON WAR BATTLE PACK[/h1]
It's about the legendary samurai Saigo Takamori, and you get to live his famous battles.
Saigo Takamori was probably one of the most influential samurai of his time, so if you're interested in the Boshin War, check out this guy on the internet or something.
Anyways, this DLC isn't worth it because it is only six battles. You're better off with just getting Fall of the Samurai, because Fall of the Samurai comes with this anyways, along with a campaign and multiplayer.
In terms of length, it took me about 3 hours on very hard, if that means anything to you.

[h1]Rise of the Samurai[/h1]
In my experience and opinion, nowhere as interesting as the base game and Fall of the Samurai, as those two were simply more interesting eras, personally. It's just that the Sengoku period and the Boshin War were far more unique in terms of history. However, the thing is, if you prefer melee combat with bows instead of lots of gunfire, you may enjoy this over Fall of the Samurai. There's also a bigger emphasis on diplomacy, so there's a lot of political stuff going on. Agents are also different, and provide a different gameplay experience. Consider this DLC if you hate guns and love political intrigue.

[h1]DLC Units[/h1]
Now we can move on to the 'Unit' DLC packs. Those, in my opinion, are quite ridiculous. Instead of adding extra unit variety in the base game, CA decides to put these units as DLC. This is why some people consider the game's multiplayer to be pay-to-win. Now, can you win without any of the DLC? Absolutely. I've beaten plenty of Fall of the Samurai avatars and heavy DLC Shogun 2 armies with the base game, before buying the DLC, but you get a lot less options when it comes to strategy as you don't have the flexibility that the other guys get. Now, is the DLC worth buying for pure 'fun'? I would say so. The units are more fun to use and generally they add a bit more spice to the game, even if you aren't playing multiplayer. However, it's still disappointing to see that this is where the Total War series decided to go all-out with the DLC milking, and it has gotten worse with every other release.
