I want to start off by saying that this game is amazing. One of the best strategy games I've ever played and, that's saying a lot. I specifically purchased Shogun 2 over any other Total War title because of the campaign game modes and because I have a strong love for Japanese culture and the Sengoku Jidai period specifically. It is well balanced, has strong core mechanics and the game modes are a pleasure.

Ok. So now that is out of the way... I honestly cannot recommend this game because it is broken and the people in charge of fixing it have zero intention of doing so. Five years later we have two expansions but the game still crashes at random intervals. Some people can't even start the damned thing.

Even if you can get it running long enough to play, good luck reading any of the text. Even at 1440x900 all the in game text looks incredibly pixelated and some of the characters will bleed into each other making it almost impossible to read certain things. If I didn't know any better I would honestly guess that this is some sort of terrible console port. But, it's not. As much as I hate to say this, the way the game runs now and with the price they are charging it's really little more than a scam. You pay $30 for a game that you can only play for five to ten minutes at a time.

TL:DR:Final Thoughts:
After five years the game has two expansions but is still nearly unplayable and there's no word from the devs. It is incredibly fun for the five minutes you'll be able to play it so maybe pick it up if it ever goes on sale for $5 or something. Otherwise it's a complete waste of your money. Pick up Attila instead. That game actually functions.

First off, let me get the cons out of the way.

There's a lack of unit variety. Every faction will come with the standard spear, sword, and bow units.
Some special units can be worthless, and a waste of time to work up to.
The AI is a high improvement over Empire, but it still has flaws. In battle, it will always try to flank your units or go for your general. This can be used to your advantage, if you're smart enough to catch them, but otherwise it's a nuisance.
The map might not be a lot, in comparison to the Europe-central Total War games, but thankfully, there are mods to fix this.
There's an imbalance in the player's growth versus the AI's growth, on the campaign map. You might capture three or four settlements, only to see that already a fourth of the map is painted in one clan's color.
To add to the imbalance, the AI can capture and hold at will, without any penalties. The player will incur penalties when they capture cities.
Pretty much by the end of the game, everyone will hate you, and there's nothing you can do to convince them not to.
Castle battles can be boring, and an assault can be more frustrating than fun.

Now to pros.

It's the most solid Total War game to date. It's the perfect example of strategy, and it truly emphasizes that aspect.
Every clan has added benefits for various units. The Shimazu clan, for instance, has better Katana Samurai than any other clan.
A MASSIVE amount of modifications that are beneficial for the game, especially at the time of this writing.
Agents are very useful, can be improved to your liking, and are not problematic, unlike later Total War games.
The lack of unit variety means battles are more dependent upon skill and strategy, which is perfect for a Total War game.
It is satisfying to overcome the odds of every Japanese clan breathing down your neck after you take hold of the Shogunate, and watch that sweet victory cutscene.
The AI can pull off some game-ending moves right under your nose on the campaign map, if you're not careful, adding to the difficulty.
The DLC is actually worth it, and it's not as harsh a policy as later games are.
Multiplayer, even though I have not played it, has been the most well-received in all of the Total War franchise.
Various improvements for ranged infantry that put it way higher than Empire.
Much friendlier game to enter into the series through, than Rome II or Attila.
Diplomacy is at its best in this game, allowing for marriage, hostage exchange, and setting military access or embargos.

If Rome II feels like a step down in the series, or you're a newcomer to the whole idea of Total War, then step right up to Shogun II.

In a lot of ways, Shogun 2 represents the cleanest, most polished of the Total War series. It's very balanced, intuitive interface, solid AI, interesting tech, and clearly defined goals. The unit art and animations look great and hold up well. The strategic map is pretty with a great interface to help you avoid "losing" units and armies like in previous versions. Playing through the main campaign is a challenging treat. 

Once. The biggest problem with Shogun 2 is the lack of variation between the factions. Each plays very similarly and is largely comprised of the same units. I suppose it's historically accurate considering the much smaller theater of Japan (versus Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia in Medieval and Rome games), but it really squashes the replayability. Additionally, having such tighter objectives makes it a much more linear Total War game. You can approach the capture of Tokyo in any order, making and breaking alliances along the way, but with a smaller landmass, minimal unit variety, and a singular objective, you'll have seen pretty much everything in your first playthrough. 

All told, it's a great game and a lot of fun. The graphics are solid, it runs well, intuitive UI, competent AI. But lack of replayability makes this arguably the least "value" game of the Total War series. Pick it up on sale.

Japan is in turmoil. I am chosen (I chose myself) to help unite the Japanese under the flag of Chosokabe and end the war. I made allies along the way, and we started winning ground. My generals grew into giants, crushing our foes long the way. Then all of the sudden, I am betrayed! All my allies turn, the neutral tribes attack me and all of the sudden things are going to shit.

I lose cities here and there, my generals are assassinated by som lowlife scum from the mountains of Iga and my armies are scattered. I am furious.

All I wanted was to end the war in Japan and bring peace to this great nation (also to unite the Japanese, so we together could wreak havoc in the rest of Asia). But after this betrayal I must get revenge. I plan a new strategy, train new armies and set out on my campaign with a new goal and more determination than before. I take back what I lost, I tear armies and factions apart, I execute everyone I can and slowly I am winning.

Through many years I lay waste to my enemies, and roll over Otomo, eventually the last remaining faction. I now control all of japan. 

I then put my final part of the plan into action. I march all my armies and all my generals onto the fleets and sink all my ships. I tear down all buildings in all the cities, and get rid of all my priests, emmisaries and ninjas. I raise all taxes through the roof.

It takes one full year of no military to keep order, no buildings to entertain and keep my citizens calm and sky-high taxes to enrage the population in all cities to revolt. After 100 years of war, turmoil and death, we are now back to where it began, all the tribes ressurected, all ready for another 100 years of war.

I played this game for the free weekend not having the kind of hardware I would have liked but I can't forget the experience for certain. It was large scale battlefield tactics depicted with artistic realism like I'd never seen. Don't go by my hours as I did play this from another source as well not tracked on steam and it was incredible. Don't come into this game expecting Mount And Blade or Civilization. That's not what you're getting here. You're getting the strategic battles at the division level that marked the Edo era of the Japanese feudal era and beyond. A civilization that along with Sun Tzu's Art Of War perfected battlefield tactics and an entire honor system based upon skill, honor, will and most importantly, the Budo and Bujutsu. Sometimes referred to as the Casus Belli in the west but not to be mistaken for the public opinion because Japanese Budo much like the Tao, is not based upon what people think of a warrior. It is based upon what is right and the warrior's ability to comprehend it and sacrifice based upon that concept.

So take to the battlefield with that attitude in this strategy game and you might survive battle though it is a strategic game in which the principles of the Art Of War apply at the tactical level to battles already in progress apply. The graphics are pretty but not the entire selling point here. As the Daimyo or Shogun it is the use of resources, the understanding of the Bushido and the flow of energy on the battlefield that will determine that. Great mystique and gameplay. Great history but there is something subtle going on under the hood here. It is the way. The Budo. Will you be savages or will you simply be, letting the Budo and Bujutsu mould you into a formidable fighting force. Stategy and tactics are words, and cannot describe the flow of battle and that's precisely how this game feels. 

I absolutely recommend this game for stategy buffs drawn to Eastern philosophy and warfare tactics. It is another SEGA masterpiece and that is not a paid advert in any way. It would shame me and SEGA to lie in such a way. When battlefield tactics are your calling get this work of art.
Great game. Must have...

[h1] Part of a great series [/h1]

The Total War series have been always among my favorite games. Rome, Medieval, Medieval 2 and others. Being someone who has played the previous 2 installments before shogun 2 extensively, what I can definitely say is that shogun is the first truly modern total war, resembling the series more recent titles, a lot more then the previous ones. Shogun however is a stand alone itself, retaining what made total war great immediately prior to this game, and adding many mechanics that a modern player of the series would recognize. Shogun however is the Ferrari of the total war series. Everything from the graphics, to the smoothness of how the game handles, and controls. Shogun is very under appreciated, due to it being limited to just Japanese style warfare, but this game truly does handle much better then stupid Rome 2 and much more balanced combat than Attila or Warhammer. Heed my words.....CA has failed to make a total war this good when the game was on a subject that more people would be interested in. Shogun mp was the most unique experience between all the total wars thus far too, since you can basically make your own faction with your own colors and unique units. Many features from this game need to be brought back, it would really save the mp in future total wars.

Your choice same results.

>Playing as the Saga in Fall of the Samurai
>Fiercly loyal to the Shogun.
>At first, I follow traditional bushido; not using guns, railroads, telephones, keeping to tradition.
>Nothing of great interest happens, I conquer a few provinces...
>All of a sudden, someone I'm fighting has Line Infantry equipped with modern musket rifles, and parrot cannons. 
> Steel my men, Bonzai charge. They're cut down by a hail of gunfire and cannonballs. 
>Dishonored forever, I see the writing on the wall; the old way is no longer viable, I must be victorious.
>Begin modernising, building factories, mines, commercializing my farming, and yes, adopting rifles.
>I switch my loyalties to the Pro-Modernization Emperor.
>I control the only port permitted to trade with the West. 
>I use that to my advantage. I import British marines and even buy an Ironclad Warship.

>This is it, the final battle between the Shogun's Forces and the Emperor Loyalists. 

>The Shogun is using elite katana samurai, cavalry, and expert bowmen. They're much more experienced than my men. They've dedicated their lives to perfecting the Art of Bushido, the Samurai Code. 

>The Shogun's men charge my line.

>My Gatling guns begin to crank, filling his flanks with bullets, Samurai begin falling in a giant cloud of blood. 

>My main line lifts up their muskets and fire, peppering their entire army with rifle fire.

>I order my Armstrong Cannons to begin punching into their main force. 

>It's a massacre. 

>I win, easily. 

>Get up from my computer, contemplating that I was willing to give up my integrity in the name of victory, but in the end, I lost moreso than the enemy I had just defeated.

>Spend the next thirty minutes smoking a cigarette outside on my padio, looking at the trees and the sky. 

>I have dishonored myself forever, and this game has shown me that I was willing to betray who I was, what I cared for, just so I could win. I vow to change myself.

>10/10 would change my entire life around again.

Although it lacks the complexity of some of the more recent Total War games (there are no army stances) and the building trees are mostly the same for every faction (since it all takes place within roughly the same culture), Shogun II and ESPECIALLY Fall of the Samurai is/are still my favorite Total War game(s). The music is great, but can get a little repetitive. The combat is excellent and you can do a lot with different tactics, unit types, etc. The addition of naval bombardment and the modernization mechanic (in Fall of the Samurai) helps to make the Meiji Restoration come alive.

I'm a huge fan of Warhammer and think that the setting is perfect for a Total War game, but I still believe that if you can only buy one Total War game, get Shogun II + Fall of the Samurai.

I recommend this game to all Total War fans and players new to the franchise.

Worth it on sale? Yes

Otherwise, it's yet another hallmark of the decline of total war.  The AI is awfully bad, worse than Napoleon and Medieval.  It's horribly predictable and bugs out at the slightest hiccup.  

Siege battles are ridiculously buggy.  The climbing wall mechanic was an awful idea.  

AI can walk straight past your armies on the campaign map, even though you can't do this to them.  Also as is tradition in total war games, agents are a huge pain because one guy can block an entire army's attack if he happens to be standing where they wanted to fight.  

There are a myriad other "features", but the game is overall fairly frustrating.  The only upside is it was the first game to have a working co-op gamemode.  Fighting against your friends is fun... but as I mentioned, sieges are still a pain due to climbing wall mechanics.

Before I go anywhere let me say that Total War Shogun 2 is a beautiful game. My greviances are few but valid.

 The first is the absence of any form of matchmaking for the competitive matches. When I say matchmaking I mean that if I'm a one star rank I expect to be matched with another player of the same rank (maybe one star above). That way its still a challenge but its still fair because you have the same men they do. What I do not want to see is a one star player with access to only small army sizes (limit of 5000 gold) and basic infantry units (me) being matched against a max level player who has access to mounted rifle and foot rifle infantry whos stats far overshadow mine. As well as all the other "modern" units found only is FotS.

 My second issue is with the AI and campaign setup. You can pick any faction on the board even an "easy" one and regardless of your choice your outcome will be the same: defeat. Why, you either run out of time (the most common occurence as your starting year is 1545 and you have only until the year 1600 (I think) to finish the game. With only 4 turns per year (one a season) you only get 220 total turns to win. Or you expand fast enough and get most of your provinces but your income dries up because, for some reason, unlike Rome II your recruitment buildings don't provide garrisons, with the exception of very few, which leaves you with only one way to keep your towns safe, train more troops, troops who will do nothing but sit in your back towns and eat your income until you're forced into the red and see all your money drain away. This of course isn't including the AI which will ally with you just to declare war on you two turns later or break their trade agrements the next turn. The AI is also immune from all negitive public order penalties. They won't have food shortages, officers loyalty won't decrease, and towns will never rebel. (keep in mind this is on easy) These goodies are reserved for one person...you the player. 

So if you want to get ripped apart play Shogun 2 if you want even a remote chance at victory try ANY of the other Total War titles.

I recommend this game to all fans of the Total War series because this one is one of the best to play. The battles run smoothly and the mechanics are good. All modes in the game are good and the units are unique to battle against.

To be frank, total war Shogun 2 is a vast improvement from its predecessors in nearly every respect, unfortunately I cant help but find it hard to recommend due to the limited scope of the game. Shogun 2 is entirely confined to Japan alone, whereas prior Total War games (Medieval 2, Empire, and Rome in particular) allowed you to conquer entire continents. If you enjoy the era, and can appreciate what I view as a somewhat limited scope, then by all means get this as its fantastic in most respects, I however, cannot recommend due to what I personally appreciate from the grand strategy genre.

Great game.

A very unique and balanced TW experience, and the standard that all TW games are held to. Unlike other TW entries, Shogun does not take place in an environment of a multi-national conflict, but exclusively in the isolated archapelago of medieval Japan. Clans have extremely similar units compared to other TW games, but geographical position, various clan bonuses, and fantastic pacing, combined with the system of a balance of power and realm divide, make a truly unique experience no matter what faction that you choose to play as. Want to become the naval and trade superpower of Japan? Choose the Mori. Want to lead a thunderous charge against your enemies? Lead the Takeda into battle. Prefer to unlock the mysteries of the West, and use the sciences of Portugal to your advantage? Play as the Otomo. Unlike other TW games, there are no bad or boring factions, because there is no feeling of being locked out of options like in the Rome series, while still keeping factions diverse enough that the factions still feel sufficiently different, unlike Empire.

Post scriptum- buy Fall of the Samurai, ignore Rise of the Samurai.

Let me start off by saying, I had never heard of the Sengoku Jidai in all of my years studying history before playing this game...but it is now firmly cemented as the most badass time period in the entire history of the world. Samurais, ninjas, guns, and every man for himself country-wide warfare. 'Nuff said.


This game can be brutally challenging. I've attempted 9, I beleieve, campaigns and only one has conquered all of Japan. The others, except for my current one, were all failures. As such, this game has a real sense of danger and you legit feel like you're fighting for your clan's survival. Nothing is more heartbreaking than watching your beloved daimyo kill himself as his armies are slaughtered and the empire you worked so hard to build crumbles. However, that does not mean this game isn't a blast, far from it, actually. Shogun 2 is a complete masterpiece. The art, the music, the combat, the strategy, everything is so beautifully done. Besides, half of the difficulty comes from mods I've downloaded, and there is always the option of playing on Easy, which makes things more manageable. I ecommend this game to anyone who loves Japananese history or intense and exciting strategy.

Me and a friend started up a coop campaign. I was the Takeda and he was the Uesugi.

After we started the game he reminded me (because I hadn't played the game much) that pretty much every unit in the game had a spear and my focus was cavalry. foooooook


So I start the rise of my great empire like any other great empire by sending off one of my two generals to die in a hopeless battle to remind me that literally everyone in Japan has a pike so why the fuck am I still using cavalry.

Undaunted by the loss I decide to fortify in my province of Kai. I begin training some Ashigaru and upgrading my stables and lands. My Uesugi ally does the same, except he isn't stupid like me so he actually has an army. Inevitably the clan he starts at war with enters his lands. But then winter sets in so they decide to leave cause they can't handle a few snowflakes.

A few turns later and my ancient enemy of like six turns has been conquered by my ally's ancient enemy of like five turns and they declare war upon me. That's alright Takeda shall stand strong. Too bad my other ally, the Imagawa, decided they don't wanna be friends without benefits anymore so they fuck off. That's alright I didn't need them anyways. I still have my ally at Uesugi and his vassal.

Well when shit hits the fan, it hits the fan hard. The Hojo, my southern neighbor, seeing my decimated army as a weakness decrare war. Fuck. I am now surrounded by enemies so I decide I'm just gonna be a bitch and hide in my castle. In a few turns the Hojo send an army to my border and I prepare for the worst to come.

However, they change their mind and decide that fighting me is too hard so they go pick on my ally's vassal and they get wreckt n shrekt. And to make matters worse the Anegakoji have invaded Takeda lands to the north and are pounding on the gates of Kofu.

The Daimyo has decided enough is enough and sallies out of the castle to meet the Anegakoji. While their army attacks the castle, the Daimyo's son, Yoshinobu, leads the cavalry out of the eastern gates and surges before the enemies rear lines crushing their archers, killing their general and delivering a crushing blow.

With that army defeated we prepare to face the Hojo horde that is bound to arrive from the east. However news has arrived from the Uesugi. The Anegakoji to his west have invaded but were ultimately crushed by their army. However to make matters somehow impossibly worse it would seem the Ikko Ikki have taken over Etchu and are now waging war against the Uesugi, all seems lost.

And yet from the jaws of defeat comes victory and survival. The Uesugi have decided that they are going to abandon everything in their captial and assist me by taking Shinano to my north. I say he's bloody mad and going to lose us the game. He says that it's ingenius and to shut up.

Regardless I have no say in the matter and can only watch from the edge of my seat in terror as two armies appear on his border as soon as he leaves his capital undefended, one from the Anegakoji and another from the Ikko Ikki. It would also seem at this time that the Hojo have decided to invade Kai and an army appears on my eastern border.

First to the fight is the Anegakoji to the southwest of Uesugi. They are torn asunder and retreat back from whence they came. But now the Hojo attack Kofu and I must prepare myself. The Hojo arrive at the city having torched the valley behind them my Daimyo gives a heroic speech and decrares we shall take no prisoners.

We meet them on the open field of battle. My Yari Ashigaru, who form the center shall be the bait for my trap, charge the enemy head on uncaring of losses. They strike the enemy with the force of a tidal wave and yet it seems that it barely put a dent in their line. But it matters not, for my Katana Cavalry have arrived on the enemies left with the Daimyo's son to destroy their line. And yet even they do not have enough of a force to rout the Hojo. So I order my Daimyo to attack with the two thirds of the Takeda cavalry.

Cutting through the enemy like a death star through alderaan we completely destroy the Hojo army with barely a hundred fleeing the field of battle. However it comes a great cost with nearly all of our horses killed and half of the Ashigaru dead, it is a pyrrhic victory in every concievable sense of the word.

However we do not despair. Our Uesugi allies have taken Shinano to the north and somehow retaken their capital from the Ikko Ikko army that had captured it. And so we begin to rebuild our force and in time advance through the valley to the east intent on returning the favor to the traitorous Hojo.

After reaching the border we spot the enemy army on a range of hills to the north. And so we advance upon them our cavalry yet again giving us a glorious victory. However terrible news has come from the west. The Imagawa sensing that our capital is undefended decrare war against us. And so the Daimyo's son races back to Kofu to save the city.

The Imagawa are at our walls before we know what has happened. But it seems that Yoshinobu has arrived with the Takeda cavalry just in time. With the Daimyo leading the defense of the city with a small Ashigaru garrison, some given to us by our ally Uesugi, distract the enemy spearmen at the walls while our reinforcements come in from behind. Looking to be a repeat of the earlier siege I begin to celebrate but then realize that those are indeed hundreds of spearmen charging at my cav.

Taking but inflicting heavy casualties upon the Imagawa I pull my cavalry back to the east gate with barely a total of thirty living. However, upon cresting the hill I notice a massive horde of enemy Yari Ashigaru approaching. Deciding that I'm going to go out on fall of the Samurai levels of badassary I charge the enemy with my thirty horsemen.

Miraculously the very first unit my horsemen encounter on their charge it the enemy Daimyo. And after about ten seconds of fighting he is slain. This causes the enemy army, which is about 40 times larger than my horsemen to shatter and rout. Amazed my Daimyo charges to save his son n friends from any remaining foes.

Having lost nearly my entire army in the battle I decide to be a bitch again and watch the Uesugi. My ally has once again abandoned his captial, which once again is under immediate threat of invasion by the Ikko Ikki. He conquers a towny held by an enemy I didn't even know he was at war with and runs back to defend his capital just in time yet again. MOFO is a lucky sonovabitch.

Destined to be eternally stuck in my capital the Hojo are attacking again and it seems the Imagawa aren't far behind.

I defeat the Hojo army in the open field yet again with my cavalry taking minor losses and fall back to defend Kofu once again.

But this time was not destined to be like the others. Yoshinobu, like a well practiced routine, takes the cavalry to destroy the enemy from behind. Everything is going well enough to plan. Enemy archers, dead. Enemy spearmen, fighting but losing at the east gate. Enemy cavalry dead from a prolonged engagement.



Somehow, t'would seem. The enemy general, by himself and himself alone, has snuck into the castle and is now twenty seconds away from ultimate victory through pure bullshit and luck. But no, I can make it! I order all of my forces inside to banzai the general and retake the tower. Beginning their charge I can only watch in desparation then horror as I realize they won't make it. With barely ten paces between my troops and the enemy general the timer reaches zero. And I lose my only city.
Very fun and unlike many other total war games the AI can get very powerful and actually pose a threat!

After 15 hours of gameplay I have gone through the tutorial and won a long campaign on normal difficulty. Shogun 2 is a very good Total War game. The AI behaves itself to a satisfying degree. Feudal Japan is a very interresting time period. The different units are weighted against each other in a nice way and the later units are clearly better than the early units.
On the down side, I have had some bad experiences with the fleet battles (no surprise). Also, the automatic resolving of battles can sometimes be a little stupid resulting in a vastly outnumbered force commits seppuku instead of defending their fort.
Something to note is that the game world is much smaller than in most other Total War games. This means that every clan with a fleet might launch a naval invasion on you even though they live on the other side of the map. It also means that the lenght of a campaign is severely shortened.

In my opinion, this is the greatest total war game to date. Even with the new release of warhammer. The base game is amazing. It is creative and fun with lots and lots of replay value. Also, the map isnt this huge thing that takes weeks to conquer. The dlcs are also great, I love both rise of the samurai and fall of the samurai. The graphics are good and the game is pretty balance. If you find something unbalanced, many modders have worked hard to make changes that fit to your specific needs. Again, I have loved this game and if you like grand strategy games or strategy in general you will likely like this game.  To date this is my favorite game for pc.
Best Total War game hands down, instant classic and deserveing of all the praise it gets along with its expansion too.

One of the best total war games, the only thing that stops me from saying it's the absolute best is that I haven't played all of them.

A really fun grand strategy / turn-based game, what sets the total war games apart from the pack is that not only do you manage your country (or in this case, clan) you also get to control your units in battle, whether you're sieging a castle, being ambushed, or fighting in an open plain.
There's a great amount of unit variety, and there's fun additional features such as espionage with ninjas, which helps make each campaign fun.

The game can be a real hardware pig, so be warned if you have a weak computer.
Otherwise, it's a great game to play if you like strategy games.

P.S. The Oda clan is op.

I like to split Total War players into 4 diferent categories. The campaigners, the multiplayers, those-who-are-so-unskilled-they-have-to-fight-an-actual-battle-against-the-AI-on-easy (It's a bit of a mouthful to say that category.) and a category that don't really have a name but enjoy pitting, for instance, 7000 Samurai against 2000 Royal Marines (That example was from FoTS.) I personally am a combination of a multiplayer and that last category. The multiplayer is *%?$ and they seem to have adopted a more of an avatar system which means that the player must work long hours to do anything other than a Yari Ki spam army comp.  The modding for campaign seems to be in abundance with all sorts of modifications available from Steam Workshop. But I disliked vanilla Shogun 2! Just didn't suit my needs. But when on a last hope I would get at least some of my money's worth I got FoTS and JESUS that turned the game into the best game I've ever played for that last category-thingy! So, I recommend this game only if you get FoTS (Fall of the Samurai DLC) and don't just play Vanilla.

P.S The More blood DLC is crazy but quite funny to play with and it's relatively cheap, I think!

I fell in love with Rome: Total War in high school and have been a follower of the TW series ever since. I'm also generally interested in the Sengoku period of Japan, and so this game scratches that itch like no other.

If you haven't played a TW game since Empire, you should know that the intricate and frequently convoluted "traits" system for named characters like generals, spies, and clergy has been significantly dumbed-down, sometimes for the better. No longer do you have to move generals out of your starting cities for fear of them picking up the "Bad Tax Assessor" traits simply by virtue of your starting cities having low population (and thus, low tax income). Character traits are now chosen by the player when a character gains a level (for generals, by winning battles, for agents, by completing missions), and they are all positive, giving bonuses to many things. This eliminates the frustration found in Rome where you basically needed two classes of generals, one to lead armies and one to govern provinces. The Chivalry/Dread mechanic from Medieval 2 makes a sort of return, with each general having a Loyalty score and your Daimyo having an Honor score (the more honorable your daimyo, the more loyal his generals). Honor is decreased by looting captured cities and not coming to the aid of allies in war. Honor can only be increased by use of a skill point at level up (up to a certain point) or making a rival clan a vassal of yours (which is actually possible in S2, unlike previous TW games where the computer-controlled factions refused to accept even the most obvious defeat). 

Each faction has some unique benefit and units, with some being more useful than others. For example, the Hojo clan can build castles more cheaply than other clans, making them good defenders, while the Shimazu clan are known for their skilled swordsmen, recruiting and maintaining Katana Samurai for less money. While the unit rosters are quite similar to one another in the base game, the styles used by each clan make playing as every clan a distinct experience. DLC adds the ability to play as unusual clans like the Ikko Ikki, who follow a unique sect of Buddhism at odds with conventional Zen, and the Otomo, who benefit from embracing Christianity by making good use of Western-style guns.

The religion aspect of the game is relatively simple: apart from the Ikko Ikki, every clan is either Buddhist or Christian (Catholic, presumably), with the vast majority being Buddhist (Shinto is mentioned, but doesn't really play much of a role, since Zen Buddhism was widely embraced by the samurai class). Depending on who you play as, religious revolts can be either nonexistant or an almost constant hassle, as trade with Western powers will introduce Christianity to your lands in exchange for powerful firearm-wielding soldiers. You use your religious agents to convert enemy provinces to your religion, demoralize enemy armies, inspire your own armies, and bamboozle enemy agents by forcing them to question their beliefs. 

Espionage is handled by ninja, who act as spies, saboteurs, and assassins. Their skill trees allow them to specialize in one of these fields, and they get the added bonus of short FMV films of them going about their missions. Success will give you a front-row seat to a cunning attack on the enemy general, and failure will get you a hilarious (though often fatal) view of the ninja's incompetance.

Speaking of soldiers, the relative homogeneity of the clans gives rise to a familiar pattern with units: swords beat spears, spears beat cavalry, cavalry beats swords (with outmaneuvering and charging from behind), spears beat cavalry, and ranged attackers plus enough distance can shred anything. While some might find this tiresome after a while, I actually like getting the chance to refine the tactics used for a given army formation. There are also highly-specialized units like Kisho Ninja, Naginata Samurai, and Fire-Bomb Throwers that you will get occasional use out of, but for the most part the tried-and-true strategies hold fast (hey, samurai were usually pretty traditionalistic, what do you expect?).

The AI of the game has been drastically improved since Empire, though not always fairly. AI-controlled factions will attempt naval invasions and tend towards the aggressive side, though astute observers will notice that the AI tends to create enormous, expensive, and highly-experienced armies from nowhere. Having a minor clan suddenly garrison its capital with an army of 2000 samurai which it couldn't possibly afford is quite common. Some people like that for the challenge it presents. I for one don't like the AI having advantages via cheating, but that's what mods are for, and there are plenty of mods to address virtually every aspect of the game.

Finally, there is one sticking point that a lot of people who otherwise love the game hate, myself included. The goal of every campaign is to become Shogun. The current Shogun doesn't like the idea of anyone else usurping that position, and so once you have a certain level of fame (increased by conquering land and winning battles), the Realm Divide happens. The Shogun declares you an enemy of the state, sort of like in Rome, except here, every faction in the game starts to hate you even if they've never met you. Your trusted allies might stand by you for a little while, but they inevitably turn on you. Even your vassals, who you allowed to live just to prove your generosity, will attack you in short order. The prospect of the middle to end of the game featuring an unavoidable, endless, economy-killing war turns a lot of people off. Sure, it's Total War, but coupled with the AI being able to spawn free-upkeep armies and navies out of nowhere, it comes off as a real "screw you" to the player. You're being told to be always focused on conquest and expansion, while really you should have been focused on building up your economy so you can be self-sufficient, all while under a time limit based on what length of campaign you selected. It can wind up being very frustrating.

But again, there are mods for nearly every aspect of the game. And for a tactical game about the Sengoku Jidai, I know of very few that give the epic feel of Shogun 2. It has its flaws, but I love this game and keep coming back to it.

One of the better Total War games.  Featured in a Japenese setting with a fantastic sound track and some great art work.  The setting is very well done as you explore the map with your massive army.  Replay value is pretty decent as you can choose to pick different clans to fight as.  The graphics are pretty good but can get demanding when fighting with a huge army.  The best part about this game is the real time tactical combat with thousands of troops.  Raiding or defending a fort with a huge army can be insane.  This game is can get very hard though.  You have to take a lot of land over in a certain amount of time to win and issues will come up whether be it hunger, war, or lack of finance.  Forsure recommend this turnbase/real time strat game to any fans of the genre or any fan of the Total War franchise.

I have Total War: ROME II & Total War: ATTILA. Those games I mention have excellent graphics but shallow gameplay, dumbed down and streamlined features. I tried to love those 2 games, even my hours playing is on 100 hours for each. 
I have played Total War since the original Medieval back in 2002 (14 years ago) and those 2 above are really boring and I regret purchased them.

Then..

I bought Total War: SHOGUN 2. Just 6 hours and can say that this is the best Total War title Warscape engine-based to date. Much much better then even Total War: ATTILA. Very deep, challenging and have family tree as well. 

Simply, this game stand in the same elegance as ROME: Total War & Medieval & Medieval 2: Total War.

I definitely wouldn't say this is the best game in the Total War series, as the 'Realm Divide' event in the Campaign ruins the fun considerably and the Graphics are a pain to optimize. That said, it very enjoyable up until that point.

It's worth it if you're a fan of the Total Wars and buy it during the Sales, but if you're looking for the best, buy Napoleon Total War - It's flawless.

Shogun 2 is an amazing game. The vanilla game is a blast, especially if you *sigh* buy the blood pack. Not a big fan of having to pay for my ultra violence, but it is worth it on sale to watch your little minions hack each others limbs off in a spray of food coloring.

The clans all use pretty much the same troops (with some minor differences), but have pretty good differences in perks for each clan. How you expand and push your advantages is up to you, and diplomancy isn't half bad. Some of the DLC clans have extremely different playstyles, which makes for a far more interesting campaign.

Rise of the samurai is a nice throwback to olden Japan, where your troops are almost purely peasant levys and not the armies of pure samurai of the vanilla campaign. Your samurai are far more valuable, like the knights of the middle ages. And when they engage in warfare your samurai earn considerable respect. Where the game falls kind of flat is the war of the different factions. Unlike in vanilla where each clan is it's own side, in ROTS you instead fight for one of three factions trying to win over all of Japan, and it becomes somewhat confusing who you should support and who to slaughter at times. Some of the units feel very underwhelming, and the special characters don't feel as tight as the vanilla campaign.

Fall of the samurai however... oh my. The game enters what many have mentioned is the "Era of Tom Cruise and the defence of the mighty sword of Japan!" You enter a civil war between the Shogun of Japan and the Emperor of Japan. Western half is 'mostly' in support of the Emperor, while the east supports the Shogun (there are exceptions of course, and people can jump ship if they feel their side is losing). Your naval combat is pretty fun, with steam boats on the way towards a semi modern navy, and while your army will likely include rifles from the civil war era of the USA, they sadly cannot fight worth beans in melee. This allows for a yari formation to essentially slaughter your line troops if they manage to close.

Makes for alot of fun battles. Rifles are not the amazing tool you instantly expect them to be, proving that a warrior with a spear and courage can kill someone with a rifle who has none. Cannons make a solid showing, starting out as wooden cannons that amaze me that they don't simply blow up, moving towards proper heavy cannons. Naval warships are also vastly important as they can provide naval bombardments, giving you solid artillery support when attacking a settlement or enemy in the open if you have a fleet close enough to shell them.

This makes having at least a decent naval power essential for attacking strongholds, as while yes you can send your troops to rush the forts... you likely will lose tons of troops to entrenched rifles and spears. If you have played Empire/Napolean... don't expect your tactics to work here. While yes there are alot of rifles here like in those games, you have to treat your riflemen like archers of old. You cannot storm a keep with these men, instead leaving that side of the load to your spears/dismounted cavalry.

If you get this game, and don't want to sink a ton of money the vanilla game is a blast. If you want to try out FOTS, understand that it is a standalone expansion meaning you can buy it without having to try out Shogun 2. The multiplayer is also a blast, and as you level up so do your troops.

Get this game, will give you many many many hours of enjoyment.

Having played this game for like 200+ Hours i gotta say i'm giving it a 100% good review and i will explain why i recommend this game to anyone who has interest on Japanese History. 

Pros
- The game has an authentic array of units at its disposal
- The campaign is so realistic than anyone who controls Kyoto shall be involved in the Realm Divide wherein all the family clans in Japan will become your worst enemies
- The best thing about Shogun is the agents. Why? is because they can make a difference in the game like Sabotaging Armies, Committing Arson and Assasinating Generals and Faction leaders. Aside from that they can administer settlements and apprehend spies from other factions
- The movement points that you can build a railway to easily transport armies across Japan
- The General can rally and inspire wavering troops that are falling back 
- Lastly offcourse no Total War game would be complete without the battle. The battle has a new animation system that you can even see Samurai decapitating enemy warriors and blood splurting all around the battlefield.

Cons
- I can't think of a bad review for the game the only thing that bothers me is the price of the DLC's so if you want to play this game better buy it on Sale just like what i did.

Shogun 2 is probably a contender for the best Total War game ever released so far. It brought entirely new mechanics, a perfect atmosphere, the most tactical battles we'd seen in a long while, coming with a huge roster of specialty units and lots of campaign diversity. It introduced provinces with bonuses, army stances, physical reinforcements following your armies from the area of recruitment and so much more

A milestone of gaming, not just for fans of Janapese history, but for fans of each and any RTS ever. One of the most important and revered entries of the Total War series.

Speaking from 10.000+ hours of Total War, this was the second most fun I personally ever had in any total war game. Especially with the addictive and complex multiplayer, levelling your units and giving them special traits.

Also, Shogun 2 featured the hands down best sieges the entire series ever had.

Shogun 2 allows you to be a Japanese general in the midst of civil war, and it is one of the most authentic, fun, and challenging games set during this period. There are many different factions to choose from, although almost every faction has the same units (with differently colored armor). My favorite part of the game was the Custom Battles option, where you can choose a map, weather, and time of day, determine your units and those of you opponents, and fight. This means that you can make crazy battles; I created a battle solely of ninjas and generals, for example, which was entertaining. The units have different tactical formations and powers that you can use, and the individual soldiers have been recreated with great detail. They also speak in Japanese, which adds to the realism of the game. 
This game is difficult, and is not exactly a good starting point for new Total War players. I have never played a Total War game before this, so I had absolutely no idea how to do the campaign, and my first few Custom Battles were frustrating and too difficult. Yet, you do learn how to command the troops, and the game becomes very fun. The graphics are good, and the music is excellent. In addition, there are Japanese quotes on the loading screens that can inspire you. If you like feudal Japan or the movie The Last Samurai, you will love this. Recommended.

This title is possibly the best one in the Total War series. The campaign is mostly well and the different starting positions of the clans really give you different feelings despite all of them having most of the time the very same units.

The weak part of the game is - as always in CA games - the AI, especially when it comes to diplomacy... I guess the battle AI has improved a little since the absolutely terrible one in Empire TW, but nonetheless it is nothing to write home about.

The multiplayer Avatar Conquest game mode and the possibility to play co-op multiplayer campaigns is brilliant. A down side may be that the waiting time to get in a battle in Avatar Conquest is a bit too long for my liking.

Another thing I dislike is that - just like in Medieval 2 TW - I think gunpowder units are underpowered because of their poor range and reload rate and always get massacred by those primitive archers -_- ...

On the other hand, I really like the agent system which they improved a lot since earlier titles. Also, the naval battles seem to be fun and more easily playable then in Napoleon TW for example. I do have a few concerns with naval battles, but not big enough to mention them. They are mostly ok.

To finish on something positive, the absolutely immense amount of mods - quite some of them actually likable - which you can get on twcenter.net and the Steam workshop give you the possibility to enhance your game experience sooo much that - thanks to the modders - from a fairly ok game you get something really really good and you will utterly enjoy it all the time - as I do. ;)

For anyone unfamiliar with the Total War it mixes both turn based strategy and real time strategy. Units are moved, buildings are upgraded, and management is done on a map as you build your army to conquer regions of Japan. Battles both on land and at sea are real time strategy. You command your units and make formations on the field, making decisions and giving orders in real time. This is one of my favorite strategy games, and many people have argued this is the best game in the series.

This is actually not a straightforward "I hate this game", I don't like it and I'm recommending that people NOT buy it, but I have my reasons.

I don't like streamlined games, I don't like games designed to be quicker and smoother - I'm talking about games like Age of Empires 3, etc. Shogun is not [i]necessarily[/i] guilty of this, but I [i]do[/i] think that they have engineered the game to happen quickly, at a breakneck pace which creates a cinematic, action-packed campaign, and I just don't really like that.

Empire: Total War is the iteration of the series that I famously (if I was famous or at least noted) think got the most things right (the combat is just a bit more repsonsive than RTW), and one of the things it certainly got right for me was the pacing of the campaigns. The status quo was allowed to exist, sometimes for many turns consecutively, if you so desired.

In Shogun 2, the status quo means death. Factions fall like leaves in autumn, and mega-factions rise in their place, and if you have not been rabidly slaguhtering foes at the same speed then suddenly you will come up against titanic armies and war declarations out of nowhere. You have no time to build up coherent economies so you can't raise the troops to repel armies that rear end you at one end of your over-stretched empire while your main force is at the other end.

Not only does this damage your chances, it also damages the chances of your opponents, as more often than not you will find provinces severely undermanned that u can just waltz in and conquor.

Maybe I'm not good enough at speed play. Maybe I can't wring every last bit of economy out of regions that I'm apparently expected to put well into the black within two turns. Maybe, really, I just wanna sit down, shut up and smell the blossoms for a bit, instead of charging across Sengoku Jidai with a katana clenched in my teeth.

I own several Total War games and enjoy them quite a lot. My favorite is Rome 2 with the Divide Et Impera mod. I have given Shogun 2 several chances over the year, but alas I simply cannot come to love the oh so glorious Total War masterpiece that everyone hold in a pedestal. I bought the game on sale a long time ago, mainly because it was said to be the best Total War game ever. Frankly, to me, it seems that this game is seriously over-hyped and is far from being the greatest ever. I cannot in al seriousness believe that this is even considered a strategy game. I have played this game with mods and without and nothing seems to be able to fix the great underlying problems that this game has. I can praise the games graphics, I can praise its UI etc. I cannot praise, however, the battle gameplay. About 3/4 of the time that I spent in a battle is mainly fast forwarding through my army's positioning, trying to find a good position etc but none of this matters because in the end, all battles are reduced to maybe 5-7 arrow volleys and then a mad charge of the entire army and pretty much everything devolve into a mess in a matter of seconds and it is over shortly after, the actual battle lasting less than 10 minutes.. I have not been able to play a single battle where this is not what happens. There is absolutley no tactics by the AI. Very rareley does it attempt flanking, preferring to simply charge its calvary to the center of my line. Perhaps the only smart thing the AI does, but it does with such an annoyingly frequent and predictable frequency is to head to hills and simply camp it out there. "Smart move," except that it is easily countered by having missile superiority. I routed around half an army just by shooting at the stupid hill camping AI, because it simply refused to leave its hilltop, expecting for me to charge uphill. That was playing as the Chosokabe. Frankly I have derived no enjoyability from this game. The best I can describe the battle system is as a reskin of rock-paper-scissors with a few wild card. Sword beats Spear. Spear Beats Cav. Cav beats sword. Archers beat anything and everything if it doesn't touch them, otherwise they beat nothing. I really tried to like the game, but I'm done trying. Maybe I just suck at Shogun but can somehow adapt to the tactics of the many other factions of Rome 2. Maybe I'm doing something wrong and that's why I can't seem to win a battle without losing over half my army. It wouldn't be so bad I suppose, if the AI losing an entire army had any sort of impact, but seeing that in 4 turns they already spammed yet another full stack, any victory I'm able to scrape is entireley pointless... Much like every attempt I've made at liking this game.

Total War: Shogun 2

Nota: 10/10

Bem, o que falar desse jogo ?! Sem duvidas o melhor lançamento da franquia Total War !

O jogo se passa no século XVI, Japão Feudal, o pais vive em uma guerra tornando o mesmo dividido entre clãs , no modo campanha, durante a seleção de clãs no qual deseja jogar existe uma grande variedades de clãs, todos com seus pontos altos e baixos. você pode escolher um clan que seja muito forte em cavalaria, mas a sua infantaria possui armamentos inferiores, você pode escolher um clã onde as construções são de pouco custos, mas o preço para treinamento militar é superior

Seu objetivo ?? dominar o japão !

estilo de jogo? RTS

Ja tive contato com todas as outras franquias de Total War, mas tenho total certeza que SHOGUN 2 foi o que se destacou pelos seguintes motivos : 


1° Desempenho gráfico 10/10
2° modo história 9/10
3° excelente temática
4° Sons 10/10, muito realista durante os combates, e fora dos combates
5° dificuldade estratégica 10/10

O jogo me chamou bastante atenção na parte de IA, muitos que ja jogaram outros Total Wars sabem que alguns deixaram a desejar no quesito IA, Empire Total War; Total War: Rome II foram sem duvidas para mim um fracasso da franquia, mesmo Rome 2 vir ser lançado muito tempo depois de Shogun 2, acaba perdendo em quesitos graficos, IA, Campanha e outros motivos. IA de shogun 2 realmente funciona. é possivel aproximar a tela e ver o combate de perto, você percebe nitidamente a interação de praticamente todos os NPCs, ao contrario de Rome2 e Empire TW ficarem perdidos no mapa, congelarem, nao receber comandos. sem duvidas a CA apostou muito alto na perte IA do jogo e acabou dando muito certo !!

Pontos Fracos :

1° modo multiplayer, o jogo foi lançado a anos e nunca chegou srv oficial dedicado a Ámerica do Sul
2° modo campanha em certos pontos deixam a desejar, turnos muito lentos, questao de distribuição de alimentos nas cidades

Bom juntei um pouco de informação que tenho do jogo, espero que ajude para que qualquer jogador tenha interesse em comprar o jogo

Probably the most well done game in the total war series. You definitely feel like a Japanese warlord, managing your armies, clan, and provinces. The game has the best siege battles in all total war games I have played. Troops can move around smoothly on the walls and you don't need a whole army to man them, you can do with a smaller garrison which is the purpose with forts, and castles. Another good thing is that the AI tries to make big threatening armies instead of several small irritating armies as in Medieval 2, Rome 1 and sometimes Empire. Another thing that makes the game very good an more realistic is that it is hard to keep up several big professional armies if you don't have much territory. You have to be careful with who you go to war with and how many enemies you can handle because very few times you are able to figth a multi front war.

Fantastic landscape on both campaign map and battle map. Really good fighting simulations, better than Rome 2.

When Total War: Shogun 2 first came out, its real-time battles made me feel like I was playing through an epic battle scenes from one of those old samurai films. Shogun 2 is like playing through a new, remastered edition of those films (if...they..where...games hmm >_> anyway....) complete with both the character dramas and the enormous battles. 

Combining beautiful graphics, scheming generals, awesome multiplayer, and deep strategic gameplay with countless small details that fill it with historical flavor and drama, Shogun 2 is one of the most captivating strategy games ever made. 

You can take charge of any of the major factions of Japanese feudal history, from the mighty Oda to the more delicate but well positioned Tokugawa clan. Any of the clans could rise to take the position of Shogun under your leadership.

I would also highly recommend you to get the two main DLC for Shogun II the “Rise of the Samurai” and the “Fall of the Samurai”, as they are stand alone games in there own right adding a whole new level to your gaming experience. 

To finish I'd like to say this game is possibly one of the best RTS's I've ever played, the attention to detail is impressive and the tremendous replayability make the game a must have for any gamers library, enjoy hours of entertainment with Total War: Shogun 2.

(Like all my reviews I do not put a score as it is my belief that games like all forms of art are subjective and therefore it is impossible to afix a number to them)

SCROLL TO BOTTOM TO SEE WHY I CHANGED THE REVIEW FROM POSITIVE TO NEGATIVE

Intel releases a chip every year; in a tick-tock system. One year they will reduce the node size, the next year they will optimize their new chip. It seems like this is what SEGA is doing with the TOTAL WAR francise, SHOGUN 2 (when Fall of the Samurai is taken into account) is pretty much the optimization of their new node size which was Empire.

[list]
    [*]Positives
[/list]

If you enjoyed Empire I would highly recommend this game especially the Fall of the Samurai standalone (guns are fun and that's why Rome II wasn't). The game has improved on almost every aspect that was in Empire that it still has in the game. Multiplayer is good, but sometimes buggy (not game breakingly).

[list]
    [*]Negatives
[/list]

However the game isn't perfect, comparing it to Empire the [b]scale[/b] that I personally enjoyed so much naturally wasn't there. You obviously don't colonise the Americas, or India, instead you're stuck on Japan and a few surrounding islands (China would have been a nice addition to colonise) however this is to be expected from the time period and location but just keep that in mind. Secondly the [b]economy/ building[/b] in SHOGUN 2 is dumbed down, which I found to be a major letdown simply due to my playstyle, you have no growing towns, you can't change what a town does (actually there are no towns at all, only resources which you can extract; farms, harbours, and various resources such as minerals, crime dens, etc). It seems like they've moved a lot of what was once in the towns to the cities, which is honestly a shame. There aren't the same "national wonders" as Empire had (where you could only build one per faction).


[list]
    [*]Verdict
[/list]

4/5; The game is very good and enjoyable, everything it still has in it is done better than in Empire save for a few relatively minor critisisms.

*EDIT* After playing some multiplayer with a friend I have changed my review to not recommended. The game is extremely buggy and crashes constantly regardless of the time and effort taken to prevent/fix the issue through loading prior saves and not replicating the circumstances that caused the crash. SEGA and CA need to fix the game. Saying that it has multiplayer should amount to false advertizing.

2/5 devs that don't care about the state of their game. (And it still isn't fixed as of 11/4/2016)

Best strategy game I have ever played. Multiplayer is decent enough but the single player campaign is without question the best I have ever seen from the strategy genre. Not only is it not the typical all numbers and calculation bullshit that make up most of the strategy games I've seen. Unlike StarCraft or Supreme Commander where its literally just make the best units and throw them senselessly with absolutely no connection to your command. In Shogun 2, you can actually develop your military and economic infrastructure and have actually be rewarded for having veteran units and provinces.
This game is AMAZING. 10/10 Beautiful battles as well as very intense 1v1 up close action. The campaign is challenging and very fun. Also the best seige battles of all time. This game is a must have.

Really love this game. If you have played other total war games before and haven't tried this one I will let you know up front the game mechanics are some of the best in all of Total War history. It's been a long time since I have played a TW game where playing on the defense of a seige has been so fun that I always look forward to it. Religion plays a much bigger role than in some previous titles and causing Religious Unrest can really be a fun way to stick it to your enemies. This game also has neat little cut scense for when your Ninja assassinates someone, commits arson, or fails in the attempt. Even if your ninja fails you might end up laughing at how pathetically bad they are if not yet trained up. This game gives you all new challenges. Will you stick to honor and tradition and the old ways? Or perhaps honor means nothing to you and the old ways must go! You might even adopt firearms to turn the tables on rival clans! Many years ago my friend introduced me to Shogun: Total War and it was one of the most glorious games I had ever encountered. The turn based campaign, the real time battles. The diplomacy, the ninjas, the family tree, the ambience, music and feel of the game blew my little teenage mind and I have been in love with the series ever since.

So, 10 years later and Shogun 2 comes out. I was excited by the trailers but apprehensive due to the underwhelming experience of Empire: Total War. But like the loyal Creative Assembly fanboy that I am, I bought this title and have been playing the crap out of it ever since. 

Because let us be honest, it is one of the finest games they have made to date.

Pros:
-Cool fights
-Epic battles
-Samurai swords galore
-Strategy and stuff
-Ninjas

Cons:
-Unrealistic duels
-Very limited unit roosters (In vanilla)
-Character skill trees (unless you are into that sort of thing, you sexy freak)
-Limited settlement development (why does my city only have 3 buildings? Can't someone rent out their living room so we can set up the gambling den in there?)
-No city battles (Probably because as mentioned the cities only seem to consist of 3 buildings)


All in all, a stylish well presented grand strategy game/battlefield simulator with some very good Expansion Packs available. I don't even have a problem with the DLC this time (the gore one is brilliant and I wish it would be a part of every game they make).

Reading around forums it was McAFEE WEBADVISOR which I had to UNINSTALL to make it work (it was surprisingly tricky to find in the Apps section of Windows 10, it wasn't marked with the Adobe Red Shield icon / logo and oddly the word filter would not find it using a wild card/partial for it's name. The other McAfee products DO NOT affect the running of this game so don't turn off Firewall or real time scanning on McAfee !.  Right back to the game, simply excellent, they've nailed down combat really well and the campaign mode elements are at about right depth. You get to play out an Akira Kurosawa Samurai epic from the comfort of your gaming chair - how utterly cool is that 9/10.

I played Rome total war when the game started airing on history channels. That game was a masterpiece, people like to seek flaws in diamonds the size of your fist. Really the game executed it's concept perfectly. Remember that games are so multy faceted, firing on all cylinders in every category has yet to happen. Rome Total War is meant to put the user at the helm of the greatest civilization the world has ever seen. In my humble opinion it did just that. Shogun 2 is a polished version of the classic. I hate to look a gift horse in the mouth  but this is a review and that's exactlty what I'm going to do. Now I thoroughly enjoy Shogun 2, yet it can't legitamitly be it's own game. There are a vast amount of improvements, yet the deepests "flaws" of Rome aren't adressed. The campaign AI and battlefield AI is literally copy pasted. Instead of expanding on Rome, they seem content streamlining the same idea. If you haven't played Rome Total War, I recommend this game; although I'm warning veterans it's Rome with cherry blossoms. Although revisiting a classic  you didn't fully exploit has it's momments.

Honestly, I'm pretty old ... I first learnt to program on a zx81. And, actually has a ZX80!  I loved stratagy games and tried to play and find as many as I could, good and bad growing up!  So, I looked forward with great anticipation the first Shogun game, it was discussed in the game magaines of the time and I couldnt wait! I bought it the day it came out - same with Medievel, and Rome I bourght on the day after I was on the old BBC 2 show"Time Commanders", just look up Time Commanders, vicars take on Teutoburg Forest  in any search engine and you'll see us..... We Won!!!  

I've kept the boxes guide prima stratagy guides and all the expansions, I've some complations  and a collectors full set.  I loved this series (.. I'm what is probably called a 'fan Boy')

However, .... Work and Family life hit in and for a few years couldnt play as much, Empire and Napolean pretty much past me by, I kept buying  them all as and when they went on sale, beacuse I knew one day I might get to play them again! (Sorry "Game Horder" alert!)

That day has come, I've played when I could on and off over the years, but this week I managed to knock the bottom out of Shogun 2, and its quite frankly awsome!

The graphics are so good I keep taking screen shots,
The Diplomacy and the AI seem great, and a challenge
The Multiplayer fun , (except theres a lot of guns out there in multiplayer world),
I like the Avatar system
Shogun 2 is polished, runs well and truthfully, I've not had so much fun since Time Commanders!

I was on my way to become the Shogun of Japan. Many allies along with rivals were fighting against each other to claim that throne, however, I was one who liked to attack from the shadows and sabotage from within. I trained my agents in the art of sublety and manipulation so that they can do their tasks without fail. 
After having the first clan to declare war on me for not trading my goods with them, I started on my conquest from then and there. Clan after clan, I destroyed them on both the frontlines and within. Although one concern was in the back of my mind; the notification kept popping up year after year, a son/daughter was born. I was misunderstanding these announcements, since I, the Daiymo of my clan have not been home for years because of my campaign. As a sign of betrayal of my wife, I executed her and the sons and daughters who followed after. My clan soon was frightened of my actions and all dishonor was shown. I, however, needed a country to conquer. I made deals with Europe and was granted superior ships and cannons for attacking castles. I bribed my enemies with hostages of other clans to marry in if I was granted freedom of travel on their lands with wealth in my pockets. It wasn't until half of Japan was on fire until I claimed the title "Shogun" for my clans name.

So you may all destroy your enemies, vast yourself in riches beyond imagining, become a Warlord of your clan, or conquer Japan, but there will always be one thing you must ask yourself when it is all done.

Remove the sword from your stomach, turn on the Karaoke machine, pull out those unwashed schoolgirl panties and get sniffin' because Shogun 2 is finally here!  All the shame you feel from dishonering your family will be washed away when you are immersed into the experience that is Shogun 2!  

Feel your innter girly side by being bombarded with countless cherry blossoms...Relive the glory days of Japan before the thing that is left out of most Japanese textbooks happened...March your armies to victory with more efficiency than the Bhutan death march...Build the most glorious railroad since the Burmese railway, but with less slaves...Pwn and r4pe your enemies  more than the city of Nanking...and destroy your enemies harbors more than Pearl Harbor!  The experiences and playstyles are endless!  

In all seriousness though here is my actual review....above was just my promotion of the game..

I could never get in to any of the other Total War games.  I played both Rome 2 and Empire a bit, but eventually stopped playing them after a game or two.  I find this game way more fun to play and I think it is way better to look at.

Here are some reasons why I think this is the best newer Total War game..

-Balance.  The other Total War games can become confusing with the huge amount of other units...It takes way too long to figure out what counters what.  In this game, it is quite simple but still complex at the same time.  Horse beats archer, archer beats soldier, soldier beats horse...this rock, paper, scissors forumula makes it easy to pick up and learn.  There are still other units that add complexity, but for the most part you can rely on trusting this simple formula

-Design/Graphics.  Rome 2 might look slightly better in terms of polygon count and effects, but not by much.  This game looks better overall though!  The Japanese artwork and music throughout the game really helps to immerse you.  Everything else looks nearly identical to the new Total War games, but this runs better and has better performance.

-Decent unit movement, control, and COLLISION DETECTION!  One of the main reasons I always got sick of the other Total War games was because it always felt that you wern't in control of your units or armies...A group of 40 soldiers, essentially acted like one unit.  This game still isn't like other RTS games where you have control over a single unit...a single unit is still considered an army, but this concept has been improved and is actually better than it is in Rome 2.  Sending in a group of 30 or so soldier in Total War games was always lame...the individual soldiers would kinda just walk around the enemies not doing anything and every 5 seconds you would eventuall see one of your units hit someone with a sword.  This is only really a problem with melee units, but its a really big problem because it make it feel like your units arn't fighting right.  Its still an issue in this game, but units are much more likely to engage eachother in battle and not just walk around not doing anything.

-The expansion!  Usually expansions in Total War games or other RTS dont really change the gameplay that much.  The expansion in this game almost turns it into a whole other game!  Without the expansion, you are just using mainly archers, sword, horses, and other simple weapons....but by installing the expansion you upgrade the technology of the Japanese by like 500 years!  This is mainly because Japan was feudalistic before the arrival of western powers...The introduction of such different weapons and technologies would seem out of place usually, but in this historical context it makes sense!  It really changes the game a lot, and it makes both versions of the game fun to play.

Way better than any other Total War game I have played...which is medieval 2, empire, and Rome 2.  A great game which you can always come back to!  Tons of cool MOD support, like one where they add tons of blood and decapitations!  Awesome!

To begin with, this is perhaps one of the Semi-Recent Total Wars that is deserving of a proper and postive review.

Think of a time when CA was innovative with each of their titles (Yes including Empire) and when DLC was actually worth buying for a total war title. 

Shogun 2 in my opinion remains as one of the best Total War titles, and I would recommend this over Rome II anytime. Not that Rome II is not fun, it just doesn't feel as innovative as Shogun 2 is. Shogun 2 set in Fedual Japan has a very straightforward Rock Paper Scissors mechanic for the massive battles. Yet, it is one of the hardest battle styles to master in my opinion, not because of the diverse nations, not because of the unit power ups, and not because of overpowered special units. The game is hard because each unit counts and can mean the difference between being conquered or conquering, I still find myself having the hardest time against a large stack of units in Shogun 2 than Rome II.

Shogun 2's campaign although not as extensive as the whole of Europe or the conquest of the New World, Shogun 2 is one of those games that will make you manage each province with specific priorites and strategies. Sacrificing a province in order for it to become a gold powerhouse while another province builds your katanas and cav, makes you ponder as to the desicion in order to become the shogun and conquer Kyoto, and if your ambitious enough Japan.

And even with the games age, this is still beautiful, even the loading screens are easy on the eyes and give you an even more realistic interpretation of the Medieval Era of Japan. CA worked around the forced combat animations that made each unit look as if they were each a Samurai Soldier that trained with their blades before the battle. 

This game is not a SHAMEFUR DISPLAY rather it still stands as a beautiful, tough and fresh turn base strategy game. 

CA and SEGA should both take the time to go back and listen to the gamers, people responded well with Shogun 2 not because it was the newest total war title, but because it was nolstolgic and fresh. The DLC is worth buying, the base game isn't "incomplete" and battles are fun to play and watch.

This game has serious problems, but is seriously fun as the only Total War game you can play co-op with.

Problems: To get the game started, you may need to uninstall certain firewall software. It's fine with Windows Firewall, but will not play so long as Mcaffee is installed. The loading screens are ridiculous. It takes several minutes just to start the game. It periodically crashes or starts bogging down with long input delays. Once in co-op it took my friends army and gave it to me, leaving him with nothing. On and on.

Still, I like the game. It could be a hell of a lot more polished, but I just really enjoy the co-op. If you have friends who play and like Total War, this is a must get. Just expect occasional frustration.

Not the most complex total war by far, but that is where this game absolutely shines!

A return to roots game for Creative Assembly Shogun 2 was meant to test the waters for future total war games. Coming out right after Empires and Napoleon met good critic reviews, but only decent player reviews (for the time). C.A. wanted to make a game with modern graphics and UI, that both new and veteran players would enjoy. Shogun 2 runs great on most systems (medium settings on my friend's gt640, a very low end card) lowering the bar of entry even further. The game let's just about anyone play with an effective tutorial, the advisors, and simple mechanics. Maintaining a balance of strategy and tactics, Shogun 2 offers many dilemmas (the good kind!). Such dilemmas include, should you have specialized settlements, some military, some economic. Should you amass a thousand Ashigaru (peasant) spears and bows? Or a few hundred Elite Samurai, trained in the ways of the horse, sword, spear, and bow? Should you adopt Christianity, and gunpowder with it? Or maintain the shinto tradition and the diplomatic ease that shadows it?

Shogun 2 will seduce you, entice you, and keep you intrigued.

The atmosphere is great and I love the historical accuracy of the game, however the castle-forts are repetitive and there is little life in them since they tend to look the same, one after the other, even when they are at the top level they tend to look pretty damn similar to other top level castles, too much so. Another issue is troop balencing, swordsmen have a horrible time winning against cavalry, but they can wipe out spearmen with ease most of the time. This is the opposite for spearmen, and well you can figure out how it is for cavalry. For your infantry fights to be more balenced and less rediculously rock-paper-scisors you NEED to invest in expensive naginata units, atleast a few for a big army that is going to be fighting in the field. Oh and archers destroy everything but have a disadvantage in melee, horsman can wipe them out in seconds. The multiplayer battles are great because you can customize your armies rediculously. Overall despite the bugs the game is great and you can sink many hours into it.

Get the DLC on sale though.

Coming from someone who feared having to get used to traditional melee centered warfare after getting into the franchise from Empire and Napoleon, this installment hooked me in a wonderful way. It looks beautiful, the soundtrack is a masterpiece and the gameplay has the same yet improved style of the previous total wars. While I initially the combat primarily revolve around a rock-paper-scissor system with units countering other units, there are thankfully a lot more tactics around that, the scissor can cut the rock if cut just right so to speak.

Battles where the odds say you will be utterly crushed can still be won if commanded perfectly, and victories like those are the peak of the thrill this game can offer.
