In my opinion Shogun 2 is the best Total War game to date. This game does have bugs and sometimes pisses you off but it is still a really good game. I'm sorry for the length of this review buyt I wanted to give you an in depth feel of the game.

Good

1) The game allows you to do whatever you want with your empire. If you want to set the Takeda Clan's land on fire, you can. You want to assassinate a general that is pissing you off? You can. Do you want to be a cold ruler and kill your own subjects if they disagree with you? You can (With consequences). Do you want to build a huge trade empire? You can. You get the picture.

2) It looks good, not amazing compared to today but back when it was made people were like "DAMN!!!!"

3) All combat in the game was animated using real-life sword masters therefore it looks amazing

4) Large scale battles. While on the campaign map you control your empire, but when you go into combat with another army it is a whole different story. You have thousands of soldiers (all animated, and looking unique) fighting each other at one time with cavalry charges, gunfire, arrows flying everywhere, and even mortars in the later stages of the game. While this is going on you have the morale factor, if a regiment sees allies routing, starts loosing a lot of men, is set on fire, is surrounded, or if the commander dies they loose morale which leads to them being less effective in battle and if it gets too low they will break (They will run away for a short amount of time), and if it gets worse than that the unit will be shattered (They will run from the battle and can no longer be controlled).

5) Meaningful allies. I found that in most of the other Total War games your allies don't help much or all out betray you all the time. In Shogun if you ally with another clan and start a war with another clan, they will amass an army to help you. They may also trade with you or give you military access to their territory.

6) Familty trees. You have the ability to arrange a marriage with another clan if you have an unmarried woman in your family. As time progresses new family members are born and after a few years in-game they become adults ready to marry or command an army (Each have their own skills, disadvantages, and personality). You may also adopt generals into your army and make one of your best family members your heir (It is chosen for you in most Total War games).

7) Huge map. Shogun 2 features a huge detailed campaign map filled with cillages, mines, docks, farms, etc. There are also 25 - 30 clans to dominate on the map each with their own buffs and weaknesses.

8) Naval battles. This is the first game in the series with naval battles. Basically you have a fleet of ships with a certain amount of archers and infantry on each ship, each ship has their own speed and strength of their hull. The battle either ends when you set the enemy ships on fire using flaming arrows or bomb throwing ships, or by boarding the ship and letting your infantry fight (This makes the crew surrender on the enemy ship if you are successful, adding a new ship to your navy).

9) Avatar conquest. This is the main multiplayer mode of Shogun 2. You create a general, create a banner, name your faction, and invade territory on the conquest map. You also build your own army, and if a unit sees a lot of battles you can make them veterans allowing you to color, name, and upgrade them. You attack other players using the army you created and are ranked on the leaderboards.

10) DLC. There are multiple DLCs that add new units to the game, and one that makes it bloodier. The two large DLCs are Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. These are based in different time periods than the base game and add new units, factions and a new story.

11) No real noticeable bugs that I can think of


Bad

1) At times units will loose morale and run even if they were about to win the fight

2) Some units in the game are unbalanced and can easily destroy most of your army



Well now that you know the good and bad about the game hopefully you have decided on whether or not to buy it.

As for my rating I give this game a 10/10

There are a lot of good things about this game. It has fun buildings, units, and management options. Unfortunately the game injects complete randomness in with possibly the worst diplomacy I've ever seen in a game. Random occurences that are meant to provide some variety instead become punitive exercises if you refuse to cripple yourself. 

Most importantly, diplomacy is absolutely atrocious. Virtually everything in the game hurts your reputation with others, and it is virtually impossible to reclaim lost reputaiton except through turn upon turn of idleness or gift-giving. You can have a faction break their trade agreement with you, and then discover that their perception of you is hurt by a broken trade agreement - one they broke themselves! Being an ally LOSES power - this means that years of staunch alliance with marriage agreements get worse, not better. Everything diplomatically is on a clock to getting worse, meaning that playing a game where you use combat and diplomacy to advance yourself is impossible. Virtually the only possible strategy is to make few friends, and just conquer and make war and not try to interact with anyone, because no alliance will ever truly help you. 

For a straight battle sim, this game is good. If you want any kind of variety in strategies or to be able to use diplomacy at all, find any other game.

Although everyone seems to love this game, its not a good game for TW series. You will enjoy only if:
1) you love japonese culture;
2) you are new to TW series;
3) you like multiplayer most.

Exclude that and this game is a poor game with beautiful graphics.

The campaign has some many flaws... First of all the siege is not siege, its a bunch of soldiers invading a mansion and thats it. They climb walls and burn the gates making it impossible to win by destroying siege weapons... well actually this is another thing, you will barely need a siege weapon and its even more rare to see one.

Armies completely disappear if you conquer all cities of the rival faction. I exploited that so much. For example a clan had an army stronger than mine, so I simple avoid them and got their city by their backs and they were gone (complex strategic plataform? guess not).

AI cheats a lot like having unlimited ammo, get ranked troops and troops magically.

Family doesnt exist on this game, so it doesnt matter if you kill enemy's general, and techs... well fire arrow is a tech ¬¬. You need to go science to make fire arrows(?) and its totally a need (you will find yourself always researching that path first just to take the fire arrow).

Factions that are not even showed on the map declare war on you, they are not even close to you!

Campaign map design is also meh. Most of the time you can only go two directions: back or fowards.

No officers or governors, something that were in on previous games.

Your and AI armies will be composed by spearman and bowman, some cavs maybe. Oh.... and AI loves to charge their general on your spearmans =).

Speaking about AI, they will never ever try to flank you.

Tenho algumas opiniões negativas sobre a diplomacia e o passar do tempo (turnos) do jogo, e o jeito que os exértcitos se jogam de um jeito meio suicida, mas o jogo em si é ótimo, o melhor que já joguei da Total War, as guerras são bem agitadas como também rápidas no período, todos aproveitam oportunidades para poder crescer, principalmente os ambiciosos e agressivos, assim como revoluções (normal do Japão naquele tempo), tanto que tentar manter aliados é primordial, as contruções influenciam muito no jogo também de um jeito que nenhum outro da Total War influencia, infelizmente tem pouco território mas caso queiram comprar, vão na Workshop, coloquem uns mods do Radious (pelo Total War Center é melhor), Collateral,  outros para melhorar o matchlock, outros pra turnos sobre tecnologia e recrutamento, para assim deixar o jogo mais real, ou como dizem: IMERSIVO! E tenho certeza que assim irão ficar bem satisfeitos com o jogo, algumas coisas no mod era para ter já no jogo em si mas, graças a Deus, não compromete tanto o jogo ao ponto de ele ficar ruim tanto que tenho esperança que a Total War faça um SHOGUN 3.

As of Feburary 2016 I still am loving this game. Mostly to how simple, yet complex the game really is.

"Conquest"
I love the map of all three era of Japanese history. Also each era are protrayed from the vibrant and lush "Rise of the Samurai", to a war torn and beauituful base map, and to the gray and industrial look of the "Fall of the Samurai". The whole mechanism of the game is perfect. They perfected their formula from their past game and added new feature to make the game have limitless lifespan. The political system is easy enough yet satisfying. The feeling of having a powerful ally then all of the sudden a war was launch against them. Do you want to take part of a war that will only help your ally gain more power, do you ignore them and break the alliance, or do you strike back at your ally and conquer them?

Combat
The combat is very diverse yet fall back on one simple game we have been playing all of our life. "Rock, Paper, Sissors". However the way they did it was amazing in the combat sequence. Remeber strength in number and this applies here. Even the weakest unit in number can take out a elite unit with ease. with over 20+ units and each faction have it's own unique troops It's a blend of diversity. Shogun 2 has been said to have the most advance combat AI in difficulity. The easier mode are prone to mistake and static formation while the harder level are a snake lying in wait.

Overall
This is a history context game but don't treat it that way. Treat it like you are a warlord conquering Japan with your faction. You are to forge your clan to victory by either capturing a single city and defending the captial of Japan or do you conquer from Hokkaido to Kyushu and make sure no one stands in your path.

I don't think I need to repeat in depth all the positives from the nice graphics and music, great gameplay, good unit balance etc. and of course the overly enthusiastic/dramatic combat event announcer, but I'd like to share something that I like about this game compared to my other favourite TW game, Medieval 2. 
Sieges:
Often times in Medieval 2 I feel that defending a siege is much more fun than attacking, but since most of the time I'm the besieger it feels like a bit of a chore, especially when attacking a city with many enemy troops in it. 
In Shogun 2 imo being the attacker of a siege is equally as fun as defending, since your troops are able to destroy/climb walls and gates without slow and cumbersome siege weapons (I realize many people like this but I prefer quicker and more fluent combat). So since siege battles are more fluent, it feels more rewarding to pressure your opponent at certain areas of the battlefield and immediatly see the results, no matter whether you are attacking or defending, while still being a decent challenge for both sides. For me it feels like playing the water temple, except while being able to move much quicker!

Awesome campaign and multiplayer, recommending it to everyone.

It's beautiful. Utterly beautiful.

   But for me, the AI just ruins it. In battles, units need to be micromanaged incessantly to stop them from doing the most insane things. Tell a unit to retreat from the battle, and they'll strike out in a random direction, most often straight into an enemy unit. Order your men to storm through the open gates of a city, and they'll insist on climbing the walls instead. Bowmen refuse to fire at enemy units who are obviously in range. Cavalry trot along slowly alongside enemies you've ordered them to run down. I can do without Swooping Crane formations or whatever; I just want a big, red 'Stop being a freaking lunatic' button.
   And in the campaign, any strategy that involves diplomacy or trade is rather pointless, because you and the AI play by different rulesets. There are people out there who say that it's necessary to give the player a real challenge. All the power to them; if they want an option to give the AI a helping hand because they're experienced RTS players, there's no harm in that. But my experience was that AI cheating made a lot of tactics pointless. For instance, strangling a clan's economy had little discernable effect, as enormous armies still sprouted from bankrupt factions. I'd come up with plans that involved forcing AI armies to leave recently conquered cities, which I assumed would result in rebellion (because of the resistance to invaders mechanic), but it turns out that that doesn't apply to the AI at all.
    So in a weird way, the ramping up of the difficulty forces you to abandon tactics, rather than encouraging you to be cunning. In the end I always revert to building up the troop-producing facilities in a couple of weaponsmith-equipped cities, and churning out enough Ashigaru to just overwhelm the AI.
    I think Creative Assembly has just worked out a reliable formula, and has no intention of really getting their act together as long as they don't have to. Which is fair enough, but as much as I love that Total War feel, I think I've had enough.

Put simply, this is a masterpiece of an RTS game and my favorite one of its genre. Has a few hiccups, but those are quite easy to overlook when the rest of the game is considered, and are more or less erased with Darthmod installed.(Awesome mod for all Total War games its made for by the way) The base game though is remarkably solid. The level of depth that this game has in developing your generals, mixing units for different situations, and overall strategy is just phenominal. On top of that the game is gorgous and the music is awesome.

My only gripe with this game is the amount of DLC that should have already been in the game. Most of this stuff was available not long after release if I remember correctly and should have been in there day one. Wouldn't have hurt Creative Assembly or Sega to delay the launch to have added them and put some more polish on the game. Goes on sale pretty often though so you can buy the whole thing for around $20 or less if you are patient. I highly recommend this game, it's the crown jewel of the only series keeping Sega afloat. :)

10 out of 10

[h1]Creative Assembly returning to their roots in good form, marred only by minor performance, and balance issues in both singleplayer and multiplayer.[/h1]

+ SHOGUN 2 is Creative Assembly's return to form, with all the gameplay of the original Total War Shogun brought to modern day.
+ Is a damn good looker all around.
+ Plays very well if you are a veteran of the Art of War, or a newcomer to battlefields of Sengoku Japan, with expanded unit mechanics and tactical choices open to the player, like time of day, weather, and more.
+ Strategic layer has more options to enact one's plans for control of Japan over previous installments.
+ Fall of the Samurai expandalone expands the game to a whole new era of Japan, where old meets new.
+ Has samurai and ninja.

- Stumbles in performance even on beastly hardware. Certainly one that was future-proofed even for 2015 era hardware it seems.
- Has some issues with middleware usage, like the use of middleware for their in-game encyclopedia.
- Strange balancing issues throughout the game make it an odd game to play in the high end.
- Fall of the Samurai's balance is heavily weighed upon the new, which is historically and logically accurate, but can prove to be an issue in multiplayer for the unitiated.
- No pirates or wizards.
A bit confusing at the first time, but it will get better and better and lags . . .

The game Is complete GARBAGE. Here are examples:

BADness of this CA cesspit.

1. The AI is trash, all CA titles try to boast about improved AI. The only real improvements are the graphics, which they use to hide the fact that the AI is garbage.
2. Increasing the difficulty just nerf's the human players Incomes while buffing the AI's income. It does NOTHING to improve the AI in ANY way.
3. Castles are useless. What is the point of walls when all of the Japanese are apparently master mountain climbers?
4. Gate houses can be burned down by infantry, then it leaves the castles wide open. You should have to use siege equipment to break into a supposed stronghold, but hey, who knew the Japanse were all capable of climbing so well.
5.Cavalry is useless. Forget the fact that that the starting peasent spearman are erm, spearmen. Doesn't matter so much when the AI runs with mostly Katana Samurai later on which brings me to the next point.
6.The enemy army composition. It's not so bad, except the fact that the AI can support bigger armies of samurai as well as afford to have a large fleet AND upgrade all of their buildings. Meanwhile, Im struggling to support 6 samurai units AND upgrade my farms/markets/castle's Etc...All while trying to scrape together enough money to support a fleet.
7. Diplomacy. Diplomacy? Diplomacy?!? I'd say it's a part of this game, but it isnt. Forge a trade agreement with your neighbor? Doesn't matter, DOW's on you the turn after. AI think's you are expanding too aggressively to control 4 provinces, well, they have only taken 6+. Never met that faction until a ship sailed to your coast, land's troops on your coast and DOW's on you the next turn. Get's a hundred times worse with higher difficulties.

The good you ask? Well here it is:

1. The graphics is a plus
2. The reintroduction of family tree's, not that that matters since MTWR2 removes them, but at least they tried.
3. The co-op Campaign

I guess that's all. Don't waste your money on this unless you have a friend to play this with You have been warned!

Dear Reader,

If you do not already own this game then...

SHAMEFUL DISPLAY!!!!!


On a more serious note though this game is definately a very good Total War game. It allows you to engage in honourable battles in the open field where you can condemn thousands of little pixelated soldiers to death, or you can use dishonourable underhand tactics on the campaign map to stab the other factions agents and generals with initially terrible agents repeatedly, until they go 'poof!' and disappear from your campaign.

However the game is seriously lacking in unit variety as all the units are samurai this and samurai that, though it is to be expected as it only focuses on fuedal Japan. Also the naval battles are INCREDIBLY boring, all you have to do is get a bunch of fire bomb ships and set fire to everything. Personally I really enjoy the naval battles in Total War and its a shame that the Shogun 2 one is quite bad (probably worse than Rome 2 naval battles where you just ram everything). Also there are no mercenaries which sucks as I really love hiring mercenary armies in my other Total War games just to diversify my armies more.

Overall a very good Total War game. Probably my third favourite Total War game after Medieval 2 and Rome 2(I only got Rome 2 after Emperor Edition came out so I never really experienced the problems with the game). I definately recommend that you buy it if you like playing strategy games and you are a fan of Total War.

I have owned Shogun 2 since the release and it has undergone some major overhauls in that time, however, one thing has stayed the same throughout: The game is great.

I will say this right away, for some people this game is not their cup of tea; if you do not like strategy/management combined with Turn-based/RTS then this game is not for you (Any de-sync issues that originally existed have been eliminated, and even if an issue does ever crop up, the host call always share the save file to fix the issue).


However, if you DO like Turn-based/RTS, I cannot recommend this game any higher. 
This is hands down one of my FAVOURITE strategy games of all time; I have had some epic battle moments with this game and I quite enjoy the RPG/planning elements on the campaign map. I've known people to play this game purley for the battles. I would recommend getting some mods to improve AI/balance/gameplay, such as Radious or Darthmod (whichever you prefer; personally I use Radious as there are many different versions).

Pros:
+Excellent turn-based/RTS elements
+Choose from many different factions each with their own specialties and flavour (more with mods or DLC)
+Compatible with many different PC system specs
+Online Multiplayer + Campaign Co-op
+Very high replayability
+Tons of mods to allow for greater customization / tweaking / balancing
+Blood & Gore DLC: 'Watch as your samurai stabs an enemy Daiymo in the gut then slices his head off as he falls to his knees'  :)


Cons:
-Campaigns can potentially take a long time; do not forget though you can always auto-resolve battles to speed things up
-None


Overall, I have very few gripes with this game. After playing it for so long I can say for certain if you like a mix of turn-based/RTS games, you will fall in love with shogun 2.

Shogun 2 is in my opinion tied for best Total War game with Midieval 2, with it's own particular strengths. Shogun 2 has hands down the best AI, campaign + campaign map, and pitch battles of anything in the Total War series. It relies heavily on using intelligence to outwit and outmaneuver your opponent rather than strength to win the day. Commands are smoother and forces more reactive than ever before. The sea battles are nice, although they feel a bit like an unbalanced minigame much of the time. Even so, it feels a little less rewarding than Midieval 2 or Rome 1, and the siege battles are boring, although most battles on campaign at least will be fought in the open fields. 

Oh yeah, and the game looks and sounds magnificent. :D

If you like Total War as a franchise already and haven't gotten around to playing this then I absolutely recommend this game.   

If you are not already a fan of Total War and are thinking about trying this franchise out for the first time, I personally would recommend trying Rome Total War(the original NOT Rome 2) first and then moving on to Shogun 2 or Medieval 2.   Shogun 2's campaign even on easy or normal can be punishingly difficult especially in the late game.  There's a mechanic called Realm Divide in Shogun 2 which pits every other faction against your empire after you expand to a certain number of territories.  If you are not prepared for it you will lose every time.  And even if you are prepared, you might still lose if you manage it poorly.  Any of the three Roman factions campaigns in Rome Total War will be a LOT more forgiving.   I felt less discouraged learning how to play Total War that way.  

With that said, if you want to feel challenged right away then Shogun 2 is the best bet.  Take a look at Medieval 2 as well.  There's some significant challenges to overcome with both titles.

Total War Shogun II

I usually love the Total War games. However, Shogun II is not that good. Primarily the unit upkeep costs are very high. This allows the AI clans to overrun each other and become huge early in the game. Usually a nearby clan will have 10+ provinces while I have 3. Also, citizen unhappiness is a real problem, forcing me to keep large forces in newly occupied towns until the citizens are happier. Meanwhile the huge clans just get larger.

I guess things my get better as one plays but currently it is not that fun.

Medieval II, Empire and Napoleon Total War games are much more fun.

Shogun II has potential but is just a little shy on being fun. I do not hate the game but there are better games to spend time on. This game is almost good.

Also, the game has older graphics and is difficult to get running. Adobe Flash player 11 is required forcing the user to uninstall Flash 19, currently needed for the internet. Many players have great difficulty getting Shogun II to even run.

I recommend Total War Empire or Medieval II over Shogun II.

Total War Shogun 2 is one of the most satisfying Total War games to date.
Amazing graphics, nice variation, innovative multiplayer and features, thrilling campaign and many tactical elements.

The game feels very complete and the DLC & Mods make it even more feature rich.

Overall a very good game with the best coop campaign in any Total War beside maybe Rome 2.

To me, this is the pinnacle of Creative Assembly's Total War series.

I started playing the Total War series from the first Rome: Total War onwards and I've loved it ever since.
And Shogun 2 is at the height of all the effort and skill of Creative Assembly's development team.

As with all Total War games, you have a Campaign Map and a Battle Map.

The Campaign Map is stunning and has a good representation of Fuedal Japan, with varying different factions battling for the title of Shogun.
The UI is simple, yet effective. It has what you need and doesn't clutter up your screen with irrelevant information.
You're able to control armies and navies of up to 20 units and send them to wage war against your enemies.
Your agents are useful in distracting and disrupting your foes.
You're also able to level up your Generals and Agents and assign them skills and traits which make them more effective in battle and in the actions they take.

The Battle Map is where this game shines for me. Tactics are more prevelant than brute force, making you think on your feet. Though the enemy AI is lacking, there are mods that tweak this.
Each battle feels visceral, with yours and your enemies Samurai dismembering one another. Seasons and weather will also affect your units.
And my personal favourite season being Spring. Nothing more poetic and beautiful than a deadly skirmish as the Cherry Blossoms fall.

As I mentioned very briefly above, there are a multitude of mods to implement, if you so desire.
From tweaking of enemy AI, different unit skins, rebalancing of diplomatic relations to complete overhauls of the game's systems. There is something for everyone.

Aside from the base game, there are also two main expansions. Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. Both of which will take up as much time as the main campaign in the base game.
I personally prefer the Fall of the Samurai, it is most satisfying when ambushing a unit of rifle carrying infantry with a supposed meagre katana carrying unit. Causes utter devastation.
Love this game and everything about it and I strongly recommend this game!!!!

So, at just under 700 hours I feel like I can finally review this game properly. As of writing this we've had Rome 2 and Attilla, and the new Warhammer is under way too, but until that gets released and we can get a feel of it, Shogun 2 remains the pinacle of Total War so far.

I'll try to split this up for ease of reading:

Animation - The animations in this game are simply the best we've had so far. From crossed blades to beheadings (Only with DLC I think though) to men drowing on their own blood on the floor, it all looks so real. Admittedly you can see how two people have to awkwardly shuffle into what seem to be "combat lanes" and their  can be clipping due to this, this only takes a second and afterwards the fight is very fluid. Men will cheer when they rout a unit, your general swanks along cockily as he walks towards his foe, infantry lower their spears when they're close enough to charge... Its all done very well. On the campaign man, generals will pull out chairs when they run our of movement, and agents will act of small gestures and do an action when they level up, such as a ninja dropping a smoke bomb. Rome 2 and Attilla sadly lack this attention to animation, especially in fights, where combat animations are hard to see or very short. Overall, the animation of Shogun 2 is very in depth, if not without its occasional clumsy moment.

Combat - Using a smaller amount of unit types makes combat a more strategic affair, as unit abilities and stats are easier as you will have access to the same units. The game uses a easy to remember but hard to master formula of sword beats spear, spear beats horse, horse beats bow and bow beats sword. On the surface this is simplistic, but your katana samurai won't last long running uphill into a spearwall. This means that each unit type has its advantages in certain situations, for example bowmen seem to be alot better at attacking a fort than defending, but they can still fit into an overall formula. Gunmen are the awkard exception to this, as at times they seem to beat everything due to their high morale shock, while at others they simply refuse to fire fast enough or fire at all, rendering them useless. Added to the mix of unit types are unit tiers, with peasant (Ashigaru), samurai, monk and hero units being respectively better yet costing alot more. This means that a balance must be struck between rather weak but cheap peasant units and more hardy samurai, though at a later point ashigaru are basically useless due to the player having a large economy. Hero units are rather unbalanced, being able to take on whole units before dying, but they are certainly not invincible and die very easily to ranged units. While there are not as many exciting units as Rome 2 or Attilla, the balance is alot better, though expect to see lots of spear ashigaru in the majority of your battles.

Graphics - I run this on max, and I have to say that it still looks pretty damn nice. On lower settings however, the game looks pretty dreadful, but this then again what did you want from low graphics? Take a look at the community screenshots to decide for yourself, but I think the game looks very nice. Rome 2 suffered from always looking bland IMO, while Shogun is full of life and colour. From a short distance the graphics get abit blurry, but I guess this allows it to run smoother, and by abit blurry I mean that specific detail can't be spotted, but maybe this is just me being picky. Each person in a unit usually looks different, though Rome 2 and Attilla have more face variations. Unit clothes are nice and detailed, with monks, samurai, ashigaru all looking very different and ofcourse all the different subgroups such as bowmen adding more diversity. Naval battles are quite bad at times though, as holes are blown in the ships you can see water just awkwardly clipping through, but again this is me being picky. Overall, very nice.

Sound - I don't know much about sound so this will be short, but the music is entertaining and can make you feel engaged alot of the time. Its not something I'd sit and listen to in my free time, but it fits the setting very well. One of the songs was even used by the Japanese in the Sochi olympics, so I guess it must be good! The narrator is amazing in my opinion, especially at the start when he shouts "The reign of the old shogunate... IS OVER!". Battle sounds are well done, and the choking sounds even managed to make me feel sorry for the troops every now and again.

Multiplayer - While not much of a fan of just playing battles, Shogun 2 has a clan system and tournaments, so if competative play is your thing you got it! You can conquer provinces on a special multiplayer map by beating other players, which then unlocks new units for you and advisors that give bonuses. Personally, I feel like this aspect of multiplayer ruins it, as a starting player is going to have a VERY hard time beating anyone expect other new players as they are locked to basic peasant units with no buffs while higher level players have hero units and buffs such as being able to see your deployment, Multiplayer is far from fair, so if you're new a hard climb will be infront of you unless you boost, which kinda sucks for people who want to level up legit or just play for fun. On the positive side, you can do large battles, seiges and naval battles online, and the maps are well made. One AMAZING aspect of multiplayer is the ability to make your own avatar and customise him from lots of armour sets unlocked by doing the steam achievements, winning multiplayer battles and conquering regions. You can choose his banner, colour and abilities, so if you've ever wanted a daimyo called Sam Peggle who wears fabulous pink and can personally tank an entire army, you can go for it! This character customisation is the only thing that makes me play multiplayer, as otherwise I find it too unbalanced, but the prospect of new armour is too good a reward! Rome 2 and Attilla sadly lacked this aspect, which is a great shame. Finally, the entire campaign can be done in coop, and unlike Empire and Napoleon players can battle the AI instead of forcing the other player to be the opponent or auto resolving, which made coop for me. You can spectate your friends battles and they can gift you units mid battle to use to keep it from getting boring. The only problem is that you are stuck between coop or vs, so in coop if your friend on the other side of the map gets declared on you are FORCED to help, but in VS all you need to do is hold their capital for a turn, meaning you can just rush through their entire empire ignoring everything. Rome 2 and Attilla sadly didn't fix this.

Campaign - Final part now, sorry if I've bored you! The map itself I find quite interesting, if not unbalanced in a way; In the south you have islands which can be heavily fortified and used as a powerbase, and also brings in naval warfare. As you get closer to the map it gets more messy, as each province can have 4 bordering provinces to be invaded from unlike the south. East and North are full of huge provinces that take ages to cross and have little need for a navy. It is alot easier to play near Kyushu as you can't be invaded from the west as the map ends, so you can focus on pushing right, while clans like Oda or Hattori will always be surrounded. Diplomacy seem off to me, with Rome 2 making more sense. Allies will randomly break all their pacts with you, neutral clans will attack or factions on the opposite ends of the map will delcare on each other. You have a family tree mechanic which is nice and reminds me of Medieval 2, and this creates a roleplay element as characters get traits and followers. When you are powerful enough all the clans unite and declare on you, which is a fun challenge as usually in TW games at this point you can't be beat by single clans, though its damn hard! The building mechanic isn't as good as Empires, but its clearer and more refined.

Take away siege towers, siege ladders, and relatively ALL of your ability to destroy ANY of the enemies walls, remove unique units for any of the factions and replace that with "unit buffs", and apply a heavy penalty to any and all units based on rock paper scissors mechanics, and what do you have?  Why, Shogun 2 of course!

I'm absolutely lost when it comes to the rabid fanatacism a lot of people have for this game, mainly due to the fact that it's missing a lot of the innovations of its brethren.  All the forts look identical, the tech tree isn't even worth including because of how shallow and un-fleshed out it is, the AI is even worse than it was in Empire, where it at least knew how to ambush the player.  It's like they took 3 steps back from the series, looked at everything they'd accomplished and said "Yea, better make a worse game", and stripped everything down.  Every fort fight is identical to the last one, there is literally absolutely no variety to them except *GASP* if you managed to slide an agent into one of their forts, he can unlock the gate for your army so they don't have to climb the walls and lose close to half of them!  Combine that where every single faction has exactly, and I mean, EXACTLY the same units as each-other, *unless* you buy DLC (at least with Empire, Medieval 2, and Rome, the DLC added MORE unit diversity that was already there, it didn't force you to buy a bunch of random DLC packs that gave your armies something unique about them).

So why is that such a big deal?  Well, let's say you look through the factions and find out which one suits your play-style based on where you start out, and the over-all bonuses you get....Hmmm, okay, the Mori look good, let's pick them.  Now let's go into battle...Oh hey, they have the same exact unit structure as I do!...Now imagine that same feeling happening to you over and over again for the next 10 hours.  While I understand that it puts an emphasis on tactics over unit composition, the tactics falls a bit short compared to all the other total wars because of how it's designed, in terms of the speed of combat, how heavy the counter system is, and how repetitive the AI is.  Occassionally the AI will do something different, but that feels less like the AI is adapting to the situation, like in previous Total Wars, and more like it's going through some sort of routine.  And when you take away unique units to each faction, it takes away a lot of the reason to pick a faction based on unit bonuses since you can just counter-pick them anyway.  While this could've been designed in such a way that it works, where you have players using advanced tactics to ambush, hold, and counter the enemy, the speed and design of battles/combat is done in such a way that it discourages this.  And when you ARE doing well, and conquering territories left and right, the AI just straight up quits.

So what does the AI do?  Flat out just sends a random death-horde your way.  How did they get that many units?  Who the hell knows.  Because Shogun 2, unlike the other Total War games, LOOVES to cheat.  Where-as in the previous games it was hard to tell if a death-stack was spawned by the AI, or actually built up, mainly because the unit structure of those big unit stacks were so odd and usually poorly built, but in Shogun 2, the death-stacks are filled with the same units, over and over again, and when you compare that with the ACTUAL armies being fielded, that aren't cheat-spawned, you'll notice the difference.  They do this because they know that if you move too quickly across the map, which is EXTREMELY limited compared to nearly ALL the other total war's, that their "game" would end so abruptly, and would offer so little challenge, that you would say "this sucks!" compared to their previous releases.  So they force the AI to cheat, wasting your time even longer.

Which brings me to my next gripe, the map size.  Maybe Japan was a large map size back in 2000, when the original Shogun released, and maybe unit variety, sieges, and all that stuff that Shogun 2 is missing in comparison were all very limited when they released their first Total War, but it's 11 years later.  If I wanted to play Shogun 1, I'd go back and fucking play it.  This game could've at least come with a Korean faction, where they could've had the player hopping from island to island right at the tip of South Korea, vying for control of trade, and even mainland control with the Korean military, but no, they went the safe route.

Lastly, the multiplayer...The god awful multiplayer.  While the customization of ones multiplayer avatar and unique units is an interesting concept, they have done nothing with that after this game.  On top of that, the only way for you to unlock other units in multiplayer, besides the very basic starting units, is to win battles and capture territories, which means you'll always be at a disadvantage because other players who have been playering longer, closer to the release, have more units unlocked, more unique units with bonuses (oh yea, did I forget to mention that?  You can level up your units online and increase their effectiveness...Because that's not broken!), and if you bought the Fall of the Samurai DLC, you might as well just exit the match since anyone who bought that is just going to spam rifle-men over and over again!  Gee, they really thought this through, didn't they?

Overall the game is bland as all hell, offers an extremely simplified and bare-bones portrayal/simulation of Japanese military and combat of that period, and the multiplayer mode, while interesting, lacks the polish and balance to keep you interested for very long (if at all).
It's definitely my favorite total war game.

Probably one of the best Total War games in the franchise, if not the best, due to the timescales it and the main add-on pack cover. First off, I am probably considered a noob to a lot of the people who played total war before me. My first total war game was Total War: Rome 2. I have almost 800 hours in it, so I can say I played it extensively. I tried to play the first rome since everyone was telling me that was the better game, but I just could not get into it. It was just too old/outdated for my tastes. So let's get right into it:

-The graphics feel complete unlike the newer games, this is in my opinion the best looking game in the franchise.
-The depth is a LOT better than the newer ones, this is not simplified down, this makes Rome 2 (have not played Atilla yet.) look like a joke. 
-Combat. That's what a lot of us are here for. The combat is a lot more balanced from what I've seen in other games. While it doesn't have the giant unit roster that the first rome had, this one is still enough to keep you entertained for ages. 
-Diplomacy actually feels like a challenge to keep everything in check here, you have to be VERY careful when picking allies or enemies. Even the most dependable clans might turn against you if you have good relations with their enemies and do not support them in their war effort.
Attention to historic detail. Endless replay value. Clean in game HUD, less clutter than Rome 2.

One of my favorite games ever, and in my opinion the most polished Total War by far.

Singleplayer is a blast, there are lots of great mods that expand the campaign and make it even better.

Multiplayer is also fun, with a separate campaign on it that I never got into much, but even without exploring half the game I still feel like this is a fantastic game. 

The DLC's are full and great, and Fall of the Samurai is one of the most fun campaigns ever (I play it more than the base game). 

I'd give this game a solid 10/10, which I don't think I've ever given a game. It is just so solid, and it runs so well, and it looks too clean to not give it that. 

The ONLY downside I can think of with this game is that many of the factions are similar, but it is Japan so that can't be helped. Also, CA definitely did their best to separate each faction by giving them big advantages and disadvantages in certain areas (many factions are a lot better with seige weapons or cavalry than others, and you can take this into account if you want when adding them as allies).

This is a great grand strategy game with real-time combat if you're into that kind of thing. I personally got annoyed with the game, I don't really have the patience to learn all the nuances and it's easy to get quite a ways into the game before it becomes apparent that you made a fatal strategic mistake many turns earlier that you won't be able to recover from and either tough it out to the brutal end or start a new campaign.

I know some people enjoy this type of gameplay and the mastering of it, but even on easy the AI can be quite aggressive in steamrolling you with a "stack of doom" army and the learning curve is pretty steep so you will have many failed starts before even getting close to victory. From reading online, apparently once you figure out the AI they're quite easy to beat, but due to the slow pace of this game that still requires many hours of time investment. This is the kind of game one can really get into which is great if you like it, but it is not very approachable for a more casual player.

Not my thing, but the game is well done and has a lot of depth so I can still recommend it if you like grand strategy games.

Overall the best Total War game in the franchise to date. 780 hours and still playing. 
It's only let-down worth mentioning is the size of the map (and how linear parts of it are), which is only due to the geographical limitations of Japan- not game design.

The best Total War in years. Lets's start with graphics shall we, I honestly can't find anything wrong with the graphics of this game because they are fucking beautiful for 2011. Like soldiers making the correct mouth movement when they talk and rain dripping off of a soldier's helmet. Great attention to detail, like unique battle animations for soldiers fighting and soldiers are able to gang up on an enemy to kill them faster. Music is fast paced and great, especially victory music, its so damn catchy and makes you feel good that you actually got a victory. Voice acting is like butter on toast (I think they hired some real English speaking Japanese people even though that sounds racist), in all my hours i havn't found a single bug, loading screens are a bit long, not an improvement from ETW and NTW, (where in those games loading screens were incredibly fast and it didn't have to go to a loading screen to get to the menu, but in this game, you do have to sit through a load screen to get to the menu). Diplomacy has slightly downgraded since the last Total War, like how you can not trade regions, but it's cool how it has little cut scenes for the diplomats instead of floating heads like in the two previous games. Speaking of cut scenes THERE ARE ACTUALLY CUT SCENES, I mean yes the advisor still takes you around the map but the cut scenes add depth, for instance when one of the great clans is destroyed there's a video of the daimyo of their clan commiting Seppuku. Also more easy to under stand research, simple trees of either Bushido (war) or way of Chi (civil research). And you know how I was talking about depth, well you actually feel like a leader, you can assighn generals to be commissioners of war (for 2+ recruitments slots and less up keep) or for finance (which will get you more money), more RPG elements like generals having custom traditions, skills, and personalitys. Also they brought back the general speeches (when your general give a cut scene speech in the beginning of each battle, skipable if you dont want to hear it). My final verdict......

10/10

Until DLC Fall of the Samurai came along and blew my effin' mind. The small investment is well-worth it and, when Shogun is bundled with FOTS, that 10/10 is immediately bumped up to a 16 or 17.5 out of 10.. This game is a must-have for any fan of the strategy genre, so do yourself a favor and get this game ASAP. You won't be sorry.

Total War has always been a forerunner of the real time strategy genre.  However, by combining this with the Sengoku Jidai era, Total War Shogun 2 is one of my favorite games ever.  The power to sway a battle is completely in the hands of the player, even when outnumbered or outmatched.  This game does an incredible job of paying attention to detail.  Even though these battles can involve thousands of individual troops, you can see and look through the eyes of a single soldier fighting in your army. Truely incredible.
U can compare this with attila or rome 2 and u will be shocked with what it offers. a truly tantalising game

Without any doubt one of the best RTS ever created, likely the best Total War game so far bar perhaps Rome I. There's a million reasons why any RTS player should own this title, there's enough info on this game as it as its already 4 years old by now but it still holds up amazingly well to this day.
There isn't much twitch gameplay such as Starcraft-esque games in TW series but having good micro definately makes a big difference on the battlefield, though the overall the gameplay is more focused on tactical decisions both in battles and in the overhead map, where atleast 60% of your time will be spent. 

The only downside to this game would be imo, that the harder difficulty AI's simply get harder by pure cheating, creating huge armylists out of thin air and gaining tons more resources than you per turn even when they do not control anything. Thus an artificial difficulty is created instead of one where the AI simply 'gets better' by doing better tactical plays or better decision making, etc.
Overall an amazing title nonetheless.
The best TW produced after Medieval 2 and Rome Total war!!!! Would suggest to everyone!

I have in my games library no fewer than 5 Total War games. I truly love the early versions, especially Rome I, but I've played many hours on almost all of them. It took me a little while to get into this one, and it's expansions, but I have to say that I'm now hooked. Definitely in my top 3 Total War games. Its the perfect blend of the old and new, in my opinion. I loved the family tree aspect of the early Total War games, and here we see it coexisting with a game that feels most familiar to more recent Total War releases. The graphics are lovely. The music is fantastic. Voice acting seems great, not that I speak Japanese or anything. Unlike other Total War games, the generals speak in their native tongues for the pre-battle scenes. Kinda cool. Naval battles are the best I've seen in one of these games; you aren't overwhelmed by different controls, which at first threw me off being so used to Rome ii, but its very easy to control your ships by clicking on the map and the few buttons you do have to choose from, mostly for special attacks and such. I've felt naval battles to be a major weakness in many of these games, and I don't feel that way (yet) about this one. I'm still fairly early into the game, so I don't know anything about any aspect of the late game, but I suspect that it follows the usual Total War trajectory. 

All in all, if you like Total War games, I'd be amazed if you don't like this one. This would probably be a decent game to introduce you to the franchise, likewise. If you're a strategy fan you'll most likely enjoy this one. Especially if you're in the mood for some Eastern flavors. 

UPDATE: I have now beaten the base game, with all of my above predictions holding true. Usual (fun) Total War trajectory. I'm now enjoying the subtle differences in characters, units, and game play of the expansions "Rise..." and "Fall...". Still enjoying the naval combat. It seems like the computer is a little more "bright" in this game. I often find that, when playing the computer in strategy games, there is no room for Real strategy, because the computer is just going to barrell right at you with all it's strength, no clever feints, no subtlety. That still mostly holds true, here, but I've found I'm able to employ more strategy in battles in this game because there is a small amount of variation to the computer opponent's strategy. I find this most satisfying, since I've always missed the spark of human intelligence when playing the computer. Now, don't get me wrong, battles are still relatively easy so long as you aren't terribly outmatched, but the slight variation in the computer's strategy makes it much more interesting. Economy is also functioning in this game, unlike "Empire:TW", which I also loved, and which this game definitely tops.

The game is very good.  However the food requirements vs the ability to obtain food is lacking.  For those of us like myself who enjoy a more of a build up game rather than a forced pace there is no way to obtain enough food to update all castles and markets in all provinces even when you have all provinces.  This is embalanced.  The markets should not use food to upgrade.  And if the castles are going to require that much food to upgrade them, then the farms should provide more food.  As well,  money is bit too difficult to build up.  The pace you have to capture provinces out paces the ability to create enough troops to do so.  Also, I would really like it explained to me how is it a cpu controlled province with only one province can obtain enough food and koku to produce large fleets of ships as well as large armies.  These are just the details that should be smoothed out.

Okay, so the run-down is that Shogun II is a solid game. What's good about it is that the graphics are exceptional, animations are very smooth and gameplay is generally fun. What's bad, on the other hand, is the initial loading time is fairly long, which is a bummer if the player wants to get in-game quickly. The AI can be fairly predictable at times as well. 


Uninstall everything McAfee from your computer if you want to play this game. Seriously, save yourself the trouble.


My personal experience with Shogun II was unpleasant to say the least. My fiancee and I were playing Medieval II and decided to look for a Total War game that has mostly stable co-op multiplayer, and Shogun II fit the bill. So, we both bought our individual copies hoping to play together but her copy was the only one that seemed to work (my copy would get to the legal splash screen, followed by the cursor switching to the arrowhead and an immediate crash-to-desktop). I spent the next day-and-a-half trying to troubleshoot Shogun II so I could finally play, but nothing was working - I requested a refund. A couple days later, while doing research on Total War games that had multiplayer (and actually worked) and on alternative fixes for Shogun II, I stumbled upon a YouTube video, where in the comments section, someone had a very simple fix that many people reported being a valid solution: uninstall McAfee Web Advisor (I can't remember the exact name, I apologize if that's wrong). 

In hopes of this fix being the right one, I unistalled the program, bought Shogun II again, and ran it. Bingo, it worked like a charm. Turns out that the Web-program-thing blocks the encyclopedia that Shogun II uses, crashing the game before it even starts. A day later though, everytime I tried to play, the same crash would occur except McAfee's website popped up. I just uninstalled the whole thing.

Gameplay wise, it's stable for the most part. It can be buggy at times, but I haven't encountered anything game-breaking yet. I play with my fiancee most of the time, and I haven't noticed any serious issues with multiplayer. All factions are pretty well-balanced with each other, each with their own bonuses such as superior katana samurai, monk-warriors, naval units, archers, spearmen, etc. The framerate seems to be fairly stable on both the campaign map and on the battlefield with my current laptop (I'm using an Inspiron 15 5000). It doesn't have the best graphics card ever, and the game will only allow up to medium settings, but I don't really mind. Multiplayer can be fairly laggy though, with 1-5 seconds between hitting enter in chat and the message actually being sent. Movement on the field can be the same way, and can cause some issues - such as not being able to move spears quickly enough to counter a cavalry flank. Basically, the lag can be detrimental at times, both for planning out your next move, and when trying to battle on the map.

Overall, I give this game an 8/10.
It's solid, but has some bugs and can be laggy: -1 point

If you're a fan of M2:TW, this is not for you.

2 Major complaints:

Combat. This is dumbed down beyond belief. It plays more like starcraft than total war. Units are very responsive and quick to respond and die very fast. I don't even know why they included a morale system because the gameplay of the combat has totally changed. 

No retraining. This is the biggest pet peeve that I've got with this game that mods cant even fix. There is NO WAY to retrain units. Yes, units replenish automatically on the world map but if you build a unit with no upgrades and get the upgraded building for it later on, there's no way to do anything about what you've already got.

Some minor issues:
World map is incredibly simple and dumbed down compared to EmpireTW and M2TW. 
No unit variations. Every faction gets one unit with upgraded stats. There are "Hero" units that you can get one of if you're willing to pay DLC for every single one of them.

This game was not worth playing. 
Cool samurais though.

Best of the recent-ish Total War Games, but just starting to show some of the bad DLC practises which came in Rome 2 and Attila.

Pros:
- Easily replayable, and actually using your factions specific traits can make them fun and diverse.
- Lots of cinematics to go with the story of your bid for the Shogunate.
- Fall of the Samurai is hella fun and adds a lot to the game.
- Hero units feel like heroes. They ****ing butcher everyone else.
- The voice acting is great. There's a lot of passion in it to help deepen the immersion. (THIS IS A SHAMEFUR DISPRAY!)
- Being able to recruit new generals from the rank-and-file if they lead an army to victory in the absence of an actual general is cool.
- Gunpowder units are well-balanced in the base game. They require excellent tactical manouverings to actually do well, but if you get them into a good position, and prevent them from being engaged in melee, and stop them from hitting your own troops too much, then they will rek all shiz.
- I like the tech trees, they're real frickin' nito. And the encylopedia has some nice little history tidbits for each unit.

Cons:
- THOSE ****ING LOADING TIMES, SRS
- Rise of the Samurai doesn't really do anything for me, I find it dull compared to the base game and Fall of the Samurai.
- It's honestly easier to play exactly the same for every faction; lots of yari ashigaru to pin your enemy in place whilst bow ashigaru (or bow samurai later in the game) do all the killing.
- There is no unit variety; even the factions unique units are just the same as everyone else for the most part but with higher stats (there are a few exceptions), and the rest of the armies are exactly the same but for their colour scheme.
- Defending a castle is laughably easy, which rather goes against the history that the feudal Japanese preferred to sally out and fight their foe on the battlefield.
- Attacking a castle is extremely hard, until you get the long-range bow troops like warrior monks or daikyu samurai. Then it becomes easy.
- Actually using your generals in combat is always a last resort; since most of all armies have either yari or naginata, your general will get slaughtered if he gets into combat for the most part. You can dismount them of course, but that weakens them anyway to a degree. Again, kind of clashes with the reputation of the lords rarely if ever shying away from getting into the thick of things.
- Gunpowder units are borderline haxx in castle defence. Unless the Date are attacking, dem Bulletproof Samurai are pretty coo'.
- The food surplus system isn't great. Kind of annoying at times. FotS removes that though.

It's a great game though, despite all the flaws I list; I personally am just better at picking out the bad bits I feel. I've invested a huge amount of time into playing this game; it's a lot of fun and you should definitely get it over Rome II or Attila.

This is by-far my favorite Total War game. It may not be the prettiest looking one of the series, but the gameplay is great. There's nothing more satisfying that watching a katana take someone's head off in slow-motion. Having DLC is a must; it adds more depth to the gameplay so you won't get bored. For example: it is stupidly fun to use guns from Fall of the Samurai against traditional units, but I created a challenge for myself to play an entire campaign using traditional units against AI that will absolutely use guns. And it feels rewarding using tactics to crush a modernized army with an unmodernized one. Compared to Attila, Shogun 2 is the less appetizing choice but all the essential parts are here. It's definitely worth the time and money to play this through.

As a Total War fan, this game was disappointing. It contained a poor set of historical battles, a limited range of units and no story-based campaign. The game can be somewhat enhanced by purchasing the FOTS DLC, and in my view, was intentionally made feature poor to force customers to buy the rest of the game to find any great enjoyment.

The AI is stupid and it shows.

Lazy programming, or programming that tries to compensate for crappy computers, make the AI engage selected enemies (selected few by the game) in a group. If the enemy is within firing or melee range but those "lucky few" enemies are not, your units will not engage.

If the enemy group is within firing range but the few selected enemies that the game has chosen randomly are not, your archers will not fire.

If the enemy group is merged with your melee units but the few selected enemies are separated (typical when they run away when broken), your melee units will run away from the merged enemies to chase after those few far far away. Since the "chosen ones" are selected within a enemy formation, your melee units will run to and fro from one end of the map to the other, and get exhausted needlessly.

The lazy rule is, the "chosen ones" must die before the computer will randomly select another "chosen one", who must die before the next one is chosen. Sounds good on paper, but is terrible ingame.

The programmers also did not know how to make the AI about face, so if u were engaged from the rear, and u want your formation to turn around, they will run and run and run and run and run and run and run like they're stupid instead of just turning 180 degrees.

The AI is weak in battles.

The decision to limit agents to 5 is nonsensical.

Still, I must say that the saving grace of this game is the fact that it is moddable, and if one can overlook (or get used to) the poor AI, then the game is fine.

I had a terrible experience with [i]Shogun II[/i] as my PC restarted everytime I attempted to start up the game. The demo worked fine, along with previous Total War titles. Looking for any sort of solution to this problem has yielded concrete troubleshooting results, and sadly it has soured my whole experience with the game. Spending $30.00 for a game that has compatibility issues on such a wide scale, yet completely unaccounted by CA, is unacceptable. It has made me wary of purchasing any of their more recent products if a problem of this size is essentially left unaddressed by the Creative Assembly.
NICE

Pros:

-Excellent gameplay and performance, nice to see actual momentum in charges (e.g. effectively punching holes in formations) and naval battles are nicely done.
-Good variation in tactics and gameplay styles (Christian or Buddhist, Gunpowder or traditional, Military based or civil based)
-Difficulty is very good and choices you make can ompletely overturn your clan (e.g. becoming Shogun too early will leave you highly vulnerable to other clans, becoming Christian can provoke your Buddhist allies)

Cons:

-Loading time is a bit longer than other Total War games
- Unit diversity isn't too great (no clan specific units), but even then it has had little impact on my enjoyment
- Opposition Metsuke and Ninjas are incredibly frustrating to deal with
- A couple of glitches, mostly naval based (enemy units being able to use fire arrows in rain yet you can't, enemy ships getting stuck on edge of map preventing boarding)

Probably the best Total War game i have played to date, the few cons there are, are easily overshadowed by the pros. If you enjoy Total War games you will love this.

I am the Daimyo of the Shimiza... I think. 

I'm not sure, we're just the ones who wear green and we're less likely to betray each other, which is good enough because we are extremely similar to everyone else on Nippon, the great land of Japan. We fight the same, eat the same, use the same weapons, if we all didn't agree to strict colour codes, it would be chaos.

After hundreds of years, we have decided it is time to have a civil war. We're not too sure why, but it seems right. Some bloke turned up from Denmark, handed us Japan's first gun, and that was it; time to declare war on each other and decide who will be Emperor... No, not that, we're just going to fight for the honour of being the guy who fights for the Emperor. Okay then. Thankfully, everyone got the message and we all decided it was a grand old idea.

So I began by sending out my son and two of his best mates with 400 blokes to the nearest town, where we had an honourable of 500 vs 45 men. Naturally, we won and peacefully looted the place, and paid the locals to pick up a spear and help us do it again.

Our neighbours were honourable men who promptly got eaten by some nobody clan nearby who in half a year managed to have seven provinces; I had two. In the winter of Japan, we fought a great battle; a whole 700 people took part, a great size of blood and glory. I gave a speech in Japanese; naturally I can't speak a damn word, but rather than learn the language, life conviently provided subtitles so I wouldn't have to try and learn it. As we fought, I had an advisor shout at me in stereotypical Jinglish about the honour of my family and soldiers. We lined up, we ran at each other, and I sneezed. As I looked up, the enemy had broken and run and my advisor was now screaming at me about the honour of our win. Alright then.

I asked if we could develop our technology, to allow us an advantage. My advisor told me I could either research how to stab better, or I could research some poetry and make everyone feel happier about me ruling them.

We went with the stabbing route. They'd give some flowery prose about honour and balance, but it was just how to better stab people. My population was unhappy? Stab them. Clan unhappy? Stab them. Enemy unhappy? Stab them. We went for... Total War!

Now, war is waged not just on the battlefield, but also by cloak and dagger. We began to hire people with a certain set of skills, skills that make life difficult for our enemies. First was the ninja; after we decided to build an entire building just for him, he agreed to work for us. He began to open gates for us, but then we realised we can just climb up the hill of dirt that is our castles. Then we asked him to sabotage buildings, but then we realised we would have to repair it later. Then we asked him to kill the other leaders; after only 10 years of constantly getting caught and showing us the comics later of how he did it every single time he failed (and he only ever did the same thing, again and again), he began to kill with semi-regularity. The new recruits? We forced them to stay on the gate of each town and look for suspicious people.

Then we hired the metsuke, or the police guy. After we had to build him a whole building for himself as well (not wanting to be second best to the guy in pyjamas), he then leaves the town (and not needing the building anyway) and spends him time sending monks to jail, and telling people to quiet down when they complain about the fires and stabbings. All in all, not a bad investment.

Lastly, we built a Temple and the monks came; they had the special power of making the enemy feel a little bit bad about themselves. Ultimately, we just had them sit in towns were foreigners came. You see, if you wanted the guns, you had to get the Christianity as well (Americans, amirite?), so we had the monk walk behind the Christians and refute everything they said, seemed to do well enough. We remained sufficiently Buddist, and in the spirit of Buddism, we continued our war.

During the war, we began to trade with other countries. Now, we had an ally trading with China; they said no. "But we're friends?" Yes, they replied, but if you want us to share trading with one of the biggest countries in the world, you'll have to declare war with us. "But you only have one trade ship, how can you possibly be trading with all of China? Why don't you have Beijing, and we have Shanghai?" HOJI DOESN'T SHARE TRADE! So we went to war for some silk.

After about 30 years of conquering, making vassals, having those vassal betray us, re-conquering vassals and burning them to the ground after learning our lesson, we eventually conquered Japan. Just in time for the Americans to conquer us later in the expansion.

The only great Total War since Medieval 2...

Shogun 2, my personal favorite Total War game, and probably one of the best titles ever published by CA, along Medieval 2 and Rome 1. 

The game is absolutely fantastic. No more. There are flaws, but the game gets almost all aspects that made the Total War series into what it is and executes them in an almost perfect harmony. You start controlling a Daimyo in the Sengoku Jidai era of Feudal Japan and is up to you to make your way trough rivals, missionaries, rebellions and even the Shogun itself to bexome the Supreme ruler of Japan. 

Now why is this game so good? 

Because it is the epitome of polish, everything seems to flow naturally, like the stream of a river. The strategic map is very well done, it creates chokepoints and natural obstacles so you will nedd to fight certain enemies to control vital regions, which also makes for excellent defensive positions to hold. There are three types of agents( actually 5 if you include Geisha and the portuguese Missionary), and their rock-paper-scissor way of interacting is perfect. The Ninja is perfect for infiltration, sabotage and assassination, and excels at eliminating Monks. Beware of the Metsuke, they may buy off your Generals, kill Ninjas and bribe settlements. The Monk may seem harmless at first, but leave one alone and you may have a full rebellion deep inside your territory, and that can be your downfall. 

Unfortunatelly not everything is perfect, as the map design tends to promote siege battles regularly, and sometimes agents fail much more than they succeed. Fortunatelly, having a level 6 agent means you have a BIG advantage over your opponents( level 6 ninja and their generals will fall one after the another like maple leaves on Autumn).

Now the battles.... What can I say regarding them that anybody else hasn't said better than I? I can only say that even after 900 hours of gameplay  leading your Samurai while they charge shouting 'Banzai' still gives me goose bumps. Units are very disciplined and will often fight to the death of you have a powerful general and high morale, which enables Epic Last Stand situations. Siege Battles may become tiresome, but are very good nonetheless, because they are sometimes quite challenging, for example, try taking Kyoto without Two full-stack armies to see what happens, specially at hard at very hard.

There sooooo many things to talk about this game, but if you want to know what I'm talking about, simply play and you'll see.All things considered, BUY this game. 

This game is a "glorious victory my lord!", and not a "shameful display"

An excellent look into the culture and warfare of medieval Japan, the historical attitude towards westerners (Nanban), and the warrior society that was the Samurai. The multitude of options leave alot of room for replay, and the diverse strengths and weaknesses of the playable clans guarantees that no two campaigns will turn out the same.
The mixed tactics of gunpowder units and more traditional units (archers, spearmen, etc) adds an interesting facet to battles. The naval battles, likewise, are enthralling. With each new battle, be it land or see, siege or ambush, the player can quickly gain an understanding of how best to win. Yet there is nearly always a challenge, regardless of how much of an advantage the player has.
Strategically, the options for the Daimyo, his family, and his generals make running the faction more smooth than in previous TW games.
Agents take on a a very prominent role, with varying agents whose actions can make a campaign quick and easy.
Lastly, the skill trees are a very nice touch, letting the player guide the growth of a general or agent however best suits the situation.

I am at a loss on how popular this game is. Even old school Total War fans of Medieval 2 and Rome 1 often praise this game. In my in depth review, Ill pick apart WHY I feel this game was a disgusting imitator, that managed to fool alot of people.

The biggest problem with this game, is the mechanics of the new engine. The "warscape engine" or "Total War 3" engine, whatever, it doesn't have collision detection. Units will pair up with the closest dancing partner, and then begin to crunch numbers on if the unit will hit, damage, kill, miss, block ect. What made the Total War games great was that it HAD collision detection. Units were physical, walking, fighting objects in the game world. If you take that away, their just images that are shadow boxing. It becomes BLATANT when you start fielding cavalry. Instead of bull dozing through the first few lines of men, you can literally see them stop in their tracks, and glitch near the opponent running to the side, and they will begin their stylized play acting fighting... its not very immersive.

This takes out so much strategy, in how you should align your armies, and instead replaces it with.... Rock Paper Scissors. Thats right, spear men beats cavalry. Cavalry beats swordsman. Swordsman beat spearman. So strategy in this game, has been reduced to that...

Lastly we come to the factions and units, something I am baffled more people dont address! Without paid DLC, nearly ever faction plays almost identical to the rest! There's some math that makes farms more productive, or Samurai swordsman stronger, or monks stronger... but everyone's using a very similar roster! It would be like playing Rome 1, with only Roman Units... how boring would that be? The answer, Shogun 2 boring.

If none of this sounds like it bothers you, well it does everything else well. Sound, the UI, the way the AI thinks and does diplomacy is actually well thought out. If your like me though, and like having REAL feeling battles, with varried armies that feel unique from one another... this isnt for you.

9.5/10. Shogun 2 is by far the best and most balanced Total War game. All of the games have their strengths and weaknesses (often glaring), but Shogun 2 has the least weaknesses by a long shot. 
It's a pretty game with a lot of depth and strategy. I played the vanilla game (non-modded) for about half of my recorded hours and I played DarthMod for the remainder. DarthMod fixed everthing, except for the trade system. The battles are intense, and the siege missions are fantastic. There's nothing better than the rush of victory after holding a castle against a superior army. Likewise, catching a stronger faction with their pants down and sweeping up half of their provinces in a single turns is equally great. The Fall of the Samurai mod is icing on the cake, as it is essentially a completely different game. I played Rise of Samurai for about four hours... it's pointless to get unless you really like crappy units and that period of Japanese history. 


The only real downsides to the vanilla game are the insane diplomacy system (AI abandoning long-held alliances, which result in immediate destruction) and the completely broken trade system. Trade agreements disappear for no reason, causing a drop in your honor despite you having nothing to do with their dissolution. Usually some explanation is giving that your home ports are at full capacity when they aren't. Unfortunately that sort of shoddy programming has plagued The Creative Assembly since day one. I still remember the day I beat a half stack army with two units in the original Shogun due to balancing issues. Good times. 

In short, buy this game whether or not it is on sale. It's fantastic. The Creative Assembly have yet replicate the success (in terms of gameplay and overall polish) of Shogun 2, and I doubt they will again after the catastrophe that was Rome 2.

My ranking goes like this:

Shogun 2
Medieval 2
Rome
Medieval
Rome 2 Emperor Edition
Empire
Shogun

I haven't played Attila yet, but I'm guessing it would be around Rome 2.

One of the best RTS games ever and certainly one of the highlights of the Total War series.
Features 3 campaigns:
1. The "original" campaign takes place during the late medieval, at a time when the first contacts with the europeans are made. The old military leader has lost his power and a number of various japanese clans vie for the honour of being the new one. Although the units throughout all factions are more or less the same (only some few units are totally unique, most of them from DLC's) they get faction specific bonuses which give your armies a direction in which to go for in recruitment and strategy. Features peasant soldiers, the legendary samurai and ninja as well as more modern gunpowder units.
2. The Rise of the Samurai campaign takes place during the early antiquity, showcasing the rise of the samurai class as opposed to the previously usual peasant and levy armies. One of the great clans is amassing more and more power through their family ties with the emperor. This eventually leads to a conflict over the controll of the powerless puppet emperor between the great clans of the time. Your goal is to either defend the emperor as the "ruling" family or "liberate" ('MURICA!!) him from their fangs.
3. The Fall of the Samurai campaign takes place during the modern age and shows the total modernisation brought about by the westerners and the ensuing "fall" of the samurai as a class, seeing that levied armies with few training can now simply outgun years of sword and bow practice. The conflict that ensues, fueled by western intervention, is one between the supporters of the shogun (traditionalists that where forced by guns from the westerners to modernize and trade) and supporters of the emperor (those that think that the shogun betrayed Japan by dealing with the westerners, despite that they are modernizing far more that their shogunal counterparts in order to win the conflict).

One of the best strategy games ever created.

Shogun 2, where to begin. This game is a gem if you are either a fan of Japanese warfare history or a huge fan if epic scaled battles. The campaign is a load of fun, after playing a few turns I always find myself wondering where to go next and how to balance my military and economic development. 

Both the building of my provinces and the conducting of real time battles are a pleassure to do. Nothing beats the sight of entire units being bombarded with a rain of flaming arrows in slow motion.
Sadly the naval AI doesn't do so well when on the defensive and is verry easy to trick.
Another sore point for me is the lack of depth in diplomacy and to oh so infamous real divide machanic where everyone turns on you even if they have been your closest ally for the entire game.

The good news is that most of these cons can be migitated with mods from the workshop, adding a bunch of mods that are in your flavour can truly makes this game shine and eat away your time like it's nothing.
