I have been a fan of the Total War series since I was a young kid and have always loved it. Total War: Shogun 2 has been no exception. The game has a ton of high points but also a few things that they could have done better on. First off, probably the thing this game does best is its style. The artwork, text and soundtrack really draw you into the Japanese theme. It may seem like a small thing but to me It made a huge difference. The second best thing about this game is that its relatively simple compared to previous Total War Games. In the past Total war has had hundreds of different units; many of which did more or less the same thing. In shogun there are at most 25 different units but each one feels unique and the game as a whole feels much more streamlined. The only two things the game could work on is that there is way too much DLC to buy that really didnt add all that much to the game, and that the Seige Units were relatively useless seeing as you could just have your troops climb the walls to the fortresses. But other than those 2 things, this is genuinely one of the Best RTSs I have ever played. Overall Score: 10/10

Update 4/08/2015

Okay so after researching for one week, Windows 8 does not let you tweak non-plug and plug in drivers in the device manager. This is essential as the game clashes with AOD driver 4.1 and AOD driver 4.3. Running a Command Prompt to show ghosted drivers wont solve anything - you will get batch file (fuck you message appear on the script). Also this game was badly programmed to have over 100000 issues where people online say constantly that the game crashes. Seriously I have never heard of such a recall of problems for a pc game. Shogun 2 has flown under the table with the amount of threads and people shouting this game doesn't work. 

So we got 2 issues 

Windows 8 - Fails
Shogun 2 - Terribly programmed

Don't give me any excuses and say it was programmed well too. If wolfenstein 3d still works, this should be able to as well.

Update 5/08/2015

After Reinstalling the game, it now works after I had to reinstall windows 8.1

Yea I must be a lucky boy or maybe it will just f u c k up on another day. Anyway's I am very happy and I may have solved the issue by downloading audio drivers from a website not by disk and not installing Shogun's 2 old flash player which is obsolete as windows comes with a modern flash player.

The game has way too many technical issues. Unit pathfinding is atrocious, especially in and around forts, and you'll regularly see troops moving in the exact opposite direction you told them to because they thought a gate was obstructed somehow or they charge after a single enemy troop who got seperated from their allies rather than the main body of their unit. It all adds up to make for an extremely unsatisfying experience.

This game is a perfect example of a total war game done right. The game feels very polished wether that be the sleak graphics in battle, agent videos, or the neat menus and tabs on the campaign map,  everything comes together very nicely. Unlike most previous games in the series, the campaign ai is aggressive and can easily end your campaign prematurely if you make to many enemies or neglect diplomacy which is a welcome change.  

Diplomacy has been improved greatly with the campaign ai generally making sensible decisions( e.g. they will usually accept any terms when close to being destroyed, allies will often offer money to assist them in wars, or offer to assist you in wars in exchange for helping them in their own)Allies  are easily the most reliable in the series and will normally not backstab you unless you are allied with a trechorous clan, have become weak and failed to maintain good relations, or triggered realm divide(more on this later) , and have even occasionally send troops to help you in battles which is a refresing change. 

The co-op or versus campaigns(when no connection issues are present) are a complete blast, cordinating attacks with your friends and building your empires together is satisfying and a very enjoyable experience. While it is unrealistic that you will both have armies in every battle, it is possible to give friends in the campaign units under your control in both the campaign, and on the battlefield allowing participation in eachothers battles, regardless of faction and distance from one another.

Now that we have spoken about what is good about the game, I will now discuss the main problems, the battlefield ai is hit and miss. Sometimes the ai catches you by surprise  with clever use of flanking, or whittling you down with massed archers when it has missle superiorty, on the flip side the ai is prone to getting careless with it's generals, or playing far to passively on defense allowing players to take the initiave. It's most noticablely bad in sieges, where it often deploys it's troops akwardly allowing them to be dealt with easily( e.g. leaving it's archers completely undefended) and will climb the walls every time, even if a gate to the castle is wide open, causing their troops to take uneccessary casualties and morale loss. Unfortunatly though bad ai is nothing new to the total war series and  may stay this way for quite some time, however if this concerns you you may opt to allow a random player to take control of the ai armies on the campaign map to offer a (usually)greater challenge.
 
A lot of people are uhappy about the lack of variety in the clans, while each one has it's own unique specialty, and often gets a more powerful and cheaper, variant of a certain unit type, they do all use the same units(dlcs add some unique units to each faction, as well as one or two factions with many different units) although personally this doesn't bother me to much as playing to the factions specialty allows each clan to play differently offering a unique playthrough each campaign. 

Finally one of the biggest issues in shogun 2 is realm devide, this mechanic happens late in the game when you take enough provinces. This causes the shogun to fear your power and declare you a enemy of the state, the result is diplomacy is thrown out the window, and inevitably all factions will declare war on you, including your allies. This mechanic is not implemted well and can often feel unfair, although mods can change the way realm devide works allowing you to easily keep your allies and friends after realm devide allowing for a much more enjoyable experience.


Some people may feel intimited by the setting of the game or the flaws that i have outlined, but i can't stress enough that this game is a easily among the top total war games in the series, and in my opinion is vastly superior to it's successor rome 2. There are ways to deal with most of the games flaws which i have outlined above allowing you to take full advantage of the many great features CA nailed when making this game. 

Wether you are a total war fan that has not purchased shogun 2, or someone who is interested in the franchise or strategy games in general, i can't recommend this game enough.

TL:DR The game is polished and has some of the best diplomacy/battles in the series, multiplayer is fun and addictive while it does have some issues(siege ai/realm devide and a lack of variety) it's in my opinion well worth the price.

A good addition to the long series of Total War games and probably the best. The combat is easy to understand but hard to master. The AI can be a bit dumn at times, especially on the Fall of the Samurai when you put them on the wall, but is reliable and all the clans in the campaign are well balanced. As you expand you never feel too overpowered and it is easy for a small clan to take a couple of your regions behind your back, this is possibly due to the similarity of a lot of clans' units. I would count this as a disadvantage as there doesn't seem to be a lot of unit variation compared to others like Rome and Medieval 2, however unlike these two there aren't a couple of really good nations that are basically easy mode. A couple spring to mind; Rome in Rome 2 and France/HRE in Medieval. Sea Combat is not too interesting in the vanilla game and improves in Fall of the Samurai. One thing that I dislike is how easy generals are to take out in a battle but they really sway the odds if you want to just auto resolve, forcing you to fight the battle, which can be off putting if you wanted to quickly take  a city with a small, elite force but the Generals simply get in your way; even though the backup units are just ashigaru.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone that wants a Total War where all start with a small empire and then you expand at your own pace, it also gives it replayability as the attitude and size of clans changes everytime.

This is... a shakey 'Yes'. The graphics are beautiful, the unit models are detailed and historically accurate as possible, and it's definetely got a different feel in combat to the other games. The combat animations are clean, the AI isn't too stupid, and it's fun to zoom in and watch individual duels. Very nice representation of fuedal Japanese warfare.
That said, I feel, that of all the games, this, could possibly be one of the worse, despite people saying that it's the best. An unfortunate result of focusing on Japan rather than Eastern Asia as a whole, is that all the units are the same. From one unit to another, the line-ups are the same with only an idividual unique unit in some factions to affect gameplay. Fall of the Samurai adds only one "new" army style, that of western-style musket-armed rank and file.
So... yeah. That's a quick summary of the good and the bad. Good luck.

Rarely does a game, strategy or otherwise, keep me coming back and replaying it over and over. The modding community is amazing and always manges to keep each experience fresh, not that it needs it to be. Shogun 2 is the perfect total war game. It keeps things basic enough with the units while still making room for more complex strategies to try out when your more familiar with the game later on. The atmosphere and design of the game are probably its strongest assets, with rich detailed infromation about every possible facet of the game and a soundtrack that really gets your war blood pumping while at the same time allowing you to contemplate on every action that has transpired.

Take my advice and download the bloodpack DLC for the ultimate Shogun experience and beware the realm divide!

FOR THE SHOGUN!!!

Simply put, the single most polished game in the entire series.
Few bugs, for a Total War game anyway, beautiful presentation, and a strong rock-paper-scissors counter system that makes combat tactical. The fast pace and shieldless soldiers also makes combat intense and exciting. The AI is still quite bad at times, but they actually try and unite against you when you grow too powerful, instead of letting you steamroll unopposed. The campaign map is smaller than other Total Wars, and far more focused- you have a central objective; control the Shogunate. This means that you feel like you're actually working toward a goal instead of simply conquering territories because you can.

However, what Shogun 2 has in polish, it lacks in Polish (heh heh)- since the only European group in the game is the Portuguese- and lacks in scale. The small map is easy to learn and helps with focus, but it's criminally tiny compared to the multiple continent conquests of Europe, Asia, and Africa of every other Total War game. There is also very little differentiation between factions. Some DLC factions are unique, but most factions have the same unit roster with minor bonuses here and there. There are no unique units for the standard factions.

Shogun 2 also has the most unique and interesting expansion- Fall of the Samurai combines the melee combat of Shogun 2 with the musket warfare of Empire/Napoleon, and adds in all new 18th century technology never before seen in the series.

Shogun 2: Total War is a masterpiece to put it plain and simple, and possibly one of the BEST Total Wars in the Franchise. I have over 300 hours on the game (I bought it before steam) and all I can say is that it is beautifully crafted. I'll get straight to the pros and cons.


PROS
----

- Game has the "feel" of a Total War game (Lel)
- Shogun 2 is Historically accurate when it comes to Clans and Clan leaders.
- Graphics are amazing
- Music is all either FROM the period or INSPIRED by the period.
- Many clans as options to play as
- Family tree (unlike some of the "other" TW Titles)
- STEAM WORKSHOP for new maps, soldiers, graphics, everything!
- Battles are fluid and your soldiers do not glob up in a large circular mass.
- Has a first person option to view the combat up and close! (Though it doesnt exactly look amazing)
- THREE campaigns with all the expansions. ALL with different units, factions, and story.
- Unique and upgraded Multiplayer System which is slightly buggy but can be fixed.
- Multiplayer includes multiplayer CAMPAIGN

CONS
----

- Not everyone likes the setting of it being in Japan
- AI in higher difficulty "cheats" by spawning in armies at times i've seen this. (There may be a fix on it on the TW forums or in Workshop but I did NOT look ) 
- You MUST pay for expansions
- They have faction packs to unlock factions, even though you can get those factions and much more for FREE in the workshop.
- Soldier AI don't always pick the best route to move in combat which becomes a problem.
Played it for 7 hours and I already like the game a lot. Highly recommended!

The DLC added to the game is really good too, to be honest I never even touched the multiplayer and think the singleplayer is worth it alone.  The campaign can be challenging and has a great tech tree with interesting mechanics. Well, I had my first experience with the Total War franchise in Shogun 2.
I bought and played all DLC's, played both the online avatar conquest and coop campaing (only once, because it is practically dead now).
All the singleplayer campaings are awesome and the playability is really good.
All campaings will give you large amount of play time even playing on short campaing (I only played on long, but I can tell that even the short one is at least 30-50 hours of gameplay), but the first campaing, Shogun 2, and the Shogun 2 - Fall of the Samurai were my favorites due to the style of gameplay and technology already available, since the campaing Rise of the Samurai is supposed to be set before both, and they diverge in the gameplay because you don't actually need to capture the settlement to make it yours in the Rise of the Samurais (the allegiance system). What I was more excited about was the historical battles you get to fight, really amazing how they made that so every ramdom battle turns out to feel like you were reviving the Japanese's past fights (at least for me).
My only complaining is about the multiplayer, it is true, I didn't play much of the avatar conquest, but from what I played (2-3 hours) it was a real shit, and the coop campaing could be really awesome, but as I said, it is dead now...

Summary, if you are a fan of Samurais and Japan history.. buy the game for sure! Just don't expect multiplayer...

I have FoTS and it is the BEST game I have played in the entire Total War series. I played a little Attila on the free Total War day and found it...eh. I used to love Rome: Total War but there's something so cool about how the fights look and play out in this one. It all seems so fluid and brutal.
Well, maybe not as brutal as I'd like. I wish there was more blood and limbs getting hacked off. I want to look at the aftermath and think "Sweet mother of Mary....What have I become?" And then promptly run down the surrendered men trying to run to their wives.

OK, so battles are awesome. What isn't awesome is the diplomatic scenario. I'm like a US General defending against ISIS. These guys throw themselves at my fortresses over and over. I don't have an issue with it because my people are patriots and pay 'Very High' taxes to keep the Commies (I mean Imperials... oops) out. Long live the Shogunate!

But seriously, it's gettin annoying. Battle after battle they fail to secure my fortress. They can't just starve me because I have an expeditionary force which I send forth for that situation. I tried to form a peace but they refused. My allies won't join me. Basically I'm like the Shogunate's little bitch and everyone else is just developing their economies.

Well, so am I. But all research is going into expanding the economy and military. It's like that guy who played Civilization for 10 years. I have no idea how to progress! But I've sent an invasion force to expand my lands. Long live Shogun!

In this review I will be going through the base game and the two other expansions individually to make you decide what products you should get. First I’ll start with Shogun 2.
Shogun 2
Total War: Shogun 2 is the Seventh game in the Total War series, and the Sequel to the Original Shogun: Total War, which was the first game of the series. Taking place in Feudal Japan following the middle Ages, you can play as one of several warlords, or factions, whose job it is to take over and unite Japan under one ruler. Each faction has their own strengths and weaknesses, Economic, Political, and militarily. There are several DLC's for Shogun 2, including; Rise of the Samurai, Fall of the Samurai, The Dragon War Battle, as well as several downloadable clan packs. Unlike previous games in the series, Shogun 2 takes place only in Japan and not Europe or the overall world as a whole. SHOGUN II offers the best polish, balance and innovative multiplayer system of all Total War titles, arguably the best in the series. The immersion created by Shogun 2 is far greater than any TW title. In the battles, each soldier looks and acts like a real person: they walk and charge with different animations, and they all die in different ways. The stylized UI and player cards, beautiful scenery, and music add so much to the feel of the game. It's just so good. A perfect score composed using many Japanese instruments to convey the mood. Overall the soundtrack is very enjoyable. It makes you feel that you actually in that time period fighting against other clans in Japan. I really enjoyed the hours I spent in this wonderful game. Though shogun 2 is more in depth than the original it is just as addictive game, and it’s a lot more stressful than Civ5, but just as hard to walk away from. If you like grand strategy, giving orders to your regiments on a tactical level mixed with historically accurate factions, environments and equipment, this game is definitely for you! The battle AI is much improved as well. I can't really use Empire:TW as an example because I don’t own it, so I'll use Med2. The battle AI attacks head on without delay when on the offensive, defends smartly when on the defensive, and knows when to pull back and regroup. One small complaint I've found in the battle AI is from time to time the AI knows when I tell my cavalry to attack a bow unit and the bow unit starts’ running before my cavalry even gets there. It's like it detects the attack "click". When I tell my cavalry to move to behind the enemy bow units instead of clicking on them to attack I get the surprise attack I wanted to begin with. Another flaw is the AI that is not too amazing (Not awful either though) are some of the lesser points of the game The AI is very keen on plundering your lands, which ends up being more of a pain in the...Rear end than entertaining as you have to repair -yet another- farm and hunt down another four units of spearmen that ran past your defense and just keeps running away from you. It does mean that you can't really sit in your fort all the time and let the enemy come to you, but in the end you don't really gain anything aside from a headache from hunting down all the little armies running through your land. Luckily there are river crossings and mountains you can stand by to block most of the enemy from getting through. Although it can be improved with DarthMod which I recommend to anybody who wants to buy this, and they use cavalry quite well to surround you and get behind your lines. They know when to attack vs. defend on a hill, and support weakened units with reserves. The Great Avatar conquest system in multiplayer is a great touch and is SIMLAR TO NOTHING CREATED IN ANY OTHER TW GAME. All those faction systems are not even a bit as deep as Avatar conquest in Shogun 2. Nothing can compare with this. Yes it is really rough to new players. But if you have enough patience eventually you will enjoy Avatar conquest like nothing else before. Also I really like coalition system as you grow strong and everyone else are turning against you even your vassals and allies. This feature is UNIQUE TO THIS GAME and makes you plan your strategy really carefully trying not to overextend too much. And that's great because for example in Rome 2 you just pierce through your enemies like a knife through butter and no one can stop you in the late game at all, so in the mid game you simply lose interest to game process because of no challenge what so ever.
Almost every aspect of the game is done the way it should be, battles, sieges, clan system, agents, diplomacy, heck even naval battles. You will have plenty of choices and options for your empire and they are all meaningful in some way. You can embrace the new western technology and get yourself some guns, take on Christianity or stick to the old ways, eventually becoming the ruler of Japan. All of this comes with you being able to manage your entire clan - Build your holdings, expand them, train units and send your military to where they're needed and command the battles yourself. Naval battles of ancient Japan (Floating castles and archers which adds a UNIQUE TOUCH) are an interesting thing, with entirely new tactics to learn - Which you can do yourself. You can lead your clan from humble beginnings to glory, personally commanding every battle on the way there. Watch those forts though - They may look simple, but they are not to be underestimated. Attrition and seasons add a nice strategic layer: you can't always afford to starve out cities but storming them will always be costly. I also like the weather mechanics like fog which greatly reduces visibility, while heavy rain diminishes the effectiveness of missile troops, such as archers or gunners, thus requiring the players to adapt their strategies. Also, as in Napoleon, armies standing on enemy provinces during winter season or fleets far from the coast suffer attrition. The campaign mechanics, such as the family tree and events you can encounter, really make you connect with your leaders. I also like the idea of generals being used more to help other units on the battlefield compared to them being used more as cavalry. 
Now on to Rise of the Samurai
In rise of the samurai players take on a brand new and independent campaign for Total War: Shogun 2 set in 12th century Japan. Set 400 years before the dramatic civil war depicted in Total War: Shogun 2, the "Rise of The Samurai" campaign is based on the Gempei War, a conflict between six legendary clans of the Taira, Minamoto and Fujiwara families. One flaw I have is that I don’t like that the first towns you get don’t have castles in them which makes them harder to defend, but that’s more of my problem just being used to some sort of castle like in shogun 2, and not so much a dig on CA. Also I thought the agents were perhaps a touch too powerful, Sou's in particular can unleash some devastating rebellions while I also never seemed to lose any agents (apart from Monomi) to failed attempts? New agents are hired through such new structures as the barter house. To unlock these, Rise of the Samurai specific arts trees must be climbed. Creative Assembly has thoroughly Genpei-fied almost every aspect of the game. I enjoy how this game adds the UNIQUE prequel story that’s not in other TW games
Now on to fall of the Samurai 
 It’s the 1860's and Japan has opened its ports to the outside world such as the United States, France, and Great Britain in to heavily influence the game which is UNIQUE. The play off between traditional sword and bow unit’s verses the emerging gunpowder technology creates an experience that is UNIQUE to the Total War series. I also like that in this expansion happiness seems more like a problem to me because some buildings increase modernization which citzens hate which is UNIQUE. Overall a very enjoyable game 9.5/10

Good game. Has a steep learning curve compared to previous Total war games but it's worth it. Lots of playability, it's pretty hard on the tougher settings. Graphics are great. It’s also quite different to previous versions and has a lot of depth. The usual total war problems remain thou in that auto resolving a battle (I have a massive fleet of cannon and normal ships vs a couple of fishing boats) can cause huge losses which, when you play yourself it’s impossible to lose a single person.

Shogun 2, what can I say besides I love this game. Shogun 2 is my first entry in the Total War series and I was not disappointed. In fact, if you enjoy turn based RTS strategy games I can say without a doubt you will love this game. I have sunk hours already into this game and I feel it still has things to offer, you cannot lose money on this purchase if you enjoy this genre. 

So far I’ve played the normal Shogun 2 campaign and the Fall of the Samurai campaign, personally I like the Fall of the Samurai battles a bit more because of the more modern weaponry, but I really miss the general’s speeches before battle which I thought were awesome in Shogun 2. Putting my personal preference aside on modern weaponry, I would say the standard Shogun 2 is a fantastic experience. 

Outside of combat, I felt the game was pretty average, diplomacy really is basic, and your family tree though cool to see doesn’t have that generational feel to it I started to wish for. So far, the AI is a bit frustrating for this game. Your allies cannot for the life of them hold their territory most of the time, you more often than not find yourself in an increasingly hostile map because those that naturally would ally themselves with you are eliminated rather quickly. Near the end I felt like the game became my clan vs the-rest-of-japan, which is pretty obnoxious. 

Regardless of my above gripes, I highly recommend this game.

Total War, what a series. While recent titles have been... subpar... there was a time where the series was considered one of the best. With titles such as Rome: Total War, Medieval 2: Total War, and the origianal Shogun: Total War, Creative Assembly made what I and many others consider the best strategy games of all time. However, of all the games in the series, one stands well above the others. That game is Shogun 2. While I still play the others often, I probably play Shogun 2 more than the rest of the series combined. It is a true masterpiece.

Pros: the game has great visiuals. Even zoomed in all the way, the character models look great. A lot of that detail is lost when you're actually playing the game, but it's always fun to zoom in and watch the 1v1 battles going on within this huge battle. There really is no feeling better than trapping your enemies and then watching arrows rain down on them. Every battle makes you go back and forth between feeling 100% in control to being helpless. It's a rollercoaster that never gets old. There are quite a lot of things to do off the battlefield. In fact, I enjoy the game most when I'm moving my units accross the world map, knowing that in 3 turns I'll conquer a whole clan. Plus, the financial system is pretty good to, if pretty simple. This is also a game that has good DLC. It isn't as good as say maybe Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon or Red Dead Redemption: Undead Nightmare but they offer plenty of new units that are different enough from the original game's units that they require a new strategy to use and deal with. Plus there are new maps (not a big deal, but still nice). Plus, it has a GREAT multiplayer. While most strategy games have pretty bad multiplayer (with a couple obvious exceptions) here it is maybe the highlight. It's pretty complex and I don't want to explain the game in a review, but if you're interested there are some videos on YouTube that'll explain it. It also has one of the best mod communites I've seen in a while. Darthmod is a must have if you want a bit of extra realism. 

Cons: longtimes have often accused this game of dumbing down the Total War experience, saying that you don't get the total idea (get it, total? ba dum tis). While technically they're right, I'd say streamlined is the better word (I think that the game feels more focused because of the simplification, but it's still NOT a simple game). Still, if you are into micromanaging every little detail, this game is far simpler than other games in the series so maybe you'd like them more. The other thing is that the diplomacy in this game is pretty bare bones. It gets the job done well enough, but compared to other games it is really lacking. Also, ship battles are awful. They make up a TINY ammount of the game and you can auto-resolve them so it isn't that big of a deal but still would have been nice.  

TL:DR- You can kill enemies as they run for their lives. 10/10 would massacre again

Honor and death...or utter humiliation in your classic total war game. 

This game sets in the warring states period of Japan. You are allowed to play as many factions (DLC included) with unique traits and bonuses. Each faction has one ultimate goal; obtain the title of shogunate and force other clans to recognize your power. 

You are a cowardly tactical commander controlling a vast army of your chosen clan behind your computer screen. In order to succeed, you must be capable of micromanaging units on the field and at sea. Flanking, positioning, and fortifying are all important; terrain is another useful concept to be aware of. You must also manage resources, form alliances, betray friendships, and troll others to obtain your goals outside of battle. Strategy is diverse from negotiations, assassinations, and total warfare; this game is meant for domination victories. 

Do you have what is takes to rule Japan? If not, you are a shameful display.
An absolute masterpiece of strategy gaming.  Highly recommend.

NOTE: This review is for the "Fall of the Samurai" DLC for Shogun 2 Total War

Overview: This game has given me the best Total War experience thus far. Nothing NEEDS to be changed to make it a better experience. While the battle pace is fairly quick and most line units are generally annihilated upon contact, mastery of battle takes time and patience. Diplomacy works the way it should. The tech tree is easily laid out. The UI is easy to understand. Everything was well put together and strategy is certainly required to effectively conduct your domain. 

Pros: 
          Addictive immersive large scale naval and land battles. 
          Effective UI and control.
          Diverse array of units and factions with mostly their own attributes.
          Decent AI strategy on harder difficulties. 
          Working multiplayer experience.
          Easy to grasp concepts and warfare.
          A great overall civil war strategy
Cons-or Considerations for improvement: 
-AI strategy on lower difficulties is simply too easy.
-Battle Pace is a little fast for the hardcore strategist looking for counters and flanks, late game battles generally result in massive numbers of casualties in very little amounts of time making grand or large scale battle strategies difficult to pull off before primary forces are either routed or the enemy is destroyed. (then again this only adds to the pressure of forming a quick and effective plan and could very well be considered a pro by most total war fans)

-Balancing the artillery... I don't know about most fans, but I greatly fear AI armies with 4 batteries of guns (even if their core army is nothing more than a levy. A single gun battery can be the winning factor in multiplayer games where your opponent is running on lower settings (smaller unit sizes) but the battery still contains 4 guns, so same firepower but less targets to rout...

Other than that, if you get shogun 2, GET this DLC pack, excellent add-on.

I have played Total War: Shogun 2 for a very very long time. I originally had this on release but I bought that at gamestop and never had it on steam. A while back I lost the key when I needed to install on a new computer. Got it on steam and I already have 250+ hours into it again. This game is literally a masterpiece. Over the (estimated) 1k hours I have put into it, I have never played a strategy game that had fit me so well, and here is why ( I hate formatting so screw the fancy stuff).

Gameplay: SHOGUN 2 itself has amazing gameplay. Like others in the Total War series, the gameplay is a mix of turnbased map movement campaign mixed with RTS battles when you engage an enemy. On the other hand, if you hate RTS games you also have the option of auto resolving all of the battles in the game. This however isn't nearly as polished and sometimes leads to the deaths of armies for stupid reasons. When not in battle, on the map you also have to deal with a lot of strategic choices. Diplomacy is huge, especially on harder difficulties where the AI can screw you over  and wipe you faster than you can blink. You can talk to other clans you have discovered to find good trade partners, allies and demand things from other clans, even if you have to threaten them. All clans have different levels of integrity and ambition. If you ally with a someone with terrible integrity, expect them to turn on you when you are off fighting battles. You also have a technology tree that you can advance for new things over turns, with quite a few options but at the same time not too many to overwhelm you. If you feel like you want more, there are tons of mods that completely redo the way the skill trees work, and even diplomacy. When it comes to actual fighting, the game is very realistic (minus those crazy bugs I was talking about) and as a RTS, lives up to the name with great praise.

Music/Audio: 10/10 definitely. The audio in the game was mostly made from scratch by creative assembly and sounds amazing with the atmosphere of the game. All of the music in the game was made by people who study such music, and trust me, it sounds absolutely amazing and is a perfect fit for the game. I believe Creative Assembly has a video on it.

Other Things: There is multiplayer campaigns and co-op is extremely fun with a friend who is dedicated to finishing a campaign with you. Head to Head campaigns are also quite fun but Multiplayer as a whole was not ready when it came out and has quite a few issues that needed polishing. While multiplayer is still extremely fun with a good friend, it could definitely use a few fixes, that aren't coming since the game is now ancient. The AI at harder difficulties has stupid scalings. Instead of being smarter they get a super steroid to their stats and better units faster. It is a unbalanced game at that point, but still amazingly fun. If you ever REALLY want to do a Legendary Campaign, I would watch Cosmic Contrarian on youtube. He doesn't do guides, but watching him play gives you a very good idea on how to manipulate ai and deal with the difficulty.


Overall I would say definitely buy this. It has it's faults. But for anyone interested in Japanese Culture or RTS games, this will definitely be a fun experience. Just wish they would make a Shogun 3.

11/10. The Last Great Total War game. Don't bother with that Rome II and Attila crap. Challenging AI even in easy mode and fast paced battles makes this a very fun RTS game,

This game becomes even better when you play with mods, radious mods will make life so much easier, and guns become insanely strong in shogun 2 especially when defending castles. Also try out the other interesting player made campaigns like Sekigahara (to play as Hideyoshi) or Morning Sun (To play as Korea, yes Korea. China is also playable although only in custom battles.). Expanded Map Campaign for the normal Shogun 2 map is also very good.

Getting Fall of the Samurai is also recommended especially if you like the 2003 movie The Last Samurai. Rise of the Samurai feels the same as Shogun 2 in both content and design, presumably because they take place in similar time periods anyway. Guns and gaijin mercenaries are more interesting.

Save yourself the cash and buy a more stable game instead.

Possibly the best Total War game to date, Shogun 2 has the right combination of setting, gameplay, mechanics, and fun to draw the player in. Set in Feudal Japan, you take control of one of many Japanese clans to fight to become Shogun of Japan. The campaign map is easy and interesting to work and navigate in. The battles and Combat are superb and attention to historical detail in the overall game is satisfying. Though there is not much terrian vareity in maps, so far I have only seen Plains or a pitiful fortress map in my game, detail in units, generals, and historical context are all pristine. Despite the few issues it has, Shogun 2 is a brilliant game and has earned its way in my book as one of the best RTS games I have ever played.

Great game, with loads of replay value due to the AIs behaving differently every time, as well as a high number of different clans to fight against. It takes a while to grasp the basics and a long time to master both economy and military aspects of the game. Campaigns can last weeks and best to be played in small chunks at a time. The battles can vary depending on the size of your armies, the number of enemy clans and their army sizes and your allies (who rarely appear during time of need, so only rely on your own). But the results of individual battles can affect the campaign map. The choreography of individual units down to the individual soldier is amazing, especially during fights. This game requires patience to learn every part of the game, foresight to look ahead of time and make critical decisions quickly during battle for it to be satisfying game.

[b]Total War: Shogun 2[/b]'s game-play is [i]amazingly[/i] unique and the mechanics are just as good.. The graphics are [i]breath-taking[/i], absolutely [i]magnificent[/i], however, there are a few issues such as it takes a bit of time to get use to if you aren't familiar with Mass Real Time Strategy games as well as the user interface being rather complicated. Also keep in mind before you pick this up that Mass Real Time Strategy games take a lot of [u]patience[/u] to play, as do any [b]RTS[/b] games. Regardless of the issues , all games have problems, it is still a [i]great[/i] game to pick up and as [i]tedious[/i] as it might be at first it can be just as [i]exciting[/i] and [i]rewarding[/i]. Total war is a very [i]respectable[/i] title, coming out with dozens of different  games and downloadable content that have yet to become [i]dull[/i] or [i]fall off[/i] even with tons of game time accumulated and I highly recommend it to anyone into [b]RTS[/b] games.

Total War: Shogun 2 is one of the best Total War games ever made. It's sad to see that many of the great aspects of Shogun 2 were never incorporated in Total War: Rome II. 

First of all, Shogun 2 makes a fantastic effort at portraying Japanese culture and brings about a type of mysticism in the game regarding their culture. The game map is beautifully detailed and colorful, and allows you to play anywhere on Japan. You are given a wide variety of factions you may choose from, and how you play after that is up to you. Of course, domination over the Japanese mainland is your end goal, but how you reach that goal is up to you. You could opt for betraying your allies and becoming a ruthless warlord, or makes strong alliances and co-dominate Japan with other factions. The choice is yours.

Military battles are great and the unit variety makes gameplay very interesting. It also increase the strategic use of your armies. Alongside that, the AI isn't too shabby. It is common to have insanely dumb AI in Total War games, but Shogun 2 does quite a good job at handling this.

There are many other elements in the game such as family trees, agents, general management, building management and more. I think it will be best for those who love RTS games to try those out rather than read my babbling. Trust me, Total War: Shogun 2 is a charm among RTS games.

[h1]Score: 8/10[/h1]

Total War games are like 2 game in one, first you have the part that play a bit like civilization on the map, complete with building various things in your cities and invading others. Once to armies meet however it plays like an RTS such as  Command and Conquer except you only have what you brought to the fight in you army(s). The fighting of units itself is well done and based on the era of time the game is based on as Total War games cover various time periods, from ROME to Medieval to Feudal Japan in this case. This one however takes the cake. The AI is good and smart, various and rather well balanced factions, tactical choice of weather or not you wanna trade for guns but if you do, can alter your clans religion making others hate you, etc. If your only going to try one of the Total Wars series I highly suggest this one. The campain time limit can be a pain, but you are free to continue playing after it passes no matter the outcome. If you feel you can't or simply don't wanna play alone. grab a friend and have a go at the co-op campain or head to head campain or the multiplayer battles. If your a fan of strategy games that actually require strategy and not as much speed then give this a try! It can be a bit pricey for some, but if its goes on sale it becomes pretty cheap. If memory serves I got it and all, but one DLC as a collection for around $15 (Only missing Fall of the Samurai). Choose a clan, and see if you got what it takes to take on Japan, be it alone, with or against a friend. One of the great strategy games, in a series of great strategy games.

The best Total War game since Medieval II. Generally speaking I really like it, although I have a few gripes.

Aspects I really like include:
Graphics, design and menu style.
The maps, location and period it is set.
Everything that makes most Total War games so great - epic campaign and battles.

Aspects I don't like include:
All soldiers on foot being able to burn down every castle door in the game. Where did every soldier get hundreds of torches? Why didn't the defenders soak wooden defences in water before the assault, or even stockpile water to use to fight fires?
The generals magic abilities - e.g. at the click of a button turn dirty, sweaty, fatigued soldiers who have been fighting uphill for a full hour into magically refreshed soldiers capable of running a marathon. These abilities belong in an arcade game, not a Total War game.

Wow, I absolutely love the total war series, but this game is something like 5 years old, and i cant even get past the 2nd Fall of the samurai historical mission because of game crippling glitches and errors, 6 tries and something every time.  Sometimes your troops won't come off of a defensive position and you can no longer control them, they are just there for good.  Or, your artillery just decides he has had enough and runs to edge of map or into the enemy troops while you are helpless to watch.  

Looked it up, just seems to be par for the course when it comes to this game, every single one of the problems i came across has been complained about relentlessly on the forums and review.  I can put up with a buggy problem here and there, but after spending an hour on a mission and watching your only artillery run away on a siege mission completely screwing you over, its a little disheartening.  

And to think, they have released not 1 but 2 new games since this, both being heavily criticized about being released way to early with bugs and issues aplenty.  Thought I was getting a pretty good deal picking this one up on sale, especially after putting a pre order on Rome 2 and being less than satisfied.  Reality, C.A. just made a few bucks off of their shoddy crappy incomplete game yet again at my expense, and thats gonna be the last time. 

Done with your games until i hear far more positive things in the future.  Put your time and energy into the game, do a friggen beta, quit having DLC ready on launch day with a game that doesn't work right.   Absolutely crushing for me as this series has been, and in older versions will continue to be, one of my absolute favorite games that I have ever played.

Three complaints:

1. Naval battles are awful. I found myself completely ditching all naval forces unless absolutely necessary.

2. AI is annoying once you are deemed "Legendary" status. At this point every living AI tries to kill you. It felt like a really cheap way to make the game artifically harder so you wouldn't win. I actually have lost two campagins specifically because time ran out from me fighting everyone or they simply overwhelmed me.

3. The economy and religion aspect is tough. Once you become a large nation everyone and their mother is demanding food or trying to start a revolt because the region isn't your religion. I ended up having to house tons of troops units at various cities just to keep them from revolting for over 10+ turns. Even then they sometimes were never happy. Eventually you learn to just expemt taxes from the regions that will never quit trying to rebel and hope you have enough money for other stuff. It's damn tough keeping everything under control and defending yourself and trying to take things over before the time limit is up. This aspect also made the game feel artifically difficult.

Other than that I really liked the game and recommend it. It's a good buy for $30 and will keep you entertained for at least 50 hours or so of gameplay. I'm a very casual player and I have over 80 hours logged, so I felt it was a good buy.

Welcome to a Luke Approved! review.

First off.. Rome 2.. is a different can of worms we shall not open today : ) 

I'll try to keep this short and sweet. Shogun 2 is by far still the best Total War game yet released. Having played all these games since the release of the first Shogun, It is nice to  see the series to come full circle - and what a circle!

Medievil to Rome was a big step for this company, the orignial Rome Total War being a strategy masterpiece for it's time, encorporating a new 3D graphics engine to the series and new features, further expanded into Medieval 2 and the add-ons of that era for the series, with the original Rome still being the pinacle.

And then came along Shogun 2. What a beautiful package. Yet again a new graphics engine and more depth to the features that stayed true to the original Shogun. The artwork is stunning, the story telling style is very inkeeping with the orients and the expansions: Rise and Fall of the Samurai gives the best Total War experience yet.

In my opinion - Empire and Nepoleon took a different path and were nice to see some different mechanics, making more use of firearms and stationary guns.. But is was lacking the depth and mysticism of Shogun 2, even the naval battles in Shogun 2 are more appealing down to the diversity of the vessels and the more responsive mechanics.

Here in Shogun 2 the developers have done a great deal to frame the emotion of the theatre of war in the orient. From the cherry blossom falling from the trees and cascading accross fields of vibrant flowers, to the harsh contrast of sanguine blood against a tundra.

Buy Shogun 2 and be happy to own a masterpiece!

THe last TW I played to death was Medieval 2. I played Empire and NTW briefly but got bored. That being said, here's a few reasons why I think this game is a winner.

It looks amazing even 4 years on. Not just the battlefield graphics, but the effort they put into music and aesthetics which makes Shogun 2 really unique and immersive. The campaign map is a serene mix of handrawn maps and little 3D communities and towns, forests that change colour in the autumn, fields that freeze over in the winter.  Everything is represented as drawings and paintings. Units communicate in Japanese. It's polish like this that shows CA went the extra mile.

On the battlefield it also looks amazing. The individual choreographed fights among thousands of detailed soldiers is incredible, I've never seen anything like it before in a strategy game.

AI is decent. Not amazing, but not brain-dead either. They use cavalry quite well to surround you and get behind your lines. They know when to attack vs. defend on a hill, and support weakened units with reserves. However I've found they're too quick to charge into battle even when they're at a disadvantage. EIther way I get a good challenge.

There are very clear advantages/disadvantages between unit types, terrain, weather etc. so you can quickly formulate tactics and strategies.

Campaign-wise, I find it's the same old as previous TW games. Attrition and seasons add a nice strategic layer: you can't always afford to starve out cities but storming them will always be costly.

I really can't think of any major problems with this game. 9.5/10.

At first, this game can be pretty difficult. However, it's a game that requires alot of trial and error: Which is not a bad thing at all. I will be honest though, as someone who was new to the series even the easiest difficulty setting can be brutal if you're not careful. Ruling over Japan takes alot of planning on your part. Where to attack next, who should I ally with, who will I steamroll to add to my territory? Summary:
Great, simplified, entry-level strategy game hampered with technical issues

The Good:
+ I am not really a strategy game player, and this game was easy to pick up and have fun with on default difficulty.  
+ Everything is simple: user-interface, controls, explanations, access to unit details, etc
+ Although this game has a lot of gameplay concepts, none of them are very complex, and they are easily understood and accessible.  This game will reward you for doing things that make sense, and punish you for doing things that goes against the general rule (like cavalry charging into defending spearmen)
+ During real-time battles (which you can pause), you can use simple strategies such as taking and defending high-terrain, flank attack, forest ambush, or just plain head-on battle of attrition if you have superior units.  It's really rewarding when you are using simple strategies that you think will work, and it works out.  When things don't go well, it's really easy to understand what you did wrong (usually, battle of attrition with similar strength gives you the worst outcome).  
+ The overworld management game is simple as all you do is build up your military units, select next thing to build on your tech/skill-tree, build buildings that affect your attribute multipliers on military units, and position your units to attack and defend.  Economy is also dead simple as all you do is set tax rates depending on provincial happiness.  Politics is also simple, as you only have about 10 options to choose from that affect how others behave toward you.

The Bad:
- The load times.  Even on SSD, things take forever to load
- Graphics and system performance.  It's not the best looking game in the world even to 2012 standards, but it struggles.  Only single core on your CPU will be utilized, and framerate drop is noticeable.

Overall:
Even if you are not a great strategy gamer, you'll have some fun and challenge with this anyways.  I can see how awesome this game can be when played against a human-opponent.

It would be another thing if there was a warning on the product page, but nothing on the product page indicates a lack of cross-platform functionality. This is an easy enough fix that was stated earlier in community forums, so it's unclear to me why it hasn't been done yet.

"SHAMEFUR DISPRAY" -The Announcer Guy

Because of my poor upbringing with anime, I thought Japan was stupid.  That was, of course, until I took a global history class in high school, and learned about the super badass history of pre-Western Japan.

As of this review, I have only played this game for 5 1/2 hours.  From that time, however, I can tell you this game is awesome.  Not necessarily "awesome" like "totally rad bruh", but "awesome" as in inspiring awe.

The RTS combat depth of this game is like something out of a LOTR film.  Mechanics include: Ship boarding, burning ships, castle sieging, hill charges, and troop morale.

Speaking of troops.  In this game, I feel like each individual soldier is counted.  For example, with archers, rather than getting in range, shooting at an enemy unit, and having a % chance to kill a random soldier in the unit; every arrow launched has a path determined once it is launched, and if that path happens to intersect with a soldier, then the arrow will hit someone.

Shogun 2 is one of the few strategy games that makes me feel like I'm commanding an army instead of playing high-tech chess.

This game has been out quite a while, but needless to say, it is one of the better releases of The Creative Assembly in a number of ways. I have played every single Total War that came out and I must say, Shogun 2 is one of the most streamlined and polished games that The Creative Assembly has produced.

Sure, it's not ground breaking like Rome: Total War but this game took the franchise to such a high level that Rome 2 paled in comparsion to it, though Rome 2 is not a terrible game in its current state.

The graphics are top-notch, though there are some times when I feel that the soldiers do look a little too glossy at times, there is no doubt that they look good. The only thing that rivals the graphics is the animation. Though realistically speaking, most ashigaru battles  during the Sengkoku Jidai consisted of giving the men a spear and standing in place while poking their spears forward, or swinging their spears from above their heads to the ground, I rather prefer the animations of the units to reality.  When unit formations break down and battles turn into one-on-one contests of skill, it feels like you are watching a movie.

Siege battles are messy. But that has been a problem ever since the early total war games. Heck, it's been a problem in the history of war. Sieges are always messy.

The battlefields are amazing as tthe terrain changes with every passing season. Though this has been true with almost every total war series, the way they depicted the seasons, including the occassional sakura petals in the spring, or the leaves in the summer that pop out of the screen adds a good effect, especially while your general or daimyo is giving his speech.

Battle AI is capable enough though they sometimes throw their general away in battle by leading a suicidal charge against your men. Also exploitable at times. Campaign AI is decent enough as well, though can sometimes be passive at times, and downright lobotomized in other times. But during realm divide, they get really aggressive.

The interface is really streamlined when it comes to the battle, though I find the unit cards a little bland for my tastes. Battles are a bit quick, but what can you expect when you give peasants weapons? They break rather easily, compared to their samurai counterparts.

The campaign map is beautiful, though I sometimes wish that I could visit my city, like in the original Rome. The tech trees are streamlined, though I think it's a bit too simplistic. Diplomacy is still broken. Realm divide can catch you off guard. The family tree is excellent. I think they took a page right out of the BBB mod back in Medieval 2, where you can give your generals offices.

Family members and generals are really integral to building your empire. This is one of the best parts of the game, and in my opinion, whzg makes it better than Rome 2. Your generals can easily sway the tide of battle if used and positioned correctly.

The best part of this is how focused the game is. Sure, it isn't as epic as conquering Europe and the New World ala Medieval Total War, or Rome, but what makes this a remarkable game is that Creative Assembly shows you evolution of military tactics and weapons in Japan, from the Genpei War, to the Sengkoku Jidai, to the Boshin War. And that, my friends, is the purest essence of a Total War game: taking the gamer on a journey of the evolution of warfare albeit in a limited setpiece.

As a strategy fan, this game is a must-play.
Great game!

Shogun 2 is the greatest Total War game ever, and one of my favorite games of all time. If you don't own this and are into strategy games at all, I very highly recommend it.

Shogun 2 offers a more refined and polished experience than any other Total War title. The base game is set in the Sengoku Jidai, beginning in 1545. Shogun 2 examines warfare in fuedal Japan more closely and accurately than any other game, with an array of samurai, ashigaru, monk, and European units.

The DLC campaign, Rise of the Samurai, takes you back to the Gempei War, beginning in 1175. Units unique to this time period are used, including early samurai, levies, and sou. Most noticeable in this earlier form of Japanese warfare is the complete absence of gunpowder, the relative newness of the samurai class, and the loose unit formations. Rise of the Samurai is an experience unique from that of the base game's campaign, and is definitely worth purchasing.

Fall of the Samurai, the standalone expansion to Shogun 2, is set during the Boshin War, beginning in 1865. The explosive rise of the modern era in Japan that began with the end of its isolation ignited a civil war between those dedicated to the cause of restoring the emperor to power, and those who remained loyal to the Tokugawa shogun. Warfare during this time period features extensive use of rifles and artillery, as the time of the samurai class approaches its end. Traditional units are still available, and useful, to recruit however.

All three campaigns for Shogun 2 offer unique experiences that warrant multiple playthroughs. Shogun 2 also features excellent multiplayer progression, through experience unlocks and a unique veteran unit system, and features multiplayer matchmaking, as well as two player online campaigns. All of the DLC for Shogun 2 is worth purchasing, though some may wish to pass on the unit packs. The faction packs offer unique factions unlike anything else found in the base game, and are definitely worth purchasing. I, myself, would recommend all the DLC, as the units included in the packs are fun, unique units.

Shogun 2 is a masterpiece RTS/TBS hybrid, and showcases epic, historically authentic samurai warfare unlike anything else.

Shogun 2 is a fun, fast paced and exciting game to say the least. The multiplayer is great, the campaign is great, the units are great and the varying factions are all great. Shogun 2 is the second version of the shogun series and one of the newer Total War games. It is unique in the use of its DLC to expand on the base game and features other great unique features that older Total War games lack. Now, although medieval Japan is not my variety historical period I loved the look of the game and got into lots of information about it before buying it finding it to be worth it. Sadly my system is not the best at running it but in playing it I've enjoyed it, especially the multiplayer for what I could run smoothly. With co-op systems, avatar general and army building combined with leaderboards that can be attributed to Steam groups the system is a great improvement to the Total War games before it. I personally stuck to the multiplayer for most of my playing period with the game unlike in previous games where I stuck to the single player nearly the whole time. Multiplayer alone would still make this game good. Unit choices are another really great aspect which works with the varying factions too. Their is even one on the president! I won't give you any clues on what its called though. The other great thing about the game not mentioned yet is the graphics. The general look of the game is great despite my poor specifications which shows that it is great beyond what I considered already good as higher specification computers will have an even better sight. To summarise the good points-

- Improved multiplayer
- Good DLC that works well improving on the base game
- Great graphics
- Interesting and varied number of units
- Unique and original factions
- Great Campaign
- Great Historical battles with huge clashes and great explanations to them

Now to the bad. The game is hard to run for me and since my system is alright I would say it may be an issue for some others out there. Lowering the quality of the game helps, but the single player can lose the nice look due to the game struggling. Also, from what I saw, the early mulitplayer battles are awful if you don't have riflemen as they are incredibly over-powered.  The DLC, although improving on what the game offers greatly is a bit unfair at times to those without it. Without DLC its hard to beat armies who have them and since most players have already got high in the rankings late entries may find the first ten to twenty matches a bit of a slaughter on them. I got some riflemen and soon found I was the one slaughtering others which became fun though, so it worked out! To summarise the bad points-

- Over-powered DLC at times
- Specification is slightly too high for some lower specified computers.

So the game is great despite its obsession with paying more on upgrades in and out of the game to make your experience more pleasing in combat I would easily score this game a 4/5, 8/10 or 80%. It shows Total War games to be improving in many aspects and is definetly a great strategy game overall.

This is easily the most thematically unique and tactically competent Total War game to date. It contains a ton of content and additional available content that is actually worth playing. The base game gives you the playground of Japan during Sengoku jidai (the Sengoku period), known as the Warring States period of Japan. It's your clan's job to become the supreme ruler of Japan, and your task to become the Shogun of Japan! You lead battles and manage the empire. This is a game that gives you tons of content: and that's just the base game. There are two major DLC campaigns: one is Rise of the Samurai, which takes place many years before Sengoku jidai, where you try to get your clan in a position of power in a similar way. However, things are different: soldiers fight with more primitive weapons and your agents are different. The other campaign is Fall of the Samurai, which takes place after the events of SHOGUN 2's main campaign. As the British and French influence on Japan increases, a war between the Shogun and Emperor starts, and your clan gets to pick a side. Support the Emperor, the Shogun or try to unify Japan under your own clan's rule in a wicked expansion that gives you modern units and completely overhauls the game, but in a more major way than Rise of the Samurai did.

Shogun 2 still rates as my shiny gold star for the Total War series. In particular, the Shogun 2: Fall of the Samurai expansion is one of the best games I have ever played. A mixture of RTS and tactical turn based strategy, the Total War games grasp me in a way that the Civilization series never could. Shogun 2 brings plenty of new features to the franchise, but what really brought the game to life for me was the combination of traditional melee units with gunmen. In Empire, building melee units beyond cavlary comes across as a mostly pointless endevor. Medieval 2 was a game of horesys. Shogun 2 is the game of mixed armies. Using a combination of cannons, cavlary, archers, gunmen, spearmen, and samurai comes across as one of the more diverse experiences in the Total War universe. Large-scale decisions, such as how to tech, choosing a large standing army or greater economic technologies creates an interesting experience where your decisions outside of combat directly impact your battles.

FotS also brings along a few interesting gameplay mechanics. Railroads allow you to ferry troops across large sections of the map in minimal turns, while naval barrages against land units and structures mean that your navy recieves more use beyond that of anti-raiding parties.

I've found this game to be one I regard exceptionally high - admittedly I am a fan of the Total War Series, I will however admit to some of their entries short-comings. However, Shogun 2 is one of their shining additions to the series - the vanilla game is one the allows multiple avenues in maneuvering around the political upheaval of the Sengoku period with being able to police your state and bribe armies with secret police. Quietly eliminate, or spy on, those who oppose you by employing ninja. Convert provinces, and incite rebellions with monks. Or provide your enemy with a seductive blade in the form of one of your geisha. Though, there is still quite a great deal of room to employ much more forward methods with fielding armies. The DLCs have their own merit, though I have yet to thoroughly explore their additions, nor have I explored the war-scorched world of the multiplayer available. I will ammend these at a later date when I have a thorough opinion formed on it. Currently, 10/10.

I love the Total War franchise, but its always a gamble for me when I try out new ones. Some, like Rome: Total War, are great, with a continous development and a possibility to actually conquer most of the "world". Others, like Empire: Total war, are too difficult and slow, making expansion take forever and always leaving you exposed no matter what you do.

Total War Shogun 2 has the perfect combination of continous development and difficulty. At the easy setting, you can more or less steamboat through the entire campaign, and at the hardest setting you have to plan your every single move. Personally I mostly play at the normal difficulty, where you get some opposition and have to be a bit tactical, but still see some development and progression in every other turn.

As with any Total War game, there's a high replay value, as each faction offers you a new challenge, with only the end-game becoming seemingly similar. Once you've played through this game a couple of times, I recommend getting the expansions: Fall of the Samurai & Rise of the Samurai, as these will further change the gaming experience and tactics that you have to use, without changing the difficulty (as did the expansions to Rome: Total War, which made that game unplayable).

Total War Shogun 2 is a wonderful addition to the total war franchise. this game is without a doubt my favorite total war game, other total war games are great to but shogun 2 is small enough to finish a domination campain in a couple days (on hard difficulty) but big enough to keep you interested. japan is small and surrounded by water so there is always the possibility of an invation by sea so you cant leave a small amout of soldiers at each base for population unrest. you have to keep a regulated army and navy in order to survive. total war games like Rome Total War and Empire Total War has land locked countries so you can create a war front or boundries that keep you safe this game is different. it takes a great amount of cosentation to keep take of all your land and to keep track of your enemies. that all being said there are cons to this game such as your allies can turn on you at a seconds notice so no sense of realibility. then again it is a computer and they have no feeling towards you so when you play dont try to be a peace maker. there is also the problem that all of the total war games have and that is that they exellerate time to quickly between turns though the fall of the samurai dlc is an exeption to this.  so i totally recomend this game for fast pace players.

This is the first real postive review I have been able to write on the TW series. For those familiar to the TW series, YOu will be happy to know that the original Shogun has come back and come back with a vengence. For those unfamiliar with TW, this is a total redo to the first in the TW series. Which ever you are in temrs of the series, you will be happy to know there are very few bugs, and none that are game breaking. The mechanics work beautifully. The AI works (this has been and continues to be an issue in past and present titles.) 

This is a grand strategy game. So it is slow at times... most of the time. The real fun is in the battles. Throwing hundreds, even thousands of men into the meat grinder. The Multiplay battles make this game truly great.

There are 2 expansions, a prequal that goes back several hundred years and really focuses on the samuri. The other goes forward in time and shows the power of modern units, gunpowder, canons that do real damage and rarely miss and a realy fun unit with the gatling gun. Watch your opponents die quickly if they decide to charge head on.

This game has the most hours on my account of any steam game, and at the time of this review I have all the other games beat by ~100 hours.

The down side to Creative Assembly games is the nickel and dime DLC. None of it is really needed and would even avoid the prequal expansion "Rise of the Samuri."

Overall, I love this game, One of the few from this series line that I continued to play beyond the 1 year mark.

8/10
Best in the series.
It's good.

Creative Assembly have been coasting since the original Rome: Total War.

This game is ridiculously resource intensive; AMD CrossFire support has been broken pretty much since day 1, significantly hurting performance.

The campaign AI is terrible, as bad as the original Medieval Total Wars - it CHEATS blatantly by giving itself free resources, and makes irrational decisions for its factions with the sole purpose of dicking you (the human player) over to create the illusion of difficulty.
The "Realm Divide" mechanic is just bullshit - simply hand-waving a lot of fundamental game balance just to artificially ramp-up the difficulty.

The modding community is solid - although these are just band-aids that patch-up the feckless and lazy design decisions the devs made on the game proper.

On the plus side, the game's pretty, the setting is entertaining enough, and there's an obscene amount of playtime to be had if you can ignore the bullshit.

Final verdict:  Do yourself a favour and get the original Rome: Total War instead.

The game Total War: Shogun 2 is awesome. I currently have 40 hours logged, and those 40 hours have just flown by. Total War: Shogun 2 is a strategy game where you are a lord and have to conquer Japan, along the way of becoming Shogun or Emperor you will make allies, enemies, and trade routes. The combat system is great as it has been in all Total War games. Strategies and analyzing and reacting to situations are key to winning. The new castle sieges add a new element to this franchise. Storming the walls is more tricky then one might think it would be with archers picking off melee units, it turns into a ranged battle until one side gets weakened enough for your melee troops to take to the walls. Another element Total War introduces is a co-op campaign. You have the option of trying to unite Japan with your Pal or going against him and fighting to the death till one of you end up on top. Now with the cons, I wish to co-op campaign would have supported more than two players. Another con is that the expansions aren’t as balanced as the original game. Other than those two cons I would recommend this game.

Game is beautiful and runs great on an i5 with a Radeon 6xxxx with 1GB (8GB system RAM).

Game is VERY deep and fun. Diplomacy, trade, Special agents, variety of technology (Arts) to research, and units to employ. You can even manage your family--designating heirs, having kids, etc.

The heart of the game is the tactical combat on the battlefield which I was at first concerned about being an almost exclusive TURN BASED player. But, you will find that with the pause feature it is manageable and even enjoyable. This game would actually be lessened by making it pure turn-based combat (something I shock myself in saying). Not knowing what every single unit is up to at all times  is the nature of the army vs. army/nation vs. nation scope of games in the total war series I find.

Great game. Very addictive. This will probably encourage me to try others of the series as this was my first.  9/10 (a 10/10 FOR ME would be something entirely turn based, but again that's not this kind of game anyway nor do I ask it to be).

I really wanted to like this game because of the classical Japanese setting and spectacular graphics, but I just couldn't get into it. First of all, the font is tiny as hell, and it doesn't seem possible to adjust without really hacking the game resources (just google "shogun 2 font" and you'll see that plenty of others have the same complaint). I usually play games on either a projector or a somewhat large monitor at 1080p, and in both cases it's basically impossible to read anything.

Coupled with the fact that there is lots of text that one needs to pay attention to, it almost kills the whole experience. But forgetting about the font, the campaigns are just not that interesting. It feels like you basically hit "next turn" a bunch of times, then march into a big dramatic battle, which you can actually skip to come to essentially the same result. Maybe I'm just more of a Civ/AoE fan, but I have just never been able to really get into any of the TW games, this one included.

When I lived in Japan, and walked around the bustling Tokyo metropolis, a question often came to my mind. And it was: wouldn't it be super cool if, like, all these Japanese people started shooting each other? 

Total War: Shogun 2 (Fall of the Samurai) has answered my question. And the answer is: "Hai!"

It's so fun! Seeing Japanese shoot each other, especially with artillery and gatling guns! And when you see a bunch of spear-weilding Japanese rushing an enemy Japanese rifle unit, and get mowed down, oh man, it feels so good! Like an angel has come down from Heaven to bless my soul. There's this inner peace unlike any other when I see, like, 5,000 Japanese dudes unload on each other until they're all dead.  

So you should get this game. It also features boats.

Shogun II was the last well polished game released by Creative Assembly before they decided that giving a bunch of brand new Devs complete and utter power to the franchise name was somehow a smart idea (I suspect meth was involved by this decision) 
Shogun II and Total War are in a genre not many style'd in its own right, it mixes two genres practically seamlessly, Grand Strategy campaigning, with an expansive map much like Crusader Kings II or Europa Universalis IV, and a real time strategy element that has you commanding your army(s) in battle. It's not like other real time strategies where building one unit is quite literally one unit, or three units (Rise of Nations did this) that decrease in power as the life bar diminishes. Building one unit can mean anywhere from 100-300 units in that one unit card depending upon what unit type it is (These unit numbers are changed through the use of mods of course.) 
So here goes: each Total War prior to Shogun II had its strengths and speeds in terms of how it was as a game. Shogun II Total War's strength lies in its polish. To date, Shogun II is the most polished Total War game currently out there. The glint of wet armor as you play on a map where rain is the main factor, the little lanterns used to keep light in night battles, The way a drum is played as your men walk to their inevitable battle. Everything just oozes polish about this game, because everything is so well done in detail, it's impressive not to marvel about it in the slightest. 
Balancing isn't much of a issue either, since all the factions to choose from are more or less the same with a specific strength variation of one or two different units. This gave the developers of the game a lot of time to polish everything else, every little detail that just makes the game so beautiful. 
I recommend it wholeheartedly.

The first Total War game I ever played was the orginal Shogun (many years ago) and I've played the series ever since. 

The orginal Shogun is quite simplistic and rather dated now, in terms of the things that newer Total war games have to offer, however my love for that game did lead me to buy Shogun 2. 

And I've not regretted that decision. 

Shogun 2 is by far one of the best Total war games I've played. It takes everything that is good about TBS games and adds to it;

~ Weather conditions play more of a factor in battles, adding realism. Thus players need to adapt better strategies when deploying troops. 

~ Naval battles have been expanded and mechanics are much improved from Empire. 

~ The overall feel to the game is improved. Clans and Generals seem to have different personalities which enhances your intrigue for the game. 

~ The Campaign map on Empire, I felt was too large and I personally seemed to get bogged down with watching things such as finances and overseas settlements than actually trying to dominate the map. 

Shogun goes back to focussing on the "War" element, that made Rome and Medieval 2 so popular but it adds more in depth realism where it's wanted most; battles. 

~ Creating an avatar and unlocking units on online multiplayer keeps your drawn once you're through with campaign.

By far one of the best games I own. Must buy for TBS gamers and Total War fans.

I acquired this game because I wanted a Samurai: Total War game. It fulfills that requirement and more. The campaigns can be tough, especially since you seem to be beset by enemies, and you have a limited amount of time to fulfill your ambition of ruling Japan. This is especially true if you are at the far end of Honshu and need to march all the way to Kyoto to secure the Shogunate.

And that's just the base campaign. There is a Rise DLC which puts you in the same situation about 400 years before the base one. And then there is Fall, which adds a LOT of gunpowder weaponry and modern tactics, and deals with a short period that lead to the modernization of Japan (and indirectly to the Japanese Empire of WWII).

There is also a multiplayer game that can be fun, though challenging in a different way. As hard as the AI can be, other players are often craftier and less prone to being trampled underfoot by cavalry. And since those with Fall can use their weaponry it can sometimes lead to quality versus quantity matchups.
