A Great RTS/TBS!

The map is small, the factions are fairly similar and the units are identical except a select few. This TW focuses more on infrastructure and politics. Allying yourself with the right factions will help in your survival and overall control of the island. Without decent trade to generate a substantial income you will not be able to make the right treaties and build your military. Without substantial political support, seizing the throne will mean suicide for your faction as it will strike enmity with all the factions including the relentless emperor. Teching is also important, staying traditional or being progressive opens various technologies that impact your economy, military, society and many other factors. You will miss the feeling of conquest but still feel the sense of accomplishment from your many decisions. One of the best games from CA and for the genre itself.

Many times I have played RTS games and thought they seemed more to do with micro and building units at an insane pace rather than planning and tactics.  Total War: Shogun 2 is the opposite of this formula.  Battles have to do with unit composition and strategy.

It's hard to point to exactly what is wrong with this one. For being set in such a traumatic period the setting is dull. Alternate history where no matter what happens it changes nothing because the differences between the factions are negligable. It's a tiny map and each faction has the exact same objective so you'll be doing the same things in each playthrough. This makes the  gamepaly repetitive. The units and cultures are generic to all factions with only slight variations. The samurai units are so grossly overpriced you can only justfy training them to have a prettier army. 
The AI does not exist. Spawned stacks of troops march towards you in response to your progress. This provides the exact same experience each time you play with only slight variations. Tactically the "AI" responds to your mouse clicks rather than actual troop movements in a most unnatural way.
Naval warfare is extremely unexciting. Nearly all engagements, even with overwhelming force, are inconclusive draws that end when one side decides to leave the itty bitty map.
They did fix seiges which have always been broken in the series, but they did so by basically getting rid of them, all walls can be climbed and seige weapons are so rare you're likely to never see them.
I understand that the multiplayer is good. 
I typically get hundreds of hours out of Total War games, this one I got one enjoyable campaign and a hundred hours trying to figure out why it's so incredibly not fun.

SHOGUN 2 TOTAL WAR REVIEW:

Shogun 2 total war does achieve beyond its predecessors by bringing the rts game up to date with the others that sweep the market today. I was really surprised for this game as it brings a great multiplayer experience to the table. The visuals do look impressive as you see thousands of samurai sweeping across the hillside as their armour shimmers and vibrant maps that gives your eyes a treat to look at, it is probably the best atmospheric total war that i have ever played. The game takes place in japan around the 16th century, rival clans battle it out to become the shogunate who is the head of power in all of japan, there are clans including Takeda, oda, shimazu and alot more. you will also find the Tokugawa clan which in reality, became shogunate around that time. Personally shogun total war has been polished and it has been a long road since the first shogun. Even though shogun is impressive, it does lack the inteligence of the ai, i can tell you that they have been improved it quite a bit but it still has some issues like random armies trying to invade you with only 1 unit and others like cavalry charging at you but then when they are 5 metres away, they decide to dismount. Complaints aside, this game is great. it has a great setting and it is just empowering when you have thousands of samurai and spearmen charging into battle. This game is amazing, i recommend it and it is more fun when you are playing with friends and teaming up to crush you opponent. SCORE: 9/10

SHOGUN 2 FALL OF THE SAMURAI REVIEW:

Doesn't it feel great when you are mowing down hopeless wandering samurai that are charging  at you with gattling guns. Yes, i am talking about the dlc for shogun 2 total war, fall of the samurai and as the name suggests it is the time when western nations pour into japan and tred on its original traditions of war. This time was a very interesting part of history as western nations fueled Japan up with the latest technologies in that time like gattling guns, rifles and gunboats. now look what they have become today, an industrialized modern country. The game starts off around the 19th century where feudalisation in japan has  flourished. Nations like Britian, France and America fuel  Japan with these technologies to make it become a superpower. The new dlc brings the game up to the point where it is close to modern day, you will see things like torpedo boats, gatling guns, and powerful field artillery which can destroy any melee unit. you will also get to try out units like the royal marines, shogunate imperial infantry and imperial infantry whcih remind me of the guys from the last samurai which is a great movie that is in the same time period. the campaign map gets a new visual look, this means you will see railway systems going from each town andmore modern buildings in the cities. clans again fight for the soul of japan and it is cool seeing the tradtitonal part of japan fight with the modern side. this is a great dlc and i recomend it if you like to see explosions and smoke. SCORE: 8.5/10

[i]Foreword: This review is also heavily influenced by the FotS DLC.[/i]

One day you realize you're at that point in life where you really can't afford to spend too much time dawdling on games, but now and then you find your hobby clawing its way back. When you find it's "that" particular game eating away at what little free time you have, you know it was one of the few that was worth picking up.

Shogun 2 is that bane and joy in equal measure. Not enough agents scouting the campaign map? An enemy army is on your capital's doorstep more often than not. Place your traditional units on the other side of a steep hill? Force the enemy modern rifle infantry units up on a tiring march... only to get reamed for never being presented an opportunity to fire before going into melee.

In some ways the game is not beginner-friendly. The tutorials leave a lot to be desired and you're left looking for other avenues (the wiki is a good first stop). I will say this: Once you're into it, [i]Shogun 2 delivers some of the most satisfying experiences I've had in this genre[/i]. I find myself watching the same replays repeatedly; from the enemy point of view as they split their cavalries into my flanks and into hidden spear walls, and again from my perspective when I force the bulk of the enemy force to wedge itself into a killzone.

If you're one of "those" types, I think the most rewarding experience to reap out of this game is watching that strength bar run all the way from almost completely red, to fully yellow by the end of a heroic victory. I'm ashamed to admit I hide the majority of my playtime by going into "offline mode"; replays are the ultimate ego stroke.

Having said this, I will not completely lavish it with praise; the game does have issues. It suffers from a thoroughly confusing honour system. At times you'll wonder if your allies will see you as dishonorable and strike your flanks. You're considered a "backstabber" for attacking a clan you've given safe-passage to... after it declares war on you and its army is laying seige to your city.

You're never entirely sure what counts as "line-of-sight" for your artillery units, right up to the time to deploy and attempt to fire. The arrow markers on the campaign map indicating your army's movement can also be misleading. On more than one occasion I found an army stopping just short of a city that was about to go into unrest. To be fair, I was taxing at the maximum every other turn, but it was very hard mode, so my sin is absolved!

Aside from that, this is a solid game. Especially if you have friends to play with on multiplayer. Some advice: As with any online game, just have an idea of what you expect from each other first! Don't force demanding play times and everything should be kept civil... unless you've included a blood and gore mod. I recommend grabbing this and the FotS DLC. I'm not saying you [b]should[/b]. Because that would be wrong. Sort of.

The total war series has always been my favorite, and Shogun 2 is my favorite of that series.  It has great gameplay mechanics on both the tactical and strategic levels due to a simple but elegant unit system.  Each unit excels in a certain situation, and there are enough unit types so that even after hundreds of hours, you can still innovate with units you have never really used before.  Each army build has strengths and weaknesses, and each clan favors slightly different build, giving lots of replay value.  Simple but elegant is really the theme of the game, and is carried over to the building trees, tech trees, agents, and political aspects of the game.  Each aspect of the game is simple enough to pick up and use easily, but the game is deep enough to allow a great deal of engaging and varied gameplay.  The campaign map, tactical maps, in game encyclopedia, and user interface show the attention to detail that was given during development.  In addition, I strongly recommend any and all of the DLC, but especially the Sengoku Jidai unit pack, which gives unique units to each clan.

First of all, I haven't played all games of the Total War franchise, only Medieval 2 and a bit of Rome 2, but Shogun 2 was the best so far. Its really captivating and its one of those games which can tie you to your chair for hours and hours, just like Anno 1503. I'm not bad at strategy games but I think that even for strategy newbies this game will be easily understandable and enjoyable.

Pros:   

-The setting. Feudal Japan is cool, Samurais are cool, Ninjas are cool, being Shogun is cool.
-The graphics. Ok, the map is not the eyecatcher here but the battles are. The details are amazing and you can follow each samurai until his death.
-Intuitive control and UI. Its impressive how easy to understand this game is. The principles and priorities are clear, you don't have to search for anything and the interfaces for diplomacy, trading and all that stuff are well done.
-Sound in general. Wether its the effects, the music or voices (the japanese accent sounds great), everything feels right.
-The campaign. Its pretty long and its full of surprises, you can always do something in a different way than you did before.
-The characters. I'm talking about the generals, daimyos, ninjas, metsukes and all these people. I got pretty attached to them and it was exciting to see how they grew with the time (plus the skilltrees are awesome).

Cons:

-After you've finished the big campaign, there ain't much to do, you can go for the DLC's like Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai, but if you want to play the campaign again I noticed that you don't get any more clans that you can play, like in Medieval 2 for instance.
-Sometimes you have to repeat battles (if you mustn't lose them) and it can get pretty frustrating after the 17th try.

Conclusion:

I highly recommend this game and if you enjoy feudal japan and strategy games, get this game. Now.

I rarely bother to write reviews but this is a game I highly reccomend and felt it needed a little explaining.

Things to point out: 

Strategy/Replay - The three major expansion all offer something different. A different story with a different kind of game play - from deciding if your focus is monks, samurai, etc (rise of the samurai) to deciding on traditional units or modern units (fall of the samurai). 

Graphics/Crashing - I hear a lot of people with issues in this regard. My older computer (that was once a "top of the line gaming computer") hated running this game. It gave me tons of issues. My new computer has not run into a single issue yet. So details aside it is likely your computer that is to blame for the crashes - try not to let your ego ruin your chance at liking this game.

Gameplay - No matter what campaign you are playing this game offers so very much. You get to pick skills (for direct or general style combat), setup family/clan aspects from assigning titles, who your heir is or even adopting generals. Your army is very customizeable and you can cater to your personal liking (Ranged power for defending/attacking cities but beware of ammo running out, melee power houses to charge into enemies or a more tactical calvary/cannons/naval support. You get to forge actual alliances (unlike in things like Civilation where anyone can turn on you any minute) that strengthen over time with trades, marriages, helping in wars, military access, etc et. 

I am some one that will probably never be satisified with any strategy game because I want to customize everything. Everything. This game could be improved but what it does have is many of the things that any stratedgy fan (RTS or Turn based) will love.
good

Ive played all of the Total War games, and I have to say this is my favorite one. Japan is, of course, not as big as some of the other places Total War games take place in (see Rome 2 huge map) but it doesnt feel small, and the relationships with other clans in the campaign map can make or break you, also there is a wild card called Kyoto that can crush you early on if you make them mad, and eventually you can capture it. The fighting is also very interesting, and I would actually recommend the blood DLC because sometimes you will want to zoom in on the 1v1s the unit AI automatically go to, put on the slow motion mode, and watch a display of skill samurai versus samurai, or a charge of ashigaru and see people get impaled and lifted off their feet. Unlike the other Total War games, this one doesnt have sheilds. You may have mixed feelings about this, but ultimately it just means ranged is more effective and strategy for this game must usually be done differently. The maps have a lot of terrain you can take advantage of, so that's a plus that replaces sheilds if used correctly. If you are not a fan of the artillery in other Total War games, there is very little of it used in this game, unless you get FotS because then you pretty much bought a game based on gunpowder.

 The multiplayer is more fun than the traditional; choose units, fight. In Shogun 2 you pick your army, after some time playing, from veterans that you have leveled up, that have their own skill branch and that you can specialize to fit specific needs and change the color of their uniforms (my entire army is pink), including your avater (general (mine is pink)) who can specialize in swordsmanship, bows, or just being a commander. There are also buffs and debuffs, and more units you can gain and use in multiplayer through a small slightly interactable map of Japan. This kind of multiplayer certainly isnt for people who hate investing time or getting slightly wrecked at lower levels because the veteran system/buffs allows higher ranking or people who have spent more time to have a large amount of veterans. You may also be discouraged by the FotS players if you play the traditional style Japanese units, which I do. I learned just to suck it up and adapt my tactics. 

I find it hard to say bad things about this game, and it is probably for you if you like other Total War games.
Very good game to spend your time.

In Total War: Shogun 2 you play as a daimyo on a quest to conquer all of Japan. Manage your provinces, beat back rebellion, train troops, and march against your foes in countless battles. Slowly you learn the in depth AI strategy, hill camping. The AI will surrender many men for their 1 troop of yari ashigaru to camp a hill. Fear not though, CA have provided the AI with money and no fear of rebellions, ability to gain the best agents without the need to train them. 

If you are looking to get into the Total War series then Shogun 2 would be the best entry next to Rome, just don't expect all too much from the enemy AI, if there is a hill, they will camp it. Over the course of playing you will start to understand how the AI reacts to different situations and game things that way. The next bet would then be on multiplayer but I'm too retarded to get into that part of the game.

If you are a fan of history and/or strategy, then Shogun 2 can be a safe bet on a game. I find the Total war series to be a very fun and replayable series. The game offers you many different situations, clans, and tactics in order to achieve victory, at many different difficulties as well.

8/10

I have only played the campaign mode of this game, and I can say it is as good as TW gets. It doesn't innovate the franchise in any significant way, but it is a perfect game to play while waiting for the next title's price to drop. Bugs aside (and mostly fixed by now), this installment has only one major weakness, and that's its own premise: Japan. Japan is a very colourful setting, but in the end it's only Japan. The factions are nearly identical. Sure, they do get different static bonuses, and even a unique special unit or two, but that doesn't really make things different. Add to that the limited variety of siege settings and you've got yourself the most repetitive TW game yet. Still, it's a pretty awesome thing to repeat.

To me, this is the best Total War to date. It is very well optimized. I could run the game at medium DX9 settings on my HD2000 Intel Laptop. I can run it at max DX11 settings on my i5 660ti Desktop. It looks great as well, and a really vast improvement in soldier models/textures over Napoleon Total War. 

The campaign is the most fun, as it is really focused. At the start you can make alliances and grow in power. Once your big enough, you start the civil war where everyone is against you providing a fun late game challenge I felt other total war games lacked. The atmosphere is spot on, but troop variety is limited so the different factions only have 1-2 unique units. 

The multiplayer is also the best out of the Total War Series, allowing for co-op campaigns and a clan focused completive multiplayer where your army levels up and you can customize them.

I have fond memories of the original Shogun and, despite its flaws, kept up with the TW series until Empire when I parted ways. When this came up in a sale I thought I'd give it a go as I'd heard it was something of a return to form and I thought it would be fun to return to the days of charging samurai. And to be fair the charging samurai are still fun and obviously look better than they did in the original Shogun but sadly that's about it.

What let's this down is the AI at every level. On land the enemy AI can put up some resistance but if the forces on each side are similar you'll usually win. The passivity of units, yours and the oppositions, is what kills it for me. You have to micromanage your supposedly highly trained samurai so that they turn to face a unit that's flanking them. Or to attack a unit that's attacking a nearby unit instead of standing around like idiots. They're may be occasions when I'd like a unit to stand fast no matter what but unless that's an explicit order from me, their general, I'd prefer them to default to doing their job when the opportunity presents itself.

At sea it's even worse. The default behaviour of the enemy fleet is to stay at anchor and let my fleet come to them. A particularly bad tactic for a trade ship being attacked by two navy ships,

Presumably to compensate for this at the strategy level the AI is essentially simple. Whatever you do they all hate you and sooner or later will attack. When they do this your economy will usually tank so you'll be short of resources reducing your strategic option to grinding down the endless attacks and hoping they run out of reserves before you do. The odd battle like this can be fun but after a whle 'grind' becomes the operative word and boredom sets in. Perhaps I've been spoiled by the likes of Crusader Kings II, where you can have a rich and complex set of relationships between and within countries, but when I see clans at the other end of the Japan that I've never interacted with in any way have suddenly decided to go to war with me (ignoring more lucrative targets closer to home) I just roll my eyes. CA could get away with this kind of brain dead behaviour back in 2000 and the original Shogun but there's little excuse for it now. Whilst the complexity of CK2 would be overkill you should get the illusion you were a part of a living world where the other actors have goals of their own instead of all just existing to provide an opponent for the human player. 

In short, if you see this in a sale and enjoy the charging samurai side of the thing enough you'll probably get your money's worth but if you're looking for something with any kind of strategic depth then move along, nothing to see here.

Released on Steam in March 2011, Shogun 2 was a long awaited game for by fans who enjoyed the first game and fans were not let down with this installment in the series. I had pre-ordered this game and paid full price, I was only upset that a few short months later is dropped to half price. Otherwise the game is very addicting to play.

The game story takes place during 1467 to 1477 where all the nations in Japan came to war, a war that involved the Ashikaga shogunate and the territorial lords. The result of this massive power struggle three individuals would emerge who would unite Japan under one rule. You play one of the warlords who is to dominate the other clans and rule the whole of Japan.

Those who are familiar with the Total War series will know what to expect in this game, but for those who are looking for a medieval Japanese strategy game, like me, will probably find this game overwhelming at first.

I found this game difficult to get into from the start and learn what to do. The tutorials really help with the controls and how to do things in Shogun 2. You need to build, manage your clan, scout and war. When it comes to fighting another army you can let the game auto resolve it or you can go into battle mode.

When you are in battle mode fighting another army, you will find yourself in a whole new mode, commanding your forces and setting up how they will advance and what formation they will be in. I really like this mode because its interesting to see how your battle is actually going and how you will react to the fight. The game holds allot more, sea battles using ships, storming castles and ninjas.

There are cut scenes during play, such as when you send a trained ninja out to assassinate an enemy force. You will get to see a successful attempt or one where the ninja fails.

The tutorial at the start to help you learn to play is very helpful and the Japanese geisha girl voice is a nice touch to help you learn what to do. 

The multiplayer portion of the game requires you to join a Total War Shogun 2 group and then you get to view a map of Japan and place your avatar on. Beyond this I haven't figured out how it plays out as there isn't any option to go to a ground to ground battle or auto resolve it. I am sure its something simple to do but I haven't been able to figure it out.

Overall the game is hard to understand how to play and takes some time to learn. The multiplayer side I found very hard to understand and troublesome to figure out. I do enjoy playing it but its one I have been able to put down and wait a long time to get back into. I think I will have to give this another try sometime soon.

I haven't gotten to the point of dominating all of Japan or anything but I do like the whole game because you get to fight during a most interesting time in Japans history and that period is a time of Total War!

[b]Pro's[/b]
[list]
[*]Samurai's an Ninjas
[*]Very detailed and historically accurate
[*]Personal control over battles or automatically resolve
[*]Music
[*]DLC adds more clan's to play as
[/list]

[b]Con's[/b]
[list]
[*]Hard to comprehend
[*]Cut scenes are repeated
[*]Multiplay isn't as easy to understand
[*]Very large download
[/list]

Let's be honest here two minutes:  Shogun 2 really wasn't that great. Except for the fancy graphics, it didn't feel like much of an improvement over the good old Shogun-the-first.  And even though I was happy to come back to some interesting melee fighting, I found the battles to be not nearly as slick as they were in Napoleon: TW.

Hopefully, it seems that CA has decided that, after releasing a kinda lame, or let's say boring game, they'll polish it with a second version/stand alone that not only fixes the issues, but improve everything. T'was the case with Napoleon (vastly superior to Empire), is the case with Fall of the Samurai (vastly superior to Shogun II) and will hopefully be the case with Attila TW.

Fall of the Samurai (FotS) lets the player choses a side during the Boshin war, that opposed the Tokugawa Shogunate to the Imperor in the late 1860's. An era just as interesting as the Sengoku Jidai, as Japan is at a crossroad: will it stick to its old, medieval, feudal ways, or embrace modernization, with the help of - financially interested - westerners?

That setting makes for a very interesting game. You can either chose to field armies that would seem right in the place in Shogun 2, made of Samurai and knights, or modern forces, with fast-firing canons and line infantry, french or british mercenaries... 

Chosing modernization will give you an important advantage, tech and economy-wise. But it also makes your domain harder to rule, as the samurai caste opposes the reforms. Unlike Empire and Napoleon, where the "clamor for reform" was merely an issue, it becomes here a fundamental factor, as your population can quickly get rebelious as you build more factories all over the place. Overall, I'd say the campaign is much harder than that of any previous TW game. Not only unhappiness can get really high really fast, but economy is also much complexe. Trade doesn't bring in enormous amount of cash, while taxes have to stay relatively low as long as your people aren't content. Plus, the AI seems a whole lot more competent, regularly launching amphibious invasions with real armies (a first in the Total War series), and setting ambushes every once in a while. Mind you, it is still mindlessly stupid most of the time, but a bit less stupid than it used to be.

As your clan evolve, so does the campaign map: villages and towns grow bigger, trains start linking provinces, smoke and pollution surround your factories, Ironclads replace the good old wooden ships... It is great to see the (huge) map of Japan evolves as turns end. And as a bonus, you can try and establish your own republic, giving the middle finger to both the Shogun and the Emperor.

But, nothing is perfect and this FotS is no exception. My main issue with it, is that there's actually little reason to stick to the old ways, despite the happiness bonus: not only will your economy and research rate suck, but so will your armies. Even veteran samurais will get absolutely trashed by armies of line infantry supported by heavy guns. To add the insult to the injury, traditional units are just as expensive to recruit and maintain as modern ones. If you could attempt to swarm the opponent with cheap armies of melee specialists, I feel the balance between the two "ways" would be fairer.

Fun ,thoughtfull, enhancing on old gameplay while increasing diversity. I would have enjoyed the ability to include factions and landmasses from the east coast of asia and the other areas surrounding Japan that could affect it. Russia, South east aisa, china the polynesian and oceanic areas. But beyond that It's effective and varied gameplay which is cool.

I have been victorious through tactics with agents and generals alike. Each factions adds a different style to your combat conquest which is cool. It would have been nice to create your own faction since the movies are almost interchangable with content, and you could use create your own opening movies based on the assigned qualities you give to your faction.

 The only issue i can find beyond that, is the same with other tw games, which is, at a certain point diplomacy is useless, which albeit is somewhat honest of their perspective on global politics, but for a game it carves out a very entertaining route to victory. Getting your enemies to fight against themselves, setting up vassal territories' to create a territory cusion agaisnt enemies and having them be loyal. once you are a big enough threat, everyone wants a piece. But that isn't historically accurate or realistic regardless of design. 

If you have overwhelming power and are next to a faction that has no power and you provide them with their stability then it makes no sense that they would turn on you because of a weaker force that controls kyoto (or whatever considering the other games) considers you a threat. Even if you argued that they are joining together to fight your "evil empire". Why are their alliances permanent and your alliances feathers in the wind.  Especially if you are between the smaller faction and kyoto(or whoever) and could wipe them out without a second thought. If you had that power over them, they would do pretty much whatever you pleased. Hence the vasal state.

 How would they know to strike back. Who tells them now is a good time to revolt. I control their borders, how do they get the message to attack from the other remaining powers big or small. Why dont they consider their survival when bitting the hand that feeds you. Why don't they consider your ruling if you are making them a vassal. I see no reason why diplomacy should get the shaft like this, it is a form of war.

While i do appreciate a challenge and perspective that the game may be trying to give you on taking the shogunate, it seems like they are missing the point of being a real power. You don't just conquer or buy your way to victory. 

You misinform, please and beg, push and argue, lie and steal, relieve and pursway. And if none of these tactics are viable because the moment you hit critical mass its all or nothing. Then you're basically wasting a lot of our time because no matter what; it comes down to all vs you anyway.

So yes, your a threat, sure, and of course some people make an alliance to try and stop you. No problem. But your telling me that the faction that was a rebel group that i conquered on my second turn and turned them into a vassal to relieve the waste of money it would have been, is going to side with my enemies? For no reason? especially when I have a full army waiting for my enemies to attack the vassal, right next to it?

Im sorry, thats just not logical.

 And what about the ai for you public?

 Sure you can say you lead the army to the doorstep of Kyoto. 

But will your people stand with you after you've killed half their family that lives in the other city you just conquered? 

Or will they depose you and put their own form of government seeing the game of war the land and the damyio's have turned into.

Will the disease created by the overwhelming ammount of dead bodies created in the last years stop you in your tracts or will you find a cure. 

Does the storm prevent you from traveling through this area at this time or doesn't it. 

Have these territories given in to your demands or become so in awe of your leadership and then they relieved themselves of their leaders  Or did you capture the damiyo's son and start holding hostages till the damiyo gives in.  

Did you create rebels through money, fear, lies,  power or inspiration.
Are you a reckless tyrant or a masterfull leader? and to what degree?


Now their are some of these things in the game. Flooding, pestilence, disease and rebellion. But it does not feel like a real problem most of the time or happens so infrequently it seems rather unnecessary. 

Diplomacy is generally a front which bothers me, but to be fair i have yet to find a game that allows 
for a realistic alliance strategy. Which is bothersome because the game has a viewable point system for diplomacy, it just seems as if they are breached or changed so often that you can rarely have a brother or sister nation. Which is again unrealistic. Sure there are lots of powers who are on and off again in diplomacy, but their are also some nation relationships that stood the test of time, and were either joined by marriages between the factions or trade and military benefits.  

I enjoyed the rise of the samurai simply because you can conquer without conquering with the law officials. You can technically bribe almost every city.

 But why only bribery?

My point is, If you are not given the ability to conquer and maintain you empire in diferent ways and you don't have events that can acutally affect the entire area with a dire rammifications to the whole. 

Then it hardly can be called a total war strategy game, It can be called a territory war strategy game, and you might as well take the "boring" or "pointless"  political or diplomatic strategy out of the game entirely; Who cares about trade rights if your going to have to conquer them in ten turns?

Who cares about disease if you have no doctors or healers to do something about it . Shouldn't disease be something that can halt you completely like the black plague did in the rome and medieval.

Who cares about destruction without something to deal with it, say engineers. Shouldn't bridges be destroyed or rebuild, should not snowstorms make certain places not only deadly but impossible to pass?

 You might as well just add a first person mode to conquering because then at least you could try to control some of the conquering personally and it would bring the variety you are looking for.

Dont get me wrong. Their is no other franchise that gives me so much pleasure with rts battle simulations, I love the combat.  it's awesome and the designers are always looking to streamline it and make it more enjoyable, that by itself deserves the play through seriously, personally i can watch boiling oil melts troops in a siege for hours on end in the first rome. Seriously, it made it feel like an actual battel field with consequences for every military action" you wanna go through the gate without conquering it first, okay let me melt your face off". Defending attacks is one of my favorite gaming fantasies so let me make this clear. Rome, Shogan1&2, medieval1&2, and even empire, are all enjoyable mass combat arcade simulators. 

But I still think they can improve and add variety and different modes to the world strategy part of the game.

So if you want a TOTAL war strategy game, then you need to account for and add the problems that conquerors had to account for and the tactics they used or could have used in face of said problem. Or else its just a war game and all that matters is which side of the island you start on, and which way you accumulated your first twenty territories. Which is cool! 

It just seems half finnished in the respect to their franchise name. Total war.

p.s I would have easily been happier with longer single player campaign modes for all of their games.  Even the full campaigns always seem too short a game to really take advantage of a lot of the units and buildings they have to offer.

As soon as I finsihed Installing the game and saw the opening cinematic; I knew I was going to have a fantastic time playing  Shogun 2. I had always wanted to play a strategy game set in the fuedal Japan era.  I wanted that game to be very Authentic and realistic and I got exactly that in this game. If you are familiar with Total War games then the mechanics should feel very familiar. If you are familiar with any other strategy game, Shogun 2 will feel a little overwhelming at first but there should be no problem to gain the feel for it. What I loved about the game is that there is a fantastic balance between economy, politics and action. You are a Daiyamo set out for a conquest to rule the capital Kyoto, Japan and become Shogun. There are multiple clans you can choose from starting from different locations of Japan. Also, each clan has a certain professioncy bonus depending on which one you choose. For instance the Chosokabe clan is specialized with better archers. All archer units have a bonus in acuracy with the Chosokabe clan. You can gain allies in your campaign or gain enemies in your goal for Total War. The map of the Japan is laid out for you and certian areas are undiscovered until your army has traveled to that part of the map. The economy is set up depending on what you spend your expanion of buildings or your spending of growing an army. Each provence has a different or smiliar buildings as other provinces and you can choose to prosper the economy or piss off and starve your population. By upseting your people, rebels will rise against you and try to over through you and your army. I found myself putting many hours into the game and loving every minute of it. The details is what really drew my attention. The battle scenes are what really make this game unique. You start off by positioning your army in any formation you choose or customizing your own. Once you have begun the battle, you have full command of your army and set them anywhere else on the map. Depending on the climate or surrouding are, your army can have an advantage or disadvantage. If you're placed in a forrest of trees, the opposing force will have a hard time landing arrows on you etc. I loved the animation for every single unit during a battle. Each unit and person has a different animation when they are attacking or being attacked. You can win a battle even though you are out numbered. There was a point in the game where I had a full conquest of japan. I had to split my army in two because of the mountains in central japan. One army on the northern passage and the other on the southern passage. All clans decided to stop me at the northern passage and I couldn't recieve reinforsments in the south because of the mountains. Wave after wave the northern army had to fight and eventually my men started to fatigue greatly. It was the final wave and everyone was exhausted. As they met the enemy forces in battle a skull icon appeared on my armies profile. I looked to see what it was and it meant that my army was going to fight to the death. My mean fought fearlessly and this allowed the enemy force to retreat with fear. Thus I had one the battle and continued my conquest. If you are a gamer who wants to lost in a world of feudal Japan; expereinced the role of the samurai and achieve the ultimate status of a Shogun. If you're a fanatic for any real time strategy game or if you want to try something totally new.  Buy this game. It is well worth every money and time. I found myself putting 6 easy hours one day where I have nothing to do. Enjoy!

E.g. Having trade routes with enemies of your allies can cause sudden backstabs or penalties to your clan's honour by huge chunks being labelled "Dishonouring treaties" causing the whole island to not trust you by default when you didn't do anything but click next turn. It's frustrating, but when you examine most scenarios they do tend to make sense. Then there's the realm divide, but you'll find out all about that. It's just an incredibly difficult and rewarding game. I haven't dared venture into multiplayer, so I can't account for that side of the game.

Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a strategy game set in feudal Japan, and is a turn based strategy game. The game has two major mechanics I will get briefly into here. After you have chosen your clan you will see a map of Japan, and where you have your units and town. This map isn't the entire game by far, but here you have an overview of how you run your lands by building necessary building for your war effort, diplomacy and gathering resources and researching technology. You will also have a family tree where members can grow up to be leaders or the women can be wed to form alliances or make them stronger. Basically you govern everything from this map.

The major strength of this game is the battles however. When you enter a battle you will enter the zone from the map you are either attacking or defending, and is where the game gets more complex for strategy fanatics. If you have 80 men attacking you will see 80 detailed men on your side in formations you can change, and the same goes for 1200 men which make battles huge and impressive as you see them battle it out. The various formations and approach you can make is extremely fun, and even the terrain and weather has an affect of how everything will play out. This also means you can win despite being severely outnumbered if you somehow manage to use the terrain to your own advantage. Generals also play a huge role here as they give better morale and can add buffs to units as well. 

There are also many units in the game, and this is not counting the DLC's out there either. 

I found this game to be impressive and extremely fun too and challenging. I certainly enjoyed this game and if you like any form of strategy game you should consider this, especially if you like samurai, ninja or is just fascinated by feudal Japan!

Total War Shogun 2 is an exemplary game in most respects, even now in 2014. While the grahpics are now considerably dated, it's still meserizing to watch thousands of indivdualy animated infantry and calvary clash. The campagin mode is a brilliant fusion of RTS and managment, with taxes, trade revenue, clan democracy and more. This leaves hundreds of hours of playtime as you learn each clan's strengths. While the avatar of the multiplayer is neat, the lack of online activity hampers gameplay, most of those who still play are also high ranked, and anyone such as myself  just beggining this game will get dominated. The Naval and Seige battles are nice, though naval battles often felt slow and dull at times. Still, it's a great game to pick up, dor those who can't afford Rome or enjoy the medival Japanese theme, this is a great game.

Do you like Samurai?
Do you love HONORABLE fights?
Leading your Ashigari (common, foot soldiers) into Battle to Unite Japan. Under the Banner of your Clan, you fight for Honor and Glory!

9/10

The Grand Campaign is more or less about the BIG armies or SMALL at the beginning, fighting for supremacy over the Land. 
The most focus is actual combat and RTS in the armies fighting, you can possibly win, with your Army in a Blitzkrieg tactic with just Ashigari troops alone. Or build up a strong army, having lots of up-keep costs.

The only downside for me, personally, is that it lacks the Family Managment, like in TW:Rome 1 - there you could build up an Family Dinasty. Here this is impossible you have no chance of having influence on making a strong Clan as it means to be a clan. You only Rule like an Absolute Ruler - there are no intrigues in your Clan or similar Stuff which makes Sengoku a game that has the features of what this game is lacking. On the other side, if you could combine Sengoku and Shogun 2 into one game - this would have been a Game that the world would love to see.

Although I am not the most experienced in PC gaming or the most tactical is any strategy game, Shogun 2 has been my go to game for years now. The only other Total War game I have had the pleasure of playing is Napoleon total war. The parts of that game that intrigued me were that Prussia could take all of Europe with enough tech and auto resolve battles. I didn't like the RTS aspect in it because it seemed more irritable for who could route who better with a gun or who was the more elite gun holder when the only different stat was morale. In Shogun 2 i have no complaints. I enjoy the RTS aspect fully especially with the Blood feature. The campaign mode is quite balanced and if you become too powerful then everyone will declare ware on you to cut you down to size. The units are much more diverse which is really refreshing. The game allows me to experiment with different methods to annihilate my opponent or be annihilated myself. Agents in the campaign are actually useful, for both sides, which adds more tension. I've never seen a perfect game but Shogun 2 is surely a must have on my list.

This is in my opinion the best Total War series ( I haven't played Rome 2). Awesome graphics, challenging AI (at least for my low skill level) and good balance. Each clan seems similar but also different which in my opinion is difficult to pull off given everyone has basically the same units. Your skill makes the difference both tacticly and on the campaign map. Many of the inovations would be a great boon to future Total War titles

Its official, Creative Assembly cannot program or design their games correctly.
I loved this game. Almost everything about the tactical battles to the strategic campaign map. Everything just fits together so perfectly right up until the point where the ai sends dozens of trade ships around to raid all of your trade routes and close off all of your ports (even if you have entire fleets inside them) who always retreat when your fleets catch up to them. There are so many little problems with the game that simply ruin the experience.
First of all, the naval portion of the Sengoku Jidai campaign is abysmal. As I said, once you defeat an ai’s main fleet, they will pester you with a never ending stream of small ships to raid your trade routes and even carry invasion forces just large enough to take one province on the opposite side of japan from your armies. The naval battles themselves are also terrible too. Once you order a ship to board another ship and said ship gets into range, it will slowly inch into position while the enemy ship peppers it with arrows/fire bombs/canon shells. I am not even kidding when I say that if you are unlucky it can take several minutes for your ship just a couple of yards away from the enemy to board them. Also, my ships seem to spontaneously combust and instantly surrender for no reason, so there’s that. The Fall of the Samurai campaign seems to fix allot of these issues, but it still has the problem of the idiotic path finding.
Second of all, religious agents such as monks and missionaries are overpowered. Once they get to level five they become basically immortal and you (or the AI) can send them all over the map inciting revolts and converting any agents that dare enter their visual radius. If you start the game as the Shimazu and you cannot eliminate the Otomo clan before they get a level three or four missionary, then its game over. You simply cannot make a ninja who is capable of assassinating the missionary before getting converted and you cannot handle the massive number of revolts that missionary will throw your way. 
Finally, the reason I rage quitted the game once and for all is that in my latest campaign I had a city with a full stack army inside of it and another full stack army just outside ready to reinforce besieged by three full stack armies. I was ready to attack them but the army inside the fort could not attack the besieging army (which is something you are supposed to be able to do in case you were wondering.) The besieged army could not even reinforce another army even though the besieging army could reinforce. I had a metsuke patrolling around for a ninja and he could not find anything, nor did I receive a sabotage notice. None of my highly skilled ninjas could even interact with the besieging army. I have looked up this problem online and others have had it. So basically all of the dozens of hours I poured into that campaign where pointless because of a stupid design decision/bug, great. 
Mind you this is all coming from a guy who put in almost two hundred hours into the game and read many guides online on how to do well, so don’t you dare give me any of that “git gud” bull crap. I did not even have a problem with common new player grips such as food shortages and the realm divide.
Overall good game with a few small problems a dozen or so hours down the road which completely nuke the experience.

I cannot believe that its been over a decade since creative assembly first introduced me to the original shogun. Back then I was very much into the Japanese  Samurai films. Until then I had never experienced a battlefield RTS like Shogun. It gave me many hours of enjoyment seeing hundreds of soldiers and cavalry battle it out across the Japanese countryside. Today of course the TW series as come a long away and gone are the sprites from the original game. I've played all of the TW series up to Shogun 2. What can I say other than a big WOW. The Samurai theme had always been my favourite so to see it gloriously updated for shogun 2 has pleased me no end. They have also removed some of the complexity of the recent games but kept in all the good bits and more. The developers must have refined the game since release as well because I couldn't get it to run when I originally purchased it over a year ago. Even on my aging rig I can squeeze enough out of the settings to make it look good and still run at a good frame rate. I salute them if they improved the games optimisation.

The game itself has a ton of content including the single player campaign, historical and custom battles. As with the more recent titles there are also naval battles. The campaign map looks beautiful and very accessible. During a game your general and clan upgrade with experience giving you a multitude of development options. All the other elements are there such as finance, construction and special units.

To top it all there are also some DLC's and a couple of expansions which will add even more hours of gameplay. In my opinion this is a superb update to what was then a ground breaking original.

Thought I would give an update on my review, as Shogun is now available on the Mac.

This is easily my favorite Total War, and I installed Windows on my mac, so I could play it and a few other games that arn't on Mac.  The Mac port is pretty good, but not perfect.  For some reason the 'Fall of the Samurai' campaign is missing on the Mac port.  And also, there is noticeble drop in framerate when the battles start to rage.  I just switched to Windows now, to just make sure my memory wasnt bad, and it runs perfect on there(Highest Settings, no drop in framerate)(keep in mind, I am using the same hardware).  I don't want to say its unplayable though, I think I spent about 4 hours on it on the OSX version, and its still a blast.  Because lets be honest, when you are commanding your troops, you arn't really zooming to watch all the details, you are watching the banners, and blobs, and bottle necks in the terrain, etc.  I would still recommend it on OSX.  Feral Interactive (the dudes that ported it to Mac) may have optimized it for newer machines perhaps?

This is a 3 year old MacBook Pro, and Shogun 2 runs great on the windows side, but a little sluggish on OSX.  Still has my highest recommendation though if you don't own it.  10/10.

Total War : Shogun 2 is a great game with a few small problems. 

The game looks very nice, the campaign map with all provinces changes its face in each time of the year. Mountains are snowy, water splashes, and you can see rainbows there and there around streams coming down from mountains with occasional eagle flying around. In the battle the units have great details, their armor and weapons looks reasonably real. Also each battlefield takes its looks from the place on the campaign map where the battle is taking place which is a great achievement! If you attack army in a forested area near a mountain these will be in the battle. If there is a castle town nearby, or river, this will be in the battle.


The campaign itself features many great things like the Civilization games do, you administer your towns, you research interesting "techs" and advancements which are reasonably historically accurate and if you are interested in Japanese history they can lead to many hours of interesting wiki reading.
All clans, their provinces, their daymios are very accurate, they have the right names, they start in the right provinces and they have even mostly the historically correctly named sons and generals. 
During the gameplay you uncover the face of Japan which makes your conquest all the more rewarding and makes you want to try to play as different clan next time. There are some differences, mainly in the  starting location of each clan, and some perks like Takeda's better cavalry or Date's better No-Dachi Samurai.
The battlefield gameplay is what makes Total War games so unique, you command your army in the high level, but if you zoom in you can see scirmishes between single men in the units, arrows are flyhing, katanas are cutting through flesh, etc. It allows all the interesting battlefield maneuvers, lke flanking, hiding, charging with cavalry, there are no limits to what you can try to do to outsmart the enemy and crush his army. Last but not least the morale aspect is greatly implemented, peasants units (ashigaru) are very easily shaken and will flee if you do not have general nearby or if they get charged by cavalry in their backs. Samurai units will most likely fight till the last few men before running away.

There is  quite steep learning curve to this game, especially to master the battle, even after the basic concepts are mastered, it takes a long time to be able to stand up to experienced player in PvP or even beat the game on harder/hardest difficulties. Still, the progress in learning the concepts is rewarded with greater victories against bigger armies and even wins in PvP parts of the game.

The only problems game faces is with AI of your opponents, at times AI does things which you know human would not do, even though you will make plenty of mistakes during your first playthroughs too. Further problems come from not perfect ballancing of units which leads to overpowered armies of single units (spams) in multiplayer, there has been some patches, but it will most likely never be perfect.

I would definitely recommend this game even today while it's over 3 years old. If you like Total War games, it is a must have. If you like Japan and want to know more about its history in Sengoku period even more. If you would like to try some strategy game you did not play before it is a sure pick.

Summary;  Total War: Shogun 2 is a game with Decent but flawed AI, horrendous CAI tag teaming (AI clans gang bang you on Hard, Very Hard, and Legendary unless you pussy out and play normal/easy,) terrible AI handicaps where the AI is magically always rich (a fact that made gaming news,) poor unit balancing (Hero units can win against 10 to one odds and people with Fall of teh Samurai can kill everyone else without it, cause guns are OP to the extreme,) and poorly done game modes (Avatar Conquest is a game mode where you cap provinces on a chest board, play MP battle to win them, and are limited to junk units, and few unit types till you level up which is impossible if you can't find another underprivileged newb for those privileged with FoTS and higher rank opportunize off lowbies and auto win.)  You can really tell CA is getting lazy with optimization, bug fixing, and realizing full development potential (facts that are FULLY evident in Rome 2 and halfway here.)  There's some DLC whoring as well, with people getting FoTS just to roll over everyone else without it, and DLCs doing little more than unlocking clans that already should be unlocked.  However, I fully recommend this imperfect but fun cultural Total War game as its overall quality is still (amazingly) better than a lot of other games.

I have tried so hard to like this game, but I just can't manage to.  I've spent 80 hours on this thing, and not once have I beaten the campaign, even on the easiest difficulty.  I have tried to learn what I'm doing wrong, clearly I'm doing *something* wrong, since so many others seem to love this game so.  I have not once found any useful tips that helped me.  

Reading others, this is apparently the pinacle of strategy games.  I don't see it.  I find it difficult and frustrating because the AI gets such huge, obvious bonuses (even on the easiest setting) that infuriates me.  If there was an easier setting (God forbid!), one where I could actually complete a campaign, I might enjoy it.

Perhaps this game just isn't for me.  I'm not a strategy-game wizard.  If you enjoy difficult games because the AI gets huge, built-in bonuses, go for it.  If you're like me, do not get this game.

There is no comparing this to other games in the Total War world. It blows away all other titles and it obviously beat Rome II which turned out to be a content limited DLC money grab riddled with glitches, lag problems and graphical issues that have largely been unfixed as they keep adding content without fixing problems. 

The naval combat in Shogun 2 is the best RTS naval combat simulator of its class. FOS DLC added great content (gladly pay for that expansion which adds an all new campaign and many new factions, troops and so on.) The naval combat gets cannons and armor. Artillery and guns on land is a nice retreat from melee and archers. There is something very fascinating with line fire combat. 

Sieging castles feels a bit awkward at times and sometimes the AI won't surrender when they should. I had an enemy army of 2000+ down to its last 20 men and they wouldn't run away. Other times they run away before getting close, a few arty shells into their ranks and the entire army flees. 

It is good fun, my hours speak for themselves, I have beaten all three campaigns with nearly all the factions. I have played online, fought the historical battles and even tested my computer by pitting armies of 10's of thousands against each other...this game is solid.

The battles in Rome II are allegedly tweaked to make them more "decisive", but what's the point when you can overrun your enemy witth stacks and stacks of high-end units? In this game you have to balance the garrison troop and the field troop, which limits your ability to concentrate a large enough army to effectively human wave your enemies to death or risk losing a chain of castles by a backstabbing "Ally".
Also, the family tree system and the councils system. Who wouldn't want a general with a crucial 10% bonus to movement range with a post in the council? Who wouldn't want a joint father & son campaign which adds to the immersion?
The economy system is certainly the best because you do not simply take hold of a lot of provinces and get a lot of money. Managing trade nodes, protecting your trade routes from bandit, rebels enemies forces... you name it
So the verdict is, best Total War game I've played since Medieval II

Total War: Shogun 2 is, in my opinion, the best game in the total war series. The game has a very great "arts" tree system, which can allow you to mold your clan based upon certain attributes and strategies; not to mention the building tree system and the clan's bonus's system which allow for even more specialization of a clan.

I love the setting, fuedal japan creates one of the most war-filled yet somehow peaceful settings that one could possibly choose. The family tree system makes it all the much better, allowing for you to have some sort of connection with your family and military cabinet; although I have commonly found myself adopting a general who is 10 years or so older than my daimyo.

The fall and rise of the samurai expansions make the game so much better. Taking place in the other two most violent and fractured civil wars the island of Japan has endured. 

Now, here's something that I've seen a lot of people have a problem with: Multiplayer.
I see no problems with multiplayer other than the fact that the gempei lords seem to be under the same category as the sengoku lords, even though they're further apart from eachother than the Sengoku Jidai (Main campaign) and the Boshin War (Fall of the Samurai) by about 300 years. My other complaint is that it allows you to pit a FOTS and a Shogun 2 army against eachother, making a clear disadvantage for the Shogun 2 army if the FOTS army simply uses guns and cavalry, effectively allowing people with FOTS to check the "Mixed Avatars" button and suddenly be able to grind points off of someone who has technology that is 200-700 years older.
Other than those problems, multiplayer is amazing. Build up an army of your liking, and then pit yourself against a random opponent who does exactly the same thing. When the battle starts, it's a battle of wit and a battle of who can make the most effective army based upon their favorite unit type and strategy (It's all about those polearms, baby.). Ocasionaly, your oponent will have the upper hand (You rely on cavalry? Well, the enemy uses yari. You rely on yari? Well the enemy has swords. You rely on swords? Well, the enemy uses cavalry/naginata.) which doens't really assure victory for them; instead, it makes combat more exciting becuase suddenly you have to use only strategy to take your enemy down with your now obsolete frontal assault units; distract and charge enemy cavalry with swords, use spears to create a deadly to charge wall around your archers, flank spearman with your cavalry while your archers fight them close up with swords; there's always a way to victory.

For the shogun!

Do you want to rule Japan with your awesome Samurai? Do you want Ninjas? Do want those Geisha to provide pleasure to your Army? DO YOU WANT TO CHOP SOME HEAD WITH A SAMURAI SWORDS? Look no futher. This is THE GAME!

Total War: Shogun 2 is an excellent RTS game that combines interesting and dynamic gameplay with breathtaking graphics. 

Played a Total War game before? If you enjoyed it at all, Shogun 2 will provide you with an extremely addictive and pleasurable experience that rivals (and I would argue surpasses) that of any other Total War game. 

Never played a Total War game? Shogun 2 is definitely worth checking out. If you're a fan of other strategy games like Civilization, Risk, or even games like Rise of Nations or AOE, I'm willing to bet you'll quickly become enthralled Shogun 2's conquest of feudal Japan. Although the game is a bit complex, within moments of starting your first campaign you'll be introduced to your own advisor who will guide you through the world of Shogun 2. By the time you destroy your first enemy army and capture their city, you'll be hooked.

Total War Shogun 2 is one of the greatest strategy games I have ever played, as well as quite simply the best Total War game in existence.

This game sets you in Sengoku Jidai, the warring states period of Japan, when Daimyos ( Lords ) battled for power to become the Shogun ( The De Facto Ruler of Japan. ) The game is filled with a rich, unique history and culture, perfected mechanics for battles, as well as a materfully tuned economy and diplomacy system - however, don't expect the depth and of CK 2 or EU IV when it comes to diplomacy. It's not built around that, but it certainly gets the job done

The Single Player can draw you in for many playthoughs ( my playtime speaks for itself ) and the Multiplayer has a very deep system that gives a lot of room for customization of your own Daimyo and Army, allowing you to sink many hours into that as well. On top of all of this, there is also a fully fleshed out coop system if you'd like to play through one of your campaigns with a friend.

I'm going to put this in to simple terms. If you like Strategy games, then you need to get this game. It's simply one of the greatest stategy games ever made and it is a game that no strategy gamer should ever miss.

Fantastic strategy game, and a wonderful time-waster that will leave you feeling accomplished, as conquering all of Japan is no simple task. If you do not enjoy the game, or feel like the game doesn't quite feel right, check out my mod pack. The mod pack simplifies several aspects of the game, but allows for more skill customization options. Easier difficulties will be easier, and harder difficulties will be harder. Give it a try, I know it has really made the game much more enjoyable for me!

This is the best Total War to date, althought it suffers a lot of problems due to the use of the Warscape engine. In terms of thematic consistency, Shogun II provides in spades. 

Problems:
Sieges are upon very small and uninspiring castles and maps. Compared to the grand sieges of Rome and Medieval 2, these are puny.
Units fight in a 1 on 1 fashion, a restriction of the Warscape engine, and as result, fights can end up looking like a slogfest. 

Pros:
Graphically looks wonderful. The rain effects on soldiers are wonderful, and the 1 v 1 skirmishes, while restrictive to looking like a duel between gentlemen, look great in action.
The game is quite hard, and require you to be able to juggle diplomacy, economy and military strength to ensure your dominion of Japan.

After 2010's Napoleon Total War we return to the land of the rising sun in "Total War:Shogun 2".

In this game we play in Japan that is made of fragments in goal to be the next Shogun.
The creators decided to leave the gunpowder behind and enter the era that started the Total war series without sacrificing game mechanics or pure entarteinmant.

Total war Shogun 2 is a fusion of real time strategy and turn base strategy,player take place as a clan leader and general,alterning between the empire managment and develop armys each turn and the real time battles where the player take control of a real time battle on a 3D battlefield.

With the tutorial and the campaign players will be able to play some historical battles aswell as custom battles.
In the campaign mode players will be able to pick one of nine clans and another one that is included in the speical and collectors edition each with its straights,weakness and diffculty level,players will be able to choose from short,long and domination campaigns depending how long you want your game to last.

In the game the player oversees the development of settlements,millitary production economic and technological advancement and unlike the last total war games where all the economic buildings were scattered around the area in Shogun 2 you can manange everything from the region capital,its much easier to manage your city without looking for the building of each village on the map,instead it scattered in the map but can be controller in the main city of that area in the detailed campaign map.

players will be able to engadge in diplomcay,political menuvers and speical agents to get the upper hand, There are ninjas that can assassinate generals,monks that can turn enemy soldiers to your soldiers,a speical agent that can kill other agents,the game adds a mini CGI to show the agents performing their jobs.

A huge add to the game is RPG bits,every general,unit and agent have their own personality,Generals and agents have speical skills that gives them speical abilitys,players will be able to unlock new and speical abilitys as the level up and gain experience,players will have to put their generals and famliy members in different positions in order to keep them loyal,you can exchange them for hostiles or even arrange marriage with other fuctions for millitary alliances,allowing players to use more famliy members much more.

The battles of Shogun 2 involves large scale clashes between armys that meet in 3D battlefield based on the place they met in the campaign map,on the beginning of battles players will notice that the opening speeches have returned aswell as wait for a change of the weather to send out the troops,sieges are different in this game,there are few objective points spreaded around the battlefield that give unique boosts during the battle,instead of the Europian forts we see now Asian castles with few tears so the focus of siege battles put less focus on wall defenses and more focus on battles within the castle and when you capture the castle a 2 minute clock will begin and if the time ends you will win.

Players will be able to play navy battles again with unique Japanese ships resembling floating castles with are mainly powered with men rather than wind,there are some cannons but most sea battles relay on boarding on enemy vessels and shooting fire arrows,also,the game provide new mechanics like shallow water that can give advantage for shorter boats.

Shogun 2 recived a welcome overhole in the multiplayer elements,it features battles with 8 players and a multiplayer campaign involving competitive and coopertive mode with 2 players,in the multiplayer campaign players can be grouped in different clans so for each clan a player assume the role of the clan leader and the others take command of the army,the clan leader has the ability to direct other players and assign the rewards based on loyaltiy and performance,intruducing clan politics into multiplayer.

If there is one word to describe Shogun 2 it would be: Amazing
Everything from the charcters to the units,stunning envirements,campaign map and the Japanese traditional backround music show how much effort CA puted into making this one of the best Total war games of all time,even through no many people dont know about that time in history who doesnt like Samurais,ninjas and classic hand to hand sword fights?
With the great grapics,fights,AI and multiplayer Shogun 2 is a high point for the Series.

My Final Verdict: 9.5/10
Totally worth it, hours of gameplay. Grahpics great for being a strategy game. Tactics needed are impressive too.

Thoroughly enjoyed this game and all it's extensions. Just having a monster army doesn't cut it here.....if you're a dodgy general or your troops are poorly trained and armoured it's still possible to loose to a superior general with less but more experienced troops. I loved the use of the imfamous Japanese 'dirty tricks' buffet......ninjas, gesha and the like. I found using these assets were ever possible really gave another dimension to the game.....nothing like using a monk to start a revolt in an ally's territory, thus being able to take the province without breaking protocol....and protocol, diplomacy really works nicely in the game and has importance. Geshas are great for seducing enemy generals....I always go for the 'son and heir'....that's gotta hurt ! So there's many ways to take territory......many ways to skin rabbit. 

   Japanese military history is one of the very few scenarios were all the generals have more or less the same tech and training levels available to them. If you win a battle in Shogun it's generally because you've out stratigised the other guy....not because you've got the ability to call and airstrike while your opponent only has bows in return. One of the only other parts of history were both sides have much the same kit available is the American Civil War.....fitting that an extension has been created for Shogun......much the same parameter odds : Now with the addition of ROTS and FOTS an gamer can immerse themselves from the beginning to the end of what was once a proud and beautiful part of human history.

   Lastly, I love those little Japanese death poems....I swear that sometimes they almost make me cry.....but don't tell my Samuri mates though, else I'll be doing more than dancing in the dojo !

This is an awesome game. However, here are some tips to give you the full experience:

Get good sound system, preferably head phones, with great bass and depth. I swear I can feel an earthquake whenever I start a three thousand man charge and my enemy initiates a charge of the same scale.

1080p is not bad, but I imagine a 4k monitor would be so much more noticable on a game like this compared to a FPS or RPG. Frankly, this is one of the few games where a 16k monitor would be worth the investment. Obviously, this is expensive and not necessary, I'm just making the point that in a battle involving 14000 men, it would be nice to see the whole battlefield

The AI is both incredibly smart and very stupid at the same time. For instance, during naval battles, if I was severely outmanned, I could play ring around the rosey around an island and watch their ships get caught on the island, where I can pick off the single ship that managed to keep up with me. On the other hand, and this really amazed me, the AI reciprocated this tactic against me. I had attacked an enemy fleet with brute force as I had an equal or superior fleet, and I set ablaze or otherwise forced surrender of all but one enemy ship. This ship then literally kited ME and very nearly picked off 2 or 3 of my ships. All the while, I was chasing him expecting him to make some stupid illogical AI mistake, and it never came. I noticed he was circling and it seemed he was not about to make a mistake, so I sent a ship infront of his path. They collided and he lost all his momentum, and then I was able to box him in and finally kill him.

The large scale land AI seems to be fine and doesn't act very different than I would. They tend to put archers on hills, and even try to redirect my melee force and make pockets where calvary is to be sent in to crush my archers. However, they tend to be impatient if they are on the offensive and put themselves in chokes that I've set up with the land around my armies. I don't suppose there was any way around that though, that was the only way to get to me and as my archers were at higher elevation he couldn't pick me off with his archers

Small scale AI, as in a unit by unit basis, could have room for upgrading.

My final thought: Great game to have and experience. Brings strategy to a whole new level

Shogun 2 has one big problem in my opinion. Its way too hard. Unless you do things in a strict order and following advices from other players, you will end up screwed. This leads to a repetitive play style were you cant try new stuff or play in different ways, like Medieval 2 (my personal favourite) allowed you. Make a mistake, and youll pay for it...a lot. The realm divided feature is the most stupid TW feature ive seen to date. It basically punishes you too soon and too fast for becoming strong. Once you become famous, prepare to be assaulted by ALL the other nations in an attrition war were youll end loosing (unless you have followed the "meta" way of doing things) due to how the AI "cheats" creating full armies and besieging you with agents. (You cant counter agents from other 10 nations at the same time). Even on EASY mode its hard as hell if you dont follow the same paths people suggest to win. Battles are also too fast. I suggest you get some mods to slow down units. 

Still, when you manage to do things correctly, the game is satisfying and the models are very well done. And the skill trees are enjoyable.

Best Total War title I've played so far. The game visuals are gorgeous both in battle view and world view. Battles are very diverse, there are dozens of options for stealth or ranged combat. Economy seems simple for a strategy game, being limited to trading which seems pretty much automatic and planning of building upgrades in key provinces. However, given the amount of warfare and strategy, there's just the right amount of economy in this game.

Playing with AI on Hard is very competitive. Spent a lot of time on multiplayer and it works well - creating a match, saving and resuming is not a problem at all, and we had little connectivity issues.

I recommend it if you enjoyed other Total War games, or if you like strategy games focused on battle more than economy.
