This is the best total war, its only problem being that I do not like the time period. But it is still my favorite total war. This was done 6/25/2014, and Ihave played every total war except shogun 1(top 3 for me are shogun 2 >medieval 2(pretty bad UI,great systems) > rome(combat is probably more varied in rome but shogun has good combat/amazing campaign).


NOTE: both expansions have the same issues and strengths of standard shogun unless noted otherwise

=<Standard Shogun 2>=
Set in feudal japan, nations use the same basic units but it really doesnt feel old because of the flavor your generals, agents, and just overall setting. Graphics are great, sound is great, game engine makes melee combat look good(unlike in rome 2, I think the lack of shield combat makes it work)


+Agents are interesting and insightful,and have a great upgrade system
+Good mix of siege and open field battles
+combat units stick to a "Type > slight bonus" style of variation, meaning it is pretty easy to tell who is good against what, and still have enjoyable special units(hero units, national specialties)
+All units are useful the whole game- yari ashigeru can win you 
+Good choice of teams for COOP(I played with the DLC though)
+AI is best in series(only in sieges can it wig out and be dumb, otherwise it is all legitimate moves)
+diplomacy is reasonably fleshed out daimyo honor system is really cool
+flavor. Everyone has flavor- your daimyo has a particular style, agents are easy to get attached to
+ lots of interesting tactical choices, and the map is small enough that conquering 4 or 5 provinces is a big deal.
+ bug free! Just dont try and do anything on your buddies turn(you can read tooltips and stats, but dont change policies on anything)

- loading times, still pretty nasty- turn timers are fine though.
- AI is reasonably derpy in sieges, but works great on open maps
-Game engine(warscape) handles only single combat and all animations are between 2 people.
-I dont like samurai, its a personal preference



=<Rise of the Samurai>= A campaign set at the rise of the samurai(WHAT A TWIST!) where early game is mostly filthy peasants running around, and late game everyone is a samurai archer- I thought it was okay(has some good mods) but it was my least favorite of the 3 campaigns due to the lack of national choices(3 teams). 

+made for 2 player coop(3 choices for "teams")
+3 team choices means that you are guaranteed to have giant wars with them


- I did not like the progression of the units: you go from arrows being great because nobody can field more than 1 or 2 armored samurai, to entire stacks where you have just samurai, because why not.
- 3 team choices feel very similar, not so great replay value


=<Fall of the Samurai>=
Starts with petty muskets and ends with mightly rifled barrels for your sharpshooters. This is my favorite way to play shogun as it actually gives me something the game engine is good at, as well as something we barely ever see in other games: line battles! Other than total war and mount and blade, I cant think of any good musket era games(paradox games dont count; unrelated genre). 


+Warscape engine made for ranged combat, looks great
+boat combat is actually fun and navies are interesting
+Artillery in first person is just peachy
+great balance between muskets and melee: early guns are terrible and yari ashigeru can walk right through it
+tech tree provides unit progression on both sides of the tree! madness!

-Choices for nation are very ho hum, you essentially pick "the left side" or "the right side". This makes coop kind of bleuarg for starting area choices.
-maybe too many siege battles? could be personal preference/playstyle though




=<Final thoughts>=
No matter which of these three you get(skip Rise unless thats your cup of tea), you are getting the best of total war. Shogun 2 on the whole has an interesting campaign that the AI can challenge you in(agents, province build choices, diplomacy), battles have AI that works! looks great and still has a lot of tactical positioning. And along with the classic total wars, Shogun 2 has the feeling of being attached to your nation: the daimyo honor system combined with actual diplomacy, fleshed out traits and family tree, general somber/serious tone, and visual differences between all factions really makes me(someone who does not like honor and samurai and cherry blossoms) really get into the game.

I played this game maybe 70% COOP, rest solo- did not touch the multiplayer(I hear it is good!) about 150 hours.

Awesome game.  A must buy if you've played Shogun 1.  Or if you're a fan of strategic gaming and planning, you'll have fun building your empire and battlling your way to supremacy... using both diplomatic and non-diplomatic tactics.

Best Total War game to date. Shogun 2 is set in the Sengoku era of Japan, where multiple lords, known as daimyos, battle to become the Shogun, or military ruler. Shogun 2 retains the gameplay of the rest of the Total War franchise, which features a turn-based campaign map, and RTS battles. 

[b] Pros [/b]

+ Graphics: Shogun 2's graphics are only beaten by Rome 2's, and only by a tiny margin. The animations, the effects, and the environment all serve to further the immersion.

+ Replayability: Even when you finish the grand campaign, you can still do more. With ten clans to choose from, you can easily play another fun campaign.

+ Mods: Even if the vanilla game becomes boring, you can use mods to enhance your game. From maps to more provinces, there are tons of mods out there.

[b]Cons[/b]

- AI: The AI is lacking in some respects. If it can't beat you, it will just spawn another full stack army and come after you.


Overall, Shogun 2 is a great game and I recommend buying it.

Total War Shogun 2 in its vanilla mode and on its single player campaign to be a very well made game with its own annoyances. 

What I enjoyed most of all was its setting during the period and invited me to look up and read up on it. But it does encourage your own path given its strategic value. The building maitenance in this game as you gain more territory is pretty well thought of and developed. The economy is also based on this, trade with allied clans, and resources. Which in my view makes your military might that much better. The units of said military are pretty nuanced in their own right and each army requires their own needs and balance. Melee, spears, archers, cavalry, and sometimes seige engines. This takes me to combat out in the field in Japan. Hills, rivers, and so on so forth create advantages and such as does the weather but this adds another dimension to the tactical field and strategy depending on the army you face. Seiging the towns are quite fun and requires a bit more developed and fine tuned mode of doing things. Next comes the non-military units like ninjas, Metsuke, and Monks. These come in some of the better uses such as Ninjas and Metsukes to cripple enemy armies and halt them buying you time to form up and get ready.. Agents actually do something very valuable here. Graphics in this game is highly detailed on my machine and does look very beautiful and as good as it can be. Helping immersion.. 

The things I felt indifferent about were not many in this game except for one thing.. That one thing being Naval Combat. Naval Combat I felt was just plainly something I had to do and could easily just auto-resolve. It is deeper than some I have played in other strategy games. But still I felt meh about it.. 

The two things I felt were a bit baffling were the AI and Diplomacy.. I have heard that these two things were pretty consistent problems in the Total War Franchise. I too have noticed them and took advantage of it when it cropped up. But it did kill the immersion I had when for instance I was backed into a corner and screwed up the finishing blow did not come in immediately and I was saved by my previous actions dragging back up in.. Diplomacy is always a curious thing and it behaves like a sort of crazed luny.. But there is a mod fix that makes it better to a degree. 

Overall I say as a Total War noob and a Strategy Game casual player pick it up.. The time period is interesting, the immersion is good enough until the AI acts odd. Economics is good and well done and combat is well done as well..

How could you not want to raise an army of samurai and dominate japan?  It is a hybrid turn-based/RTS game.  While you are in the strategy map you must build and move armies, upgrade cities, manage family affairs, adjust tax rates, and open new trade routes in order to gain a strategic edge over your enemies and allies.  Once an army or navy engages another in combat it becomes a classic RTS game.  This game engine is CA's most stable, well-balanced engine out of the entire TW series.  If their Rome2 engine was even half as good as this one, then Rome2 wouldn't be such a piece of shit.  Love this game, the campaign is fun and the multiplayer makes for a unique online experience.

Where do I start, hmmm well, Shogun 2 is one of the greatest strategy games that you will ever come across. It has decent graphics, meh AI, a great UI, cool mechanics, awesome clans and much more! However, the diplomacy is pretty damn bad (at least for a beginner like me). Even with a moderate chance of success for an agreement, the other clan will ALWAYS say no (At least they did for me) or will want you to give them thousands of koku for a fucking trade agreement! WTF is up with that? Not only this but once you capture a single province (just one), TONS of clans will start declaring war on you for no fricking reason! And get this! Every time another clan breaks relations or an agreement with you, it makes other clans hate YOU instead for "not respecting agreements" or other similar BS. Vassals are a pain in the ass and are the biggest backstabbers on the planet, and allies BARELY help you with wars and they just sit on their ass and watch as doomstacks of 20+ units from  5 different clans steamroll my fucking provinces until it's game over! Also, Multiplayer's a bore since I can never win 'cause everyone is a 10+ star player with annoying-as-hell Roman names such as Mark Antony, etc.

On a lighter note, this game has lots of detail, the battles are awesome when 2000 men aren't unfairly attacking you, I like the natural beauty of the game, and I really love the dlc such as Rise of the Samurai and I love the quasi-realistic mechanics of  Shogun 2 and the Mastery of Arts. Nice job CA! My verdict of the game, a 79%/Good for now.
In spite of these issues, the game is still playable and great, do not underestimate this game, it's cool.

If there is ONE game every PC owner must have, the flag bearer of the PC as a platform, no experience is better than Total War: Shogun II. The scale, detail, and strategic and world buidling content is without equal. 

Our story is set in Feudal Japan, during the 'Sengoku Jidai' or 'Age of the Warring Country' period, during the 16th century. Western trade (and weapons) have found Japan. Long story short, the old Ashikaga Shogunate (Military leader, serving the figurehead emperor) has grown lax, and varous clans start to rebel, plunging all of Japan into all out Total War. In this time period you can: 
a) fight various historical battles with set unti types and sizes, attempting to relive history as it was fought.
b) Fight other players in multiplayer modes, utlilizing the vast array of units
c) (most importantly) Take the place of one of the warring clans, and conquer Japan through diplomacy, sabatoge, and war.

In this single player campaign, you choose one of the almighty clans, and attempt to take control of the captiol, Kyoto, and install yourself as Shogunate. You must fight your way there, of course. Each clan has bonuses, from the Chosokabe's elite archer, to the Hattori's deadly ninja. Regardless, you must ally with or defeat all, and march on the capitol yourself. That shall be a very long and difficult road, however. (Seriously though, this game is HARD. Even on easy, I've only beat it once out of the 3 campaigns I've played. The AI is intelligent and ruthless.)

Step one, research various Bushido and Chi arts, to master your military tactics and unit variety, as well as stabilize your economy, agriculture, and religous practices. Christian (gunpowder units) or Buhdist (elite warrior monks)? Bettter build some naval forces, because trade with the West and Asian mainland brings unheard-of wealth. Your capitol could use some new roads and farms, and maybe a Sake den as well to get some of those elusive Ninja, or heaven forbid a Geisha. Diplomacy helps too, from establishing inland trade routes, creating tight-knit military alliances, or simply extorting money from weaker clans. That enemy Monk is getting annoying, I do believe that Geisha you found earlier should... End his preaching. (And watch a nail-biting mini-movie that determines your success too!) Didn't honor the gods, and the goddamn volcano erupted again. Crap, Buhdist revolt, Wakko pirates attacking shipping routes, ninja assassinated your son, mass hunger in your capitol, and the Shogun decided you're a threat after all, massive 20,000 man army of Samauri knocking on your gates!

Fans of civlization will be right at home, as Shogun features complex management of your clan, Military and cultural research, complex economies, and diplomacy. The game cannot be won through cultural or scientific victories, but Muskets and badass Shinto-Buhdist Naginata warrior monks sure help. Manage taxes and marriages, religoin and public order, trade and expansion. But this isn't civlization with a japanese cover, oh no. 

You see, this is Total War for a reason. For instead of sending 3 attack 4 defense crossbowmen againt 2 attack 1 defense barbarians, you must defeat the enemy general on a Real Time Strategic battlefield. Remeber those Naginata Warrior Monks that you bought? Time to put them to use. You assault the enemy general at night, to prevent reinforcements from his nearby city. 500 spear weilding monks, advance under the 'guard up' order, sneaking through the forests supported by lethal Chosokabe bow samaurai. A warhorn sounds, the enemy have spotted you! Columns of enemy Samauri shout bone-shivering warcrys, and charge into your columns of spearmen, in a fearsome Banzai charge. Your monks raise spears, and you zoom in close. Beautifully modeled individual soldiers run to their deaths, shouting and waving their swords. Waves of infantry crush against your spears, eventually forcing themselves in between, and the enemy begin to hack and slash their way to your monks, exceuting them in fully motion captured duels. But the Shinto buhdists refuse to break, and their morale remains high. The supporting archers let lose with fire arrows, lighitng the night sky, and sizzling down to the opposing mobs of men, burning whoever they hit. The lines remain locked in furious melee. Another horn sounds. They enemy have fallen for your trap! From behind, triangles of heavy horse smash into the enemy Samauri, sending men flying, jostling the remaining into the spears of your monks. What follows is slaughter. The enemy die bravely, but all fall one-by-one. You take the city the next day, and put it to the torch. You have lost too many men for too little. 

Only in Total War can you go from managing a city, to fighting in a brutal close up battle, hour to hour. Engagements are dependant on terrain, season, and have weather effects. (Attack a city in the winter, and guess where you are going to be fighting.) On the field, you must manage formations, unit types (swords beat spears, calvary have great charges, ect) and morale. Unit abilities like the Yari Ashigaru's spear wall, Chosokabe bowmen's fire arrows, and No Dachi's banzai spice combat up.

So how's it run? Beautifully. The campaign map is charmingly scaled, and quite well textured. The japanese art style is very unique, and very eye pleasing, truly immersing you in various grave edicts. On the field, unit detail even down to the single man is astounding. You can see rain running down armour, men breathing heavily, and the blood coating your generals sword. The battlefield terrain is again, well textured, with various buidling dotting the landscape, changing the flow of battle. Unit clashes are heavy and powerful, and sword clangs and battle cries very well recorded. And just too top it off, a superb and appropiately mournful and heroic japanese score immerses you even more. Be warned, Shogun II is VERY CPU intenisve, as each solider is his own AI. With upwards of 1000 men in 'small battles', you'll be needing a monster rig to run this beast at ultra. Luckily, unit sizes can be reduced, and even at medium, the game is still quite beautiful. 

So in the end, you get a masterpiece with incredible art and musical assets, slick and authentic presentation, incredible detail, mind blowing real time battles, and an addictive economy and empire management. At the forefront of the library of games that show 'what a PC can really do'; Lies Total War; Shogun II. Absolute reccomendation.

Total war Shogun 2 is a beautiful strategy game that really allows the player to be immersed in what is one of the most overlooked periods in ancient history. Shogun envelopes you into 16th century Japan and challenges you to control some of the strongest families during the Sengoku jidai or age of war. The challenge that is posed against you is to overthrow the shogunate who has betrayed your family , therefore striking you to pursue unifying and controling Japan. With the highly acclaimed single player which contains the Civilisation style turn based gameplay to the real time strategy from the likes of Command & Conquer and competetive multiplayer, you will never be stuck with nothing to do. 

The multiplayer incorporates a unique personal avatar system that was introduced in Napoleon total war and has been reworked, adapted and enhanced within the newest total war title. The user has an avatar which can be created and edited from the start of the multiplayer experience. Throughout the multiplayer battles and through gaining single player acheivements new items for your general can be unlocked to make your leader dominate the battlefield with his new shiny greaves . Upon winning matches you start to conquer the area's of Japan, allowing for seperate unlocks to units and retainers (buff cards) which gives the multiplayer some replayability and continuinity. 

8/10 - 
*Great strategy with beatiful visuals and great competetive Avatar multiplayer*
*Lacks greater unit variety in the single player*
*AI has improved massivly since napoleon total war however still somewhat lackluster*
*Wonderful mix of real-time and turn-based strategy really makes this game a winner*

With mods (both available on Steam and TWCenter), it's very possible to even recreate the rise of such warlords as Oda Nobunaga or Tokugawa Ieyasu, if you enjoy an even more historical bent to your war sim games. If you like RTSes at all, get this game.

In my mind, this is a contender for the best game ever created by mankind.  That sounds like hyperbole, but the algorithms that were apparently used to balance the strategic AI are quite devious and lead to near-infinite replayability.  Add to that the visual aesthetic that literally takes your mind back to feudal Japan, and the scene is set to begin philosophizing on strategy at the grandest scales, in the grandest of traditions.  A companion piece to Sun Tzu's Art of War as much as it is a game, this is something that provides the opportunity for one to raise consciousness to new levels ('how' is up to you - and entirely subjective) and have a lot of fun at the same time. 10/10

It always bugged me how in some past Total War games (Medieval, Medieval II, Empire, Rome) the enemy had a habit of cowering behind the walls. They thought their puny walls would keep me out. They were mistaken. But there was so much I thought got lost in siege after siege after siege. The only times I really would find armies out and about is if they were headed someplace. Maybe they were going to a new home, maybe they were coming to die in front of one of my castles. And a lot of times the stacks were small, more like skirmishes than epic confrontations. This has not been my experience in Shogun 2. The Samurai do not hide. The Samurai wait in the field for you to present yourself for murder. Not only do they wait in the field, but they all wait there. I've found that most wars I have with clans are one battle affairs. They throw everything they got at me, so I throw everything I got at them. Winner take all. Sure, there's some small garrisons to deal with but if you break a clan's main force, you've broken the clan.

I like this a lot. It seems far more epic than drawn out struggles. I've found the politics to be more satisfying than previous games, and the land battles to be the best of the series (note, I haven't played Rome II).

If I have a gripe, and I do, I hate the sieges in Shogun 2. Attacking is no problem, but when you're defending the AI gets all wonky and wierd. I dread having to defend castles, so sometimes I just don't bother. If the enemy wants it they can have it, but my Daimyo is coming just over the hill to wreck their whole world presently.

On the whole, I recommend it. It has a glaring annoyance for me but that's not enough to put me off the game because the rest of it is as close to perfect as I've seen Total War get.

The Shogun games are the odd members of the Total War series for me - I was first exposed to the series with the first Medieval, and never played the original Shogun. Furthermore, I'm much more familiar with the history of Europe/Northern Africa/Asia Minor than I am with Japan, so coming to this game with familiarity with the mechanics but less familiarity with the history it was based upon, in many ways the game just didn't seem to *click* with me.

Like all Total War games, there is a split between a turn-based strategic campaign map and a real-time strategic battle map. Each turn is one season of a year, with each season having different benefits to various aspects (happiness, recruitment, etc). I thought this was a nice touch, and was pleased when it got patched into the next game in the series, as well. Rather than straight stat improvements, generals and special characters have ability trees that you unlock as they level up, which allowed for fun specialization of those units.

Beyond that, I'm not really sure what all to say - it is a mechanically sound and nice looking game. I like how the map looks when it hasn't been revealed yet. I enjoyed myself playing it even if some of the changes (how units can invade during sieges, for example) were choices that I would have made. Ultimately, though, I realized that a lot of the fun which comes from these sort of strategic games is the investment which you yourself are able to put in, and without the historical knowledge to serve as a base, I simply found myself far less interested in the games and their outcome than when I played other games in the series. So if you're looking for more Total War? By all means - this is one of the greats. But realize that it'll be exposure to a new environment you might not be as familiar with, and that might alter how you perceive the game.
THE BEST GAME .. !
cool game! i feel its the best that total war has made.

Epic Total War-ness.
Pro's: 
1. Better AI (though not so in Fall of the Samuri), esspecially in the campaign. The BAI can be a bit dull at times but if you play on Legendary they'll skillfully wipe the floor with you. I'm not kidding: this is probably the only Total War game I've acctually LOST A CAMPAIGN in. For Total War Vetrans, that's not just a challenge, it's a massive humbler as well: BRING IT ON IKKO IKKI!!!!!!
2. Sea Battles: Not as hard to control as in Empire, but not as dumbed-down as Rome 2. Epic effects (particularly in Fall of the Samuri), the ability to sail in inland bays, bombardments of coastal cities, and MINES (!!!!) combine to create something truly amazing. 
3. Graphics: As always a Total War staple, but epic all the same. 
4. Really Awesome Ninja Duels: The absolute pinnacle of Total War theatrics: watch ninja's drop from trees, come out of nowhere, throw grenades, plead for mercy, get run down by Samuri.... Once again: if you've played Total War, you know what I'm talking about. 
5. Funny Cutscenes. 
6. Multiplayer: Campaigns and such acctually work now, the "conquest" mode is quite addictive (allowing the customization of unit skins, abilities, and all that...), and ussually lag is absent from the equation unless you get some idiot running with wi-fi (unlike the horror of Napoleon multiplayer, desyncs are rare and stuttering rarer). 
7. Bigger battles: though unit sizes and army caps remain still the same, you can now command up to 40 units (a "large army") on the battlefield. 
8. Realm Divides provide a welcome challenge. I, unlike other TW players, welcome their ferocity, though they may be a con to you, I'm not really sure, I personally consider them one of the more brilliant features of the game, providing for some really interesting gameplay just as you're about to fall into that "rolling ball" of conquest which so desperatly lessens interest in other TW games. 
9. steam workshop: maps n' mods galore, though I haven't yet figured out how to use the TED editor. 
10. Rise of the Samuri and Fall of the Samuri provide welcome unit variation, but for a price, which is one of the cons. 
11. More aggressive CAI: true, this is kind of covered under the "AI" section, but passive CAI was so much of a problem in previous TW'S, I feel it merit's it's own number. CAI will now conquer at the pace of the player or faster, esspecially religious fanatics like the Ikko Ikki, who litterally terrorize Japan, including the player, into submission. Try playing as the Hattori on Legendary, you'll see what I mean. 
Cons: 
1. Not much unit/faction variety: though the map is large, multicoloured etc., there really is no variety to the men you're facing. Sure there's plenty of units per faction, but every other faction has the SAME units, aside from a few specialized ones. Not exactly a detterent if you look at the number of hours I've spent at this, though it does contribute to a bit of strategic boardom as the game lacks the traditional encounter with new cultures as your faction expands. 
2. Terrible Fall of the Samuri AI: just as a prequisite, that DLC is well worth it, if only for the myraid of Civil war maps and the multiplayer, as well as one or two epic campaigns. Other than that, you'll soon find out that the standalone expansion has some of the worst AI in Total War history. Though not bad in it's own right (it's tactics are essentially the same as Shogun 2, which has a damn good AI), FOTS enemies tend to Banzai charge in a style that would have been terribly effective in Shogun 2 but, aside from the occasional well-placed Cavalry charge, leads only to friendly fire and certain death in the 1860's environment of the expansion. 
3. Diplomacy: though much improved from games like Medieval 2 (where this action was essentially useless), Shogun 2 diplomacy still needs work. Though an ally will declare war (manditorily) on your enemies, they will seldom acctually help you, and more often than not betray you. Playing this last weekend, I acctually found myself missing the "non-aggression pact" and "set alliance target" options of Rome 2. However, Diplomacy isn't neccesarily worse than in Shogun 2's predeccessors, it's just not much of an improvement either, which is kind of a dissapointment. 
OVERALL: 
A brilliant enstallment to the Total War series and definetly worth it. Addictive, fun, and challenging, (as well as eye-popping), the flaws of this game are easily ignored as you trample your enemies from the annals of history.

Total War's most focused (or limited) game sees the series come full circle from the first Shogun. In terms of personal preference, this game is somehow the most balanced in the series whilst also being the least enjoyable. The small unit roster, whilst accurate, leads to repetitive gameplay, and the lack of diversity between factions means the game can get dull. However, the solid battles, wonderful design scheme, and engaging core gameplay mechanics make for a decent game. 

The Fall of the Samurai Expansion pack, on the other hand, is the most fun thing Creative Assembly have released. The unit roster is diverse, thanks to influence of Western Military advisers, which leads unusual units as well as ironclad dreadnoughts.  Naval artillery and the addition of controllable Gatling guns completely revolutionise the Total War battle system, being some of the most entertaining features ever placed into a strategy game. Railways increase the speed of armies when navigating the limited topography of Japan. This game also has the best multiplayer put into a Total War game. 

Overall, a focused effort in distilling the turn based genre into its core elements that is in the end let down by a niche and uninspiring era. Fall of the Samurai, however, highlights some fascinating pointers as to how strategy games could portray the modern era. 

A Shamefur Dispray!

Total war: SHOGUN 2 is a strategy game, where the main objective is to take over feudal Japan, thereby becoming Shogun. 

Attack castles, make or break alliances, large scale battles; with sometimes over thousands of individual units with individual battle animations. 

Manage your finances, recruit units, and control your empire.

But thats not all. This game has a brilliant multiplayer, which allows you to play a campaign with another player, co-op or head to head.

There is also a mode called "Avatar Conquest", where you create your own general and fight other players and gain experience for your soldiers. This part of the multiplayer will keep you addicted for a long time.
My only problem, is that people will sometimes use cheap tactics to achieve victory.

Overall, Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a game any strategy fan cannot pass up.

I clearly remember the day when i bought the first Shogun: Total War back in 2000. 
It was really a turning point in my gaming career, and not only in that.
It was the time where my interest in japanese history, especially the Sengoku Jidai period,  
was beginning to grow....and i was also looking for something fresh in the RTS genre beyond
Blizzard's Warcraft serie which was the start of my pc gaming period.

And i wasn't disappointed: Shogun Total War was really the beginning of a new generation of
RTS games which i've followed and loved up to recent times. And i was thrilled and excited
when i heard about CA's decision to create a remake of the first chapter in the saga.

Shogun 2 Total War is exactly what i was expecting: a re-imagination of the old Shogun TW
plus the gameplay, graphical, UI and tactical improvements developed during almost a decade
of new installments.
Not only we have back almost everything that made the first chapter great....but Shogun 2
also managed to improve what, due to technical limitations, was impossible to do at the time:
adding new minor and major clans (in the first TW there were only eight), new provinces while
at the same time "nerfing" those agent units like the geisha who were game-breaking overpowered.

After the "debacle" of Rome 2... i think Shogun 2 will remain the symbol of what TW really meant
for me and for the older fans of the serie.... and also one of the most solid RTS of recent times.

The brilliance of the Total War series continues with this epic game. Probably the best in the series to date.
This game is immersed in the art and culture of Japan. The overall gameplay is similar to past TW games. New elements include the decisions which you have to take from time to time, different kinds of castles based on the geography of the province, trade nodes and others. 
The (minor) flaws in this game include a slightly below par diplomacy system (an old bugbear of TW), little unit diversity among the various clans and the fact that trade nodes are concentrated in the South, giving clans starting there an advantage in the early game (finance) and late game (advanced buildings need these resources).
Definite buy. Worth it at any price.

OWA MEN ARE FWEEING THE BATTLE FIIELD! A SHAMFUR DISPRAY!
Oh, Shogun 2, is there anything you cant do? To the general player, the Total War series may seem complicated and scary. But, to a seasoned veteran, you too can become Shogun! Leading thousands (THOUSANDS) of men into battle and watching them flow over and around obstacles while they fearlessly charge into certain death has never been so inspiring in a video game! From an economic standpoint, the campaign is complex. One season you may be prosperous, in the next a neighboring province sacked your farm land, blockaded your ports and cut off your trade! In the blink of an eye your certain victory can become a defeat! Any one can lead soldiers, but paying them, repairing their equipment and replenishing the ranks cost money! And if you dont have money, your men will turn on you! This historical epic is one too great for words, and i whole heartedly recommend it to ANY stratagy games enthusiest. What more can I say about my love of the Total War series? This entry is no different. Whether its building a thriving economy, sending spies and assassins in to wreak having on your enemy or zooming in on the battlefield to see the brutality of Samurai combat, Shogun 2 is one of my favorite editions to the Total War series. The detail, accuracy and brutality of the game are unmatched in my opinion. If you want to start the Total War series, however, this is not the game for you. This game is challenging, and in between the times of triumph and victory you will fell soul-crushing despair as cities riot, food supplies run empty and your soldiers desert your armies. An experienced Total War player can navigate these obstacles and enjoy the challenge but a new player to the series may be lost. There is quite the learning curve with this entry in the Total War Series, although this is definitely not one to miss.
Best Total War game!

As all Total War games, this one is split between real-time tactics battles and turn-based strategy campaign maps. This game is streamlined, making it a good entry point for new players (Especially the Rise of the Samurai campaign), and the multiplayer modes offer an incredible amount of variety. However, there are some confusing aspects of the game that go unexplained (How much DOES armor reduce damage, exactly?), and the competitive multiplayer world for Sengoku armies is now engulfed by overpowered DLC units (This does not apply to Fall of the Samurai's competitive multiplayer). There are some unpolished aspects to the game, but this game is so expansive, and has so much depth, that you're unlikely to notice them until you're more than a hundred hours into playing it. Shogun 2 is a massive game (Even by Total War standards), with a great deal of replay value; this game is a massive time-sink, but you will learn every step of the way, keeping it a fresh experience.

The best Total War game in the series in my honest opinion, Shogun 2 has the single most amazing battles among all other Total War games. Shogun 2's graphics are insane, the graphics on low still look great, even though I run the game on High settings. Shogun 2 has the extremely good AI for a Total War game, The AI actually makes smart moves, like flanking you when possible, or not charging its cavalry into your spears. The fighting moves each unit makes are flawless, and insanely well done. When you zoom in on your units, you can see what each individual soldier is doing on the field. The campaign has great factions you can play as, each with their own separate art they master in (spears, swords, cavalry, bows, no dachi, seige, etc.). The DLC's, are a must have. They range from special units, new factions, historical battles, to even expansions like Rise and Fall of the Samurai. The Campaign is very fun, with several challenges, but it is relativly short, but it makes up for it, with its fun battles, and challenges. This game is a must have if you are into RTS games, the Total War series, or into Samurai, or even those time periods in Japan (Rise and Fall of the samurai, and the original shogun 2). All in all, the game is a 9/10 for me because of the campaign, units, factions, DLC, AI, and battles. The only negative are the Naval battles (not including Fall of the Samurai), and how quick the campaign games are.

Twice the Shogun

Creative Assembly revisits the Sengoku period of Japan with Shogun 2: Total War. The game feels like an extension of their previous title Napoleon: Total War with the faster paced movement, morale effects, and some AI elements, but in the end delivers a fresh new Total War game you’d be more than happy to sink your teeth into.


Gameplay

The heavy focus on melee troops will kind of throw you off if you have been playing a lot of Empire/Napoleon, but the same rock/paper/scissors tactics will apply here. Typically there are three types of units you’ll see in a battle. Spear/Sword units who do all of your fighting, Ranged/Archer units for supporting your battle lines, and Cavalry units that can flank and take care of the supporting units behind the front lines. These types of units are then broken down into quality (Ashigaru or Samurai), and unique versions (Matchlock, Cannons, Bow Cav, etc). Combined with a standard set of battle maps to play on and plenty of castle sieging, things will start to look and feel the same after your initial play through of a short campaign.

Sieging in this game is also handled differently. Do you know how Japanese people got past a Castle’s walls in the 16th century? Ladders? No. Grappling Hooks? Nope. Siege Towers? Uh-uh. They scaled the walls with their bare hands and climbed that shit like a man. All units are able to scale the walls. Troop disposition and location of attack is more important here since your men will suffer casualties getting to the wall (archers), climbing up the wall (falling off), and then fighting garrisoned forces inside. Burning down a door presents a more direct way of getting inside, but also a nasty choke point for the defenders to trap you in. Also, Castles can be upgraded to provide more tiers of walls to go through, elevation changes, little moats with a handful of places to ford across and Towers to help fend off attackers.

Castle Sieging brings out a fault of this game early on, since there’s only one battle map per Castle tier. So if you fight a Tier 1 castle in one province and then go next door and siege another Tier 1 castle, they will look exactly the same. Standard battle maps are also limited in selection and you will start to recognize them early on. This is kind of disappointing since this has been an issue in the past games. You think they would introduce some sort of map generator/randomizer by now.

Elevation plays more of a factor now since units charging uphill not only move slower, but suffer a penalty to attack doing so. This means battles are mostly focused around or on top of a defensible hill. Shock units (units with a high charge value) are also more effective in this game, able to decimate and route units within seconds in some situations. Battles play out faster so you’ll have to adjust your lines quickly and use your General frequently to provide morale boosts. Babysitting troops will make it hard to watch the awesome new highly detailed units and brutal fighting animations.

The naval stuff isn’t as good as the old Empire or Napoleon ship battles, mostly because you’ll be fighting with arrows. Essentially, there are boarding ships with a greater amount of Samurai to board with, Ranged/support boats with faster ships, and unique gunpowder ships that toss grenades and mines. There are a few canon ships in the game and the dreaded “Black Ship” with 60 cannons but it’s mostly just alot of boarding and surrendering, nothing very explosive like a proper 18th century ship battle. Not exactly a fault of the game, just the time period.     
   

Graphics

Speaking of which, the graphics engine is reminiscent of Napoleon: Total War. There are prettier fire and smoke effects, but the big push was made in the detailed units and fighting animations. You can see units intricate armor and weapons they’re equipped with. The fighting animations are exciting to watch (alot of dudes get stabbed through the face). The lighting and shadows are done very well and weather effects do not look cheesy. There are alot of fog effects and clouds sailing through the skies which adds a nice atmosphere to the setting.

The 3D Campaign map with a moveable camera is a welcome addition, but not necessarily needed or useful. Using it just makes me lose orientation of the map, so I hardly bothered rotating the map at all. It was only useful selecting some troops hidden behind some one else’s flag.

Multiplayer

A heavy focus was put into multiplayer for this game as there are plenty of features to choose from, a customizeable and persistent character you can level up with, and best of all, a Co-op Campaign mode! The latter is fully featured and plays out like you would expect, essentially a single player coop with another person. The battles can be fought between you and your partner, you can gift him units on the battlefield to control or if he is the reinforcing army, he will take control of his own forces. There is an adversial campaign mode as well. I experienced a steady flow of glitches and bugs during an online coop relating to the campaign map and not being able to finish my turn, and also not being able to join a coop game at all. I hope that these will eventually get ironed out.

AI

The AI have been improved some since the last Total War game, but you'll still witness the random cavalry unit charge all by itself straight into your lines, awkward unit placement, and little focus on out manuevering your lines or flanking period. I was happy to see that the AI can form proper battle lines for the most part and it is also able to determine the best defensible hill to perch upon. You'll be glad to hear that the General doesn't charge into certain death as much as he used to, but he'll dismount and siege a castle's walls if he is the last unit left for some reason. I guess honor before death right? With that said, the AI has made some noticeable improvements but not all is perfect. Although having the option to have Drop-in battles is nice, it's just an excuse for poor AI to be present in the game. It would be nice to have an AI that would try and flank you every once in awhile.

As far as the Campaign Map goes, the AI does a decent job there as well. Allies are involved more when attacking an enemy, the AI does a good job on moving armies together for support, and also not sending in smaller sized armies to attack you. On the higher difficulty settings there is some noticeable cheating going on with the AI being able to afford lots of Armies even with only a few provinces.

Shogun 2 is a solid release for the franchise, no game breaking bugs, a nice change up in the style of gameplay, and a different setting besides war torn America and Eurasia to fight in. I'm glad they chose to revisit Shogun and implement what they have learned as well as new technology into it. If you're looking for a new Grand Strategy game, give this one a try. And if you're already a Total War fan, why are you reading this instead of conquering Japan?

Now, I haven't played this game nearly as much as any other guy has(only 7 hours played at the time of this review's creation), but I don't need to. This game is amazing! I don't even have to go into any detail about anything really because it's nearly perfect minus a few rare flaws here and there. The campaign in the game is really fun, the interface is about as user-friendly as you can get without losing appeal to Total War veterans, the game is historically accurate, and the battle scenes are stunning. Multiplayer is unique and will get you hooked(especially if you have friends to play with), and even after a gaming session on Total War: SHOGUN 2, the game still has me thinking about my next moves in campaign, or a new battle strategy. The only downsides are the AI and lag spikes that can sometimes boot you to your desktop. But compared to the pros, they're just drops in the bucket. 9.75/10.

this game is set in the Sengoku period of Japanese history, where the country is divided by feuding lords, cut-throat agents, rebellion, treason and the newly emerging Christianity (them Nanban traders, eh?). The way of the samurai is still very much in place, but the threat of foreign influence, combined with the import of banned foreign goods and growing influence of the merchant classes means the old ways are in danger of extinction. The single player campaign is a true Game of Thrones where the wrong decision in your turn can literally end your game if you're not careful. The battles range from defending castles against sieges, ambushing large armies in forest terrain, and using the cover of night to attack a lesser prepared army, all the way up to having massive armies charging across fields in a head on collision or large navy fleets at war on the sea (the naval combat was much more fun than I was expecting). There is a lot of mod/ community support for the game, but I've yet to properly plunder most of it. Huge enjoyment from the campaign mode, albeit with some slight bugs and glitches in places, but there's no hugely frustrating gamebreaker that I have encountered as of yet. If you are interested in Japanese history, or large scale strategic realtime battles, or both, then this game is for you.

In a series of superb strategy games, Shogun 2 stands out as being the most magnificent of an illustrious bunch. It has everything - fun gameplay, proper difficulty (the harder difficulty levels really are evil), a genuine need for strategy (unlike some 'strategy' games), excellent character, lots of variety, good music, and it covers my favourite area of history: Feudal Japan. What more could one possibly desire from a game? Anybody who enjoys strategy games and/or likes Japan's history should play this game, as it is, in my view, peerless.

This is the kingpin of the genre. In Total War, Grand strategy meets tabletop battles and combine to create an immensely deep turn-based game. 

On one hand, you have a Civ-style overworld heavily tuned for combat, cutting out the peaceful nations and getting to the stab/backstab nature of war. On the other hand, you (finally) have a polished battle system that rewards tactical thinking and timely decisions. Both are easy enough to pick up, yet unfathomably deep in both content (1560 base, 1050AD and 1867AD expansions) and the real historical strategies you'll use, without even realizing it.

This is one of those games that make you forget you need to eat and stuff. If you like strategy games at a more sedate pace than an RTS, while retaining the tension and feel of RTS battle, Shogun 2

Total War done right. I've been a big fan of the Total War series since the original Rome and I own almost every one since then. Shogun 2 is potentially my favorite of all of them. The graphics are beautiful if you really pay attention to them, the campaign is dynamic with all kinds of diplomatic intrigue and backstabbing and the gameplay remains faithful to it's predecessors. In the years I have owned this game I have logged over 650 hours, which, while revealing about my personal life as it may be, speaks more to the quality of this game than anything else. Incredible replay value and immensely entertaining. If you've enjoyed previous Total War games, chances are you'll enjoy this one even more.

Personally, I`m very attached to this kind of strategy games, from the more simple - but with beautiful storyline - C&C: Red Alert to the later Tiberium Wars. I`ve never played this kind of turned base strategy game until I decided to buy TW: Shogun 2. 
I must say this was a truly good choice: the graphics are spectacular, the story is a little bit "simple" for a strategy game ("take command of your clan and make the Daimyo Shogun of Japan") but I assure you you`ll be very busy trying to make that so! 

I find very interesting that the game truly tries to adapt it`s gameplay to the principles of the Art of War; you`ll have the option of a direct attack with an army, the indirect approach with agents (monks, ninjas, metsukes and the Geisha) and with diplomatic and economics ways to achieve a dominance with your neigbours clans. 

For me this is the closest simulation game you`ll find in the Art of War; every character will gain traits if the are active, passive, with low loyalty, all will be a reflect of your Daimyo`s honour.
There are a few more surprises awaiting for you in the middle of the war (or the diplomatic relationships with other clans), but i just recommend you to try it, explore it for every clan point of view and develop naval a land campaigns more sophisticated with every try. 

Thank you for your time :)

8/10-- Worth the time!

Total War Shogun 2 is overall, a very solid experience.  This has been my first Total War title and as such, my review is not tainted through the comparison of this game to any of the games in the TW franchise which people tend so frequently to do.  First, I will run through (very briefly) the pro’s and con’s.  I have chosen these based on elements (absent or present) commonly found in most strategy titles.  This should give all your strategy gamers out there a chance to stack this game up against your other strategy titles.  There is also a section of neutrals and warnings.  This section provides elements that could be seen as either pros or cons depending on what you as a player enjoy.  Hope this helps.

-------------------------------------------
PROS
1.	Near seamless blend of turn-based macro management and RTS battle sequences.
2.	AI is relatively advanced and can be extremely challenging on higher difficulties.
3.	Steep learning curve that forces new tactics and strategies with different difficulty settings.
4.	Extremely well detailed environments and unit animations.
5.	Co-operative campaign mode is very enjoyable to play.
6.	Provides a game that feels relatively fresh each play through due to the real time battles
7.	When playing co-operatively, players can “gift” control of units to their partner in real time, allowing both players to share in the battle experiences every time.

------------------------------------
CONS
1.	All of the various clans lack diversity concerning units they create.  Units are the same across all clans, merely receiving bonuses in certain areas depending on the clan that is creating them.
2.	This entire game takes place in Japan, meaning players must play though the same provinces over and over again.
3.	Co-operative campaign only allows a maximum of 2 players to take part (host plus one).
4.	Economic development is fairly limited and rudimentary; lack of depth here
5.	Tactical prowess in real time battles is not as developed as it could be.  Generally, the player with a higher number of units wins the battle, despite geographic location.
6.	Naval battles are a complete snore-fest and not worth the time of actually fighting them.
7.	Some units are nearly worthless or so situational in nature that they can rarely be used effectively.

-----------------------------------------------------------
NEUTRALS AND WARNINGS
1.	This game is EXTREMELY lengthy to play.  One campaign can take days to complete.
2.	Higher difficulty settings seem to border on the absurd.
3.	Drop-in battles can be enabled by the host which will allow other real players to play battles for AI in single player and co-op modes.
4.	Learning curve is steep and new players should take baby-steps when learning this game for the first time.  Play the tutorials, then play a single player campaign on EASY and start with an easy clan like Hattori.

-------------------------------------------------------------
SUMMARY
Over all, this is a very enjoyable game for the strategy gamer.  While it blends both RTS and TB styles, it falls short of mastering them both.  The turn-based macro management (economy, unit selection, movement, and trade) falls short of the complexity of games like Civilization, and the real-time battles sometime seem unnecessarily simplistic.  The strength of the game, however, lies in the real time battles which allow the user extreme levels of tactical control much in the style of Company of Heroes.  This serves to keep the game fresh for much longer than would normally be the case.
All in all, this title presents an interesting hybrid of grand-strategy games (Risk, Axis and Allies), turn-based strategy games (Civilization), and real time battle sequencers (Company of Heroes) which is very satisfying to play—just don’t expect all of these elements to be as powerful in sum as they were in part in each of the other titles.

Alright where to start, I own every total war but Rome 2, I also own shogun 1. Now i've only got about 50 hours in shogun 2, but it is most definetly my favorite total war. It has the best optimization by FAR. Also the graphics are stunning and the blood pack is really nice. The Sengoku Jidai period of time is an amazing setting and make sure to purchase Fall of the Samurai. The animations are stunning, the battles are intense, you actually feel like shit when your best general dies in this total war. The map is also rather large. The only downside is vanilla Shogun 2's naval battles, they are rather dull. FOTS has very good naval battles. The multiplayer is also amazing with the online campaigns and the avatar conquest. Drop-in battles are an awesome feature i like to use to ruin my friends' days. Shogun 2 is definetly one of, if not the, best total war. I enjoy every single total war game equally, but something about Shogun 2 really clicked with me and i fell in love with it. Buy it, love it, live it, let it ruin your social life.

Shogun 2 is without a doubt the best game in the Total War series. Its got beautiful graphics along with a nice array of maps and castles to make the giant battles a true glory to behold. Possibly the best Total War game to date. Well designed, well balanced, and full of intesting and well-conceived features. While the lack of faction variety means that the grand campaign (and the battles in general to some extent) doesn't have as much replay value as other installments, it also helps with the games' balance. But what makes this installment stand out among it's predecessors (as well it's successor) is the impressive mulitiplayer experience that finally raises the bar from battle lists in an outdated lobby to actual machmaking, leveling, customizing, and reward systems that will keep you invested. The games' supurb balance and beutiful aesthetics (plus great modding and mapmaking tools) make for a memorable and rewarding Total War experience.

The best Total War game since Rome.  CA went back to creating a deep game with a narrow field of vision and they've done a great job.  The game is well polished and full of detail everywhere you look with a AI far better then anything else I've seen from them.  
Usually with Total War games you struggle to start with but once you have spread out over the map you are able to take on your enemies one at a time and wipe them out.  In Shogun 2 your enemies recognise a threat on the campaign map and gang up on you to take you out.  Even better the game provides you with feed back as to how close you are to this end game event.

I recommend you play with Darth Mod's mod which improves many aspects of gameplay and graphics in a single, configarable package.

Keep an eye on this one, it often comes on sale and can go for $10 during the holidays.  If you want a fun strategy game or have been burnt by Rome 2 give this one a go, you won't be disappointed.

Total War: Shogun 2 is probably one of the best modern Total War games. Revisiting the classic that started it all, venture into the tulmultuous period know as the Age of the Country at War, when the Ashikaga Shogunate declined in power and left a vacuum to be filled. Will you unite a divided Japan under one rule. Do you have the will to lead your house to its destiny in order to become the next Shogun?

Overall, this is probably the best Total War on the Warscape engine to date. I would very much recommend buying this and trying it for yourself. I'd also say it has excellent replay value and attention to detail in the historical world of feudal Japan.

Overall Pretty good and well worth buying on sale, got some joy from this game, gameplay is good, graphics are nice too. It turned the game into a bit of a chore and left me a bit irritated that the Takeda didn't get punished for what I did even though they were a bigger threat, just because it was an AI faction. Also, I must say, it felt almost like the clans were "pick a colour/start position" which led to it being rather samey on subsequent playthroughs. All in all though if you're a fan of The Warring States period and like a strategy - you should like this

Of the the total war franchise, this edition has the most solid gameplay.

First off I love the Total War series.  These games are exceptional to say the least.  SHOGUN 2 is probably my favorite out of the franchise thus far.  The ease of map and town navigation make the game simple to jump into if you've played any of the previous Total War games.  If you haven't, the overwhelmingly helpfull "advisors" will get you through the early stages of the game rather quickly and efficiently.  

What's good:
- Graphics are smooth and quite detailed even when you zoom way in on units
- Map control is crisp and easy to manage
- Naval battles are easy to get a handle on after a few battles
- The technology trees are easy to understand and plan out
- It's easy to jump right in and play

What's not so good:
- Understanding what each building does or chains to easily (it took me a few games to get it right)
- Not knowing what building to make keeps you from getting the right units as early as you can in the game.
- The time table to win the short campain is VERY challenging
- Takeda clan never wants to trade with me....... WTH Takeda!?!?!
- There always seems to be SOMETHING that makes your Dynamo dishonorable, and everyone hates that.
- some diplomatic solutions just plain don't work, I've tried to give children away as hostages so many times, nobody want's my kids!  they must all be brats.....

All in all I love this game.  I've played it a bunch just solo.  I can't vouch for any online play however so those experiences may vary.  I hope you pick this game up and check it out.  Enjoy!

Total War: Shogun 2 is a fun and hard, but rewarding game. The single player mode can some times make you want to throw stuff, but I believe that this is because the CA developers put some much time and effert into making the game as real as they could. The AI acts in way you wouldn't really thing it would and can never really trust an "ally" completely, just the way it most likely was back then. The multiplayer mode is very challenging. You do not start out with every unit and must earn them through hard work, but achivements from the single player game and multiplayer unlock clothing items for you avatar and when you get a full set a match bonus item. If you're not sure you would like the whole spear, sword, and arrow types of fighting then try out Shogun 2: Fall of the Samurai. This lets you use gun units and has awesome naval units to work with. The Fall of the Samurai add-on is not a DLC for Shogun 2, but is A completly different version of the game and can be bought by iself.

Normally when people ask which Total War game they should start with, I tell them to choose whichever era they have an interest in.  While this is still true, many people lock up with indecision or simply don't care.  Which is why I'd recommend that if you also lack the ability to make decisions, allow me to make this one for you.

Total War games are similar to Civilization games but with a real-time strategy element for battles (which you can auto-calculate if you must, but generally your troops do far worse without your guidance unless you vastly outnumber the enemy).

So if Civilization is your thing, and you like RTS, Total War is their lovechild and it's beautiful.  And Shogun 2 is extremely well polished, and a great entry-level game to start off your addiction of being an armchair general.

Besides, who doesn't love the history of Japan?

Total War: Shogun 2 is definitely the best Total War game I have ever played in my entire life. The graphics, music, animations/effects, setting, environment, and scenery were incredibly AWESOME. I currently have Total War: Rome 2, but that game is nothing compared to Total War: Shogun 2. If I were you, i'd stick with this game instead of buying the newer game (Total War: Rome 2). Vicious Japanese soldiers fighting against each other? Now that's just awesome to me and historically, the events and dates are far more accurate than any other Total War game. The DLCs are freaking amazing as well, everything about this game is purely flawless. Get it regardless of the price along with the DLCs, you won't regret it.

This game is absolutely fantastic in every possible way. I have no words to fully describe this top tier game that is Total War: Shogun 2. It will have everything you want for the $60 pricetag. Wait, it isn't $60? That's even better considering I personally believe it is a far superior game to Rome 2. The game is easy to hop into, and it primarily uses melee combat (bow & arrows too). Which requires a bit more skill then when you are able to use firearms to dispatch of enemy units. If you want firearms just get the expansion Fall of The Samurai, it will have everything you want. The campaign mode will supply you with at least 15+ hours of gameplay and you will enjoy almost every minute of it. The minutes you won't enjoy are the ones in which you know you are going to be double stuffed no matter where you locate your army, so you take the loss on that turn and begin your resilient comeback to crush whoever just shamed you infront of the rest of Japan and the European powers. Buy this game, you're going to have a good time, I guarantee it.

The TW traits common to all their games are here too

There's the initial zerg rush, you have to achieve critical mass by conquering "rebel" provinces fairly quickly, otherwise the other clans will appear over the horizon to stomp you flat however good you are and how easy it's set. There's also the "brake" mechanism. Instead of the senate or mongols/timurids, it is a matter of time before all of your enemies declare war and even your alliances unravel

The real stinker to this "realm divide" is that no NPC faction seems to trigger it. They can have conquered have the map, but if you even gain a single tech advance, boom; you better be ready to fight everyone

-----------------------------------
9/10 w/o Mods; Up to 10/10 With.

This game is a masterpiece, to put it simply. If you like large scale strategy and tactics, this game is for you. 
-----------------------------------
Base Game Review;
_________
Graphics: 9/10
The game looks great on higher settings, and pretty good on lower.
_________
Audio: 9.5/10
Realistic sound effect paired with Japanese speeches and battlecries creates an exciting mood.
________
Story: 6/10
The game has no storyline, as you can do whatever you wish. However, it is based accuratly on the Sengoku Peroid of Japan.
________
Length and Replayability: 10/10
A single campaign can take 100+ hours without bordem. Co-Op campaigns are also available.
________
Gameplay: 9.5/10;
________
Campaign Map: The campaign map is turnbased, so you can take all the time you want thinking. Armies are displayed by figures that march across the map. Units can be hired, tech can be researched, deplomacy can be reached, castles can be built, and wars can be fought. This is essential for the base campaign, and you can play singleplayer without ever leaving this via autoresolving battles. It is increadibly indepth, with many, many options.

Battles: Here is where tactics come into play. You control your army in real time, and watch as the battle progresses. The thought and realism of these battles is astounding, from morale, to fatigue, to the effects of charging down a hill vs up one. The terrain can be your best friend, or worse enemy, and you can win seemingly impossible battles through shrewd choices, and exploiting enemy weakness.

Campaign and Battle AI: The AI is smart enough on the main map to pose a challenge, and competent in battles. It should be noted that a skilled player can predict many of the AI's choices. It should also be noted that changing the difficulty does not change the AI, only how strong your men are vs theirs.

Multiplayer: Here is where you can really test yourself. You can fight other players in battles of wit, or engage in a multiplayer campaign with a friend.

________

To sum it all up, if this game goes on sale- Buy it.

-CalvinSoul

Shogun 2: Total War has to be one of the best experiences I've had in an RTS in a very long time. The campaign is stellar and reeks of creativity. Many features from previous Total War games really lacked in comparison to this game. It literally kept me up for a 36 hour period of non stop campaign fun. Multiplayer is the most hilarious fun I've had in years. The players are fair and challenging, not to mention friendly which is a surprise from most of my RTS experiences over the years. The games mechanics and innovation from previous Total War games are awesome to say the least, the Concept of Bushido, the ability to convert to Christianity, and the whole concept of massive warfare, I loved this game, I highly recommend it to anyone who's ever enjoyed an RTS or a TBS game. The game play is fun and challenging. The one flaw I'm sure they will correct is the sort of uselessness the Bow Calvary have, otherwise this is simply a great game. It's one of the best games I've played in two years.

You feel in absolute control over every aspect of battles, and when you lose you feel like it was because of something you did, not due to some mechanic of the game. The game is fantastic in single-player, but there is also a multiplayer meta-game, where you create a general and battle against others for more money and different troops. This mode isn't as popular, but is still functional, and entertaining to fight friends with.

The Creative assembly returned with their finest iteration of the TOTAL WAR franchise when they released Shogun 2. You will truly feel as though you are conquering feudal Japan as you play Shogun 2. It's only crippling flaw being an occasional corrupted save which seemed to occur most frequently after many turns (80-100). I don't know if this particular flaw has been addressed as of this date. Shogun 2 is great on it's own and it becomes exceptional with mods. Thanks to Steam Workshop some of these mods which were only accesibly through forums are now easy to apply with the click of a button. Some mods actually improve frame-rates and game-play. DarthMod for example removes the white lines that are rendered behind arrows. "Visual tracers" if you will, which are sometimes overwhelming, disctracting, unrealistic, and on top of all that it taxes your machine to render them. Anyhow this is an excellent game, I found it difficult to go back to previous renditions of Total War after having played such a vastly superior version.

WIth the release of Total War: Rome2 being.....a "little" crappy, is it time for the gaming community to forget about the Toal War franchise? hell no, whilst Shogun 2 isn't as new as Rome 2 it is better in every way. 
In Shogun 2 the game takes place within the Sengoku Jidai period of time within Japanese history, a time when thousands of soliders fought and lost their lives in one battle amongst the thousands of other battles. 
Shogun 2 has a really good variety of clans to choose from, each with their own bonuses, these are shown as stat bonuses or reduced costs for certain units but often the best part about a lot of clans are the territorial positioning, with the southern clans having more trade points than the nothern or central clans. 
Of course having more trade posts leaves you open to naval attack, so keep your navy strong if you plan on sailing trade ships to the trade points near the island. 
Another thing to consider is how far away the point is from territory you own, as Soliders and the navy both suffer loses at winter if they are not inside their own territory, this means that as well as staying close to provences you own, you have to tacticaly plan out when to attack, it's best to attack somewhere right after winter, if you don't your units will suffer loses and you'll be at a disadvantage. 
Enough tips, it's time to tell you why you should buy this game now. 
Shogun 2 is incredibly refined, and I haven't ran into a single bug, well......gamebreaking bug at least, dancing soliders aren't gamebreaking, right? 
As well as this the game offeres a sense of scale, there are always massive battles that are amazing to look at, but the battles aren't so big that you can't easily control your units and make more tactical decisions. 
The game as a whole is gorgeous as well, the water is amazingly well done and other graphical features are really pretty. 
Diplomacy isn't neglected in this time of war, you can ally with clans, trade with them or do other in depth actions such as demanding another clan to cease trade with a rival clan of yours, depriving them of the funds they'd otherwise recieve. 
The only bad thing about the diplomacy is your allies behaviour towards you being attacked, if I'm getting my ass kicked I want to be able to ask a fellow clan to support my troops, or to place naval support around my trade ships if they have a bigger and better navy than me. 
Another gripe I have with the game is the cutscenes, by this I mean the video that plays when say a Ninja assasinates a general, I want a proper video cutscene, not a CGI thing that has a small box for you to look at, it doesn't even fill half the screen and is annoying for me personally although you may not care. 
This game is one of the best in its franchise and deserves your money, I highly reccomend this game if you jumped into Rome 2 and were disapointd, this game will not leave you disapointed or without your moneys worth, with hundreads of hours of content and endless replayability, this is a must buy.

The Way of the Samurai is found in death.
Meditation on inevitable death should be performed daily.

Every day, when one's body and mind are at peace,
one should meditate upon being ripped apart by arrows,
rifles, spears, and swords. Being carried away by surging waves.
Being thrown into the midst of a great fire. Being struck by lightning.
Being shaken to death by a great earthquake and
falling from thousand-foot cliffs, dying of disease or committing seppuku at the death of one's master and every day, without fail, one should consider himself as dead.

This is the substance of the Way of the Samurai.

My experience with the Total War series has been a largely good one, recent developments aside. I've put several months worth of hours into the series as a whole, and out all the Total War games- Nay! All the games in my library! This one is my favorite.

But enough mindless praise, lets cut this one open. 

Firstly, the BAD. Overall, there is a minuscule unit pool. Sure, you can say that this is due to it all being set on a relatively tiny bit of land compared to the rest of the world, but that was still a hurdle that had to be faced when playing this game.
Secondly, the AI cheats like crazy. Every warlord in japan must have been a mathematical genius, because there is no other explanation for how they can guess the range of my siege weapons down to a few feet. 
Thirdly, the AI is hard as hell, even on the medium difficulties. This became abruptly clear to me when I tried to introduce my friend to this game. He's not an avid rts player, so the steep learning curve kicked all the enjoyment he could have gotten from this game right out the door.

So why do you want to buy this game?

Firstly, the balance of units across factions puts a greater emphasis on battlefield tactics than the more recent Rome II. Despite having a fraction of the units, the game offers a deeper strategic experience because it levels the playing field and forces players to think rather than just rely on which unit has the higher numbers.
Secondly, the game is very rewarding. Upon breaching the learning curve, you find yourself filled with delight at your newfound victories, at the levels your generals are gaining, at the growth of your empire. By making the goals more challenging to reach, the game makes it feel all the better when you finally reach them. 
Thirdly, the expansions to the game give it extraordinary longevity. Fall of the Samurai offers a while new experience for veteran players of the vanilla game, and though Rise wasn't nearly as well made, it still had its own merits. 

One of the things to keep in mind when debating upon buying this game or not is just how much you like a challenge. If you enjoy trial and error, learning from mistakes, and visibly seeing a measure of your improvement, then this game is for you. If you're not in the category I mentioned above, go play something else because chances are you won't like the early game beatdowns this game will give you.

Probably the best Total War I have played for a while. What it lacks in creativity, it makes up for it in everything else. 

What i mean by creativity is the unit, building, and event diversity. All the factions or Clans have the same units that they can use, and unless you have dlc, those are the only units you can use. Some people might say "Well, Shimazu have different katana samurai," not really. It's just a better version of a katana samurai. 

However, the game is made very good. The optimization in the game is probably better than any other total war. The idea and setup of the game is terrifically made. I like now all the playable factions only have one or two provinces to start. This way, whenever someone starts a campaign, it is a lot easier to manage and forces the player to expand earlier in the game. Even though I am against DLC, most of the downloadable content in this game are highly recomended because of the added diversity and ingenuity (especially Fall of The Samurai).

I love this game! Clan packs are worth it! Game has amazing visuals at maximum video quality, although I only recomend higher quality settings if you own a computer with better than recommended qualities. Custom battles are fun to play around in and campaign is amazing. You can chose the length of your campaign which is a good feature. City managing is good and despite complaints I heard, diplomacy works fine but is very simplistic. Enemies will wage war on you and some clans do expand and become roughly the same size as your clan late in the campaign. Enemy armies usually contain many units and are powerful. Agents are useful and I use them a lot. Upgrade trees for agents, generals, and clan development are organized and make hard choices to choose which upgrade or research. A good thing is massive armies and navies will greatly impact your income so having less units that are better is a good strategy. Real time battles are fun and I always look forward to them, especially when they are between massive armies. AI is good, although it does some questionable things. I had this problem only once though. The AI's calvalry unit ran in circles instead of charging my ranged unit who was firing at them and eventually broke them. Sea battles are fun, although I don't have them often. Despite minor bugs, the game is excellent. I recomend this game to anyone who likes strategy.

Total War: Shogun 2 is an outstanding achievement, certainly worth the price you'll pay. It may be just focused on Japan and there's no cultural diversity etc. But that means that CA have been able to pay a lot of attention to detail and when it comes to detail there's a lot of it in Shogun 2. 
The battles are amazing, all the animations and effects are really immersing and will have you playing for hours. Along with the campaign, which is great fun. This is another game that I want to love, however, like most strategy games of it type, the AI suffers from what I call PoP (Pile on Player).  I am still trying to fight my 2nd war and the AI has now declared war number 5 on me from yet another side.  My diplomacy and trading must not mean much to them, because they keep dumping our treaties and opting to attack me.

Actually holding my own, yet another army attacks my provence and stops on the other side of my bridge, I click my army to attack them and, to my horror, my army marches off in the other direction, the colored arrow informing me that it will be several years before I wll reach them.  So the next turn the enemy army marches right over the bridge and takes my city. (You see, the enemy had a lone monk standing on the bridge and my army couldnt possibly deal with that guy, so they opted to march for years to get around him)

I know I could load a save game, but if i have to save scum, what is the point?  I could just declare myself the winner now and go do something else.

If you must play it, play a side on either end of Japan, that way it limits the AI ganging up on you with all its sides.

Let's say that Shogun 2 Total War is the best strategy game of its type and series. But this game WITH mods make it the beast that it truly should be and as such merits a 10/10 (with mods) and a 9.5/10 (without mods).

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND! This game will TRULY push it's way to your favorite game top ten list!! The graphics are stunning, they differ due to seasons which is phenominal (I absolutely love a good snow battle). You can truly capture the essence of the art of Bushido and the way that ancient Japan and her culture used to be. I can not explain in words how incredible the fights are. You are allowed to use specific moves and formations for different units which can directly relate to ancient battle tactics, and you can see first hand how certain units could crush others base on expertise. Anti cavalry units simply crush cavalry, samurai dominate the melee heat. The gore mod is absolutely heart wrending, watching your well-seasoned samurai unit PLOW into a bow unit and watch people get decapitated and gutted in a flurry of blood and gore made me yell a few times due to the glory. The game is all about how in depth you want to get, and how much you wish to delve into the art of war. Quotes relate directly to Sun Tzu's art of war book. The game teaches you many lessons, like how being loyal and friendly can yield unexpected rewards when you most need them. It more importantly teaches you how obliterating cities and armies and striking fear into the hearts of Japan can earn you the RIGHT to call yourself.... Shogun.
