I had to rub my eyes. How could this have happened? Scant turns into Shogun 2’s campaign on the Hard setting, and I’d conquered my first city. My early-game army was already marching toward the next. Then one of the other clans landed a naval transport next to my home city and walked a small army right in. Total War’s AI, it seems, doesn’t have trouble with ships any more.

Thus began my army’s panicked march home to retake its own capital. Dismay, bedwetting, and the thrill of a fateful challenge: a good opener for ten.
Japanese castles: like chess in Kirk-era Star Trek.
Set, like the very first Total War, in the Sengoku period of Japanese history, Shogun 2 recalibrates the scale of the series in both geographical and military terms. After the multinational splendour of Empire and the continental romping of Napoleon, it narrows the focus down to a single geographical location and fewer troop-types.

The Sengoku (‘Warring States’) period seems a natural step; it’s the perfect backdrop for a multi-faction strategy game, and the martial culture is fascinating. By 1545, when the campaign-game begins, the ruling shogunate’s reach had dwindled, leaving Japan a shifting Venn-diagram of growing clans. Within this lay the seeds for Japan’s ultimate unification under the Tokugawa clan – and here’s where you intervene. As Daimyo, or clanleader, your task is to increase the power of your own clan, conquer or subdue the opposing clans, claim the seat of power in Kyoto, and, ultimately, form the new shogunate.

Every victory is celebrated by a round of cheering.
Even for those accustomed to Total Wars past, Shogun 2’s armies look fabulous. Each unit-type features incredible levels of detail. Zoom in close, and individual touches pop out at you: a full-face demon-mask here, an unusually crested helm there, a moustache... Creative Assembly have raised the technical bar too, with wonderful season-specific effects, specularity and downright splendid texture-work, especially in the rain.

The accents and intonations of the campaign and battle advisors are also fantastic, especially when things get heated. You can almost hear the spittle flying when your battle advisor yells, with great emotion: “Our troops are running from the field! A SHAMEFUL DISPLAY!!!” And the music matches pace. From the airy, atmospheric, intrigueheavy string-and-flute music of the campaign map, to the drum-andgong- and-grunting-Samurai martial accompaniment to battles, the sense of atmosphere is palpable.

As ever, there are two phases of play. A turn-based strategy layer, in which you manage your clan and decisions take seasons to play out, and a real-time battle mode, in which you lead your armies to victory or humiliating defeat.

Early on, diplomacy is key. Even more so on higher difficulty settings, where you’ll find the AI working the clans hard, and you even harder, with bullish demands accompanying every overture. It gives the clans a strong sense of personality: they come to you more frequently with offers, but they can be ruthless in their exchanges, and prone to breaking off relations. They also gather bigger armies on higher difficulty, and are more proactive about expansion.

Keep your peasants happy lest they rise against you.
With alliances come serious responsibilities. Attacking an ally is deeply dishonourable, and while it may gain you territory and the production capabilities of captured cities, it also reduces your Honour, a factor contributing to your peoples’ contentment and the way other clans perceive you. After an experimental backstab, I spent a hell of a lot of turns paying for my land-grab with broken alliances, reduced trade and the resultant economy-hit, followed by civil wars as angry peasant-armies rose, and major hostility toward me from other clans.

When Geishas attack

As with the earlier games, special agents can be recruited to tip the balance on the map, and their influence can be pronounced. The Ninja is a highlight. His Subterfuge and Assassination skills enable him to lock down an army for a turn or slay its general, and if you point him at an enemy castle, he can sabotage key production structures within, or its very gates – a beneficial precursor to a siege. Monks, Geisha and Metsuke – the era’s ninja-sniffing secret police – are also available to perform a range of covert offensive and defensive actions. All these units can level up with use.

A small percentage of troops will tumble to their doom.
Halfway through my first campaign, diplomacy ceased to be an issue when realm-divide happened. This happens at different points in each game. When the AI assesses you as the biggest threat on the map, the Shogun decrees that you’re the enemy, and all the clans fall into line. A design feature to stop you sweeping effortlessly to victory, it changes the pace of the game remarkably: suddenly you’re under siege everywhere.

To keep things interesting in the meantime, events, missions and dilemmas pop up periodically. Winning a mission (by researching a specific skill, say) confers turnlimited benefits to your clan - a military or civic buff, perhaps.

Warrior Monks are highly skilled bowmen, but lack armour.
Kyoto protocol

Balancing military and civic development is crucial. Every now and then it’s wise to turn your techtree research away from Bushido (fighty) towards Chi (civic). This lets you unlock new farming techniques and tax-improvement technologies, as well as advanced structures and agent improvements.

However, civic navel-gazing won’t win you any battles. Idling armies hoover resources and offer no recompense, and you need to conquer a set number of provinces to win. Kyoto, bang in the centre of the map, must also be yours. So war it is.

I’d win more battles if I spent less time admiring my troops.
The defining characteristic of Shogun 2 is its refinement of troop variety from more recent games in the series. Good old-fashioned infantry, archers and cavalry form the backbone of your armies, with the odd clan-specific exception. According to which structures you build and which technologies you research on the tech-tree, they come armed and armoured in a variety of ways for different battlefield roles. Befriend western traders and adopt Christianity (gasp!), and gunpowder weapons are yours, at the cost of social and diplomatic enmity.

The bulk of your force begins with Ashigaru – essentially peasant conscripts – and shortly after, Samurai: disciplined, resilient, better-equipped and with considerably fancier hats. Yari (spear) Ashigaru and Bow Ashigaru are available as basic recruitment options in any town, but with suitable development, Monks, Ronin, and battlefield Ninja units become available, which tend towards specialisation in one statistic at the cost of another. Attain the top techtier of any school of weaponry and build its related building, and you can recruit high-stat legendary units, though the recruitment cap for these is extremely limited.

The prettiest fog-of-war ever? No doubt.
The direction in which you push your tech-tree, and therefore your army development, is dictated by your clan-specific perks. The Takeda clan, for instance, receive improved morale, recruitment costs and upkeep costs for all cavalry units, and can recruit superior cavalry. Another clan might benefit more on the campaign map, with bonuses to diplomacy and campaign-map agents, such as Ninja, Geisha and Metsuke. And in the traditional Total War way, each clan also differs in challenge according to its position relative to friendly or hostile clans, regardless of the difficulty level.

I was surprised when I saw no one wrote a review for Shogun 2 total war, maybe because they are too busy playing it? ... I donno anyway I thought I might enlighten some folks out there.
Hello and welcome ... firstly if you don’t know what Total war is about let me give you my simple explanation ... you control a country (or clan in this case) and your objective is simple ... TAKE OVER .... not simple really but i guess someone has to do it ... There are MULTIPLE ways to do this ... Build a ridiculous army and crush your foes, affectively everyone :-/ 
forge alliances, help destroy large annoying clans which differ to culture to your own then betray those who were closest to you and take them unexpectedly .... Send agents to assassinate, seduce, demoralise, bribe key figures, to join ure cause or destroy them ... if that make any sense ? 
plan your own characters development, marriages, heirs and deal with family strife and honour .... deal with your neighbours through diplomacy, manage your finances and your people happiness in your domains ... its a beautiful fine balance to try to manage .... and anything can destroy it  ... choose to skip battle or zoom in and command your armies personally, watching the slaughter in all its glories ... if you are into those things ...
So what’s different/better in this total war? 
1) Improvement to the A.I. (but not perfect) compared to Empire total war which was HURENDOUS ... A.I attacking you with a reasonable size armies, responding to ure failings in term of dishonourable acts, your power and so on ... diplomacy is still ridiculous unfair but at least they engage better than before.
2) fantastic character deployment (ninjas, geisha’s and much more), you can upgrade ure characters and control their development trees as they level up almost giving RPG like feel to it.
3) well balanced and fantastic looking armies and battles!
4) Excellent improvement to multiplayer, providing you with amazing variety and personal development to your OWN avatar ... about time!
Deep variety of character’s, agents and what you can do on the battle field map,

I feel Total war went to back to its best in this title Shogun 2 ... It is well fleshed out, a lot of deep innovated mechanics to character development, A.I interaction, single player campaign, its feels more challenging, where you have to be forced to forge alliances, to try and take an upper hand in the campain, I LOVE the fact that during expert mode YOU CANNOT SAVE ... only auto save after each turn is allowed ... so it REALLY feels like a wrong move OR decision such as breaking alliances, or going to war could cost you your land and empire, the A.I is not scared to gang up on you if you get or getting to strong. and this bold move and tenacity of Creative assembly I respect ... 
This is one of the BETTER total war games which ALSO looks beautiful and music in tune with the game setting ....
This game is a must for any total war fan and for new comers a definite try out if you are interested in strategic management and domination of japan through various routes ...

Score 8/10

Being a huge fan of the Total War series, I am very happy with Shogun 2. I amassed hundreds of hours playing Rome 1 and was extremely excited for the release of Shogun 2. I was not disappointed.

The campaign map looks fantastic. The time period is interesting and immersing. As feudal Japan heaves under significant political turmoil, clans rise quickly to vie for power and respect. Other clans will keep a close eye on you as you expand and will feel threatened if you acquire too much power. The beginning of the game mostly revolves around mundane land disputes or battles over historical greivances, but by mid game and late game, wars will rage over religious choices, alliances with western powers, threats to the control of the capitol and even rebellions you can initiate. 

The expansion pack "Fall of the Samuri" is worth looking into. There are many DLC packs that increase replayability. I am not a huge fan of how playable factions are introduced at a price, but it seems as though CA firmly believes in it. 

Battles are balanced and fun. A problem with battles is that the majority will be sieges. The AI seems to prefer to hole up and the game can become tedious as you hop from castle to castle to conquer the land. I did like the improved siege maps and I love that you could control artillery units personally. 

I have not played the multiplayer, but I do hear it was done very very well.

If you are a fan of the Total War series, Shogun 2 is still a must-buy.

Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho
The screen is shaking, the war march is underway. Scores of Yari Arigashu, Bow Arigashu and Loan Swordsmen descend upon my castle. My meagre defence is lined up at the wall, archers at the ready and katanas sharpened. Ready for the upcoming battle. 
Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho
They fire flaming arrows at my battlements, leaving my defences as naught but charcoal and ash, and then they begin to scale the walls. A few fall and plummet to their death, the rest scale over the side and charge into my men. The sullen grey sky now full of smoke from the ruins of the wooden pallisades.
Yo Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho
My mens morale is dropping but they're staying steadfast in the face of certain death. I rally them with my makeshift general in the form of Katana Samurai to get my troops to hold their ground. They do. I win.
This is Shogun 2.

The gameplay in Shogun 2 is the pinnacle of the series, everything is fluid and just works seamlessly. From the campaign map to the battlefield, it's glorious. The graphics are beautiful too, you just sit at your seat, in your boxers covered in sweat and you can't help but gawp at some of the landscapes. The online is fun but can get samey over a period of time. This is where Shogun's Achillies heel is, it's the samey troops that every faction has. Sure they have a little variation but they look and mostly feel the same to play as.

Overall, Shogun 2 is a definite purchase for any strategy fan or anyone that plays video games in general as this is, in my opinion, the magnum opus of the series.

The key to whether or not you're going to enjoy Shogun 2 hinges on your interest it's historical era - 16th century Japan.

Unlike the other Total War games, Shogun 2 is limited to essentially one culture in a relatively small corner of the globe. While this will certainly be reason enough for some to give the game a pass, those that dive into it will definitely be surprised.

Working with such a limited amount of potential diversity, CA actually managed to do a solid job at making each clan feel different from the other - chiefly by giving each one their own bonuses and specialties. Religion also became a defining trait amongst the clans with the ability to convert to Christianity and the introduction of the Ikko Ikki clan and their off-shoot of Shinto-Buddhism. A clan's religion actually became relavent in regards to diplomacy, economics, and what avenues you could explore with your military.

Agents continue to play a major role on the campaign map and their ability to shift the flow of the game is a big improvement on the slightly more helpful ones introduced in Empire. The combat looks great and large melee battles make a grand return with higher detailed soldiers and terrain as well as much more life-like fighting animations and movements. 

Another big point of this game is that it probably was CA's most stable Total War release on launch. There weren't too many bugs or unexplained crashes when the game hit shelves which was a big deal for fans given Empire's less-than-stellar debut. After some patches and a little down the road today and any technical issues Shogun 2 had are all but forgotten.

Overall Shogun 2 is a great experience but it's not without its flaws. Naval battles feel like they were just half-heartedly added last minute since Empire debuted them (and so they're expected now), given the much shorter time frame you're stuck with the same three or four clan family members the entire time, CA still struggles with battlefield/diplomacy/campaign AI (though it has gotten much better), and finally the campaign's end game is just one big cluster-f**k where allies turn on each other and go crazy while the player tries to take over nearly all the map as fast as possible.

In the end though, the biggest thing working against the game is the setting. If you're not into the whole ninja, samurai, etc thing you're probably going to get kind of bored of it actually a couple of hours.

On the flip side, if you understand how the battle engine works, you can beat the computer a majority of the time. So, when this happens, ramp up the difficulty and see how far you can go.

Unlike the previous Total War games, there is a clear rock, paper, scissors effect between different types of units and the controls are very responsive. I have been a Total War player since the very beginning with Shogun Total War I, and have played every game Creative Assembly has release since (except for Rome II).  In my opinion Total War: Shogun 2 is the best title CA has released.  For a long time I considered Rome Total War I the best game in the series, but after putting some time into Shogun 2 I feel this is has to be considered the best Total War title of them all.

The visuals are fantastic, indvidual combat within a larger battle is superb, and Shogun 2 has without a doubt the best computer AI of the series.  Which makes this the most challenging of any of the Total War games.  I have played a few online multiplayer battles, and these are as satisfying as the campaign mode.  You cannot spam units and rush in this game.  If you do you will get beat.  Strategic thought, and solid battlefield tactics are a must if you want to be successful in this game.

If you like this kind of game, or are a fan of the Total War series, this is a must have.

I have played all TW from since Rome 1 with over 2000 hours combined and I have to say that this game is excellent in every way.
~Pros~
~The first thing you see in a game are the graphics, this game looks awesome. Its very well polished and has great animations in battles.
~The campain map is beautifull and detailed.
~The UI has been improved from Empire and Napoleon.
~Has easily over 150 hours of gameplay and add another 50-100 with the two dlc "Rise/Fall of the samurai".
~The battles are awesome with thousand of troops charging to battle.
~Cons~
~The mosh pit issue is still here and personally I hate it. It looks bad and ruins a part of the expirience.
~The AI is still broken, e.g. they still charge their cavalry on your spearmen which is just disapointing. Diplomacy works but its not excellent. Please note that I am playing on legendary (hardest). Most of the problems can be fixed by the awesome mods out there. :D

Shogun 2 Total war takes us back to what started the franchise and done an excellent job doing so. Before we get into things, I'll start with the negative points. 

1. When first released the game was pretty buggy in some areas, and while most of these have been resolved over the years, there are still some that persist, particularly in co-op/multiplayer.

2. Feels smaller, due to the setting in S2 the game feels much smaller than the locations covered in Medieval or Rome. This is largely in part to being focused strictly on the island of Japan, and the islands being split into provinces. 

3. The AI isn't always the brightest, between leaving a castle to disrupt a raiding party and leaving your main army to take the keep behind them, and the sheer volume of armies they will make with two or three troops in them just to go around and raid your provinces with it makes you wonder what their leaders are thinking. Diplomacy is also a little wonky with long time trade partners just deciding one season that you've slighted them and that they are now your mortal enemy. 


So okay... those seem like pretty big issues to get around. However, somehow Shogun still managed to steal almost 150 hours of my life. 

The different factions promote extremely different game play and tactics. Some that don't work well with the games auto-resolve, but are fun to play through as yourself regardless. There is nothing quite like causing an entire army to route with an army made up of mostly archers, or a significantly small force of highly trained samurai that are out numbered 4-1 

Co-Op when it is working for you is extremely fun as well and works surprisingly well for a turn based game. You can purchase troops / armies on your allies turn and essentially get all of the micromanaging of provinces out of the way before you start your actual turn. Once it moves to you it becomes a situation of moving your armies around, confirming you still want to make your purchases and then passing through your turn.  Battles are also extremely more enjoyable with a Co-Op partner. Gift half your troops to them (don't worry it is just for that battle) and the two of you can now do very effective multi-flank attacks that the computer pulls off so seamlessly all the time. 

I'm not sure how accurate the lore is, but the setting does very much make you feel like you are in the era, and you can feel the tension of the old ways fighting against the new.
I recommend this game to anyone, who believes they would enjoy it. Especially its DLC Rise of the Samurai! It's AWESOME  to play a RoS army. XD

Addictive, engaging, and absolutely stunning in its art direction and gameplay, Shogun II: Total War is a masterpiece in the Total War franchise that combined most pleasing aspects from previous Total War games without becoming tiresome. A player will always find oneself challenged by choice of sword or musket, lance or sabre, stone or cannon. Although the game is seperated by two seperate products, "Shogun II" and "Shogun II Fall of the Samurai," it is impossible to enjoy the experience with solely one. The multiplayer mode "Avatar Conquest" was a novel addition that added an RPG element to the franchise that makes the player feel more connected to one's avatar. Matchmaking is much improved as the server tries its best to pit you against the most competitive player at your level. All in all, a masterpiece by the Creative Assembly!

Shogun 2 is as of writing the pinnacle of the Total War Series. It has the best graphics, best UI, best soundtrack and is the most polished of all the games in the series. 
The game has the least diversity of the series but this is both a strength and a weakness. The enabled the game to have a very easy to graspe rock, paper, sissors style of gameplay. Of course the downside to this is fans of the series felt that the diversity of other games, such as Medieval and Rome was not on display. Though the time period and more mono-block culture of Japan works alongside the game mechanics.
Shogun 2 has a good deal amount of DLC, not all of it is needed to get a great experience however. Pick up the Fall of the Samurai standalone expansion if you can, it completely changes a lot of mechanics from the base game. Set against the backdrop of the Boshin War, the end of the Samurai period in Japan. Gunpowder, foreign influence and steam power comes into play. I have played two full campaigns of Shogun 2 and one full campaign of FotS. Everytime was different and this is by far the most challenging of the Total Wars. 
Don't bother with Rome 2 just quite yet, Shogun is polished, full of content and absolutely beautiful, go grab it for 2 player co-op play or solo, it's a great blast.

- Enemy gets a little confused in Seige battles - never brings heavy weapons and kills himself climbing the walls
- Avatar Mode is the WORST thing ive ever seen - pits new players vs. max rank enemies or DLC factions.

วิธีแก้เปิดเกมไม่ติด
Please try the following:

1)	Go to C:\Users\YOURUSERNAME\AppData\Roaming\The Creative Assembly\Shogun2 (You may have to enable “Show Hidden Files” in Windows Explorer in order to see the folder)
2)	Delete the following folders: (if some folders are not present, don’t worry)
-	Army_setups
-	Battle_preferences
-	Fx_cache
-	Ui_Cache
-	Scripts
3)	Right click on the Steam icon in Windows toolbar and exit Steam
4)	Go to C:\Program Files\Steam and delete the following files:
-	AppUpdateStats.blob
-	ClientRegistry.blob
5)	Go to C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\total war shogun 2 and delete the shogun2.dll
6)	Start Steam as an administrator (it will update) and validate Shogun 2 via Right Click on Total War: SHOGUN 2 > Properties > Local Files tab > Verify Integrity of Game Cache.

If that does not work, please create a new thread in our official Shogun 2 forums, which can be found here:
http://forums.totalwar.com/forumdisplay.php/96-Total-War-Shogun-2-Support-Forum

This one is a bit tough to review, because I have not gotten through a full campaign yet, or even maybe half way through one.  I have no idea how long that would take to complete a campaign, since the one I have going has about 6 hours and has yet to conquer more than one neighboring Daimyo, I think it will take some time.  Regardless, I wanted to sit down and give my thoughts on my experience with this game, for anyone thinking about buying it.

Shogun 2 is a grand strategy game.  Part of the game is played in world map where you manage your troops and provinces/castles, part of it is in combat where you control your army in skirmishes, battles, and sieges.

The graphics, like most Total War games, are magnificent and demanding.  It runs well on my newer i5 computer with high settings, but will chug HARD on lower end computers, even with graphics turned down.  Not to mention loading the game takes a good few minutes, or longer if your computer isn't that good.  Point is, it's playable on high and low end computers, but probably pass on this for now if you don't think you could wait 5 minutes or so just to actually get into a battle.

The aesthetics are wonderful.  The scenery, art, and sound design are delightfully immersive and pull me into the battles, where I can zoom in while my soldiers are marching and admire their incredibly polished, pristine armor.  I am not a Japanese art or history buff, but I felt this game did a great job of immersing you in the chaos around the rise of a new Shogun.

The strategic element of the game is tightly balanced and somewhat complex.  This is a grand strategy game, which your strategy on the world map and in battles will strongly influence how well your campaign goes.  The game is much better at teaching new players the basic tactics needed than older Total War games, but really understanding battle tactics will take some practice.  

Do note though, this is the point of a strategy game: great depth in its systems.  For me, battles were quite difficult tactically, with my men often losing morale and fleeing without me understanding why, or dying in flocks despite having the advantage of numbers (quality of troops goes a long way when you pit peasants against samurai).  I never blamed the game for my losses though, knowing that if I had more practice micromanaging my units, I'd be able to perform much better.


Despite this, I can only give this game a resounding yes in my review, with the disclaimer that if you don't really like or understand the niche that is Grand Strategy games, you may not like it.  This isn't a game to pursue if you're looking to zone out and not really think hard about how you want to siege a castle, or try to figure out how to hold a castle with only 3 archer platoons against a huge army.  But if you enjoy strategy or grand strategy games, or are looking to try one, I cannot recommend this game higher, for all the points mentioned above.  Total War: Shogun 2 is a fantastic game, and a fantastic Grand Strategy game, and now that I've written this, I'll probably take another stab at the campaign again.

Campaign map is massive and varied. No two battles are fought on the same kind of ground. Trade posts and variable resources on the map make for interesting strategic objectives. Large amount of clans and intricate diplomatic system is fantastic. Variablility in clans aptitudes and unique units plays in to resources on the map. Agents can do any number of amazing and tactically influential things, like bribing an enemy army, assassinating a general, arresting a monk, or converting a population to Buddhism/Christianity. 
Battles are challenging and the AI manages to win a good portion of the time, assuming you aren't a tactical genius (holla). Lack of unit variety can make battles visually uninteresting, but brings focus back to the command portion, and there are a number of mods to make more unit variety.
Highly addictive gameplay (the next turn button calls your name).
Buy it. Get the blood dlc, and Otomo/Hattori factions.

Shogun 2 is a total war game and if you have been following the total war series you know how consistent they are with breaking the game at first and then developing upon it into something that looks and works great. This game however was a great exception and its release was alot more smooth than the other total wars.

The diplomacy is a pretty good system in this game however I find myself bribing to many kingdoms in order to gain a favorable status to the point where the neighbors are attempted to invade my barn! You have to remember that just giving people gifts can weaken your own status and make you more prone to attacks.

The RTS combat is pretty great in this game however I find myself hitting the fast forward button (basically making AI fight) when I am being lazy and I suffer great losses as a result. The Generals do not take kindly to a lazy shogun/Daimyo (player). While your generals might have ranks that can help them overcome battles easier for you its best to improve your own skill set to outmatch any AI you encounter!

I have tried the multiplayer with my friend and tend to drive him mad. I would invest to much money into the most ridiculous things. Multiplayer sometimes takes coordination between two people in order to better penetrate the enemy forces or you might end up with a minecraft partner.

Overall I would say shogun 2 is a great RTS that has lots of re-playability both single player and multiplayer wise.

Probably the best game this company ever made and will ever make. Tremendous combination of turn based strategy and RTS strategy combat. Amazing graphics and an amazing multiplayer system that sucked you in on many levels.

The game may look intimidating to newcomers to the franchise, but the journey to become shogun is not complex to manage. Taking place in 16th century Japan as the various warlords of the land rise up to replace the corrupt Ashikaga shogunate, you command one of the many clans, using your skill in diplomacy, strategic, and tactical knowledge in the art of war on your journey to conquer the shogun's seat in Kyoto.

I notice that Shogun 2 suffers the most in terms of the diplomacy AI, which does not necessarily limit your ability to manipulate the political atmosphere in the game, but it does present awkward scenarios such as a clan that asks for peace when they are about to be wiped off the map... alongside a payment of koku (the currency that Japan used at the time).

Other than this fault, which is not uncommon in games that attempt to balance war and diplomacy, I very much enjoy this game. Recommended to anyone who likes this period of history, a fan of the Total War franchise, or likes real-time strategy games with a turn-based map management system.

Total War series is historical strategy at its best with a combination of turn-based, 'semi-grand' strategy, and real-time combat.  On top of that, Shogun 2 is one of the best in the series.

I can't say much more than has already been said.  That I have over 200 hours on this game should be endorsement enough, but I will add a couple extra comments:

Multiplayer battles.  The battles are certainly 'streamlined', trading realism for a more accessible type of gameplay.  Balance is sometimes a noticeable issue and I occasionally experience things that seem to be cheats:  outrageously fast or strong enemy units for their supposed level, although various combinations of retainer modifiers could account for this on occasion.  It just seems like skill is not well represented in the battle outcomes as well as should be.

That's all I got. The Fall of the Samurai campaign was really excellent, and I loved playing multiplayer and building up my various units levels.

What can i say other than this game is what the total war series is all about!!!! if you like strategy, battles, history and obviously japanese history for that matter then this game is for you......... set in the sengoku jidai 'age of the country at war' period 1545 your thrown in to  japans bitter civil war, each clan no longer obeying the ashikaga shogunate as supreme military leader of japan, you can choose from many different clans to lead each with there own speciality..... some specialise in castle buildings to strengthen there provinces from attack.... others are masters of the sword with elite katana samurai which strike fear into the hearts of there enemys.... others charge into battle with fierce cavalry breaking enemy formations and running down fleeing troops.... it really is a great way to replay the game time and time again by trying these different clans, each clan is also historically accurate in terms of where they start on the map and there strengths i.e horses, archery, ships etc.......... the map looks great and is very easy to navigate as is managing your clans finances building bigger castle with markets, sword dojo's, trading ports etc etc and also discussing diplomacy with other clans for strengthening relations on your borders, trade or asking for help in your struggle against your enemy, you can use ninja to assasinate enemy generals or spys etc (with awesome little cinematics}  it is also beautifully set out with fantastic japanese music which gives the game great atmosphere, there is just to much to list!!! ........... battles are fantastically detailed with a great array of different units from samurai to warrior monks, cavalry, matchlock guns, siege weapons, spearmen, archers etc etc lots and lots!!! unit detail is crazy! and the battles up close look incredibly detailed and dramatic, the A.I though can suffer from time to time but even so it isnt enough to hamper the game experience at all, this is the way to learn history the fun way!!! i could go on for along time saying how great this game is and there is just too much ive missed, this game has a ton of features i havent mentioned i highly recommend it as its a game that you will just keep coming back to again and again its a game thats worth the price because of this, great job CA...... now fix rome 2!!!!! A remake of the classic Shogun: Total War, and possibly the last decent title in the Total War franchise.

I have mixed feelings about Shogun 2. It followed on from Empire, which was epic in scale and one of my all time favourite games, but I was looking forward to doing something that didn't involve gunpowder. Shogun 2 offered better graphics, and a return to the swords and spears and arrows that made Medieval 2 and Rome so enjoyable.

Unfortunately, I found Shogun 2 a bit disappointing. It did everything well, and unlike Rome 2 it was a reasonably bug-free release. But it just didn't seem to have the same staying power as earlier TW games. Each faction seemed to be a carbon copy of all the others, with only minor bonuses to specific units separating them. The strategic map felt much less "epic" than what I had grown accustomed to, yet still seemed to take forever to conquer. The AI was at least reasonably challenging, but battles felt very much like a game of rock-paper-scissors. Although some unit types have always had an advantage over others, Shogun 2 took it to Age of Empires extremes, which I found very annoying (why are swords so devastatingly effective against spears?).

All in all, Shogun 2 felt like a dumbing down of the franchise. While I appreciate that CA was trying to make the game more appealing and accessible to casual players (and thus boost their sales), I can't help but feel that this weakened the game for seasoned Total War veterans. In light of the recent catastrophe that was Rome 2, it seems clear that Shogun 2 was the start of a downhill slide for the franchise that may well spell it's doom. However, it's also fair to say that Shogun 2 is still a much, much stronger title.

The bottom line is this: Shogun 2 is a lot prettier and a lot easier to pick up than Empire or Medieval II, and a much better game overall than Rome 2. If you're wanting a less demanding experience, or just can't stand the aging graphics of the older titles, then Shogun 2 might well appeal to you.

Great TW game, highly polished and among the best TW experiences I've ever had.  Beautiful to look at, smooth to play, probably the most stable TW game I've ever played.  The Feudal Japan setting is not for everyone but a must-play if you're curious about it.

Seems to have great multiplayer features, including drop-in battles if you're online to spice up your enemy.

Worth noting is the Fall of the Samurai DLC, which is HIGHLY, HIGHLY recommended.  It's musket and railroad era Japan, and it's a very refreshing change of pace from other TW games.  Some of the features here are game-changers, such as the ability to call in artillery strikes if a navy is near a land battle, and agents that have multiple meaningful uses.  Get Fall of the Samurai, do not hesitate.

A few downsides:  

1) Unit variety is a little lacking, each faction can field 90%+ of the same units.  Some factions get a few bonuses and extra units but factions are more generic than in any other TW game I've played.

2) Terrain is meaningful (and very pretty), but not as meaningful as Empire/Napoleon, where you could hide in houses and take cover behind fences/walls.  It feels like a step back from that great use of terrain in Empire.

3) Realm Divide feature is controversial and is not for everyone.  Basically, if you get powerful enough (and you'll know you're getting close before it happens), all factions who are not your solid allies will gang up on you and try to destroy you.  I suppose it's a decent alternative to the frequent TW non-ending where you just steamroll everyone, but it's controversial and a bit gamey, so I mention it.

Highly recommended.

Shogun 2 brings out the best of every strategist. Massive numbers simply are not enough to defeat your enemy, and inferior forces still stand a change with the right strategy. For the most part, the battles system itself is well balanced; it is easy to gauge which type of unit would fair better against others, or how disadvantaged units could hold off, distract, harass, or even defeat the enemy. The campaign mode suffers from having a very ill-defined economy in terms of the inflation penalty experienced when your empire grows. The AI also cheats extensively, planning their movements against you even if you've never encountered them before. The notoriously infamous "Realm Divide" event is the biggest turn off in this game, but there do exist mods to lesson the impact on gameplay. Overall, I highly recommend this game. the game has a lot of life to it. I've played 1000 hours so far, and I can easily see myself going at it for another 1000 hours without the game getting boring or feeling repetitive.

Total War: Shogun 2 is almost perfect in every way. It has great graphics and optimization, spectacular gameplay and balance, and the sound effects immerse you into the game. Other than that, I can't think of a way they could improve this game anymore. It is simply a masterpiece, and one of my favorites.

Overview: As the Creative Assembly's sequel to the game that launched the Total War series, Shogun 2 is a big improvement in and represents a culmination of the learning the developer has done over the years. With a return to fundamentals in combat with a distinct feel and look, Shogun 2 is a well-polished game that serves as a great entry point for players who enjoy turned based strategy fused with real time tactical gameplay.

What is Shogun 2?

Shogun 2 is a game in the Total War series that focuses on the Sengoku Jidai (Warring States Period) of Japan. The player chooses one of the prominent clans of the period and vies for the title of Shogun among many factions.

The Total War games focus on two aspects: Strategy and Tactics. The strategic side focuses on campaign map management, which includes using agents such as Ninja and Buddhist monks, planning and developing provinces, researching new military and civic technology, trading with other clans, and diplomacy. The tactical side involves set piece battles, the hallmark of the Total War series, involving (mostly) period accurate units such as samurai, warrior monks, ninjas, and ashigaru (levied) units.

Gameplay (4/5)

The gameplay is more polished in Shogun 2 than in earlier games in the Total War series. Units are recruited out of settlements and formed into armies. Due to the fact that the game takes place in Japan entirely, the unit rosters between clans are pretty similar, with most units being fielded by everyone, and only a few unique variations of base units available as clan specific units. While this doesn't detract much from gameplay, many Total War veterans will definitely notice the lack of the usually diverse units and factions a player can interact with in older games in the series. A player can choose the composition of their armies and take them to the field of battle against another clan. 

Combat is fought on battlefields in a set piece manner. The battles have a higher than average pacing, lasting usually five to ten minutes. Some may find battles too short/fast, but I personally found that it lasted a satisfying amount of time. In a typical campaign it isn't unusual to fight a hundred battles or more, so there is no shortage of combat. Tactically, the AI knows what it is doing but has a tendency to do dumb things, like misuse generals as well as not taking opportunities to flank your troops. Players may find the AI tactical abilities lacking in some areas.

Units are pretty responsive to commands and overall controls are easy to learn and use. Tactics have a lot of depth, with players having to manage unit morale, field positioning, and maneuvering. The camera look system is robust and designed to allow a player to zoom in on the battlefield and watch individual units fight.

The campaign map includes most of Japan, with the game taking place on the Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu islands. Mountainous areas allow for choke points and forests act as ambush points. A player can move their army along well-trodden roads, or cut through a mountain pass to make an attack deep in enemy territory. Ships allow for faster movement across the map, which can take a long time to travel on foot. Certain provinces have special resources important for research and development, which adds in another strategic layer for war planning.

City management is smarter now, and with the encyclopedia, it is easy to plan cities. As you upgrade the castle in a province, more building slots open up, allowing the player more room to build. As there are a limited number of building slots possible in a province, it is important for the player to consider the purpose of the province and plan accordingly. Provincial combat focuses on field battles and castle sieges. As provincial control lies in castles, most of the important battles you fight will involve one. 

The AI seems to be an improvement over previous games in terms of decision making, although diplomacy with the AI is still pretty clunky. It is hard to know the decision making process behind the AI, but it isn't unusual for a very weak clan to declare war on a much stronger opponent, among other obviously self-detrimental actions.

Look and feel - User Interface (4.5/5):

The game has a distinct period-specific Japanese feel, with the art and interface design reflecting those themes. The campaign map retains a parchment look until explored, and the four seasons of Japan play a role in campaign strategy. 

Campaign map management has been improved over the earlier titles in the Total War series. The Creative Assembly has gotten better with each iteration with how they present relevant information to the player. Family trees are very user friendly, and allow for promotions and adoptions for generals. Finances are easy to manage through the trade and tax windows, and the Shogun 2 encyclopedia can be opened on just about anything clickable in game, which provides deeper information found in just the tooltips.

Graphics (4.5/5):

The graphics are pretty well optimized. The game can run on lower end machines, but to appreciate the detail put into the individual units on the battlefield, a mid-tier and up machine is necessary.

Zooming in during battles will reveal the detail put into the individual unit's appearance, but also mundane things like grass and rocks. The details presented in every iteration of the Total War series improves, and Shogun 2, especially with the Blood Pack DLC, is incredibly visceral up close.

Sound (4/5):

The music and sounds are Japan-themed, with the sounds of the Koto and Shakuhachi prevalent through loading screens and as ambient sound in places like the campaign map. Units respond in Japanese, and the unit advisor speaks English with a Japanese accent (the adviser can be turned off).

Overall, the sounds and music are subtle and unobtrusive. You'll notice it if you're listening for it but otherwise it sort of blends in with the game.

Verdict:

The Total War series can be daunting for the uninitiated, but Shogun 2 is an excellent entry point for new comers while offering to Total War veterans a great gaming exp with a distinct look and feel that builds upon the things The Creative Assembly has learned through the years, knowing what works and what doesn't. While it isn't anything revolutionary in terms of new mechanics, it doubles down and nails a lot of the positive characteristics of the older games. Some may not like the narrower unit roster or gameplay focus on castle sieges, but it doesn't noticeably detract from the game. Shogun 2 is definitely a title worth picking up.

Total war Shogun 2 is a beautiful strategy game that really allows the player to be immersed in what is one of the most overlooked periods in ancient history. Shogun envelopes you into 16th century Japan and challenges you to control some of  the strongest families during the Sengoku jidai or age of war. The challenge that is posed against you is to overthrow the shogunate who has betrayed your family , therefore striking you to pursue unifying and controling Japan. With the highly acclaimed single player which contains the Civilisation style turn based gameplay to the real time strategy from the likes of Command & Conquer and competetive multiplayer, you will never be stuck with nothing to do. 

The multiplayer incorporates a unique personal avatar system that was introduced in Napoleon total war and has been reworked, adapted and enhanced within the newest total war title. The user has an avatar which can be created and edited from the start of the multiplayer experience. Throughout the multiplayer battles and through gaining single player acheivements new items for your general can be unlocked to make your leader dominate the battlefield with his new shiny greaves . Upon winning matches you start to conquer the area's of Japan, allowing for seperate unlocks to units and retainers (buff cards) which gives the multiplayer some replayability and continuinity. 

8/10 - 
*Great strategy with beatiful visuals and great competetive Avatar multiplayer*
*Lacks greater unit variety in the single player*
*AI has improved massivly since napoleon total war however still somewhat lackluster*
*Wonderful mix of real-time and turn-based strategy really makes this game a winner*

The epitome of a good Total War game. Though I received this game a year after it was released, I feel no regrets in purchasing this game. Shogun 2 is the perfect game for beginners to get a grasp of what the series is like and its now become one of the classics for Total war veterans. Nothing feels more amazing than leading an army of samurai in Japans warring states period: The Sengoku Jidai. In this game, the mix of turn based strategy (with economic, political, and diplomatic ramifications) and real time battles is wonderful but the need to balance timing and aggression is more important than ever. The AI may seem difficult at first and hard to deal with but the Total War series has always been about realism and the AI's scripted actions make logical and historical sense.
Graphically Shogun 2 is stunning and one of the more easily run games in the series. It is a testament of Creative Assembly's hard work.
If you end up playing Shogun 2, I would also recommend playing its two expansions as well: Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai. Both expansions add more depth to the title while adding various new units and factions to play as.
My final word is Shogun 2 is the perfect game for history buffs and action fans alike who love leading massive armies into battle but also love using passive or aggressive diplomacy in the campaign as well.

Shogun II improves upon its immediate predecessors in the Total War series, but that's not saying much. The AI is somewhat better, true, and naval battles are no longer a nightmare of inefficiency. However, the game also takes some steps back. Most notable amongst these is the utter lack of replayability; with a single exception (available through DLC purchase only), every faction shares all of its units with every other faction on the map, and the only real variance you'll see between campaigns will arise from your starting position. Needless to say, that isn't much. 

Beyond this, you'll find yourself confronted by the usual products of this developer's notorious laziness. Worst of all amongst these is a combat engine limitation that also exists in Empire and Napoleon but manifests itself much more prominently in Shogun: the engine is unitary. That is, each soldier can fight one enemy soldier, and only one. Soldiers cannot be flanked and cannot be overwhelmed by numbers. Nay; if you've got a unit of ten men fighting against an enemy unit of one, then nine of your soldiers will stand around and do nothing. While this was less of an issue in Shogun's two immediate predecessors, being as that they were focused upon firearms, it is inexcusable that this limitation has persisted in a game focused entirely upon melee combat. This sort of disregard for creating a complete product is, sadly, a hallmark of the developer of this series. 

I do not recommend that you purchase this game. This is, actually, a somewhat odd case in that one of its standalone DLC products is superior to the title that spawned it; Fall of the Samurai is a more novel, more engaging experience than Shogun II is. If you simply must have your Total War fix, then buy that instead.

A polished addition to the Total War series. Stunning graphics, colourful voice acting and a variety of campaign choices make it a rounded and interesting game. Multiplayer features much of the same map-based campaign as the single player, though the addition of general customisation and clan warfare makes it a good game to play with friends. My only complaint with the game is the end-game mechanic of "Realm Divide" when you capture the capital Kyoto. This mechanic, which involves everyone in Japan declaring war on you while you fight to maintain rule of the capital city, seems like an artificial way to ramp up the final difficulty and becomes pretty annoying.

Total War is a series that has intrigued me, but frightened me off just the same. The difficulty in learning what unit does what, and how each operate was a very difficult task, but learning to overcome that uncertainty pushed Shogun 2 into a limelight that it's easier predecessor (Empire) held.

Shogun 2 provides a mixture of well-designed characters with extremely detailed animations into deadly historical war. In true Total War fashion, just having superior numbers and "zerging" an enemy unit does not always win. It's the proper use of the right "tool" to do the job that prevails here.

It does take a LOT to get used to, and it takes awhile to get into the "swing" of things, but give it enough time and you will be stroking your chin in thought as you effectively play your real-time chess against an opponent that already knows your army better than you do.

Most likely the apex of the Total War series, Shogun 2 manages to hit almost every high point the series has had in previous installments. Shogun 2, despite trimming down some features like town management, manages to capture the previous games' glory without sacrificing much beyond excess tedium. Despite this, it still has a steep learning curve as in the previous installments. The more focused scope of the game allows for a much easier time of getting into the series, placing Shogun 2 as the first game that one should buy if they are interested in the Total War series in this reviewer's opinion.

Strengths:
Preserves the depth of the franchise without getting lost in the tedium.
Beautiful, engaging visuals with some heavily stylized artwork.
Preserves the culture of feudal Japan, doing it great justice.
Good mod support.
Focus on Japan ensures you understand every unit's purpose.

Weaknesses:
Relatively steep learning curve, despite having been more simplified.
Discouraging to new players, as the game can take some time to truly start in force. (Not exactly a con for veterans)
Small focus on Japan, disallowing unit diversity.

Overall numerical rating: 9-9.5

This game pretty much takes everything that has gone right with the total war franchise and boiled it in one massive pot of awesomeness.  Any complaints I had from Empire have been addressed and the game feels extremely polished and well made.  For people who enjoy just the single player, the ai is no longer a dumb ass who sits around waiting for you to kill them building garbage units to be slaughtered.  Not only will the AI launch naval invasions and have well rounded armies, but if you become too powerful they won't have any reservations about ganging up on you turning the whole campaign map into a giant cluster fuck of endless battle.  The big improvement is the multiplayer where you make a custom general that you can upgrade and level up with new abilites, armor, and retainers which grant bonuses allowing you to specialize your army the way you want.  I don't have enough room to fully tell you how good this game is, so i guess you would just have to try it yourself.

"We forge our own destiny. We are as ronin — wandering samurai without a master."-Henchmen 21 to Henchmen 24

Imagine playing a game for five hours only to get yourself in a situation where you cannot win and your last recoverable save was an hour ago.  Only to recover as you sacrificed a few provinces for your armies to retreat to a defendable position like the hot gates.  

As the filthy Oda peasants amass for a siege, your general screams "THIS IS KAGA" as he Shogun kicks a captured ninja into a well.  Your elite warriors line up side by side and make short work of the peasant army armed with pitch forks as your men's katanas gleam with blood and martensite.  Only to be slowly dwindled down by mass goddamn peasant archers that have fire arrows, your elite samurai get picked off dishonoruably afar from a man in a loincloth. 

The actual gameplay for Shogun 2 is quite diverse.  From the economic and diplomatic standpoint the game is turned base, as you set up buildings for your provinces to build up to bargaining trade routes and exchanging sons and daughters to secure alliances.  Just be wary, the computer is very devious and in the end most alliances turn into treachery.

Think of a RTS where instead of creating a new army for every different map/campaign mission you play, you maintain your army throughout the entire camaign (unless you get them killed).  

It is quite simplified compared to past Total War games, and if you have ever been interested in the Total War series I'd recommend this one.

Truly an epic addition to the Total War series, this magnificent game moves the Total War battlefields to the Far East. The Singleplayer gameplay is centered around a Turn Based campaign map, where you are allowed to Macro your Economies, Commerce, Armies, Diplomacy, and Agents all on one easy to follow medium. One drawback is the lack of castle variation or construction ability, each siege battle will have the same castles for each stage of construction achieved in the province; However in other modes in the game, you may choose to preload a unique castle for one battle. The actual battles themselves take place in a Real Time Strategy environment where the player must field their units in battle against enemy forces. There are many types of battles; Sieges, Skirmishes, Night Battles, Ambushes; Each battle providing a different experience and strategy. Countless units will allow you to construct a diverse army capable of accommodating for any possible enemy strategy. The online play has obviously seen better days considering the date of release; However one can still find a competative game here and there. The Avitar campaign feature was truly one of the best facets of the game, allowing for players to join clans with their friends, and play a competative campaign style map which eliminated all Macro management, and focuses only on the battles to consider the outcome of each turn. The player then gains veteran units to field in later battles, and also the opportunity to upgrade each veteran unit with unique abilities such as fire arrows, or the swooping crane. The game also allows for historical battles which actually have some historically accurate information provided in the massive in game index. Trust me if you have any questions about how to do something in the game, it will be in that index. All in all this game will keep you entertained for hours, whether you enjoy playing solo, or multiplayer; there are endless opportunities to replay this game.

Shogun II, I think, is the best of the Total War series so far. The new Total War: Rome II is at the moment a buggy mess, but I believe even when that is fixed it will not be able to compete with Shogun II. I've always like the Total War games, but they're often set in such broad periods, with countries to conquer all over the map. That can be great, and many people like it about Total War games. But it can really bog down a play session, and sometimes it can get really silly. The more factions there are, the longer turns take, until you might as well go do something else with your time after you've hit end turn. And the broad timeframe can mean that you find yourself fighting dark age vikings with your army consisting of pike and shot.

Shogun II manages to avoid these pitfalls by being very narrow. The map consists of Japan, and nothing but Japan, and although there are several expansions set in different time frames, each of the campaigns stays within a reasonable narrow scope. This means the unit roster will not change much, and some may find fault with that. I like it, because it means you can really get a feel for your troops, and they never become useless. There are no large empires to carve out, and this may hold back those who are bent on world domination. But it does make for a much smoother experience gameplay wise, and it is also easier to keep track of things.

The AI usually is the main flaw in Total War games, and Shogun II is not a complete exception. I do feel though that the AI of Shogun II is the best we've seen yet, and all in all Shogun II provides a good challenge even to the veteran Total War player, especially if you choose some of the really difficult factions such as the Tokugawa. That old Togugawa Ieyasu certainly did not get things handed to him on a silver plate!

If there is one thing I would change about this game it is the sudden and anti-climactic Realm Divide. Suddenly age old alliances start to deteriorate, and everyone declares war on you. It feels really metagamey, and makes you wait for ages after you've hit the treshhold, and you know you can't conquer any more provinces or else you have to deal with that annoying Realm Divide. I find that the solution offered in Fall of the Samurai did it much better, as there you are divided between your collective enemies and your allies and friends.

But all in all I can definitely recommend Total War: Shogun II. If you would have to pick up just one Total War game, this would be it.

This is a difficult game to recomend. Not just anyone can play it. It's tough. 
It's tough 5000% of the way through. But if you can play it then it is outstandingly satisfying. Shogun 2 is a turn-based strategy game but also a real-time tactics. It's no cruddy little action-based MOBA that gets off on calling itself a strategy game. Total War is the epitome of strategy. It lets you plan and expand and build up an empire in a fashion not completely unlike a Civilization game during the campain but then allows you to take up the role of a general out on the field in an incredibly realistic battle simulation. There are ridiculous amounts of factors incorporated into each part of the game such as speed, size, skill, and armor and taxes, trade, wealth, happiness, honor and loyalty. A genius general can make a hopeless battle elementary, but a wise emperor can remove any disadvantage years ahead. It takes lessons from both Sun Tzu and Alexander the Great to excel at this game. It seems that I might just be able to trace my lineage to some very interesiting characters.

Unlike most strategy games, where a larger or better army always wins unless each unit is sent to their deaths individually, in Total War even a smaller and weaker army can win.
Morale is a powerful weapon in the Total War series. Why clash swords with Goliath, if you can scare him with flaming arrows into retreat?

The graphics are also fairly impressive, given the sheer amount of units that can take part in a battle.

This game is definitely a must-buy for anyone who enjoys strategy games.

Действие игры происходит на трех из четырех крупнейших японских островов: Хонсю, Кюсю и Сикоку, а временные рамки охватывают период окончания Сэнгоку Дзидай. В роли даймё — лидера одной из враждующих группировок — игрок должен вести боевые действия, заниматься экономической политикой и вести дипломатическую игру, чтобы добиться главной цели игры: объединения феодальной Японии в единое государство под властью клана игрока.

В сухопутных сражениях игрок командует армией. Армия делится на отряды, максимальное число отрядов — двадцать. Каждое подразделение имеет свои преимущества, недостатки, стоимость обучения и общий уровень эффективности.

Подразделения имеют определённый моральный уровень, который может увеличиваться, если битва проходит удачно, или уменьшаться при тяжелых потерях, гибели офицеров или в случае смерти генерала.

Осады принимают в учёт архитектуру японских замков, которая отличается от своих европейских аналогов. Японские замки состоят из нескольких террас, окружённых стенами. Высота каждой террасы зависит от рельефа. В Shogun 2 нет нужды строить осадные машины, хотя в состав армии и могут входит мангонелы (катапульты) и европейские пушки, которые не могут перемещаться во время боя. Все пешие войска способны карабкаться по стенам во время штурма замка. Чтобы захватить замок совсем необязательно уничтожить всех защитников. Достаточно пробиться к центральному зданию и захватить его. Войска также могут поджечь замковые врата, чтобы иметь более прямой доступ в замок и позволить кавалерии вступить в бой с защитниками. Также, кавалерия может спешиться чтобы залезть на стены. Крепостные башни могут быть захвачены во время штурма, как и различные здания присутствующие за стенами замка. Например, захват фермы повышает выносливость армии в этой битве, тогда как захват додзё лучников пополняет запасы стрел и аммуниции.

В «Shogun 2» разработчики вернули подбадривающие речи генералов перед боем. Все речи — на японском с субтитрами. В ней по возможности максимально точно описывается ситуация: кто противник, количество обеих армий, честь вражеского даймё, качества своего клана, и т. п.

Чтобы стать сёгуном, клану необходимо захватить и удержать Киото, а также необходимое количество провинций.

The Total War series has consistently improved in just about every way (except moddability), and this game continues that trend. 

The game has a good balance of combat, campaign map tactics, and diplomacy, as well as great visuals. Sieges are probably the weak point in the combat as they're a little too one sided most of the time, especially with a lack of decent siege weapons. Field battles feel great on the other hand, and the graphics are remarkably good considering the thousands of troops that are often on the field. 

The expansions are more like entirely new games, but the DLC is pretty mediocre otherwise.

If you've played Rome or Medieval TW, this is a step in the right direction for the series (assuming your machine can handle it).  You choose which faction to play as, and there are key advantages/disadvantages for each.  The battle mechanics are such that it's possible to hold a walled city with archers and well-placed infantry against a superior invading force.  The diplomacy system has improved dramatically, and you can usually squeeze the other factions for some cash in exchange for your agreement to trade with them.  I've earned 15,000 gold for this in some cases, so this is a critical element.  Overall, a great title.

If you like total war, get it. If you dont know what Total war is, get it.    Just dont expect great matchmade battles online.


Singleplayer- The global map is much easier to understand then in Napoleon or Empires, which is a big selling point for me.  Units seem balanced enough, in all three versions of the game with the exception of the navy unit with the cannon.

Multiplayer - The 1v1 coop/vs campaign is a lot of fun. Other modes are the drop in mode where you play the AI's side in other peoples campaign games, also fun. 
The rest of the modes, however, are garbage.  At this point in the game, the people you play against have usually already found the cheapest way to win.  The DLC factions have added some crazy units that are hard to deal with unless you're familier with them.

Within the first week of the games release it seemed like no one was playing in the lobby, it took minutes to find a match and forget about asking questions in the chat rooms.
Samurai Warfare on a massive scale, what more can you ask for?

I've never played a Total War game, but after Shogun 2 I'm definitely interested in trying more. Every single battle in my first campaign so far has been highly suspenseful. I recall trying to defend Yamaguchi castle against a larger force comprised mainly of samurai units with a garrison of mainly ashigaru and two units of yari samurai. I felt like it was over, and that I was going to lose the castle, but I fought the battle and with some quick planning I managed to rout the enemy army and sally the remaining soldiers to eliminate them once and for all! Intense moments like that make Shogun 2 a must have.

Total War: Shogun 2 is a nice blend of turn-based and real-time strategy. The player takes control of one of the Daimyo (or other factions in the DLC) in an effort to unite Japan under one ruler.

There are many paths to victory: Gain allies through political maneuvering to crush a common enemy; employ the art of subterfuge to undermine the populace of another ruler; or simply build a massive army to steamroll an enemy force--the choice is up to the player.

And don't forget the management of resources. A well-equipped, well-trained force can turn the tides against a larger, untrained one. Keeping the populace pleased and under careful watch can be vital in preventing peasant/religious uprisings.

Overall, there is much to like about this game, and for those who enjoy the genre, Total War: Shogun 2 will provide countless hours of fun.

Fun as hell. The combat is the main focus in this title of Total War. T.W. is known for its addicting combat, and in Shogun 2 its taken to another level. Unit variety is quite expansive, but mainly its hand to hand and bows for range with the occasional siege weapons and exotic units. Its just a freakin blast watching samurai charge eachother, mounted horseback units chasing down routing foes, archers launching mass flaming arrow volley towards a crowd of enemies, and everything in-between. Marching your armies through Japans provinces and claming them as your own, controlling resources and manipulating conquered provinces to fit your intentions, all whilest ranking up your generals and armies which is incredibly satisfying and well advantageous. The units are very responsive, so tactical planning and play is ideal, making most every battle unique. Defending in a castle/town siege is one of my personal favorite activities in this game. i HIGHLY reccomend this game for any strategy fans, especially if you had ANY liking towards other Total War titles. 9.5/10

It's an excellent continuation of the Total War series. Coming back to its roots, Shogun II provides crisp and well-developed naval battles, a leveling system for both agents and generals, and a reinvented castle development system that allows infastructure and taxation to develop the way you want it too. The AI still function with backstabbing prejudice and unit diversification between clans is lacking, but all in all the game is well-made, quite fun, and rather addicting.

I'm a sucker for Total War games, so I felt obligated to buy it. That and with the relatively low price of the deal it was offered at; I couldn't help but cave in. And this is a game that is awesome. The various updates to Total War mechanics makes this game stand on quite the pedestal. It's soured my opinion of previous entries like Rome Total War as a result; Rome's a great nostalgia trip but with its mechanics feeling as primitive as they do in comparison to Shogun 2 I can't help but feel that it's lacking in some ways. In short; if you like strategy games, this is a great investment.

I prefer Shogun II over Empire, but still, Shogun II doesn't have the feeling that Rome or Medieval II had the first time i've played them. To be honest I only played Shogun II for approximately 136 hours so far. It's more polished than Empire was on release, as of now Empire (not Napoleon) isn't exactly bad, but I just never liked the era, gunpowder and canons just don't cut it for me, I need raw army clashes with swords and shields and arrows, give me that any time over Empire. 

Additionally, I prefer the micro-management of your empire in both Rome and Medieval II, Empire's management of your forces and resources was streamlined/simplified, I never understood why since it was working fine the way it is in Rome and Medieval II, I guess they wanted to change it for the sake of trying something new, who knows. 

From what I've played of Shogun II it does feel better overall than Empire (the management). What I can say is that the beautiful graphics, the music and the cutscenes, the scale and size of the world map and the soldiers on it, make Shogun II with the ROTS and FOTS expansions a solid and brilliant game.

 In the final count, it's consistently thrilling, grand in scope, surprisingly atmospheric, and bloody hard to put down.

The Total Wars franchise is one I enjoy imensly, and Shogun 2 was a great title in the franchise. The gameplay is largely slow paced, and consists of city management and diplomatic relations, but as you manage teetering truces and all out war, you find yourself burried deep into the game. A games that is easy to find yourself saying 'just one more turn' and then hours later, you are still playing. The first Total War game I've actually beat, it does a good job of insturcting you of the finer points of the game early on. Might be slightly easier than previous games, but never felt overly easy, and definitely cut down on some of the situations in earlier games where every broken siege was followed by a train of another large AI controlled army. Battle map engagements are as fun and challenging as ever, but tend to go by the wayside later in the game, as the conquest map becomes your primary focus. If you like a game that takes some thought, this is one for you. Highly reccomended.

Creative Assembly has made another awesome total war game.  This time, its a sequel to the original Total war.  Instead of making the game more complicated and adding more units, they simplified it and streamlined some of the options in the game.  Although it is more simple and streamlined, it still maintains a factor of challenge that I cannot seem to overcome.  I have only beat the game once, and that was after reloading many saves.  When starting a game, you will choose a clan to play as.  Each of the clans have a different attribute assigned to them that gives them a bit of an edge.  For example, the Shimazu clan is better with Katana units, while the Takeda clan has better cavalry units.  The game is well balanced and not that hard to get into.  Would reccomend to anyone that is looking at getting into Total War.

Creative Assembly, known for producing highly bugged messes with Medieval 2, Empire, and to a lesser extent, Napoleon, have finally created a game that simply works out of the box. There are some issues left, but if you were put off by the previous few Total War titles, Shogun 2 is a good one to return to. It's also the first time the Shogun era has been seen since the format change they made with Rome, and it carried over very well. Easily one of the best Total Wars out yet, the addition of a multiplayer co-op campaign makes the deal all the more sweet.

Familiar but well-executed,  Very polished Total War Franchise, and has a gigantic multiplayer suite that should keep you playing long after you've run through a few campaigns.

Shogun 2 brings Total War back to it's wonderful roots. The game dismisses the complex number of units and their strengths & weaknesses and instead focuses on a simple triangle with Yari Spearmen beating Mounted Cavalry, Calvalry beating Katana Samurai and Katana Samurai beating Yari Spearmen. The challenge comes in the form of very aggressive AI. This often gives you very little time to think but it really stresses a solid defence. The big flaw with the game is that it's heavy on the PC. Load times can be absurdly long but it's fairly fluid once you get into the game.

One of the best strategy games I've ever played in my life. Combining the wonderful and intriguing aspects of Japanese culture, warfare, and politics during the Sengoku Jidai era, this game offers a complex system of diplomacy and warfare. Easy to learn, but difficult to master, you take control of one of the famous clan's in Japan and fight your way to unifying the country, much like Nobunaga Oda, Hideyoshi Toyotomi, and Tokugawa Ieyasu. In fact, these leaders even appear in the game as generals to be commanded (provided you selected a certain clan). Beware, this game tends to slow down a bit towards the later stages, as even though the amount of clan's present tends to drop off sharply, the amount of control of those left vastly increases, and the AI takes a fair bit of time deciding what to do. Other than that, this game is a must-have for RTS, Strategy, and/or History lovers. :)

CA have really pushed the limits of their engine in this revisit to the Sengoku Jidai period in Japan.
The game keeps a similar mechanic to that of the other games, but this time has severely improved the campaign ai. 
The Campaign map is highly detailed, and is accurate to the time period, as is the castle building and recruiting system. 
Each clan has specific bonuses, for example, the Oda having cheaper costing ashigaru that have better morale. 
Also, because the campaign have better Ai, you are forced to take more care in how you use your turn, sometimes having to turn to diplomacy, which has also been improved by adding the likely reaction to your offers and demands. 

The battle system is a bit more responsive, and the sea battles are a large improvement on the other games. Not to forget the multiplayer, which has been expanded upon to become another major part of the game.

At an average playthrough time at about 15+ hours,this game is well worth buying

Shogun 2 is another great addition to the Total War franchise. it's based in the sengoku war era where the clans inside Japan are fighting to become the new shogunate. 

In the turn based campaign mode you'll have to manage your clan by raising and lowering taxes, making alliances, going to war and managing trade. I spend endless hours trying to conquor Japan with the different clans and make myself the shogun.

Ontop of the rich experience from the campaign the player can experience Avatar conquest which takes you online in head to head challanges against real people where you must move your avatar around the map conqueoring regions and unlocking newer units to create the best army and desimate your foes.

This is one of the best Strategy games I have ever played and would add to the imense amount of hours already spent into other Total war games.

Shogun 2 from the total war series. If you have ever played any of the series you know how good are they, if not try it out its a gr8 strategy game...

I've been a longtime fan since the first installment and played all the releases except for Napoleon. This one takes the best of all of them and adds a lot of new features and tech. While it still has the Empire model for taxing (1 tax for all towns) It allows you to exempt a town from taxes or to place a Matsuke/Monk in them to moderate their hapiness level. This adds more gameplay and purpose, as there are many more RPG elements for Generals, Heroes and Specialist characters now. 

I was floored with how many more RPG elements are in this than the others, with the Skill Tier systems for characters as well as bonus systems for over all class types. 
Diplomacy is more important in this game than any before it. It really makes you think about even little decision you make. Even on easy/short campaign, one wrong move could send your Clan spiraling out of control. 

Graphics are better than ever, sound is superb though initial loading times are a little longer due to scale. 

9/10 -XD

It's the original Shogun Total War from way back when, but polished, gorgeous and totally playable. Will suck you in like all other TW games will, but is far improved from the AI catastrophe of Empire, and a natural progression artistically from Napoleon, with a single direction and a concise image. 

The location and point in history might put some people off (I can't think who though), but it's the perfect thing to get you ready for Rome 2!

Though The Creative Assembly needs to work on its ability to juggle between technical fixes and new content releases, this installment in the Total War series is the best overall since Medieval II.  The art direction is well executed, the multiplayer functions (at times), and the battles carry the same PC-straining fun that they always have.
