If you like japanese history, this game is for you. I had never played any game from the Total War series, but I decided to check this one out because I heard a lot of people talking good things about it. It requires some time to learn, but the result is worth it. I never thought I would like so much of a strategy game -- I'm really astounded. In this game your goal is to control most of japanese provinces of the Sengoku Jidai (Japanese Civil Wars XV-XVI centuries) and the strong part of the game is to plan strategies for your armies in real time battles on the field and defending or attacking a castle. If this sounds interesting, I'd suggest you to download the demo and check it out for yourself.

so far one of the best entries into the total war series as it seems to take pretty much the best aspects of the previous games and mash 'em up.

personally I really like how you now have some degree of control on how your generals/characters develope(skill tree/semi random retainers), it makes you much more invested in them.

combat seems to be fine tuned and more responsive, positioning of your general is really vital to sucess due to the sphere of influene, so want to place him close to your troops but also avoid getting him killed.

graphics are gorgeous if you have the machine power for it(currently I don't :-( but I still enjoy it)

as for the bad things the two things I can think of is
1) loading times can be really long, especially the startup is tiring.
2) in some aspects the game is even slower than previous games, since a year is now 4 rounds rather than 2 it takes forever for your family-tree to expand.(e.g. sons first gets useful at age 16 so you have to play 1024 rounds)

A stunning entry in Creative Assembly's Total War series with solid gameplay mechanics and a user interface that is practical and aesthetically flavorful. Both the turn-based strategic and real-time tactical modes are rendered gorgeously. There are enough options for strategy fans to sink their teeth into, from single-player grand campaign to skirmishes on land and sea. Multiplayer campaigns and battles are also available along with the new "Avatar Mode." Not since Company of Heroes have I every played a strategy game so savage and bloody yet so overwhelmingly beautiful.

It's Total War: Shogun Motherfucking 2. You should know by now whether you will like this game or not. I do like that the units are streamlined so you don't have to sit around comparing minor stats for what often amounts to a name change and a new model, but it does make a lot of the armies feel kind of samey and detracts a bit from the immersion. Sea battles suck dick, but at least they're present. Total War AI is present in full force, so get ready for multiplayer if you want a real challenge. In the end, this is my favorite Total War game gameplay wise, but the asthetics and spectacle of it all may be a bit lacking.

В игре загрузочные экраны с яркими иллюстрациями, матерчатая карта страны, по мере исследования оживающая на глазах, привязанные к событиям ролики и превосходная музыка, встроенная энциклопедия. Ему предоставляется карта Японии, разделённая на множество провинций, и окружающие её моря. В игре совмещены режимы пошаговой стратегии и тактики в реальном времени. Моя оценка 8/10.

Shogun 2 and I have had a rough road together. In the beginning it was all honeymoon, great graphics, lots of fun units and good combat mechanics. We then hit a great divide called “Realm Divide” and our love affair faltered.  I then had a stroke of genius and I searched YouTube. I was very lucky to find a channel mostly about Total war Games. The channel was “Heir of Carthage” and the video was part of his “Total War Shogun 2 Shimazu Campaign Commentary” play list. Not wanting to give up on a Total War game I decided to watch his whole campaign and see how he dealt with the Realm Divide. Maybe, just maybe I was doing something wrong. It turns out I was, I ended up loading a saved game from back when I first got the game and I was able to finish the game with a WIN! I have since fell back in love with this game and I can easily say its one of the best Total War games. I give a lot of credit to “Heir of Carthage” for his great videos which helped out tremendously.

Killing the Japanese peasantry has never been so much fun. It comes in three neopolitan flavours. Vanilla - the 16th century Sengoku Jidai full of samurai, religious tension and anime haircuts; Strawberry - the centuries earlier Gempei War packed with political intrigue, warring houses and more questionable haircuts; and of course Chocolate - the Boshin war, a fracas of artillery, ironclads, gattling guns and ludicrous wigs. So if you enjoy RTS games, turn based strategy, interesting hair styles, ice cream and Japan, all the Shogun games are reccomended.

Commenting solely  on Shogun 2 itself, as I didn't try the expansions.
It's a great addition to the Total War Franchise, it adds a lot of depth, and features, and also helped them recover from the failure that was Empire: total war.

The graphics are very good, as is the gameplay, micromanaging an empire isn't difficult and the game provides a decent challenge, save for the odd broken AI moments, but you can gloss over those as they don't happen too often.

Sadly, I can only give this game a seven out of ten, due to CTD issues it seems to have with my PC, while it's not game breaking and all the time, it's annoying to have to reload the game and continue again after it does so. Which also leads me on to another small flaw, loading into the game and getting to the main menu can sometimes take ages.

All in all, a  very good strategy game, with DLC that is worth it, even if you only get a couple of the extra clans or the Blood pack. I'll still play it, but rarely due to the CTD issue.

Awesome game. New technologies and new game mechanics. This is clearly the next evolution of the Total War genre and I heartily recommend it.

If you're a fan of the Total War series, then this is another must-have.  By far the most polished of all the series.  Excellent campaign, excellent gameplay, excellent graphics and a winderful gaming experience.

Now for the not-so-good:

The battle-replay system seems to be flawed - you will rewatch a battle and think, "Wait... that didn't happen like that."  It gives a good idea of what occurred early on, but starts to deviate later.

I am not a fan of a PvP leveling system in a game meant to be only about strategy and unit choices.  All players should be on a level playing field and the outcome should reflect who made better use of their money and had the better on-field strategy.  I would prefer the leveling system affect visual elements only and keep the playing field level for all.

They went big with empire. Too big, some might say, though I think 'big' gives it more character, and Shogun feels like a scaling back that strips some of that character away, but tightens up the very loose game mechanics that empire had. Yeah, the AI is still silly, some of the starting games are horribly unbalanced and initally its just a Rock/Paper/Scissors game (especially in Rise of the Samurai), but stick with it and you'll be pleasntly surprised by how well the game chugs along.

If you're a fan of turn based strategy games, Total War: Shogun 2 offers some of the best gameplay the genre has to offer.  The most stand-out feature of this game is the ability to overrun a vastly superior force through the use of cunning tactics that effect the morale of your enemy, causing him to flee the field of battle.  Never before has the necessity for a sound strategy been such an important part of melee combat.  With specialty units like ninja, who can sneak over castle walls to open the gates for your invading army, or bullet proof samurai, whose armor gives them the ability to survive a charge against some of the newest European technology the enemy can throw at you.  Total War: Shogun 2 is a solid addition to any game library, and I give it a solid 5 ot of 5.

The Total War series of games have always stood entirely apart from every strategic level game ever produced. The increasing detail of the 3D battles with each game iteration calculates every sword stroke, every arrow fired, every morale check. Nothing demonstrates the unique power of a PC to game as do these titles.

Shogun 2 is breathtaking in its depth, beauty, learning experience, opportunities for varied play, tactical reality, and the interplay of strategic characters and tactical elements -- such as whether your good general is still well enough to lead a battle or the castle gates are still bolted shut against the enemy as you remember them. You can zoom in so close as to hear the horses breathing, and when you do, you will see that each man's face and equipment vary as to the individuality of each character. There are heroes and role playing elements especially as your nation expands, and the diplomatic issues are real and significant.

What can I say? The best!

After the incredibly promising, but fatally flawed Empire, and the far more balanced, but generally lackluster Napoleon, Creative Assembly returns to true form with Shogun 2.  Taking many of the great, but poorly implemented innovations of Empire (a tech tree, decentralized provincial setups, incredible one on one combat animations), the Shogun 2 focuses and refines the structure of the turn based campaign, making it much smaller and more personal feeling in scale, while not compromising the epic nature of the real time battles.

That said, the rock-paper-scissors interaction of the different units, while existing in every Total War game, is way too obvious here, and hurts the overall unit variety.  And while shrinking down the map from much of the known world, to just the three main islands of medieval Japan was a logical choice, given the bloated mess that was often Empire, it is a little disappointing.

This is still without a doubt the best Total War game to date though.

Shogun 2 keeps up the tradition of the fine Total War heritage.  Modern graphics, beautiful menu and art style, incredible real time battles and in-depth macro strategy.  This iteration came with a little more polish than Empire, and harkens back to melee combat which, in my opinion, makes the franchise shine.  It's been on sale a few times and is no longer full price; that makes this title one to pick up if you are a TW fan.  The multiplayer is also a treat, with your co-op player's ability to command part of your troops during battle.

The Total War series has produced some impressive titles in the past, and Total War: Shogun 2 has joined those ranks. Put simply, this is one of the best strategy games I've ever played. To begin with, it's historically accurate. In terms of gameplay, the campaign is reflective of real-life politics, economics, and warfare. Nations dislike you when you expand your territory, dishonor treaties, or if your leader is dishonorable and/or unintelligent. Allies will betray you if it's in their interest, and rival clans declare war on you when you have something they want. You literally have to manage your clan's entire economy, including taxes, trade, and food supply. You must also manage your clan's educational development by mastering arts. On top of that, you must lead your armies in real-time battles against your enemies. However, the game is very streamlined and easy to play. While the AI still isn't as good as it could be, Shogun 2 is another great Total War title.

A wonderful return to form for the Total War series. Every game in the Total War series since Rome has been rushed, buggy, and had horrible AI and spotty decision making, reeking of an unfinished game. No longer. They have finally broken the mold with this game.

There are problems. Don't get me wrong. It's not perfect - but it's complete. Your units follow your orders to the death. There are few movement bugs. The AI is competent enough to challenge you in strategic warfare, actually raising armies and attempting to take territory. They will not shy from engaging you. Nor does the campaign hand you the keys to victory as every other Total War game (since Rome) seems to.

Buy it. For the love of god. Vote with your wallet. Show Sega that the only thing they have to do is SIT BACK AND LET THEIR DEVELOPERS WORK.

A strategy game on probably the most epic scale available, Shogun 2 continues improving upon the elements that made all the previous Total War games a success. You will find yourself enthralled by the simplicity, but at the same time noticing how complex it is. Gameplay constantly changes, and you won't find yourself in the same situation very often. Combine all this with amazing graphics (given the sheer scale) and with the new blood pack (to satisfy my bloodlust), and you get a winner.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoy Shogun 2. It's well built upon and well-made. You won't find much else like it in the strategy genre.

I love this game.  I am actually a huge fan of the last Total War installment, Empire.  I appricated how huge that game was, even if its size lead to some big issues with gameplay.  It was ambitious and truly gave the player a sense of global domination.

Shogun 2 is much more streamlined.  But, it's still huge and the setting is perfect for the Total War game type.  The experience system with your family, generals and special characters is a great upgrade as well.  The only big problem I have with this is the same as all Total War games, you can't really have a solid "non-violent" diplomacy.  Eventually, unless you're allies within the first dozen turns, everyone will turn against you.  It'd be nice to be able to sway enemies to your side, even if you've had conflicts in the past.   Make it cost something, sure, but allow for it somehow.

Still, the game is fun and flaw has just encouraged me to be prepared to kill 'em all.

Be careful though as each clan brings its own advantages and disadvantages. Are you ready to conquer Kyoto and become Shogun or will you just fade like the rest of the clans under the mighty boot of anther Diamyo.

A polished effort as the Total War studio goes back to its roots.  The best presented of an already impressive series, this is an empire building RTS which offers jaw-dropping battles and intricate empire building through diplomacy or conquest.  

The Total War games are arguably the most complete strategy games ever made. 

While economics are important, it is skill, not spamming a 'build queue'  that will determine success.

This game will not be nice to you.  After the tutorials, which give a basic overview of battlefield tactics, you're ushered toward campaign mode, in which other daimyous will kick you in the groin, stab you in the back, bully you, anklebite you, and dogpile on you.  Why play then? Because it's cool.  5 cell phones, 3 popped collars cool.  Game play is solid enough, but aesthetics are where the game really shines.  While trailers and screenshots do a good job capturing the visuals, you don't really see thigns like the pre-battle speech scenes and the loading screen poetry until you're actually playing.

TLDR: if you appreciate a challenge in your games and/or like samurai stuff this game is for you.

Shogun 2 is the highly anticipated sequel to the original Shogun game from the Total War game series. SEGA is well known for their very successful and fairly original gameplay style. The Total war games offer turn based campaign progression while also making it possible for players to experience real-time strategy combat in exquisite detail on a stable and massive scale. In doing this it appeals to civilization type gamers and age of empire type gamers alike. The Shogun franchise, as the name suggests, focuses on the art and lore of Japan's feudal era. Players battle with various disciplines of Samurai, Ninjas, and even hero units, each unit-type wielding different weaponry. Players can focus on either of the game's two major components as much or as little as they choose: empire management or combat. These qualities combined with the addition of COOP campaign mode make this game an easy 9 out of 10.

Outstanding game, more polished than many previous titles in the Total War series (all of which I love). Everything is gorgeous, from the menus, the campaign map and voice acting to the battlefield unit animations and intricate scenery. The gameplay is challenging and varied despite the reduction of scale from the previous 18th-19th century Total Wars. I've already played over 90 hours since release and have no hesitation in diving into another new single player campaign. Multiplayer, however, is where the biggest improvements have been made. Built in clan competition using steam, customisable general, and XP progression gives an overarching sense of progression to each multiplayer match. It could still use more patches to cut down on server problems/lag but the effort they've made has definitely paid off and I've already played more multiplayer Shogun 2 than I have the rest of the Total War titles combined. So go for it and buy this game, so that I have more friends to play against!

Still a few glitches. Some may argue that the low number of factions or units make the game uninteresting. But real strategy lovers will understand that the difference between units is real, unlike NTW, where units were the same except one or two points of difference in reloading speed for example.It's not the number of unit that is important,it's how you use them and combine them with others. Fights are brutal, quick, and the online clan tournament gives a reason for people to keep fighting.
Don't play the game if you're the 'Not enough units roflntwwasbetter' guy, you won't appreciate the game like you should. And if you're not happy with 10 factions,it's not the game who is to blame, but History.
Anyway, far different from NTW, but I prefer Shogun because it offers far more strategic possibilities than the other Total War Games.

Perhaps the most polished Total War title yet. Shogun 2 combines many of the best features of previous titles, and rejuvinates some of the cinematic appeal eschewed in the Napoleon/Empire games.

Some of you may recall the original Shogun, which featured a battle scene from Akira Kurosawa's "Ran" as its opening cinematic and cornerstone inspiration. Shogun 2 is a return to that Kurosawa-esque aesthetic, capturing the flair of Period Drama in the general atmosphere, ambience and graphics of the game.

Pre-battle speeches are back. Naval combat has been integrated into the game and adapted for Sengoku-era boats. Individual agents are much more effective and important, and an experience-tree system allows for robust customization.

There are a few downsides: A lack of topographical variation leads to similar battle maps (it is one island after all) and a lack of variety in the clans leads to a lower replay value. 

Nonetheless, highly recommended.

This is a tale of the historical rise of Ken-sama to power in nippon during the sengoku period, using his spot at his new highschool as daimyo along with his trusty and superior katana.

You take control of Ken-sama in his fight to unite his favorite nihon in hopes of bringing about a new order of peace so more animays can be made, fighting for honor in your kimono under the sakura. It's up to you though, as you play as ken-sama; will you unite all of nippon or will you and your tomodachis falter and let your yume of being a pure japanese be crushed?

While it is not exactly accurate description of Sengoku Japan, the game did a great job in capturing the essentials of battle in the time period, and to be honest, if the game's good what's a little error on facts going to anything, right?

If you're a lover of strategy games, then this one is definitely for you! Beautifully combines macro- and micro-management together to create an awesome gaming experience. First, you need to choose a clan/faction to play as through the main campaigne; then, you manage and expand your empire, move various agents, and move and engage armies via the world map.

Once two armies are engaged, you are brought to a real-time battle map, where you take control of your troops and clash them with the enemy! Remember, numbers doesn't always dictate who the winner will be. Strategy and superior tactics define who is the victor!

Although slightly more limited in scope than other Total War games, Shogun 2 delivers an oustanding experience in a lush presentation.

Shogun 2 takes everything that was great about Empire: Total War, amplifies it, and removes all the slow, uninteresting components. Shogun 2’s naval combat is much more refined and the land battles are very fast, but the simplification and heightened sense of pacing did not drown the game’s tactical prowess.  Quite the contrary actually, this game is phenomenal, bugs aside.

Beautiful and full of tactical considerations.  It's a call back to the beginning of the Total War franchise and needless to say, it doesn't disappoint .  There's still matchlock rifles and cannons if you think you're going to miss it from Empire or Napoleon but I personally like going back to bows, arrows, spears, and swords.  Time flies by with this one as you have many countless things you could be doing each turn, especially on the harder settings.  My one complaint is that you can feel kind of cornered on what feels to be a small map sometimes.

One of the best games I have ever had the pleasure of purchasing. The stragety level and the amount of time you invest in the game could be more then you would like if your really into FPS and not so much a RTS or Turn based game. However, there is so much to do, that it almost become a RPG of a sort for you and just draws you in. Really worth the money in my opinion. However, I am a little biasis since I own almost all of the Total war games. 

Though, on a objective mindset. It deptics accurate historical infomation and allows you to simulate that to the best of it's ability. I myself find playing the game on "legendary" to be rather exciting because there isn't a save button that you can control. I like to think and I like to have the feeling of a victory actually being a victory, and a defeat actually being a defeat. Not a "oh crap" let me just reload this and try something else. 

I'd give it a 9.5 out of 10 currenlty.

Best one in the series so far, they took the engine from Empire Tottal War they developed a perfect looking game.

AI is sharp, with a deep understanding of when to fight, when to evade, and how to fight with out fighting...(ninjas and secret police have caused many tears)

Multiplayer has many features, most noteably is the upgrade system where you upgrade your general his bonuses and his army unit types..

I would highly recommend this game to any one who has liked any game of this series

Total War: SHOGUN 2: I have never had as much fun playing a RTS, ever. I didn't think any of my friends would buy this game, but after learning that there was a Co-Op campaign, one of my friends did, and it's been uphill from there.

There are a few glitches that could have been resolved with an open beta, but I am confident that The Creative Assembly won't pull a Treyarch (See: Black Ops) with this game.

I wasn't really a big fan of the whole Japanese Shogun thing.. until now.
TWS2 turned out to be much better than I thought it would be.

I am not a die-hard RTS fan at all. I did not enjoy Civilisation or any turn-based strategy game either. However, the Total War series has once again made me forget about all my doubts I have with these genres. The Metascore of 90 does not lie here, what you get is a very well balanced and exciting game in both single- and multiplayer. I recommend this to everyone, regardless of what type of game he or she may prefer.

Creative Assembly needs to get working on the annoying little bugs that taint the multiplayer though, should that be done I have nothing else to criticise.
Without a doubt the best Total War game to ever come out, now with awesome multiplayer and ai improvements, this is probably the 2011 rts of the year. :D

Awesome, it has all the music from the classic Shogun: Total War I used to play, brings back a lot of memories of conquering fuedal Japan during the days of my youth.  Takes everything the Total War series has done over the years and has refined them.  The AI is smarter than ever and even as a Total War Vet I am being challenged and having to come up with complex strategies with ever battle, from the small skirmishes to the epic clash of thousands of troops.  Graphics are great, sound is great.  The only problems I've had is sometimes your units can have some path finding issues, but this is rare and hasn't made me lose a battle yet (due to that at least lol).  BUY IT!!!!

A real gem from the total war series. Easily the most engaging campaign mode ever, with superb atmosphere. Most strategy games run into the problem of pacing; usually 1/3 of the way through you know you're going to win. Shogun 2 avoids this with well placed challenges throughout the campaign. 

Also, the rallying cutscene before each battle has some terrific voice acting.
